review: I'm not too familiar with rhythm games, but this is one of the coolest experiences I've had with gaming in recent memory. The psychedelic imagery, broken soundscape, and the simple gameplay with a very brutal difficulty curve make for an already pretty great game, but the ending is so incredible that I genuinely can not think of a better way to end off on, and it makes for a stunning moment to end the game on. This is an absolute must buy for anyone looking for a challenging rhythm game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994049222', 'num_games_owned': 1319, 'num_reviews': 163, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1695956841}
review:
I'm not a huge rhythm game guy, but I got my teeth cut with Audiosurf 1 & 2, then sharpened with Beat Saber and Pistol Whip. I can hold a beat in my head, and this game... doesn't feel very interconnected with its own elements.
The music could be better, the challenges on the track don't feel super connected with the beat/song, so what you end up with is just... an obstacle course game that relies in part on aesthetic, and in part on passing as a rhythm game, which it honestly doesn't feel like.

The VR mode is... present. I found it a little disorienting and unpleasant for my tastes, but who knows, maybe my VR legs aren't as sturdy as I thought them to be? It largely doesn't feel like the game really benefits a whole lot from having it, to be honest.

I don't like to pound on an indie, but this game genuinely feels overhyped by everyone who said it was the best thing since sliced bread or something. Best rhythm game of 2016? How many were there that year that it warranted a specific award for it? Sounds a little overblown to me...

author: {'steamid': '76561198117769788', 'num_games_owned': 181, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 56, 'playtime_at_review': 1677, 'last_played': 1712287420}
review:
I have now S-ranked every single level in this game, so here goes:
[i]Thumper[/i] is a game that describes itself as "rhythm violence", and it absolutely lives up to that label. From the animations to the boss designs to the gameplay itself, it's violent in every way. It doesn't have a lot of mechanics, but it doesn't need any more, since chaining the existing ones together at the pace the game throws obstacles at you (especially at harder levels) is already very difficult. This game also has a tendency to punish you for doing well: for example, ground-pounding an activated thump panel will pause the gameplay for a beat to play an impact animation, potentially completely throwing you off the rhythm if you don't expect that to happen already. Despite that, I really enjoyed playing the game, and am now trying to get over 5M total score, so don't think beating the game (or even S-ranking it) is the end.

9/10 Would crash the beetle into a wall again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060605471', 'num_games_owned': 641, 'num_reviews': 329, 'playtime_forever': 1818, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1818, 'last_played': 1708176763}
review:
This is how people with astigmatism be driving at night.

I didn‚Äôt know what on-rails rhythm combat racing looked like before this game, but now I can‚Äôt imagine it any other way. Legitimately challenging at times, especially if you‚Äôre going for S-rank. This is the kind of game where scratching an itch can be the difference between life and death. It will test your vision, hearing, memory, pattern recognition, motorskills, reflexes, hand-eye coordination, timing, patience, and sanity. It had me cramping up in spots I didn‚Äôt know cramps were possible. By the time you‚Äôre done, you‚Äôll have calluses for thumbs, forearms like tree-trunks, and a six-pack on either palm. Or you‚Äôll develop arthritis, could swing either way. The controls are simple enough that you can set it down for years and pick it back up again whenever you want, although it may take some time to get back into the swing of things. I do wish the music was a bit more diverse. Each level is basically a variation of the one song, so it starts to get old after a little while, but the one major complaint I have is that you can‚Äôt replay specific checkpoints. In order to replay your favourite sections, you need to replay the rest of the level it‚Äôs attached to, and arguably worse, the entire level if you missed a single S-rank. I spent four hours on level 9 and ended up missing a tile right at the end. Didn‚Äôt think it was a big deal since most of the levels allow for one or two mistakes per checkpoint, but then the game ended and it gave me an a-rank, so I had to replay the entire level thanks to one single tile. That legitimately pissed me off. Good game, though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027178198', 'num_games_owned': 901, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 1035, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1035, 'last_played': 1686770098}
review:
Amazing [b]rhythm game[/b] with very simple controls.

You need directional keys (or a joystick) and a single button to [b]thump[/b] (the beetle‚Äôs main action).
I enjoyed playing this game with a DualShock4 controller using the [b]directional cross[/b] for movement and [b]R1[/b] for thumping.

Every main level introduces new [b]gameplay[/b] elements and slowly ramps up the [b]difficulty[/b].
A main level is partitioned into sublevels (mainly normal sublevels and some boss sublevels).

There are two main game modes : Play and Play+
[list]
    [*] in Play mode, you can replay the last sublevel if you die or to improve your score (normal mode)
    [*] in Play+ mode, you can‚Äôt replay sublevels (hard mode)
[/list]
There is little to no story but that‚Äôs not why I play these types of games. 
The art and feel is amazing. My main satisfaction came from ‚ÄúS ranking‚Äù levels !

No performance problems detected.

[h1] Should you buy it ?[/h1]
The trailer on Steam gives you a nice idea of the type of music involved as well as the artstyle. 
I think the game is worth it at [b]full price[/b] if you love rhythm games and like climbing the leaderboards.
I think the game is a must buy [b]on sale[/b] if you are curious about the game mechanics and like the electronic music.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978968208', 'num_games_owned': 611, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 2346, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2346, 'last_played': 1632797036}
review:
You'll find yourself falling into the aggressive and tribal musical flow of this futuristic nightmare.
It's definitely fun in the first half or so of the game, but I've never played such a mind-meltingly difficult game that requires insane physical dexterity and speed combined with memorization. The later levels have these rings appear that pulse lasers - my greatest fear and nerve spike that require ABSOLUTE perfection or instant failure...I know that I CAN beat all the upper level S challenges and final boss, etc, but to do so would take maybe 3 hours of solid attempts just for the final boss AND physical pain and stress XD
Compared to say Spelunky 2, which is much harder because you cannot memorize anything, but it's more quick and far less painful and stressful I would say. You need to be good at improvisation there with moderately fast reaction speeds.

author: {'steamid': '76561198137675234', 'num_games_owned': 401, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 444, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 289, 'last_played': 1708523997}
review:
This is an exhilarating and disturbing game at the same time. The rhythm sounds are just amazing when you press the right buttons and makes you feel like a bad-ass beetle flying through an acid trip!

WARNING! - Stay away if flashy lights, colors and trippy visuals make you dizzy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038284069', 'num_games_owned': 368, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 798, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 798, 'last_played': 1701708527}
review:
I love this game, I love a good rhythm game with great sound design and a neat soundtrack, there's this one part of the first level's track that I adore, but I don't wanna say too much.
The final part of the last level, and the ending, left me stunned the first time through, it was a great challenge with a good payoff, I swear I had goosebumps all the way down my arms for the entire final 5-10 minutes or so!

If you're a fan of unique indie and rhythm games, definitely try out this one! 5/5

author: {'steamid': '76561199203687953', 'num_games_owned': 27, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 688, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 474, 'last_played': 1707069507}
review: Thumper is a game I discovered on Playstation originally. I found it at a cheap price so I decided to get again, and DANG was it worth it! Thumper is an extremely satisfying rhythm game with a smooth progression that increases in difficulty right alongside your skill in the game. It adds new mechanics consistently, before you have a chance to get bored of the old ones! Even though I've beat the game before, it was just as fun and maybe even a bit better as I found a few extra tricks I didn't know in my last playthrough. This game gets your heart THUMPIN' and your head BOPPIN' to the percussive adrenaline rush of each level - I highly recommend it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198336441212', 'num_games_owned': 655, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 848, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 805, 'last_played': 1704604270}
review:
[h3]Pros[/h3]
+ Fantastic and surreal visuals. There's nothing quite like it. I would recommend this for the visuals alone.
+ Once you master a level it makes you [i]feel[/i] like a percussionist. The concentration involved results in great satisfaction once you nail a difficult section effortlessly. Seriously, I think I learned a few beats.
+ Great music - it perfectly fits the description of rhythm violence.

[h3]Cons[/h3]
- I don't know whether it's ok to call this a rhythm game. The gameplay certainly relies on rhythm, but it definitely isn't like your usual rhythm games. Sometimes, you just cannot tell what inputs to do by listening to the sounds or trying to read ahead with visuals. As a result, you need to rely on pattern recognition and memorization. I could put up with this, but someone with an expectation of a "rhythm game" might find it unacceptable.
- I feel the pacing could be better. Since the game relies on pattern recognition, why not ease the player into learning them, instead of throwing new patterns in between long levels and forcing a restart?

[h3]More thoughts[/h3]
This game lies somewhere between Geometry Dash and proper rhythm games like Dance Dance Revolution. It's not as reliant on memorization as GD, but does have a few sections which you just have to remember to get right. If you don't mind that, you'll have a blast. Even if you do, just get this to experience its really unique combination of visuals, audio and gameplay. You'll love the first few levels, at least.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960673955', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 212, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 212, 'last_played': 1703387318}
review:
My biggest problem with the game is it does not communicate effectively enough.

First, the mechanics are not well indicated. There were several things I had to either looks up or try to figure out by trial and error. Only after several hours of play and reading some other comments do I now realize what they were trying to say with the first "tutorial." Jump on the squares, but they are optional, only for points. Whereas things like blocks/turns/evades are non-negotiable.

Second, the pace is quite fast. You must queue information as far ahead as possible. But with the track all rotating in the distance and the rather monotone color theme, I think they artificially increased the difficulty. Also, the action sounds play over the heads-up sounds, so the audio is not super helpful to determine what is ahead.

I generally enjoy difficult games, but I found this to be quite frustrating. Difficult for me and difficult for you are not the same, so it would have been nice to have some difficulty slider to make it accessible to a broader audience. I'm happy to play a game on baby mode to learn and then ramp it up.

Making a hit mistake (e.g. not making a turn) is way too punishing. They add way too much visuals on top of an already busy screen making it way more likely that you take another hit almost immediately. I found myself going from a perfect run to dead way too quickly. By the time I made it through some sections, I noticed I had basically put it into short term memory.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031338034', 'num_games_owned': 624, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 148, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 78, 'last_played': 1703638664}
review:
This game is. Like a cancer. Like a clawing, squamous, insidious parasite worming its way into your very being. You are in hell. You are more scared and uncomfortable and stressed than you have ever been. You want it to end. And you want to keep going. When you open the menu to reset a section to try for S-rank, you will do it on rhythm.

This game is an eldritch horror made of sick beats.

I will say that cues are often hard to hear, covered up by other sounds. This is a downside, but I'm going to defend it anyway. It adds something to the atmosphere; you have to focus that much harder. You have to *welcome* the parasite into yourself in order to conquer it. You can do it, but the world will not help you, and you will not emerge unchanged.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060030397', 'num_games_owned': 359, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 421, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 301, 'last_played': 1703278586}
review:
The aesthetics and gameplay are amazing, pretty challenging even for someone that played rythm games for a long time.

There are some negative reviews saying that you must memorize some levels to get through and honestly I didn't feel that way not even a single time. I believe that those reviews come from people that are trying to get S score on all levels and that's not your average player.

I think the game could be a bit more musical, all levels seem to be pretty similar in terms of rythm. The visuals in general are good, but it could have more diversity in each level.

I recommend this game for the challenging gameplay, but if you are more of a musical person then I wouldn't expect much from this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064833939', 'num_games_owned': 342, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 506, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 405, 'last_played': 1703737263}
review:
If you have a background in percussion or an understanding of rhythm, you need to play this game. 

An intense voyage through an eldritch land, Thumper combines the satisfaction of a rhythm game with the beauty and tension of a Lovecraftian story into an incredibly polished product.

The rudiments presented by the game are sometimes unforgiving and spontaneous. You will die, and you will die lots; but from the death comes understanding. From understanding comes deep satisfaction. And from this satisfaction comes a daring pursuit of perfection.

This game is absolutely worth every penny at full price. There's nothing like it, as far as I know. However, if you find yourself skeptical, this game is an absolute must on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067258571', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 309, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 309, 'last_played': 1702866867}
review:
There are a handful of spots in the game from level 7 onward that felt pretty bad, with the track jerking around in nauseating ways and the screen becoming littered with visual noise.

In this respect it reminds me of another game, "The Witness", which featured several puzzles towards the end that were not challenging in essence, but instead were presented to you at acute angles or through painful flashing lights. These types of obstacles do not need to be solved or practiced. Instead, they need to be tolerated. It's something I particularly dislike. 

That being said, these moments are rare and forgivable. The remainder of the game is a masterpiece, and you owe it to yourself to experience it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198201381471', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 540, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 254, 'last_played': 1705261611}
review:
TL;DR
The game is a true masterpiece, inducing a deep state of flow through it's gamefeel, challenging gameplay, and presentation. While technically being mechanically comparable to an auto-runner, it does not feel like one, it feels more like speedrunning mirror's edge.
10/10

WHAT I LOVE ABOUT THUMPER
I am a sucker for games that pull you into a state of flow. Doom eternal with it's funzone design, when you fight bosses in darksouls and momentarily forget that you exist, the entire original mirror's edge, which was my previous favorite flow game that would have me breathing in synch with the pov character. Thumper is the platonic ideal of this concept, there is no game that captures it better.
Thumper is strange if you try to describe it. You're a beetle going along railways in space at maddening speed, reacting to obsticles that appair in time with the dark synthy music, and which occasionally service the goal of fighting a boss. But not a single part of that is really relevant, because Thumper is a game about two things.

RYTHM GAMEPLAY

The game has you push buttons in a predetermined pattern which are telegraphed to you visually and audiably 2-3 seconds before you encounter the obsticle. This is basically like guitar hero or rockband, but you have more sophisticated rythms and inputs. What makes this game imo far superior to other rythm games is it's willingness to explore. There are odd time signatures, absurd patterns, and I'm pretty sure I have already encountered some polyrythms.

In addition to the exiting rythms, and unlike other rythm games that often fall into the category of either being entirely about perfect inputs like guitar hero, or having only a basic beat but more freedom in gameplay like crypt of the necrodancer, Thumper manages to grant both complex rythms and demanding challange, but also some sense of freedom. While the game is literally on rails, you relatively early uncover that you can choose multiple ways to solve individual sections which may have different results, and while there is likely an arguably best way, you will find that sometimes you will have to choose between the optimal method for ranking (based on hit percent), point score (there are some manouvers that grant more points) or survivability (only some obstacles damage you, get damaged twice without recovering and you are forced to restart from last checkpoint), and even within each category there are occasionally multiple options and ways to balance the different parts.

Survival is the base challenge, but points and ranks grant the game plenty of replayability, which is easily and swiftly managed with the ability to replay earlier levels individually, and jump back if you fail getting the result you want from a section during a level.

This combination of sophisticated rythm and limited but engaging choice, makes the game feel a lot deeper than it's peers, and I believe basically all the other games in the rythm family (that I have played) could learn from it.

VIOLENCE PRESENTATION

The music uses a mixture of spacy synths and harsh industrial sounds, both given enough reverb to make you feel like you really are in space. The trippy visuals with reflections and twirling geometry mixed with vague eldritch allusions create this sense of vastness and serenity that makes a lot of this game feel calm and zen-like, but not quite safe at any point. You get a strong sense of this by just opening the game. Then you press play.

You move with the velocity of a bullet train, and the slightly shaky camera and the way sparks fly when you touch things makes you feel like a rocket on rails that could explode any moment, and you might, if you crash into most obsticles you withness parts flying off as your beetle exoskeleton is smashed of and the shattered pieces fly into space. If it happens again, you see the same happen to the rest of you, but in both instances you don't slow down, but the camera keeps wooshing ahead and merely fades to black for a moment to reload you. The speed is constant, and it is devestatingly fast.

Jacob Geller mentioned in a review the feeling of crashing into walls in mariocart so you can turn without slowing down, only you're moving much faster, and I find this a very apt description of the feeling of playing the game. You don't feel as if this beetle you're controlling was ever meant to move at these speeds, much less grind along turns and smash through hinderances, and every move feels like you have to force it, but rather than frustration it envokes catharsis.

author: {'steamid': '76561198181096765', 'num_games_owned': 429, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 581, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 288, 'last_played': 1701119450}
review:
[h2]Full Game Thoughts[/h2]
What a game. The audio-visual feedback after each successful/failed action is super on point! The levels start off slowly where you can play using reflex alone, but the game quickly ramps up the difficulty in each level by introducing more mechanics and increase the pace of your beetle.

You will eventually need to pick up on the audio queues, as beetle will move too fast to just depend on your eyes. This happened to me at around Level 6 Boss. The experience of being able to "predict the future" using your ears is surreal, and is probably needed to get S-rank in all the levels.

That being said, the checkpoints between each sections of a level are quite generous and I was never stuck on any level for too long. The levels are also littered with various optional actions that can be easily ignored when you get overwhelmed. S-rank is for losers anyways.

author: {'steamid': '76561198152417821', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 2369, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 65, 'playtime_at_review': 1541, 'last_played': 1712203819}
review:
I'm new to rhythm games, unless you count Sekiro. I did two playthroughs; first just getting through every level, and then S-ranking everything for my second. I used a keyboard, and had a very positive overall experience. The visuals and audio all work very well together to create a satisfying game. I feel like a lot of the reviewers saying the game throws unfair curves at the player are missing the audio cues; there are definitely a couple of tricky ones, but there's a clear audio cue well in advance.

My only negative feedback has to do with the final boss. Without getting too spoilery, it felt pretty cheap to throw out the muscle memory the player has been honing over the course of the game in favor of a memorization gimmick. Not a great note for an otherwise fantastic game to end on, but the other 99% makes up for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198328001566', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 464, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 464, 'last_played': 1699912554}
review:
Very fun, tough game.  Its extremely addicting.  If you watch any demo movies, you'l get the idea of what this is.  Its like a DDR, guitar hero, racing game.  It has this gorgeous fiery neon look to it, the soundtrack is this stressful techno beat.  
You are a little space ship thing that is racing down a track, you need to push buttons to the time of the beat/ time of the objects flying towards you.  It just keeps getting faster and faster, and your timing needs to be more and more precise.  It gets VERY hard after a handful of levels, and can become quite frustrating, but that also makes you replay a bunch of times, quit in frustration, then come back for more punishment.  
I

author: {'steamid': '76561198994218001', 'num_games_owned': 273, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1855, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1700, 'last_played': 1709964070}
review:
While I wouldn't say that Thumper is a revolutionary rhythm game nor it being the most difficult, (that honor would go to A Dance of Fire and Ice,) it has to be the most primordially invigorating game of the genera. It really drives home the speed at which you are going and the increasing rate and which obstacles are coming at you with ever more complex patterns. The setting of a single metal track barreling down past the point of no return through hell also contributes to the feeling of abstraction and frantic pacing that is present in every level.

     The mechanical , or whatever it is that you control, doesn't move in time to music; it moves in time to drums and synth-like screeches that hardly resemble music. It definitely isn't a soundtrack that is especially Spotify worthy, but for the purposes of the game feel and overall identity I wouldn't have it any other way. Each level can be quite long which can drain the player when played too long, but it isn't that bad since you can quit at any time and your progress will save.

     What is most rewarding is climbing the leader boards for each level along with their + variants. You start to pick up on certain tricks such as slamming down on any beat that you can and sliding on walls at the last possible moment to rack up extra points. It sucks that it's impossible to take a break in the middle of a level if you want to get a decent score, but I understand why that is. What sucks even more are the times at the top of the leader boards that are obviously cheated and a lack of a workshop editor to make your own levels for replay ability's sake.

     Still, what is here is a great package even when it isn't on sale. It's a great game that could have been a very great game given some adjustments. While I do think that A Dance of Fire and Ice is the better option because of those adjustments. most of all being the workshop, Thumper is still something that shouldn't be missed for its own vision: a spiral into hell; metal to metal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198843648404', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 450, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 450, 'last_played': 1698371963}
review: Thumper is a difficult game to describe, but "rhythm horror" is a pretty good way to start. Brutally difficult and constantly innovative, the game can certainly be frustrating. Sometimes it feels like it's asking you to memorize inputs, and others the new challenges come so quickly it's quite difficult to adapt. But the end goal of playing the game, for me, was to get in that zone where I didn't even know how I knew it, but I knew what to do. That zen, where my eyes were drying out from watching for every new turn and my fingers moved before I knew I needed to move them, was what recommends this game. It's quite a rare experience, and well worth the risk. Granted, took me like three hours to get to that point, so if you've not got the time, it might not be worth it. But if your well of novelty is looking dry, Thumper will hand you a glass. Or more likely stab you in the eye with it, but hey, it's a one-of-a-kind scar.

author: {'steamid': '76561199055303689', 'num_games_owned': 62, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 199, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 199, 'last_played': 1697679306}
review:
This game is not bad and I want to finish it, but I have a MAJOR gripes.

I'm consider myself a pretty good rhythm player but I found this game unreasonably challenging. Absolute perfection is demanded even when it seems impractical. More often than not, I found myself getting blinded by the effects or surprised with an unexpected wall. I would not be as frustrated if didn't instantly kill you most times. Short play sessions were all that I could handle. 

Perhaps this game is not for me, but I will not be playing it again anytime soon.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047503760', 'num_games_owned': 388, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 421, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 417, 'last_played': 1698366510}
review:
Fast-paced and thrilling. The charms of a rhythm game, combined with crazy, out-of-this-world visuals and presentation. It has put me in a trance whenever I played the levels. Is a bizarre and amazing experience when you come face to face with the bosses that just seem such horrific, cosmic abomination and I absolutely love that. Like you're seeing into something that you're not supposed to.

The rhythm mechanics is satisfying to experience. Rather than just tapping a button to the beat like in typical rhythm games and have it react by just flashing a word and removing the note... in this one, the reactions are punchy, and violent. The description of "rhythm violence" fits perfectly into this and it makes me want to see games approach this route more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080205770', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 1043, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1043, 'last_played': 1653557366}
review:
I never liked rhythm games. I feel like a lot of them don't try innovate. You just press random buttons whenever a prompt demands it, on arbitrary patterns that neither really align with the rhythm, nor the melody, but something unintuitive in between.

But Thumper? Thumper somehow scratches just that right itch. Its simple control scheme lends itself to easy pickup, but hard mastery and interesting beats that stretch the gameplay to its limits.
The patterns somehow click with me. While hard, I can intuitively follow them a lot better than in other rhythm games, which is no doubt because they are not only memorable but also repeat and ramp up on a satisfying difficulty curve.
All that combined with the surreal, scary aesthetic and industrial drums, this game has earned the description of Rhythm Violence and then some.

I never thought I'd count a rhythm game among my favorites of all time, but here we are.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025540634', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 1148, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1148, 'last_played': 1693365942}

author: {'steamid': '76561198048616837', 'num_games_owned': 96, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 707, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 707, 'last_played': 1693240765}
review:
Thumper is one of the most memorable experiences I've had in gaming. It's not a music game in the traditional sense but it brings forth musical catharsis and deep focus through it's surreal atmosphere and non conventional rhythm structures. 

At its core it's an action game that asks you to be quick and respond to the obstacles it throws at you. But contrary to what it may seem at first this setup leaves a lot of room for player expression. There are maneuvers that the game teaches as it goes on that are rewarding to pull off, giving an increase in score or rank at the cost of risking a lose state and a reset.

The visual design is astonishing. I specially liked the mid level bosses which were represented as impossibly grand fractals and geometry, their beauty was as much a hazard as the twists and blockades in the road as it kept me looking away from were I needed to look.

I didn't find the game particularly hard but I think I might be in the minority looking at the achievement list. From level 7 onward the difficulty plateaued for me except for the last 3 sections which ramp up towards a mind blowing finale. 

I think Thumper is a game that should not be overlooked and will be remembered in the future. Anyone that finds it's aesthetics intriguing needs to give this game a try. It's certainly not for everyone. But if it's for you you owe yourself this experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061914709', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 257, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 103, 'last_played': 1693415216}
review:
I remember when this game came out, people were calling it "The Dark Souls of Rhythm Games" I remember scoffing at this notion. "Really? You can't think of another way to describe the game as difficult?"

I'd compare this game to Dark Souls in one singular respect. There are moments when you first go through Dark Souls where you come upon a boss that smashes you flat over and over again to the point were you stop having fun. It grinds you down with frustrations and bullshit until you're just begging it to be over.
Thumper invokes this feeling more purely than Dark Souls ever did.

I don't enjoy playing Thumper, if it wasn't for my pride as a gamer, I'd have given up and played something actually fun by now. Maybe if I can claw my way to the otherside I can enjoy this game but until then, can't recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046425367', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 583, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 583, 'last_played': 1692981582}
review:
This game is like really awesome unique and satisfying but one huge problem with it being a rhythm game is it's lack of clear audio cues for certain obstacles in the later levels. Many times it just feels like you need to keep replaying parts to remember certain turns because it is literally impossible to hear the cue when there is so much shit going on especially if you are trying to combo for your score. Great game and really fun gameplay but it's just a really glaring problem you will encounter the further you get.

7.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198029447924', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 5958, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 5287, 'last_played': 1711578641}
review:
I absolutely love this game. I find it a bit difficult to explain [i]why[/i] I love it, but I'll give it a try...

I've enjoyed rhythm games like Guitar Hero in the past but I never reacted to them like I reacted to Thumper. It's just one of those games where the feel, the look, the music... it all combines into something so wonderfully distinct, I can just totally lose myself in it. I feel exhilarated when I [i]finally[/i] nail a section I've screwed up so many times before, terrified when the music hits just that right ominous note and the game seems to be doing everything in its power to throw me off, frustrated when I crash on a corner which I've hit perfectly the last 20 times I've tried it... and finally relief when I complete a level and find myself at the score screen, when some music plays which eerily sounds just like The Shining soundtrack (awesome!)

I think part of the reason I keep coming back to it is that it can put me in a state of absolute focus which I don't often find in games, but I find really really helpful when I just want my internal monologue to shut up. The closest experience I've had in the past is the total focus I had to find when I played through Dark Souls for the first time.

I've no idea if any of the above will make sense to anyone else, but I hope it does. And I know I'll keep coming back to this game, because I haven't found anything else like it before or since.

author: {'steamid': '76561198985659416', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 355, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 355, 'last_played': 1692584074}
review: I enjoyed this game, though I felt the audio and visual cues for some obstacles (particularly the walls and some beats) weren't descriptive enough for the player to be aware of them. I found myself being caught by the second turn many times, not being being able to hear or see the threat in time to react (accounting for 90% of my mistakes). I also found it annoying missing beats that were right after turns, as they appear right after the screen has to re-orient itself. In general I found myself playing very visually, as audio cues were often deafened by gameplay, or too subtle for me to notice. I also felt like gameplay consisted mainly of abstract beats, rarely actually sounding like music. There were certain parts in level 8 that created a catchy beat, but I found this game as a whole was lacking moments like that. The game's visuals are remarkable, and certain moments (like dropping beats in chains) felt cool, but I found this game lacking as a rhythm and music game. If there were more moments in this game that felt like I was creating the music, I would be happy to give this game a positive review.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046892492', 'num_games_owned': 264, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 798, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 798, 'last_played': 1691113018}
review:
I AM SPEED
Puisque ce jeu n'expose son pitch qu'√† travers le gameplay, voici le r√©sum√© :
on joue un scarab√©e de m√©tal lanc√© sur une piste, qui a pour but d'abattre des boss appara√Æssant le long de cette piste.
Ces boss font appara√Ætre en rythme des obstacles pour nous arr√™ter, notamment des palettes lumineuses qui chargent le scarab√©e en √©nergie quand il en touche (ou √©crase) assez √† la suite. Le scarab√©e peut alors r√©talier avec un tir concentr√©.

Finir les niveaux est de l'ordre du faisable (avec un mix d'apprentissage du niveau, d'anticipation quand on peut voir assez loin, et une bonne dose de r√©flexes), le vrai gameplay consiste √† les faire en prenant un maximum de risques pour faire des actions bonus, et donc finir le niveau de la fa√ßon la plus classe possible.
Si c'est votre premier jeu de rythme, je vous conseille de reconsid√©rer l'achat, la BO pouvant rebuter et un certain sens du rythme √©tant obligatoire.

Review:
+ meilleur racing game qu'on ait vu
+ ultra-satisfaisant quand on r√©ussit une s√©quence correctement
+ le jeu qui te pousse au greed, de toi-m√™me, jusqu'√† ce que tu rates parce que tu as pris trop de risques
+ psych√©d√©lique √† souhait, visuellement, c'est un m√©lange entre une bonne grosse cuite et champis
+ un jeu de rythme o√π les bruits des √©l√©ments avec lesquels on interagit sont tous tr√®s distincts et √©toffent le rythme, aidant √† maintenir le timing
+ bonne courbe de progression, tout en douceur
+ plut√¥t peu co√ªteux en terme de performances
- pas vraiment de musique en tant que seule BO, seulement des percussions dont le rythme change selon les niveaux + des sons (souvent longs et aigus) en fond qui renforcent l'aspect oppressant, mais rendent le tempo parfois difficile √† distinguer. Le volume n'est pas configurable :(
- un jeu de rythme qui se joue beaucoup sur les r√©flexes visuels plut√¥t que sur les auditifs ou sur l'apprentissage de la track. Dans certains niveaux, l'angle de la cam√©ra change tr√®s l√©g√®rement, mais assez pour r√©duire la visibilit√© ; ce qui, combin√© √† la distortion et les filtres de couleurs plut√¥t agressifs quand le scarab√©e prend des d√©g√¢ts ; fait que je vous souhaite d'avoir des bons r√©flexes.
- je n'ai jou√© que sur mon √©cran 165Hz, et je vous recommande aussi de d√©passer les 60hz si votre mat√©riel vous le permet, vu qu'on n'a souvent que quelques frames pour r√©agir
- les boss se d√©roulent en 4 phases (1 phase = 1 tir sur le boss), chaque phase se r√©p√®te jusqu'√† ce qu'on meurt (et donc retour √† la phase 1) ou qu'on ait r√©ussi √† toucher une s√©rie compl√®te de palettes lumineuses sans en rater. C'est un peu frustrant de rester bloqu√© dans la m√™me phase pendant plusieurs minutes, en restant en vie d'une fa√ßon ou d'une autre, mais sans r√©ussi √† d√©clencher le tir.

10/10 je ferais √† nouveau imploser un col√©opt√®re de m√©tal parce qu'il s'est mang√© un mur √† la vitesse de la lumi√®re

review:
So I have beat the game.  Sort of tough, but nothing too hard to handle.  When you get into the groove and you're cleaning through several checkpoints without dying on a blind run, it's exhilarating.  I did quite enjoy it, but I will hold to the negative feedback negative reviews give.

Visually, it does get cluttered and double turns in tunnels just suck.  Some levels don't really feel matched to the music either.  The midboss in stage 7 is a pain in the ass just for visuals.

author: {'steamid': '76561198841559685', 'num_games_owned': 27, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1871, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1864, 'last_played': 1691105450}
review:
Found this game through a Youtube video on games that save the best for last and pretty much immediately picked it up. In short, I absolutely loved it. The visuals are great, the sound design is sharp and impactful and the gameplay is challenging in all the best ways. At no point in my playthrough did I feel like the game was unfairly punishing me, and that's what stands out the most. Everytime I died I could pinpoint exactly when and how I made the mistake that led to that outcome. While the soundtrack may have occasionally felt a little repetitive, the overall feeling of smashing through the sticks and hitting perfect turns more than made up for it.

If you enjoy rhythm games and want to be properly challenged, I would highly recommend Thumper.

author: {'steamid': '76561198260694372', 'num_games_owned': 169, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 330, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 330, 'last_played': 1690138937}
review:
A very disappointing game, it starts off very strong at the beginning where you get to witness amazing visuals, great soundtrack and sound effects and get to feel awesome while navigating an epic obstacle course, racing into the endless void.

After all mechanics are introduced is when it starts to go downhill. My biggest problem is that the main levels are unbelievably repetitive, they only have a handful of obstacle gimmicks to throw at you and the only semblance of variation they could come up with was to throw them at you faster, for a longer period of time, which was exhausting.

Other people have pointed the problem of not being able to see the walls in a tunnel, these apparently have a sound cue that I still couldn't point out to you after finishing the game, due to the soundtrack being so damn busy. Of course this problem gets worse later in the game, such as when the mini-bosses of level 8 and 9 spawn walls directly in front of you. 

The visual clutter keeps building up throughout the game, impeding your ability to see the light pads, walls, or anything in general. On the 'final boss' of level 9 it becomes laughably bad and it is very surprising that this was deemed acceptable.

The time between checkpoints also varied widely. They gradually get longer and longer in each successive level, usually taking longer than a minute to complete on a single attempt, which was absolutely tiring. But then you would have the odd checkpoint that would take 10 seconds or so to complete, which made no sense at all.

If you don't mind getting it on a sale then the first 2 levels are absolutely worth experiencing, but my lord the entire game is not worth playing at all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052920998', 'num_games_owned': 269, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 868, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 269, 'playtime_at_review': 868, 'last_played': 1712117366}
review:
[h1]Mesmerising[/h1]
+ Captivating visuals. 
+ Sets its own mood and expands on it well. 

- It can get to a point where on-screen effects, especially when you take damage, can obstruct your vision of oncoming obstacles and tiles. Occasionally the screen can get so busy it can feel unfair. 
- Changes in tempo are extremely jarring. They occur when you take damage AND when you 'pound' recovery tiles with a high enough score multiplier. I understand that these are included for emphasis, but the disruption to tempo is extremely distracting.

author: {'steamid': '76561199147028014', 'num_games_owned': 2300, 'num_reviews': 403, 'playtime_forever': 9, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1660587441}
review:
Thumper is a visually stunning rhythm game that immerses players in a mesmerizing and intense audio-visual experience. The game's abstract and psychedelic visuals create a unique and atmospheric world that is both captivating and unsettling. The gameplay mechanics are simple yet addictive, requiring precise timing and reflexes as you navigate through fast-paced tracks. The combination of the rhythmic gameplay and pulsating electronic soundtrack creates a thrilling and immersive sensation. 

Each level is meticulously designed with challenging obstacles and boss battles that keep you on the edge of your seat. The sense of speed and momentum is exhilarating, as you seamlessly flow through the tracks and execute precise actions. The game's difficulty gradually ramps up, providing a satisfying challenge for players. The overall presentation is sleek and polished, with smooth animations and seamless transitions. Thumper's immersive audio design enhances the gameplay experience, with impactful sound effects and a dynamic soundtrack that syncs perfectly with the action. The game's minimalist approach allows the visuals and mechanics to take center stage, creating a cohesive and immersive experience. Thumper is a unique and adrenaline-pumping game that offers a captivating audio-visual journey for players seeking a rhythmic challenge.

author: {'steamid': '76561198163061412', 'num_games_owned': 330, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 1470, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1470, 'last_played': 1530116659}

author: {'steamid': '76561198030006280', 'num_games_owned': 604, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 1159, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1159, 'last_played': 1688762126}
review:
Thumper is a very promising and very bad game. The longer you play, the less fun you'll have.  At some point, you'll stop playing because you want to and instead play because you hope it'll become good again.  But Thumper doesn't, and by the end you'll regret the time you put into it.  Let me explain.

Thumper does a fantastic job of rewarding skill in early levels.  You can scrape by with fast reactions.  Then you can come back and learn the levels, honing your skill and score.  To get S ranks, you'll need a bit of memorization but not much.

Then the mid levels hit.  Turns appear offscreen, with no chance to see them ahead of time.  So you rely on the sound cues... but with so many things happening you can't hear the sound of the next turn over the constant pinging of your score.  You start intentionally missing things so that you can hear.  That doesn't help enough, so you give up and start memorizing.  

But the checkpoints are now one every 60 seconds, rather than one every 20 seconds.  You /know/ you'll die on every new section.  So you replay the section until you get to the new stuff, die, go back 30 seconds, play it again, die after 35 seconds, play it again.

Then the late levels hit.  At this point sound is completely unreliable, and things are coming so fast that even with memorization you can't keep up.  And when you play too well, the game speeds up the pace even more... so you intentionally start missing things.  Instead of memorizing the best pattern, you start memorizing the pattern you're least likely to die doing, just so you can get 5 seconds deeper before dying.

The only reward for playing Thumper is more Thumper.  At first you play to have fun.  Then to see how far you can go.  And then you play because you can't give up.  It's not worth it.  There's no satisfaction at the end.  It's selfharm.

Thumper documents is a drummer's journey into time signature hell.  It's torture.  Please don't torture yourself.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007343154', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 449, 'playtime_forever': 192, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 192, 'last_played': 1680881757}
review: I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996033127', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 293, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10, 'last_played': 1696384247}

author: {'steamid': '76561198316451531', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 294, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 228, 'last_played': 1707149888}
review:
This game is super fun, and the perfect low pressure thing to do when I need to de-stress and focus. I'm usually shite at rhythm games, but this seems to be the sole exception for me. Was shown this game when I went to a pal's house and he and his pal were playing the game with frustrating results. I gave it a go and I seemed to be a natural at it.

I'm usually never gifted with games so I already felt a little enamored with it. I got the game for myself and it's so much fun. I enjoy trying and failing and executing the increasingly challenging combos as the levels go on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198261555557', 'num_games_owned': 330, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1868, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1268, 'last_played': 1690577253}
review: This game is addictive. And I love it!  Easy to learn, almost impossible to master.  Once you start, you don't want to stop until you get perfect "S" scores on all levels. It's a quick "jump in and play".  Though its a bit disorienting in VR, it works flawlessly on the Steam Deck. I highly recommend Thumper.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043819781', 'num_games_owned': 109, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 605, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 600, 'last_played': 1707062534}
review: speed

author: {'steamid': '76561198292175000', 'num_games_owned': 175, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 276, 'last_played': 1699143194}
review:
Thumper saved me.

I was extremely down on my luck. Everything in my life was going to shit until I bought this game. I played it, thoroughly enjoyed it, and began to do what I called "thumping out". "Thumping out" to me was what some might call "beetle-maxxing". Basically I would crawl on the floor and make little beetle dens out of dirty laundry I left on the floor, and on occasion I'd roll my own dung into balls so that my newly hatched beetle children could have food to eat. My life had purpose and I was happy. Thumper consumed my life at this point, and I began texting everyone my original Thumper memes. They all cut me off and blocked me, but it didn't matter. One day I sent this girl I met 3 years ago a Thumper meme, and she responded with one of her own! I was beyond ecstatic! For 3 weeks straight we traded Thumper memes and trivia until I had the guts to tell her about how I'd been "thumping out" and to my surprise she to had her own beetle dens and dung balls! I invited her to come see my beetle den and dung balls, and she loved them! 

It's now 4 years later, and me and my Thumper wife have Thumper children and a Thumper dog! We "thump out" daily, and life is great.

Thank you Thumper, you changed me for the better!
~With love, the Thumpino Family.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978822994', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 509, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 95, 'last_played': 1683426581}
review:
finally, a game that answers the ancient question: can a triangle [i]hate?[/i] (yes, and venemously so.) relentlessly visceral, brutally challenging, dripping with contempt, and positively entrancing. thumper will slap your t*ts clean off. 9/10

THE RAD: exhilarating gameplay, tightly designed mechanics, complex yet addictive rhythms, fair bar for just scraping by but an incredibly high ceiling for technique. an S rank is only the beginning.

THE SAD: lack of options and accessibility features. more than anything i would like to see options for turning down the eye candy (flashing, glowing streaks abound) for increased legibility and better access for those who may experience sensory overload. more granularity on volume control (rhythm SFX vs enemy FX vs ambient FX) would be a bonus.

thump away, and stay resilient üéµ

author: {'steamid': '76561198089629541', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 146, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 132, 'last_played': 1707191273}
review:
Thumper is a very hard game.  It is hard to the point that it would be a much better game with difficulty settings to tone it down a bit.  I just don't have the reflexes necessary for a game like this myself.

This being said, I'll still give it a very mild recommendation in that I keep coming back to it.  I don't know that I will ever put in the practice necessary to beat this one, but it is still fun, especially when you get a perfect sequence in.  There's something about the feedback that is just very satisfying.

Still, this could be a lot better of a game for causal types like me with a more forgiving mode.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022172146', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 288, 'last_played': 1703190380}

author: {'steamid': '76561198006676463', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 300, 'last_played': 1680834787}
review:
I don't know how long i've owned this game...years?? 
Yes. I'm aware that i've only played it 5 hours. 
Problem? i'm only at the omega boss of level 3.  so. ...

5 hours to get to the end of level 3. i think i've played that level 30 times.  My problem is that it stops becoming a game when my inputs are no longer working when they did just a retry before.  
...by the way...what is the difference between a "thumping glowing box" and a "stomping glowing box"?
After 30 minutes on a level...its your ass.
I own too many games to have to waste an evening on a lack of progression game.
I would venture to say this is a "rogue-like" game.  And I hate those.
Play for hours to "learn" how to pass a level is my definition of "R-L".

Visually its amazing in VR.
Rhythmically?  I forget there is actually a beat, when i'm spending more time "memorizing".  In one sit down with this game I got lucky and maybe passed 5 or 6 levels before restarting became frustrating.
Play-ability?  If you've played this on the Index controllers and got good you can have it.  I lose when right turns into down, or up is left.  And when I adjust my style to stop doing that, after 5 or 20 retries i fall back into a comfortable state of use with my thumbs and its restart city for the next 30 minutes.
If this was made for a controller or the VIVE  ... state it. a "traditional controller"  ... is what exactly?
4 out of 10.  Its eye-candy, but its a Sour Patch on steroids.  Better left to the ones that actually like the sour taste.
P.S.  That 3-Omega boss can suck it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028088441', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 359, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 314, 'last_played': 1689805599}
review:
I'm torn between recommending it or not, if there was a rating system I'd give it a 5 out of 10.

Everything up until Stage 5 is quite good, fun, and engaging. 
Since the game is visually noisy, there are some clarity issues at some points. Luckily the ability to quickly restart from the previous checkpoint softens the blow of you getting less than half a second to respond to something sometimes.

Past Stage 5 some 'rhythm's' in the 'rhythm' game don't really exist- Sometimes it'll actually build up foundations and patterns just to go completely against them in the next part. It becomes a glorified dodge oncoming traffic simulator with good sound design for Stage 6 onwards. 

I consider Stage 5 to be the peak of the game because Stage 6's boss isn't really fun at all. Not because of the mechanics that add extra difficulty like the lasers, but because in its 3rd phase it completely defies any patterns set up in the previous 2. Since it's around 1-2 minutes into the boss fight, you die because of the very little time you have to respond to a new pattern out of the blue. The checkpoints mentioned before don't apply to boss fights. You'll have to play the first 1-2 minutes of the boss fight over and over again just to get a gist of what you're meant to be doing in the 3rd.

Really unfortunate because I had a blast playing until that point.

author: {'steamid': '76561198160743560', 'num_games_owned': 224, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 547, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 511, 'last_played': 1703435288}
review:
Even after beating Thumper's main levels on S, It's still hard to describe what an experience this game really is...

All feels like a fever dream: you're a tiny beetle going on a track that seems never-ending, being thrown a bunch of obstacles in your way that follow some form of rhythm to follow by humanoid face monsters, fractals and other entities.

I would dare call this an actual rhythm game as supposed to anything else on the market. As those 'rhythm' games make you follow a song with notes that do not have to match the melodic track. Whereas Thumper's level and sound design make you build a rhythmic track as you progress.

Though short by having only 9 levels (there are about ~25 sub-levels in each) it's a very enjoyable and satisfactory game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198871436868', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1222, 'last_played': 1679703890}
review:
I've had this game on my wish list for about a year now and finally decided to purchase it when it went on sale, needless to say I wasn't disappointed. 

As of writing this review I'm currently with an S on Round three and all the Rounds before it, and when I tell you it's challenging, it really is. The graphic are INCREDIBLE and I'm not sure if the title "Thumper" is a play on word, but the overall atmosphere and the disturbing graphics really makes your heart beat fast (THUMP). 
   
This game is a MUST BUY if you like seeing some shitlessly spine-chilling graphics and are up for a challenge.

Meanwhile I'll be working to get S tier in all the Rounds, good luck to any future buyers!

author: {'steamid': '76561198038926821', 'num_games_owned': 272, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 493, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 87, 'last_played': 1688754753}
review:
[h1]Who knew being an interdimentional beetle could be this fun? -- 9/10[/h1]

[h3][i]No blinking required.[/i][/h3]

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Summary: üöÄüêûüí®üí•üéµ[/h2]
[list]
    [*] Story quality:  ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ‚òÜ‚òÜ - Story? Who needs that when you're a space beetle thumping at the beat of the music.
    [*] Story depth     ‚òÖ‚òÜ‚òÜ‚òÜ‚òÜ - That's not what you're here for.
    [*] Controls:       ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ - Simple to memorize
    [*] Immersive-ness: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ - The game will suck you in faster than a black hole.
    [*] Difficulty:     ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ - Braindead at the beggining. Hard AF as you reach the end.
    [*] Level design:   ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ - 50% of the game is a tutorial. Gradual increase in difficulty.
    [*] Graphics:       ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ - The game's visuals are breathtaking for an inhouse engine from an indie developer.
    [*] Sound(track):   ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ - The music and sound effects are perfectly synced with the gameplay.
    [*] Gameplay:       ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ - The gameplay is simple but addictively fun, with a great sense of speed and intensity.
    [*] Bugs:           ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ - None, except for the beetle - [i]Ba dum tss[/i]
    [*] Playtime:       5-15 hours
[/list]


[i](Also available for Nintendo Switch)[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198028041217', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 21, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21, 'last_played': 1677070432}
review: I played this game for about 25 minutes total. It got boring and repetitive really fast. Lots of opportunities here to switch up the trippy DMT nightmare graphics but it's literally just the same imagery all the time. After 25 minutes it just became too difficult as well, and since there is seemingly no payoff for persisting and plowing through more levels, I'm done. Also, even though it's a VR game, it's not anything special. I may play it again someday, so I won't refund it.

review:
Old game, yet still one of a kind. Played before on flatscreen and was not too amused. Pschedelic racer something, whatever. Then switched to VR and lost my hearth. Don¬¥t ever think, just be, and you will be fine. Like a good cigar: In the beginning smooth and delightful, then getting stronger step by step. Up to to you when to drop. Keep focus.

For guests;
Once you showed them Google Earth, Accounting and the other beginner VR stuff, this is the one to get people hooked. While fast, it works well, even for those without VR legs, and it really sends them into another dimension. Best served with Reshade and Vrtoolkit, And Pimax maybe.. 

Worth the money, even today. 
Really hope the dev(l)s will release more of this some day.

review: I really enjoyed the first level, the 2nd was okay and the third was more like a grind. Thumper is something else and I love the idea and the artstyle but at the end there was not enough music there, thumper is more like a reaction game. If the developers could have made staying with the rythm more important, this could have been a great game. If you get it for 5-10 bucks it's ok, but don't spend more.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998448503', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 928, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 925, 'last_played': 1674343117}

author: {'steamid': '76561198082419386', 'num_games_owned': 3652, 'num_reviews': 375, 'playtime_forever': 782, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 782, 'last_played': 1674129228}
review:
Thumper is one of a kind. This game has no story (at least I don't think it has any), it's all about to experience this game. The music aspect is great, basically the instrumental in the background and your actions makes the music. Most of the time the game is understandable and fun, meanwhile it has weird mood, thanks to the graphics and... and basically everything what going on your screen. Playing this with a controller is indeed recommended, however you could try with a keyboard, but that's more difficult. About the difficulty tho, the game is going to bring it to you. Later levels are ruthless, some bosses and additional gameplay elements are making sure that you won't have an easy journey. There is even a Play+ mode, where you have to beat the game without dying... well, if you up for the challenge.

However, there were parts in the game, where I had to react to things, which had no indication and also, you had to memorize a few parts to be able to complete it. But probably my biggest complaint about the game is the lack of rewarding. Don't get me wrong, the game barely stops between chapters, making it fast paced, but at the end of the levels you only get your score and your placement in the leaderboard. The only exception is the last level. Maybe I ask much from a game like this, but this was the reason I played for a hour or two per day for 2 weeks.

Thumper is indeed an adrenaline filled fever dream. If you want some challenge and experience this madness, then buy it when it's on sale, for around 10‚Ç¨. I can definitely recommend it, but don't have high expectations about the ending.

author: {'steamid': '76561198133193542', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3096, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1515, 'last_played': 1700861416}
review:
Thumper has to be one of my favourite rhythm games so far after fully completing it (except plus levels). It offers plenty of challenges and things to learn as you progress.

The visuals are absolutely gorgeous, especially considering when this game released. Bright lights and flashy moves, the horror filled environment making you feel as if its hostile and that you don't belong, and the calming, but brief pauses between levels that let the player relax for just a moment, before being plunged right back into the center of the chaos.

The gameplay is satisfying, and mixed in with the audio, it feels euphoric to match the beat, collect points, and to slam down onto the blue rectangles.  It introduces mechanics at a good pace, and allows you to experiment with it even on the earlier levels when you didn't know about it. When you start to realise the path, and match the music, you'll feel like you can conquer the entire chapter. The music, sound and gameplay made it enjoyable to the point I felt comfortable achieving S rank on all the levels as I repeated through them. It was challenging, but satisfying seeing that last achievement pop up.

There are a few issues that I feel this game has as somebody who hasn't played too many rhythm games.

The Visuals, while beautiful, can be annoying to deal with too. The beats / rectangles you're supposed to hit can be obscured by the intense lighting from some areas and bosses, and can completely throw you off.
The Pathing can also be to your detriment, as some areas you either need pure muscle memory or insane reaction speed to even know what's coming your way. (Such as walls back to back, or your environment not allowing you to see what's coming)
One really annoying thing that can throw off completely is when you do take damage. The effect of your armor breaking off obscures the screen, and I've missed a few notes just because I couldn't see something travelling at mach 10 infront of me.

I feel the game also lacks additional content, or reward after you have completed it. I haven't played the plus levels which is just a more challenging version, but it would have been nice to see some time of reward for completely S ranking the game.
I honestly wished there were custom levels that people could submit. This would make the replay value of the game so much bigger, and allow for community involvement.

I love this game a bunch, and would recommend it to anyone who enjoys rhythm games. Just know that you may get very tired or exhausted from the amount of effort, sounds or visual the game has, as it can be a lot to get through an entire level in one sitting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063284842', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 13229, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1092, 'last_played': 1707678449}
review:
Thumper is a defamiliarized rhythm game that feels, through and through, like playing an alien instrument. The visual are an eldritch take on a Journey album cover, impossible geometries and textures warping the usual note highway into an undulating metal rail. As you scrape across this rail at blistering speeds, the pounding drums and rumbling, wailing synths fill the gaps around an orchestra of thumping, clanging, dinging mechanics, which build from tutorials, to rhythmic words and phrases, to sequences and motifs, to climactic boss battles.

Thumper straddles the blurry line between thrilling and overwhelming with grace and precision. Both the dissonant blare of missing a critical input having the potential to throw you completely off your game if you are not focused, and the triumph of decoding a line and playing it perfectly on your controller, seem like direct adaptations of key elements of performing live music. The ever increasing tempo of the beat, the complexity of the note charts, the gyrations of the rail, all keep the pressure on and urge you to master the mechanics, which in turn reward that mastery with satisfying noises and an expressive range of variance. The game's nine levels are quite a tough progression, but if you can beat level 4 then you have a good picture of what the rest of the game will look like. After level 6, the difficulty curve (for just clearing the levels, not necessarily S ranking them) stops steepening and even mellows out a bit, at least until the end, so if you get there then you probably have what it takes to finish.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086092089', 'num_games_owned': 658, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 235, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 88, 'last_played': 1675138850}
review:
I have mixed feelings about this game. 
When we think about rhythm games one of the most enjoyable aspects is the flow state that you get into where everything comes naturally and automatically. Thumper manages to achieve that flow state but in a completely different adrenaline pumping way than any other rhythm game I've ever played. The music and visuals really combine to create some intense white knuckle gameplay.
On the other hand, this game is quite hard, and the vast majority of the deaths I encountered were from my reaction time not being quick enough and being hit with multiple sliding walls in succession. I found that the only way I progressed past these parts was due to memorization. What the game intends for you to do is to listen to the audio cues before each section of gameplay but with everything else going on and the frantic pace, I found that quite difficult. The aspect of skill progression that I usually get from playing rhythm games wasn't there despite pacing myself over multiple play sessions through the course of a week.

It's still a very enjoyable and unique experience but I don't think I could bring myself to get to the end

review: Thumper's atmosphere is utterly intoxicating and addictive, and I've never played a rhythm game like this that captures such raw energy. This game is simple to understand, but quite hard to master and get those juicy S ranks. Thumper is a beautiful game, which is impressive, as the entire game is literally just a bending track. If you're looking for a rhythm game with an atmosphere that grips you so tight that you can't stop playing until your fingers hurt, then look no further.

author: {'steamid': '76561198383366135', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 146, 'playtime_forever': 84, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 84, 'last_played': 1672451694}
review:
I'm more neutral than the thumbs down rating Steam allows.  I personally don't recommend Thumper, but I can see the draw.  Which in large part is down to how good one's sound system is.  Particularly the bass.  Thumper feels equal parts pattern memorization and getting into the rhythm of the beat.  The rhythm portion almost wanting me to have the game give me it's bmp, time signature and show the inputs as musical beat notes to follow along. Which could be nice not musical instrument practice.

But the game isn't really that.  I found it fun-ish.  At least until the Boss sections which pulled me out of the groove waiting to the damage to actually strike.  Again, there is definitely a group of players that are going to dig this game.  I'm just not part of it.  Because of that, given the binary yes/no options of if I recommend it, I don't.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071705486', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 536, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 536, 'last_played': 1643386259}
review:
I am a drummer. I love rythem games. Always have. 
I always look for a new challange and love entering flow states. 

This is all of that combined. 

The pace is breakneck, the timing has to be excellent, the music is entrancing and the enviorment is horrifying in a wonderful alien way (and I don't really like horror). 
I don't tend to like games with no narrative where you make your own but this somehow made me make so many. 

Would have loved some better guides for some later machenics but it's alright. 

NOT FOR PEOPLE WHO CAN'T DO FAST CONTROLS, FAST REPETETIVE CLICKS AND GET NAUSAETED EASILY. 

Wonderful expirience, very gratifying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198156328384', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 132, 'playtime_forever': 1101, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 401, 'last_played': 1702854805}
review:
Normally, I wait until I've finished a game to review it but godDAMN this game needs a thumbs up right this instant. 95% positive steam reviews doesn't do it justice. It's a rhythm game that NAILS that 'game feel' thing that every game wants. It feels so incredibly satisfying to hit perfect timings, and the game balances simplicity with some insane difficulty and complex rhythms. The visuals are so alien and cool and the soundtrack is pretty much melody-free, leaving you with this guttural, intense drum beat that you, the player, make with your gameplay.

Gameplay is made up of 9 Levels, each broken into around 30 sublevels that act as checkpoints for the larger level. Within a given level, you learn a new mechanic, face harder difficulties, and learn new rhythmic phrases. Each level teaches you new short lines of rhythm, which show up in later sublevels, but sometimes with more challenges, or multiple phrases you've learned start getting placed back-to-back, and you have to keep rhythm for a much longer period, combining and synthesizing your skills.

review: Late review but looking back to this game was one of the games that I genuinely enjoyed back then. The visuals and music was all just pure chaos. In terms of a rhythm game it's honestly more reaction based than actually following to the beat of the music, I would give it a positive but saying this game is rhythm is miss leading. It just feels like the beats only come into play with just one input and not every individual input from your key presses.

author: {'steamid': '76561198137880597', 'num_games_owned': 399, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 111, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 94, 'last_played': 1665188664}
review: Got to level 5, started getting frustrated with how bad the clarity is in some sections. A tunnel with red lines, where I'm trying really hard to look for walls with a red line? When I miss it and get hit, my screen turns red, making it hard to find the wall after that? Feels unnecessarily punishing, and like I didn't have a lot of control over it. A rhythm game should be clear with what you're missing, and let you strip away anything unnecessary except what it necessary to play. Take away the trippy background visuals and the tunnels, especially in tight timing sections, and I'd probably be more motivated.

review: Really great and well-polished game. It's a lot of fun and very challenging. That being said, during the later stages, sometimes there are just too many particle effects and too much camera shake to decipher what the hell is going on. A more in-depth options menu, with toggles for some of the effects (as well as more volume sliders as others have mentioned) would have been really nice.

author: {'steamid': '76561198187977709', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 2571, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1084, 'last_played': 1684074172}
review:
It's hard to describe in words how physical this game feels. At the beginning I was wondering how anyone would be mad enough to play this in VR - but after a while it started making sense to me. Thumper immerses you completely by overwhelming you with light, speed and sound, and you can only rely on your instincts and reflexes to react to the mayhem it throws at you. Also, I love the visual design. It feels very alien and intimidating, and it matches the music perfectly.
This is a brilliant take on a rhythm game.

review:
