author: {'steamid': '76561198037680558', 'num_games_owned': 260, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 236, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 236, 'last_played': 1663110071}
review:
First 2 stages are an absolutely beautiful introduction of seamless game design, visuals, rhythm, and feedback. If the first 2 stages were a demo I'd absolutely recommend everyone to play it.

Unfortunately the game doesn't end with 2 stages, its all downhill from there as the game design plummets with a nose dive. The "track" twists and turns aggressively reducing the amount of heads up of oncoming notes by over half. The tunnels obstruct vision much the same. The sheer amount of particle affects, screen-f$%#ing, and other models around the track. Some sections of certain stage background models blend in with the notes/walls. How you have to squint to see which track rail its coming down in the later stages. Could keep adding more but its not worth my time. Take all the above, slap them all together, and voil√† you have the later stages. A constant feeling of being cheated after mistakes instead of "darn, I messed up."

author: {'steamid': '76561198010192388', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1693, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1679, 'last_played': 1687412338}
review:
THE BEST Music/Rhythm game I've ever played!

- The controls are simple, but the game speeds up and gets incredibly challenging. That being said, It does a good job of easing you into things and ramping the difficulty in a linear manner.
- The music is unnerving and oppressive, it does a good job of keeping you on the edge of your seat with tension.

Couple that with the speed and complexity of some of the stages, your hands WILL get sweaty, your Adrenaline will kick in and you wont be able to stop until you've completed at least one whole level.

As for the Negatives - There are some annoying stages with multiple lanes which can get frustrating, and may feel impossible if you're using one hand on Keyboard. I would recommend using a controller overall, or switch between inputs to give your hands a break if you're marathoning the game.

In short, if you like a challenging test of reflexes and rhythm, just buy the game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198932053660', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 8550, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2432, 'last_played': 1705948895}
review:
Thumper. Everyone else here has been selling this game short. It's a perfect piece of art, a masterpiece even. Truly like nothing you'll see anywhere else. So, this is my interpretation of what I just played. Buckle up, we're going to Betelgeuse!


You're a steel beetle from the edge of space that's trapped in a metallic hellscape, screeching down a magnetic track as you work your way through musical rails, brackets, nodes and even eels. You crash, you explode, you demolish, and you persevere for eternities through this rhythmic, coruscating, psychedelic purgatory. You encounter enemies of the wildest sorts, from spiraling fractals, to twisting steel, to godlike abstraction, to monstrous shapes, all regurgitating the winding track, and your nemesis: A snarling face, chromatic spines erupting from its scaly flesh, its eyes burning with hatred unknowable - Your nemesis? Your escape?

You don't know when and how it all began - You've forgotten how you got here. You've been thrown around like a ragdoll, smashed like glass, burned to ashes, crushed to dust. And yet you keep going. You kill your nemesis, and yet the track goes on. You kill it again, and again, and again, watching it burst into spines, tendrils, eyes and razor teeth every time it comes back, torn to shreds and stitched back together. You drift faster and faster, and the eldritch abomination seethes with boundless trauma. And then, the final thump. Its eyes go dark, and it collapses around you. But it's not over.

The true enemy. The needle that's been creating the track, hiding in plain sight everywhere. On the title screen, in your visions, summoning your false nemesis every time you reach it... To protect itself. Because it knows the only thing that can end it is you. Time is ripped like paper, as you send shockwave after shockwave at the needle, splitting it, shattering it, and then tipping it over with the insectoid rage of infinite eternities. It falls, off the track and into the abyss of chaotic, trippy colors below. The real end before you, a tear in the hellscape. Blinding light. And then you're free.

A tale of beetle and needle, a game of determination and dominance, destroying your purgatory with every inch. Eyes locked, wings shattered, rhythms pounding, head thumping. Blinding light, and then you're free.


Now then. We've arrived at Betelgeuse, and I think I've made my point. I can't express in words how satisfied I am with my beetling journey - Thumper is worth every penny. It's not for the faint of heart, and beating it requires insane willpower, but you can at least give it a try. And hey, as a reward, YOU get to decide what the ending is like! In my headcanon, Junebug Joe here got some juicy leaves and an IRL meeting with his Facebook group. So yeah! Beetle game! Dracovish out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198109187748', 'num_games_owned': 85, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1025, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 553, 'last_played': 1703799911}
review:
I would highly recommend this game to anyone. It looks stunning, feels incredibly satisfying, sounds awesome, plays well, and overall provides an incredible experience. I'd highly suggest playing this with a VR headset as it makes the visuals and scale really come to life. Even though the game is short, it is absolutely worth every penny.

Update: I took the time to S rank every song and appreciate every detail of this game. There is so much effort put into the developers for this game, and I am proud to say that this is easily one of my favorite games ever.

review: Thumper is the only game like Thumper that has ever been made. It is the most intense action game, rhythm game, VR game... the list goes on. Everyone should experience Thumper if they like video games. The fact that this game was created by two former Rock Band developers working across a 10 hour time difference is nothing short of astounding. Buy Thumper when it's on sale if you're not convinced, but if you are, buy it now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059442781', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 327, 'last_played': 1660361195}
review:
Listen. It takes a lot for me to review a game. And it is very, VERY difficult to get me to DISLIKE a music-based combat game. So when you mess up #2 enough to make me #1, we have a problem.

The game is SO CLOSE to awesome. The beats are bumpin', the premise is lost in the acid trip, and your little space beetle beats up voodoo faces to the thumpin' sounds of the cosmos.

There's only one problem: there is one master volume control and that's it. So this super fast-paced reflex-heavy DDR for your fingers has no way to tune the sound effects, music, and specific sound queues that alert you to what's coming up. Like, the music is supposed to be like call-and-response: you hear *thump thump clap clap* and you know that you've got two jumps and two turns coming up. But the sounds effects of your jumping and smacking your hull off the walls mixed with the little DING you get for doing it perfectly in sync with the beat PLUS the sounds of you racking up points drowns out the NEXT set of queues. Before you know it, you've got nothing but a maddening cacophony in your ears and your beetle is moving far too fast for you to play by sight alone.

Obviously plenty of other people played this game and can hear just fine. Maybe I'm in the minority of those whose auditory senses get overwhelmed to the point where all the noise just blends together. But this would have been easy enough to remedy if I could have turned the music and sound effects down while turning the sound queues up. Instead I just have tinnitus and a blood pressure problem.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076834130', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 2398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 195, 'last_played': 1712331377}
review:
Completed four levels at the time of this review - Absolutely amazing game. Headset required. It's hypnotic and mesmerising. It's challenging but nailing those perfect runs is rewarding and satisfying.

UPDATE

After finishing the game and getting an S rank on first 5 levels I have to say this is by far the most brutal and violent gaming experience I had in my life. If you want to feel like the game wants to hurt you, try this one. Same with speed - no racing game has ever produced such an overwhelming sense of velocity. By the end of level 3 You will feel violated and brutalised. You will barely survive until the end breathing heavily and covered with sweat. You will think that there is no way this can get any more intense and then you realise that there are still 6 more levels and each one raises the bar so much you'll think it's unplayable. But you will pull through and the game will suck you in. After each level you might want to go back to previous ones and try getting a better rank - It will reward you with an achievement but will also prepare you for what comes next. 

This is one of the most amazing gaming experiences to have. Just a caveat - do not expect a typical rythm game - this is a hardcore survival game that wants to trick you and will often use the beats to throw you off. You will have to watch out for these situations and learn to act off beat, following visual cues. This is about survival and overcoming crazy amount of pressure. This game communicates one thing - it hates you and wants to hurt you. If you are up for a challenge, go in and have a time of your life. Get mesmerised and sucked in by it's violent beauty and relentless brutality of speed and colors. You will hate it back and then you will cross the thin red line as your hate turns to love. 

I love this game. 

Side note - don't play this on deck - although it's perfectly playable, you will need a disposable controller because if you intend to beat it, you will absolutely wreck one. You will also want to play it on a big display with at least 120hz refresh and matching FPS. Not only it will improve your immersion but it will really help you to pull off those split second input margins. 
Also headset - do not play without one and make it as loud as you can bear. You will understand and you will thank me later.

author: {'steamid': '76561198871142732', 'num_games_owned': 113, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 825, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 825, 'last_played': 1658761154}
review:
7.8/10
If you‚Äôre looking for speed, if you‚Äôre looking for something to mindlessly smash your controller without any dialogues, any story, or pretty much any thinking, this game is what you need.  Thumper is a combination of NOT doing things that make a game go to hell.
With excellent design decisions and getting rid of anything that could‚Äôve been boring, these guys have managed to make a real experience. With A good balance between challenging and ‚Äúnot killing" the player, Thumper has a nice pace of getting stuck in a level for a good 6-7 minutes (the levels are mostly less than 2 min), and then right before you‚Äôre getting frustrated, passing the level and starting to enjoy the game again and possibly even more this time.
Since you don‚Äôt expect that much variety from this kind of game I‚Äôm not gonna stress this that much but there‚Äôs not many things you can do here. From the start to the end you are mostly doing the same things and that‚Äôs what makes me wish Thumper was a bit shorter. There‚Äôs plenty of fun gameplay but it‚Äôs not all fun. Duplicated sequences and some of the smaller levels are nothing but fillers that lead the player to getting disappointed.
For a music based game, the music is really not that good. It serves the atmosphere well but I think some drums and electric guitar could affect the experience big time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198233374604', 'num_games_owned': 91, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 926, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 549, 'last_played': 1696757131}
review:
amazing, very unheard of gem

do you like rhythm games, but are coincidentally tired of baby shit DDR and OSU? well come on down to thumper, the only rhythm game that feels like it would be played best with a stick shift, while also allowing you to live out your childhood fantasies of playing as what is essentially a sentient Hot Wheel, while ALSO living out your naughty adult fantasies of using previously mentioned hot wheels to kill beings in higher dimensions than you

here's some cool facts that might sell you on the game:
1: the game doesn't increase in difficulty, it increases in complexity.  there are 9 levels, each filled with about 20 sub-levels.  level 1's music is in 1/4 time signature. level 2 is in 2/4 time signature. level 3 is in 3/4 time signature, all the way up to 9/8.
2: game can be played in vr, which i reccomend, because it looks insane.
3: game pulls a bloodborne on you at the end of each level and says "fuck it, lovecraftian horror that exists on a higher plane of existence than you"

I'm not going to spoil anything more than that, but do not just give up on the game on level 3 because you think its repetitive, keep going. once you hit a time signature higher than 4/4 it starts to get a little wacky, everything past 5/4 is when you can enter a flow state.

and one more thing, play until the end. i don't know how to explain this, but they put a plot twist in a rhythm game where you play as a beetle on a hot wheels track. just trust me its insane. if you get there

issues i have with the game: sometimes it feels like they don't explain vital controls well enough. on level 3-1 it teaches you the "ground pound". string enough of these in a row, or in quick succession and you can regain your armor. if you press the thump button while holding up on a blue tile thing, you can fly. you can extend your flight duration by continuing to hold the thump button. you cannot fly forever. that is all i felt like the game didn't explain well enough.

I got this game for 5.99$, which is a GREAT price for it. i don't think its worth 20 dollars, but 5.99 is still on the low side. highly recommend to anyone who likes rhythm games and punishing difficulties, but i recommend it even higher to anyone with ADHD

for anyone wondering what it feels like to play thumper, this is the video that i thought of every time i tried to explain it: 
( https://youtu.be/PScdq0wxIgc )

author: {'steamid': '76561198042551729', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 61, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1658282368}
review: Was genuinely enjoying this game till level 3-1 when I had to google how to progress the game as a new "stomp" mechanic is expected to be performed with no explanation. Even after figuring out this inconsistent mechanic I made it to the final boss of level 3 where it expects you to perform 3 of these terrible mechanics in a row. I managed to get 2 and was not able to get 3. You are then stuck in an infinite loop of this godawful mechanic in which youll never die as the obstacles arent hard. So after 5 minutes of attempting this I gave up and probably won't play this game for a while simply as this takes all the fun out of the game. It breaks the immersion of level progression to just put a wall in the way of playing the game. Maybe it just feels inconsistent in VR, but from looking online many people despise this mechanic.

review:
I will finish the game later but initial reaction is disappointment. You got to do movements off-beat in order to accomplish. In fact, I think anyone muting the sound will do a better job because your brain does not try to place the movements in sync with the music. Better focus on what you see than what you hear. As soon as you start trying to sync with the music you lose. Why would they make it so damn unsatisfactory and sell it as a rhytm game? I don't know. 

Also, people comparing this with a psychedelic trip or shrooms have never actually done that. It is nothing like that. Literally just a fast moving computer game with 2015 graphics.

review: I've already played this on Switch a few years ago so I got the upper hand, although I haven't beat it there. After completing all of the achievements, Thumper is definitely worth the asking price, it's fun and intense. Its tight controls and tough-as-nails-but-manageable difficulty makes this a worthy challenge to conquer, and the feedback you get for getting all those bars and rings to the beat makes it so satisfying to do. Every time you die, you don't feel like you want to ragequit, it's more like "How can I improve this to the best of my ability?". This is Thumper, and you are in for one hell of a ride.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079321337', 'num_games_owned': 189, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 3250, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3201, 'last_played': 1662651015}
review:
HOLY FUCKING SHIT. There's no other way to describe this game.

Game is being advertised as a rhythm violence game and it does live up to its nature - brutally difficult levels which leave you no breathing room aside from small pauses at checkpoints. All while doing actions to the beat, performing interesting rhythms.

However, after having grinded this game a b i t I've come to a conclusion it's an ANTI-rhythm game. There are many patterns where you feel out of control AT ALL TIMES while still, somehow, having to stay in rhythm. At times you have no fucking idea what's happening, you just kind of go and pray and solely push through your twitch reflexes, but when you do it, it's a moment of "holy shit I did it". And boy, there are a LOT of moments like this here.

As for the gameplay itself, it's pretty cool, yeah. There's a plenty of objects to work around with, such as turns that will brutally murder you if you don't react in time, thumps which keep your combo up (or alternatively you can brutally ground pound them for mad score), bars and rings which act as additional score pickups. Despite very limited number of potential obstacles, the game never seems bland. Everything serves a purpose and there are just enough mechanics that spice up the gameplay and allow for high score pushing. All in this nightmare-reminescent landscape.

Final verdict: game fucking THUMPS! If you have a knack for unconventional games, or rhythm games for that matter, it's definitely a worthwhile investment. Also, can we just have a moment to appreciate the fact this game was made by TWO PEOPLE?!

author: {'steamid': '76561197973301905', 'num_games_owned': 2279, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 386, 'last_played': 1654050941}
review:
A nightmarish twist on rhythm racers, Thumper is fast-paced and energetic. It has a kickass, pulse-pounding soundtrack, backing a great musical gameplay experience. For the most part.

The game is great at cultivating its atmosphere. The music, the art direction, the sound effects, all serve to immerse you on the wild ride through hell that is Thumper. I found early stages to be just the right level of gradually increasing challenge to help you master its various obstacles and techniques. There may come a point when you'll feel like an expert, swerving and grinding down Thumper's rails.

One minor issue the game has is the visual effect that occurs when you take a hit. It takes two hits to end a run, but the exploding effect of your shell being destroyed is distracting and disorienting. There seems to be some kind of invincibility mechanic to prevent you from taking a second hit right away, but it doesn't last the entire duration of the visual effect. You will die on more occasions than you like because you can't recover in time from the first hit to avoid a second. This mechanic definitely needs a retool.

But much more frustrating are the game's later tracks, which become less forgiving, less rhythm based, and less fun. Starting in level 7, and increasing in frequency as time goes on, the game features segments that are less about reacting to the rhythm and more about memorization. Obstacles that are not well telegraphed will come out of nowhere, and can only be overcome by knowing the inputs ahead of time. You will run these sections dozens of times memorizing the track one beat at a time. This is very frustrating, especially during one particularly poorly designed boss fight. And as the pace of the tracks picks up, figuring out the game‚Äôs exact timing seemed impossible. If by level 6 you think you've figured it out, these segments will flip the script on you. Some beats will be more forgiving early, others will be more forgiving late. Some beats won't register at all even when you seem to have hit them perfectly. This inconsistency in a rhythm game is rather egregious. It's really the one thing a rhythm game needs to be get right without fail.

All of which culminates in a final sequence that would be clever if it wasn't so very frustrating.

By the time I finished Thumper‚Äôs final track, sadly I have to say I wasn‚Äôt having fun anymore.

That said, those final levels of frustration don't undo the hours of fun I had playing and replaying the early tracks. I still have fun going back to the early levels trying to master them. With a leaderboard to climb, and always room to improve, these are endlessly replayable. I look forward to shooting for those S ranks on levels 1 through 6, testing my mettle against friends and strangers alike. The bulk of Thumper is a tight, thrilling, pulse-pounding experience you'll come back to again and again. You can get lost in the game for long stretches playing entire levels, or focus on more bite-sized tracks and boss fights for shorter binges. But be aware that the quality isn't maintained all the way through.

Despite its frustrating ending, I still greatly recommend Thumper. As a beginning-to-end "campaign" type experience, Thumper has real issues. But as a replayable, score attack, rhythm game, Thumper is incredible. Its dark, unsettling, beat-driven madness is a joy, and those first 6 of 9 levels are worth playing and playing over again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064416241', 'num_games_owned': 650, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 74, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 60, 'last_played': 1656424395}
review:
Thoroughly unsatisfying to play (And not because it's hard and I'm bad, or I don't play rhythm games)
Thumper has a very good formula at the very base: Thump out to the rhythm, with different obstacles and points requiring different techniques, mostly pressing A or holding it down while going in a direction.
Where it fails however, is everywhere else. I wish the easy parts were harder and the hard parts were easier. There are obstacles where you just have to hold the A button and the beat hammers itself for a second or two. You have to look ahead to spot the telegraphed twists and turns and figure out where to hold the button and where to press it, which is fine, but if a section goes on for longer than 4 beats, the telegraphed blips and bloops are layered on top of the bangs and booms of your current actions. All of this may just sound like added difficulty and me complaining because I'm bad at it, but after the occasional hiccup I got through the levels just fine, it just made the game so much [b] less satisfying. [/b] And the mechanics of the core gamplay isn't even the only thing making it less satisfying: the game insists on giving you the most unusual time signatures and off beat inputs, which again, sounds like cool difficulty, but even if I get an S rank three times in a row it feels so utterly boring. The music feels very utilitarian, it gives you a baseline beat for you to orient yourself and nothing else. Landing hits on a boss gives you a little slow motion animation, which feels like a bad joke in a rhythm game, because instead of getting a satisfying hit, the slow motion messes with the rhythm.
I've played alot of rhythm games. I've been bad at many of them, but this one I really didn't like despite the fact that I was surprisingly ok at it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198801214808', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 5702, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 3, 'playtime_at_review': 975, 'last_played': 1711479861}
review:
One of the most unique takes on a "rhythm game" I have yet to see. Thumper hones in on being intense and fast-paced, with near split-second reactions that prove challenging, but entirely doable; leading to an incredibly gratifying experience to both play and view.
 The game offers frequent checkpoints throughout each level and allows you to pause and jump between levels at any point if you so choose, however greatly rewards commitment and truly tests the player's ability with some more drawn out parts scattered in each level. 
 Thumper makes a clear point even in the earliest levels, to try and seemingly trick the player by throwing a series of obstacles out of beat or that are barely noticeable. But as of passing some of the later levels, it became apparent that the obstacles themselves were being used as part of the soundtrack; often the level demanding for you to interact with the soundtrack rather than simply copy the beat, creating a unique and all the more satisfying experience as your success is shown both visually and audibly.
 If I were to truly critique it on one thing, it is that some obstacles and visual / audio queue's are lost at points to an occasional overload of the games extremely flashy visual style; making these obstacles virtually impossible to notice unless you had prior knowledge of them. 
 With all that said, Thumper is an incredibly challenging and sometimes taxing game, I would not recommend expecting to complete this game in a single sitting as it also proves taxing even after just a single level. However I would be lying if I didn't say that it has thus far been one of the most enjoyable games i've played from this genre, and that I would highly recommend it to anyone who can handle it.

author: {'steamid': '76561199049954239', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 826, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 360, 'last_played': 1706131204}
review:
What an amazing game! This was my first rhythm game and I was not disappointed. As a musician I found this game especially enjoyable. Other rhythm games I've seen stick to easy to understand beats to follow. Thumper doesn't pull any punches and includes everything from crossing meter to heavy syncopation that rivals that of prog rock. 

I would recommend this game to anyone who is looking for a super intense rhythm game that makes your adrenaline pump and doesn't hold back the difficulty.

P.S. The beats are not wrong, they are just placed in unusual spots that aren't normally seen in games like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198166562199', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1818, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 109, 'last_played': 1677604688}
review:
What can I say about this? It's an insanely exhilarating gaming experience. I've only played the first 3 and a half levels so I can't comment on the entire thing.

If you're used to a typical rhythm game you may find it frustrating and needlessly difficult; sometimes it really does feel like the game is f***ing with you. However, if you like overcoming an immense challenge like that you will find this game incredibly satisfying. There's something so good about accomplishing a difficult rhythm first try and going "HAHAHA YOU THOUGHT YOU COULD GET ME WITH THAT? I AM A RHYTHM GOD" and then immediately crashing into a beat 1 obstacle and dying. 

I'm a musician, so I can tell how difficult the things it's asking me to do are. What's funny is that I reach a point where I can't really "count" anymore the way I might if I were playing a song, and instead I have to rely purely on feel and embodying the rhythm. The game is actually fairly forgiving with the inputs, but it never feels like it's holding my hand or making things too easy for me. It feels rewarding to hit things perfectly in time, but when the game lets you get away with stuff it never feels like it detracts from the sense of stakes.

Basically, if you want a game that's going to throw e of beat 4 rhythms and 3 against 4 polyrhythms at you within the first three levels you are gonna have fun with this. It reminds me of those fake 3d rollercoasters where you're basically in a moving box staring at a screen, except now it's actually up to you to avoid all those obstacles.

If they added custom music, a level designer, and user levels I would literally never stop playing this game lol

author: {'steamid': '76561197980907866', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 274, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 226, 'last_played': 1659144271}
review:
Magst du Rhythmus Spiele? Hast du Spa√ü daran Dinge immer und immer zu wiederholen bis du sie perfekt beherrschst? Dann solltest du Thumper ausprobieren!

Hier bei handelt es sich nicht um ein normales Rhythmus Spiel. Man selbst spielt den genannten Thumper, ein K√§fer √§hnliches "Raumschiff" das sich auf Schienen durch das Universum bewegt und dabei noch das "B√∂se" bek√§mpft. Eine richtige Story gibt es hier nicht. Dies ist auch nicht von n√∂ten.

Zur Grafik kann man auch nicht viel sagen, au√üer das sie Zweckm√§√üig ist. Das Spiel ist nicht h√§sslich, doch man achtet sowieso mehr auf die Strecke als auf den Hintergrund.

Die Steuerung ist einfach gehalten und schnell gelernt. Auch hier merkt man das dieses Spiel etwas f√ºr jedermann ist. 

Der Schwierigkeitsgrad steigt von Level zu Level. Am Anfang hat man noch das Gef√ºhl gut zu sein und zu wissen was man macht, doch das √§ndert sich sehr schnell wenn man Level 5 bzw 6 erreicht hat. Dieser zieht das massiv an und man muss einen Abschnitt mehr als nur einmal machen.

Dieses Spiel ist wahrlich nicht einfach, aber davon sollte man sich nicht abschrecken lassen. 

[b][url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/Gcolly]Kuratorseite: Gaming f√ºr jedermann![/url][/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198044792231', 'num_games_owned': 850, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 52, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1653080672}
review:
Really cool concept. Not the best execution.

This game -should- tick all the right boxes for me. Abstract eldritch horror rhythm game scored by the guy from Lightning Bolt? Sign me the hell up! Unfortunately it's hamstrung by a lack of both variety and clarity. The visuals become so overblown that it's nearly impossible to see what's coming up and the sound cues aren't high enough in the mix to overcome the repetitive, uninteresting music so you'll run into a lot of areas with turns and obstacles that come up seemingly out of nowhere. The bosses look basically the same throughout, as do the tracks, so the only way you'll know you're on a different level is through the tempo and the sheer length. Levels go on for way too long, often teaching you a new trick at the beginning and then spending ten segments reiterating on it - but the prompts for these tricks are often unclear and don't tell you enough about what you're learning so that you can actually capitalise on it.

It all adds up to a frustrating experiences that falls short of the potential it has. I really wanted to like this but even less than an hour was enough to be thrown off by its shortcomings.

author: {'steamid': '76561198197243822', 'num_games_owned': 142, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 3171, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1828, 'last_played': 1702575443}
review:
Thumper may not be for everyone, as it is not like other rhythm games at all. Instead of playing a single song, you are stuck in a hellscape for stretches of about half an hour at a time, maybe more, maybe less, depending on how well you do.

Thumper makes you attack the music instead of harmonizing with it. By slamming into the track, incoming walls or barriers, you create your own song from heavy thumps, metallic clangs and other noises, with the background music mostly being there for atmosphere. 

By slamming into the track at the right moment,  the game can intentionally 'freeze', which only helps to increase immersion, as it really makes it feel like you did a really powerful attack or something like that.

I think Thumper deserves its genre: Rhythm violence.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045191888', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1197, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1197, 'last_played': 1650005482}
review:
Let me start off by saying that this game is intense. It is by all definitions a rhythm game, but as I think any music major could tell you, some horrendous things can be done to rhythms. Instead of usual genre songs in a comfortable 4/4 time, Thumper opts for weird time signatures and bombarding you with audio cues, mush, and crashes. Tack on trippy early 2000's Microsoft screensaver effects, and this game will easily overstimulate you. And in my opinion, it does a damn good job of doing that and causing a sense of unease and tension. It makes you feel like you're fighting tooth and nail to make it to the end of a track in one piece.
With all that said, I need to touch upon a few things. There are obstacles along the track, and the game is nice enough to let you know what's coming ahead via audio cues. The unfortunate fact is those cues can and will be drowned out by the sounds of the music and the general sfx's of your little beetle boy riding along his track. This leads to the  issue that you'll find yourself relying more on memorization than the intended cues meant for the player, which is a shame. Those moments where you find yourself in the flow, struggling and making last second twitch reactions are where this game feels it's most addictive. This leads to my next point, the only audio options you have in the menu are the total volume of the whole game. No choice to slightly raise the cues, or lower the music, or any of the other noise. I understand this was probably intentional so we as players can play the game as intended, but it would've been nice to have the option nonetheless. 
Ultimately, I did love this game. Nothing about it was chill, the whole experience felt anxious and had my heart racing, but you know what? That was fun as fuck, and nothing felt more relieving coming out alive at the end of a level. Some of you might even find something deeper and more meaningful within the gameplay.

review:
What if H.P. Lovecraft fabricated a rhythm based video-game?

This is what I think of when I play Thumper.

While my in-game time isn't nearly as dense as others, I assure you from what little I've played of it, I /highly/ recommend this game. One of the most if not /the/ most unique experiences in the genre.

The original soundtrack for this game is also absolutely superb and really nails the gameplay hook. The two are in near perfect harmony.

Really need to go back and devote more time to this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198309882298', 'num_games_owned': 144, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 263, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 161, 'last_played': 1686488806}
review:
Note: While the playtime suggests I'm still new to the game, I have finished the game on mobile.

I consider this game as fitting for an arcade game: simple controls & mechanic, sharp difficulty increase, has score system. As others mentioned, this is a rhythm game, but "it does not have music nor it follow to the beat of the music". The game teaches you to remember the rhythm by giving you the same beat notes across several sub-level, while the "background music" serves as a metronome.

Players who just want to play the game can just play like it's nothing, but for those who wants to compete on score, that is where the game shines. You will find yourself that the game demands perfection and practice, as you have to turn at the last second before hitting the walls, pounding over bonus thumps, beating bosses at attempt one and keeping your preserverance trying to not crash at any moment.

TL:DR
100% Not your typical music rhythm game, simple gameplay, can get hard real quick, has scoring system that evaluates to performance & accurancy. Prepare to die at least 5 on certain sub-levels.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995370472', 'num_games_owned': 285, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 395, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 395, 'last_played': 1650057701}
review:
The difficulty was a bit steep, but I call BS at the final boss of level 7 (when there's like 3 'locks') and stopped playing immediately. This game is a perfect game to send to someone if you want them to be miserable.

There's a fine line between challenging and brutally difficult. I'm not your target audience. I'm out. I'm done. Byeeeeeeeeeeeeeee

There's a reason why there's only 9.9% of all players who finished level 6.

It's worth it at the price, but I'm very confident that it won't be worth the time and patience I would need to spend in order to finish this game. So, if you want to buy this, just buy and play until you hit the brick wall, then go play something else. It's fun until the BS starts.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023025930', 'num_games_owned': 459, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 444, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 398, 'last_played': 1707666684}
review:
An avant-garde gaming masterpiece in VR

Astounding and successful in its simplicity, Thumper shines a bright light amongst a barrage of dull and unimaginative VR zombie shooter games.
The game revolves around you piloting a beetle-like creature with insane speeds throughout surreal Lovecraftesque cosmic landscapes and trying to avoid any potential crashes with seemingly infinite amount of traps and gigantic monstrosities. 
The game constitutes a truly one-of-a-kind experience in VR with its trance'y and dark soundtrack. Highly recommended for any people who possess a VR headset and are up for a fair challenge.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030533945', 'num_games_owned': 694, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 427, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 344, 'last_played': 1662422720}
review:
this game is insane. I've only completed up to and including level 4 so far, but it's already getting crazy difficult, especially if you are trying to get really good scores. it's easy to learn, difficult to master. each element of gameplay is simple, but what you can do for score is almost exponential with each new addition of an element.

first of all, this game is amazing at giving your feedback. When you're hitting your blocks and turns, the game feels good. when you are hitting everything and then adding in some,  it feels AMAZING. try hitting a couple slams in a row on some blocks and just watch the game THUMP in response, really selling you on the feeling of hitting a strong combo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047038666', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 7119, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2202, 'last_played': 1709689599}
review:
This game is not what you think it is. It is not a rhythm game. It is an anti-rhythm game. It is designed to lure you into a false sense of steadiness and throw that away with sudden twists and turns which seemingly do not match the beats. Every level is made to correspond with that time signature. It will leave you thinking about any possible leads you can create with real music, and God willingly, your own "solos" should you dare thump down and stutter the entire melody itself. 

I was a tiny disappointed with original expectations and only 9 levels, but it was an interesting twist. Unfortunately, many of the patterns must simply be memorized and have less to do with "rhythm" and reaction. Since the tribal drumbeats can throw you off the melody hard (especially level 9 which is my favorite) you may find the game actually easier without any audio, but of course that's a boring experience. Still, there is more to this game.

The joy of beat pounding over and over from successful blue notes repeatedly causing short frame pauses and large reverberations is felt in very few games. It is enough to put you in some kind of mild trance. It's like the notes you play and the background beating are two different rhythms but still work wonderfully, the same kind of syncopation you might get from your favorite Meshuggah song. 

Finally, what's most intriguing but has absolutely no impact on the gameplay is the "lore". At first I couldn't figure out why I couldn't stop thinking about this game. Its parallels to Lovecraftian horrors really sell it for me, even though I don't care whatsoever for that genre. The visuals are "asymmetrical, shapeshifting creatures" and often times "frustratingly formless." And that is exactly what the music is. It is made of chaos, it is made to destroy you, not to comfort you, and you know in the final level that perhaps you have gone where you shouldn't have.  

This game is a nightmare, and it's amazing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198140725739', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1496, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1496, 'last_played': 1646614149}
review:
Really telling when only 6% of the people that bought this game actually beat it. For a rhythm game, it lacks the one thing that defines its genre. Trial and error is not a good look for a game like this. Speaking of looks, the graphics are really charming and make for a satisfying thing to look at. Without much rhythm to make inputs feel natural, the player depends on visual reads to know how to complete a checkpoint. The terrible bloom and intricate backgrounds make that such a chore, I had to squint in some sections of the game. Some more graphical options would be a simple fix to this, while making this game more accessible.

I like the aesthetic of Thumper and I want to like it, but it just doesn't stick the landing. No spoilers, but the final boss uses a new mechanic that is not used anywhere else in the game, which is flat-out bad design. It doesn't feel rewarding to have to learn an entirely new way to play at the very end. I still had a good time playing this game, but only in that satisfying "I've mastered this" kind of way. Very little replay value if leaderboards are not your thing.

review: Thumper is a unique rhythm game where you are a beetle traveling at supersonic speed. While the music is minimalist, the music comes from the beat which your beetle generates as it interacts with the environments. The premise is simple but it's quite addictive and satisfying when you get everything right.  I played this for a while when it first came out, and recently started it to play this again after getting the Quest 2 VR kit. This game plays great in VR as well.

review: As someone who doesn't play a whole lot of games, I feel like I understand video games and what makes people love them so much better for having played this! Something about how precisely designed it is in balancing challenge and enjoyment flipped a switch in my brain that made me want to become the best Thumper player in the world and that feeling isn't going away no matter how much I play it. My only complaint is that the art design and cosmic horror-inspired aesthetic is far far too gorgeous for a game where you're spending the entire time focusing on trying really hard not to die and can't focus on what's happening in the background

author: {'steamid': '76561198063349729', 'num_games_owned': 630, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 459, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 459, 'last_played': 1644015361}
review:
This game feels less like intentional control inputs and more like ricocheting at light speed.
There is a lack of clarity with the dark heavy rhythm of the music, sometimes its impossible to pick up on. The time signatures  / tempo of the music is very, very, very unconventional. 
And I can see how it can put people off. Its jarring, it makes no sense. It feels like you have to rely on pure reflexes to beat levels rather than any rhythm at all. 
To an extent I feel like that is the point of the game. As its aptly self proclaimed genre, rhythm violence; feels really accurate. 
Spoilers: 
[spoiler]Only when you start to feel somewhat comfortable with the discomfort of it all by level 8-9. The game breaks the foundational principles of its already confusing world by transgressing on the one thing that makes this game a rhythm game. Like a dying record, the tempo and the corresponding speed of the game bounce erratically up and down; from extreme speeds to slow-motion. It is extremely destabilising.[/spoiler]
The ending really wraps this game up neatly. 
Yes, thumper is a rhythm game. In the conventional sense. 
but it is also very violent, and very ugly. and does not care to only be a rhythm game.
and I love it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198413904874', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 118, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 118, 'last_played': 1643684815}
review:
I had a hard time parsing the screen after midway through level 3. Colors and textures kind of bled together. Maybe it was a depth perception thing. The music is fun but getting the hits of character movement to line up with it while struggling to parse what is on screen was beyond me. I could probably brute force my way through but if I'm not going to enjoy the time I spend with it I'd prefer doing something that doesn't frustrate me.

 I am not the target audience so if the above sounds appealing go for it, and it is a beautiful piece of art with a cool beetle. If I want to enjoy it I'll watch an expert play-through. YMMV

author: {'steamid': '76561199187456791', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 1475, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 913, 'last_played': 1704958304}
review: I wouldn't say I am a rhythm game connoisseur, but this seems to offer something new. This game goes though time signatures 1/2-9/8. So you might experience different rythms then the common 4/4 time in all pop music (Rock is pop by the way, hot take I'm sure.) It has that viseral pounding music that gets your heart pumping. And the visuals are super sick, very metal.  If I was going to give a rhythm game outside Guitar Hero for someone to try and play, this would be it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198983445365', 'num_games_owned': 59, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 895, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 548, 'last_played': 1702346235}
review: It's an interesting rhythm game which is fun at first. However, after awhile of failing for an uncountable number in sections I could feel my anger build up. At one point the anger moved onto something more where instead of fits of rage there would be cold flashes that would wash over my skull. All in all it's a good game if a bit headache inducing due to the rapid flashing. I would not recommended this for your first rhythm or if your not good at rhythm games in general.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058887844', 'num_games_owned': 270, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 491, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 491, 'last_played': 1642500685}
review: Very fun, starts pretty easy and then progressively gets a LOT more difficult. I can see it being very replayable if you want to go back for S ranks on every stage. Trying to maintain a jump/glide around a corner turn can be a real pain but it's a fun risk/reward element.

author: {'steamid': '76561198243227552', 'num_games_owned': 132, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 1634, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 380, 'last_played': 1664569747}
review: This is probably the best rhythm game i have ever played. It gives you a feeling like you're not supposed to have gotten through the game. It does sound so well, you'll feel like what you're playing is not music at all. Normally, i suck at rhythm games, but it wasn't so hard once i memorized the patterns. This is the first rhythm game i have actually beaten all the levels to. I would recommend to EVERYONE.

review: Hardcore rhythm game, in an intense roller coaster ride but with awesome soundtrack and trippy visuals

author: {'steamid': '76561198860188558', 'num_games_owned': 539, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 1025, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 233, 'last_played': 1667606430}
review: Thumper is a rhythm violence game with simple controls yet punishing gameplay that i ran out of patience for. I got up to level 6 before i gave up and believe me, i died many many many times. It's rare for me to give up on games because of their difficulty. I've heard some people say this game is revolutionary in the rhythm genre but i don't fully see why. I still do recommend this if you're looking for any music games described as rhythm violence and if you don't mind getting your a$$ handed to you in the later levels if you're looking to beat it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021112470', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 1897, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1876, 'last_played': 1673737199}
review: thumper makes me shake my dumper

author: {'steamid': '76561198026719448', 'num_games_owned': 429, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 720, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 720, 'last_played': 1642205341}
review: I tend to get little mileage out of rhythm games, but Thumper's gotten me the most enjoyment out of any I've tried yet. It's not without the classic pitfalls - retrying levels to get a perfect run is still frustrating due to the long periods of inaction or gimme sections - but there's enough mechanics and interesting twists on them, that in addition to the difficulty make it really fun to get through the stock 9 levels. They are long, grueling affairs that are violent and stylish and exciting. Pretty neat game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116546358', 'num_games_owned': 237, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 201, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 158, 'last_played': 1667334810}
review:
A really good rhythm game with some amazing aesthetic.

Negative out of the way first, it's music is a little lackluster, being closer to playing drums at a club with little semblance of a backing melody. Sometimes, timing seems slightly off from the background music and it's $20 price tag as of writing seems a little too high for me ($15 or less in my opinion).

With all that being said, it's overall a real treat to play. The game does a great jump introducing new mechanics to the player, with difficulty stacking up nicely as you play on. It's very unique in its gameplay, and I can't stress enough how good the visuals are accompanying the gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075202999', 'num_games_owned': 814, 'num_reviews': 333, 'playtime_forever': 349, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 37, 'last_played': 1641418860}
review:
this is simple and fun and tense but
it's so unengaging and slow to start
and from the menu you can't choose specific sub sections of levels to replay, so if you get an S rank somewhere and a B somewhere else you have to replay THE WHOLE GODDAMN LEVEL just to fix one mistake
I've tried this game 3 or 4 times and every time I just get too frustrated to keep playing, not cause it's difficult but because I get bored and then when I do make a mistake I can't rectify it without testing my patience
maybe it's worth it in the end tho

it's an odd sort of off rhythm game in that
you're playing a rhythm with your hands that you just heard while trying to listen for the upcoming rhythm you'll have to mimic
of course with DDR and Rock Band you're doing the same thing except you're doing it visually, this game you do it aurally and you could almost play with your eyes closed if there was an audio cue for which direction upcoming turns go, seems like a missed opportunity

weirdly I've found that you can wiggle the movement stick rapidly to reliably enter turns perfectly and you don't die despite aiming yourself in the wrong direction
seems like a weird exploit but whatever

author: {'steamid': '76561199181839271', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 1210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 704, 'last_played': 1656729257}
review: I would have recommended this game to just about anyone, but the difficulty ramps up quite a bit after chapter 5, and not everyone may appreciate the "trial by fire" gameplay the latter half of the game evolves into. The steam achievements may back this up, with only 5% of players actually finishing this relatively short game. The game also seems to like to take the players out of the rhythm in certain levels. Most of Chapter 6 (especially 6-19) and level Infinity are the main examples of this issue. Overall though, I very much enjoyed the rest of the chapters; Chapter 8 being my favorite. For players who are interested in difficult games, the price of admission to experience the unique gameplay this game offers is worth it, and on sale: it's a steal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198868557020', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 203, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 56, 'last_played': 1681415350}
review:
first things first: if i could leave a mixed review i would, and im writing this after getting a full s rank on the first level, and i did not play his in virtual reality. jesus christ i do not want to.
this is as much a rhythm game as resident evil 1 is a third person shooter. you may come in expecting edgy guitar hero or ddr and you will come out looking like my icon. 
in most rhythm games ive played, the songs are electro-dance-shit, (im not that great at identifying genres) which allow for easier detection of the rhythm and timing. you can hear the beat the same way you can see a whale when you go out into the ocean: its not guaranteed but it does happen. fully s ranking this level was a fucking terrifying experience and finishing it gave me the same experience as getting an s rank in a platinum game.
repeating the same section over and over until i got it perfect, only this time i wanted to lie down and take a 2 week nap.
id recommend playing it in small bursts, its very stressful.

author: {'steamid': '76561198228702788', 'num_games_owned': 606, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 1906, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 522, 'last_played': 1710592673}
review:
Old Fashioned Pumpkin Pie

2 large eggs
1 large egg yolk
1/2 cup packed dark brown sugar
1/3 cup white sugar
1/2 teaspoon salt
2 teaspoons cinnamon
1 teaspoon ground ginger
1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg
1/4 teaspoon ground cloves
1/8 teaspoon cardamom
1/2 teaspoon finely grated lemon zest
2 cups pumpkin pur√©e from a sugar pumpkin (see Recipe Note) OR 1 (15-ounce can) pumpkin pur√©e (can also use pur√©ed cooked butternut squash)
1 1/2 cups heavy cream or 1 (12-ounce) can evaporated milk
1 homemade pie crust, chilled or frozen (see p√¢te bris√©e recipe or our no-fail flaky pie crust recipe), or 2 pre-made pie shells

Preheat the oven:
Preheat your oven to 425¬∞F.
Make the filling:
Beat the eggs in a large bowl. Mix in the brown sugar, white sugar, salt, spices ‚Äî cinnamon, ground ginger, nutmeg, ground cloves, cardamom, and lemon zest.
Mix in the pumpkin pur√©e. Stir in the cream. Beat together until everything is well mixed.
mixing pumpkin pie ingredients
pumpkin pie ingredients mixed well
adding cream to pumpkin pie puree
pumpkin pie filling ready to add to pie
Fill the pie shell and bake:
Pour the filling into an uncooked chilled or frozen pie shell. Bake at a high temperature of 425¬∞F for 15 minutes.
Then after 15 minutes, lower the temperature to 350¬∞F. Bake for 45 to 55 minutes more. The pie is done when a knife tip inserted in the center comes out wet but relatively clean. The center should be just barely jiggly.
(About half-way through the baking, you may want to put foil around the edges or use a pie protector to keep the crust from getting too browned.)
Note that the pumpkin pie will come out of the oven all puffed up (from the leavening of the eggs), and will deflate as it cools.
pumpkin pie in dish ready for baking
Baked Pumpkin Pie From Scratch
Cool the pie on a rack, then serve:
Cool the pumpkin pie on a wire rack for 2 hours.
Serve with whipped cream.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065407531', 'num_games_owned': 836, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1099, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1099, 'last_played': 1600612374}
review:
This is a weird and fun experience at the same time.
Unlike other rhythm based games, this one does not focus on having funky beats or catchy tunes.
Instead you are welcomed solely by drums, kicks, scratches and distorted sounds while surging forwards at ridiculously high speeds trying your best to react in time.

It is quite fun once you get a hang of it and manage to perfectly dodge or essentially speedrun bosses. 
More than enough fun for a first playthrough and definitely worth it's price. 
And if you're a completionist, trying to get a perfect score on every level can also be quite a challenge (Especially if you try to get through the entire game without dying).

author: {'steamid': '76561198024156051', 'num_games_owned': 532, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 894, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 309, 'last_played': 1702698667}
review: Holy guacamole this rhythm game uses 100% of your focusing power. It's so intense with ridiculous speed and vibrant colors. Years of Guitar Hero, Rock Band, Osu!, and Project Diva have barely prepared me at all for this challenge. Fantastic game. I think it's helped me with my IRL drumming a bit, haha.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015745796', 'num_games_owned': 770, 'num_reviews': 128, 'playtime_forever': 149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 149, 'last_played': 1640379709}
review:
Played 2 levels of this game and beat both bosses, and while the game looks pretty great, there's some major gripes i have with it.

Firstly, the obstacles don't always feel like they're on rythm. Some sections feel great and let you time your stuff based on the music, but sometimes it'll throw you off and just put stuff there that doesn't really gel with the beat.

Secondly, the music is shit. It's just some beats and clangs, over and over. When i got to the 3rd level (out of like 8) and still heard the same sodding beats and clangs, i just quit.

Get some real music in this game. I wanna play levels to some epic trance or some heavy fucking metal, not 3 chefs banging their kitchen tools together repeatedly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198100649113', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 94, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1683330488}
review:
Not really a rhythm game, more of an arcade reaction game. That being said, it gets fun and satisfying to play after the initial tutorial-like part of the game.

Some of the timings are a little tight and if you hit it slightly late you're out of luck.

Worth buying on sale, I probably would not spend full price on it (19.99 at time of writing)

author: {'steamid': '76561198053168828', 'num_games_owned': 472, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 478, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 456, 'last_played': 1640269541}
review:
In places frustrating.
But still satisfying.

Violent drumming.
Just keep on trying.

My ears are bleeding.
From all repeating.

Fingers keep twitching.
Game is bewitching.

And then the plot twist will come.
To the great evil undone.

Scarab will fly on the track.
[spoiler]Menacingly___________________[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561197987312742', 'num_games_owned': 142, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 127, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 127, 'last_played': 1638595063}
review:
TLDR: it has turned into a puzzle game when i just wanted a rhythm game. 

Man i wish i could have said i recommend this game and i was thinking that with good reviews it would be just good.

But its not what i wanted from the game. I wanted a rhythm game where you always know what to do but just have to build up the skill to do it. This was that up till level 3 hits then they start throwing things that you have to figure out to beat it . BUT the game if it has given tutorial for then i must have completely missed somehow because I HAVE NO CLUE WHAT TO DO?!? i learned the extra hard smash thing you have to do to hit the boss but then they make a satiation where YOU CANT DO THAT and that is the only way to pass the level.

author: {'steamid': '76561198212668601', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 551, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 551, 'last_played': 1638604735}
review:
Thumper is a really neat game for the way it feels as if it's all focused on a single, abstract concept and nothing more, that concept being "catharsis". I also think that this concept plays well into a rhythm game such as this where feedback is already an absolutely integral component, in this case simply making attempts to amp it all up while guiding the player through an abstract hellscape with seemingly no end, setting a really cool aesthetic to go with the gameplay. The whole moniker of a "rhythm violence game" is something that I feel is absolutely spot on in some respects but a bit overstated in others with this however. From a visual perspective, the game does an incredible job at sending a constant barrage of lights and obstacles at the player, with the high speed of the game making it feel even more intense as it almost feels as if you're completely incapable of taking a breather before more stuff gets sent your way. My issue actually comes from the audio side of things, as while the audio feedback from the player's actions are wonderfully bassy and have a ton of weight behind them, the music itself feels a bit off, there's a lot of heavy drums, which I love in music and I think it works well for the vibe that Thumper is going for, but it feels mixed weirdly to the point where it can often feel like background noise rather than the backbone off what you're playing the game on. This leads to the rhythms that the player is following to overcome the obstacles in their way sometimes feel entirely different to the soundtrack, and causes this odd disconnect that made the game feel far less satisfying than it really should have.

While this disconnect definitely makes the game feel far less satisfying than it really should by all rights, it's further compounded by the fact that sometimes it barely feels as if there's a rhythm at all, or if there is, it's too complex to have a tangible enough groove to be conducive to a game like this, especially one that is attempting to be so overwhelmingly intense with each individual interaction, to have these more intricate, difficult to grasp sequences feels directly at odds with the game's vision to the point where it can be distracting, especially in later stages where there are these moments combined with an absolutely ludicrous speed that makes it feel more as if the game took the concept of a "rhythm violence game in hell" and shifted its focus towards extreme difficulty rather than its cathartic, meaty feel. The level design is also pretty hit or miss, as while there are a lot of sections which work well in naturally guiding the player through some intense scenarios, there were so many times where the game felt less like a test of anything other than memorisation due to how quickly it would throw things at you in quick succession and then punish you harshly for failing to react to an unreactable situation.

Despite the numerous complains however, it's less that I even dislike the game, as I truly think that it's often an amazing experience that goes above and beyond to fulfill a singular artistic vision with a lot of effort in having every aspect of its design contribute to this one idea, despite its shortcomings in certain elements of its execution. The game is just a touch too inconsistent for me to truly say I love it despite all of its incredible potential, but it's not enough to say that this is anywhere close to bad either. Play it if you want an intense, visceral experience and can deal with a bit of inconsistency and some brutal difficulty.

7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198058806173', 'num_games_owned': 673, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1078, 'last_played': 1692223540}
review: Beautiful, challenging, and unique rhythm game. The soundtrack is violent and eerie, and is complimented really well by the sound design. Getting in the flow and hitting things perfectly will compliment the music well. The difficulty curve is great, and introduces you to new mechanics/obstacles at a good pace and lets you learn things naturally through trial and error. Some of the more advanced techniques (which arent required to beat the game, just optional if you want to get higher/perfect scores) could use some better explaining, but I eventually found them out naturally through gameplay, and some forum searching. Highly recommend for anyone, even if you're not a fan of rhythm games. Good replayability and extra challenge in the Play+ mode once you finish the main game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055346859', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2947, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2690, 'last_played': 1672209422}
review: Thumper will challenge you in the best possible ways. It is as beautiful as it is humbling. The game is fast-paced and requires intense focus and coordination - in some strange way, I find Thumper to be incredibly meditative. The victories are worth every devastating defeat. I truly love Thumper, but will say it is not for the faint of heart. If you want an easy win, this isn't for you. If you want to be tested, take the red pill and dive in.

author: {'steamid': '76561198165837838', 'num_games_owned': 904, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1635636889}
review:
12 minutes was all I needed to tell this game was garbage. The first two levels are just tutorials in a game that only has something like 7 levels. The style of the game is ripped straight from audiosurf, but has no real mechanics that makes the game enjoyable. The 'music' is just a synth with a backing beat every few seconds. For being a rhythm game, the music is god awful and boring, as well as being unoriginal with the aesthetic. There is no challenge, the game is just supposed to be an "experience", but it's the same type of experience you can get by opening a song in windows music player and turning the audio visualizer on. Not worth the time to play this game, and wouldn't even play it if it were free.

This game doesn't deserve a sequel, follow up, or anything like that. Unironically the worst game I've ever played.

author: {'steamid': '76561198105048184', 'num_games_owned': 111, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 135, 'last_played': 1630783413}
review:
It's a pretty insane game. Both in difficulty and experience. Can be played on a potato, still looks good. Proper audio-set-up or headphones required. Worth the money, 4/5

Pro's:
- Amazing visual and audacial experience
- Great sound design and soundtrack
- Highly optimized
- Small download size (for such a good looking game, props to devs)
- Difficult, but satisfying
- Immersion is top-notch

Con's:
- Not for the faint of heart & stress-inducing.
- Can be scary (if that's not your thing).
- More of a tip: You need a good audio-set for the optimal experience, sound from your laptop won't do. Headphones are ideal.

review:
Where do I start damn.

-Game art style looks amaze
-Rhythm and music is pretty INTENSE AND WOAH
-The game play is both like enjoyment and learning and then passively just MASTERING THE INSANE SPEED SKILLLLLL

Yeah game was fun. Just a couple of tips:

-Xbone control did me favours
-Don't play if you're like dead tired, it's almost like driving drunk but like harmless. You just won't be able to like ride the riiiide
-Also make sure the lighting in your room benefits your eyes cos I played for 4 hours straight then looked to my side and went "Is this my room?"

author: {'steamid': '76561198008898709', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 200, 'last_played': 1630726553}
review:
You know how in amplitude, frequency, ddr, or guitarhero there are those sections where the actions you're performing line up perfectly with the music? And then there are those sections that just don't quite feel right?

Thumper has a lot of that. Sections that just don't feel right.
Like I'll get though a section, even get an S rank and at the end just think "ok? I guess that was right? It didn't really feel right."

So if that sort of thing really bothers you in other games I'd recommend staying away from thumper.

Read on for details about what specifically makes it feel bad.
1. Cues
The game will provide you with visual cues and audio cues, and will respond to your inputs with sounds and graphics.
So as you play what you're doing is being played on top of the cues for the next section.
Because of this you can't really appreciate the music you're making (because the cues to the next section are playing), and you can't really pick out the cues to the next section (because you're making music on top of it.)

2. "extra" inputs
Thumper doesn't have you just 'tap' inputs, it also has you hold and release inputs. 
The problem is with this is that the game doesn't care when you release them, so you end up with extra 'beats' of releasing an input that don't fit with the music you're playing.

3. Delayed beats
All of the mechanics other than the main 'thump' require a combination of multiple inputs, some of which must be preformed pre-emptively. Sometimes I swear I'd hit them at the same time and it'd work, but by and large I found that I had to hit the input early way out of time with the music

4. Tempo skew
When you hold down the 'thump' the camera pulls in making the game seem faster and when you release it pulls out making the game feel slower. But the timing of the inputs doesn't actually change!
Similarly, when you get hit the game drops frames as a part of the effect. During this time your character doesn't feel like it's moving, but again, that doesn't actually affect when you're supposed to hit your inputs.

5. Controls
When you tap the input to hit a beat quickly the bug plays a slow 'coming out of a thump' animation that makes it feel really unresponsive (especially in sections where you need to hit many fast single inputs).
In level 4 the game introduces switching tracks from left to right using the same buttons that are used to hit the corners which makes for a lot of misinputs.
Now both of these issues are things you can master with time, but they both introduce extra release inputs making what you're doing feel even more disconnected from the music.

tl;dr
The rhythms in the game don't usually line up with the music and the audio and visual effects get in the way of the actual gameplay.
Combined with lackluster controls it makes for an experience that just feels bad.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020403888', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 678, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 499, 'last_played': 1699593235}

author: {'steamid': '76561198355336300', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 906, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 523, 'last_played': 1664328496}
review: Definitely a challenging game but still a good one. Presentation is great and the visuals are very unique, as well as the music. The mechanics are solid but there are a few times where the level design gets a tad repetitive. This may also be a problem on my end but there seems to be some sort of bug/feature where in the lane changing sections when I try to change lanes it will, at times, randomly switch back to my previous lane which many times leads to me taking damage or losing flow. It doesn't take away from the game too much but it is a bit annoying. Most certainly worth the purchase though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198328913775', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 242, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 215, 'last_played': 1647285790}
review:
A great game, but a not-so-great rhythm game. While the visuals, the gameplay, the aesthetic, and the soundtrack are all amazing, what one expects from a rhythm game is that the soundtrack more or less guides your actions through... you know... rhythm. Thumper misses pretty hard on this opportunity.

Yes, the soundtrack is on the same tempo as the challenges... most of the time, but the point remains that this game would be just as easy - or just as hard - without the music. Like I said, this is a pretty big missed opportunity for a game that advertises itself as "Rhythm violence".

That all said, I'd still recommend the game for it's unique aesthetics, pretty great gameplay and a soundtrack that really puts you in the mood to smash some lovecraftian horrors (make of "smash" what you will).

author: {'steamid': '76561199043714820', 'num_games_owned': 52, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 705, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 108, 'last_played': 1661147679}

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198053962896', 'num_games_owned': 121, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 495, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 307, 'last_played': 1630793261}
review:
This game will teach you that failure and repetition will eventually lead to success. I have previously perfected the game on Xbox. I put in many hours the first time playing through the game. Thumper will make you frustrated and angry. However, after all the trials and obstacles the individual faces and once they perfect the game, the reward yield leads to an immense amount of feeling accomplished. The game taught me patience too. I do not recommend plaything this game if you are tired or have dry eyes. Probably one of the best rhythm games I have ever played.


Overall this game I would rate 9.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198306008406', 'num_games_owned': 146, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 696, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 503, 'last_played': 1665725631}
review:
This game is not a horror game or anything, despite what some other reviews might imply. But it is a very very intense rhythm game that feels less about getting a song right and more about surviving as you hurtle through space at increasingly uncomfortable speeds.
One thing you might notice is that the levels aren't actually really based on songs, but each level has a bunch of different sections, with each section adding onto what the previous ones set up, or introducing new patterns, and they come together at certain miniboss/boss sections where you're tested on how well you've really internalized those patterns. So this is not your traditional rhythm game, and it's not as much based on precision as it is on survival.
I really recommend this game if you like rhythm games, and especially if you wish it could feel like more than a grade. You still get graded, but I care less about that and more about surviving the level, and that's not a priority I'm able to have in other rhythm games, which usually leads to the point being to perfect each level. This has that perfection element to it, but where in other rhythm games I usually perfect a set of songs before moving on to more, I haven't replayed a level yet and probably won't until I complete every level, because I just don't care about the grades yet.
Things worth noting:
This is an intense game, as in I ended up causing myself to bleed all over my controller (admittedly I had accidentally cut myself earlier, but I still managed to open a cut from several hours ago because I was that into a rhythm game.
The levels get progressively longer. The last level I completed I was stuck on for maybe 3-4 hours. Like I said, they're split into sections with checkpoints, so you can always quit partway through a level and come back. Personally, I don't like that idea, and I'll only do it if I get really desperate. I like to complete levels all at once

author: {'steamid': '76561198044983798', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 639, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 342, 'last_played': 1688840797}
review: I found this game to be fantastic, enjoyed it thoroughly, and look forward to playing it more after clearing it with mediocre scores the first time around. That being said, it's not for everyone, and can definitely be unpleasant if you come in with the wrong expectations, or look for ways to blame it for your losses rather than taking responsibility and trying to do better. It is a rhythmic game, but It's not a rhythm game in the sense that you follow a simple beat or musical score and push buttons in time with the notes. You can memorize most of the levels if you aren't able to make full use of your eyes, ears, sense of rhythm, instincts, or ability to find patterns. As a general rule, the further in you get, the more physically demanding it becomes, and the more important it becomes to not just know what to do, but to practice until you can execute it. There are probably some people who buy this game that physically won't be able to clear it, but for most, their biggest obstacle will be their mindset. If you enjoy being tested by a game, finding the flow in the madness, and putting your full focus into succeeding rather than into finding excuses for why it's the game's fault you're losing, then you're going to have a great time. Alternatively, if you don't feel compelled to complete it and can just enjoy the earlier levels, the visuals, and audio design, I think it's more than worth buying on sale. Accept that your first play through of the game isn't something you'll be able to casually do after a hard day at work, but something that you need to be mentally and physically present for, and I believe you will appreciate this unique, intense, and rewarding experience.
