author: {'steamid': '76561198035100973', 'num_games_owned': 395, 'num_reviews': 766, 'playtime_forever': 59, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 59, 'last_played': 1629909610}
review:
ehhhhh I like the concept and the aesthetic of the visuals and the music, but it gets a bit stale pretty quickly. I got S rank the first 2 levels and made it about halfway through the 3rd before deciding I had enough.

The game feels very stretched out and repetitive.

The visuals are cool but they severely hinder the gameplay at times. 

The syncopation is also cool, but without visual time-grids like in rockband and guitar hero there is no way you can "sight read" the harder sections, and I can imagine it only gets worse later on. So failure and memorization are pretty much to be expected, anyone that says otherwise in a review is delusional or lying.

They "strongly recommend a controller" but for some reason the game doesnt utilize almost any buttons of the controller lmao. You pretty much only use the A button and analog stick as far as i experienced. There is way to much multi purpose functionality for no reason when they could have easily split up the various inputs to the other face buttons, and triggers.

author: {'steamid': '76561199014221641', 'num_games_owned': 251, 'num_reviews': 154, 'playtime_forever': 951, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 402, 'last_played': 1704782171}
review:
I've never had a non-vr game make me feel motion sick‚Ä¶ then comes Thumper. A brutally difficult rhythm game with some of the most abstract visuals and music I have ever seen and heard.

Alright so to start off i‚Äôll just say this game is weird as fuck, your a space beetle going down what seems to be an infinite rollercoaster of death, hitting beats and dodging obstacles at the right time. There's also a giant head that wants very badly to ruin your day. After every level you fight this head, and slowly weaken but anger it to its fullest extent. In between these boss battles you have lots of other gameplay beats that I will be talking about.

It's rather unique for a rhythm game, because in most rhythm games you are doing actions TO the rhythm, but in Thumper it's almost like you make the rhythm itself. When you get into the game for the first time, you'll notice that the music is very non-music-ey. I mean its music but it doesn't seem to have a real beat or rhythm to it. It sets the atmosphere very perfectly but when you start the first level- you realize that you are making the beats. As you pummel down this long road of obstacles, you hit beats and make turns right on time with the music and it creates this harmony of sounds. So what I'm trying to say here, is that this game revolves around its sound design, and I think it does that perfectly.

Visually, I think it goes right along with the sound. It's so bizarre but it really gets the tone and atmosphere that it wants, and it is truly like nothing I've ever played. The background can be scary, it can be bright, it can be dark, but whatever it is, it fits amazingly with everything else. The graphics are stunning as well.

Now for the real gameplay. Like I said, you hit beats and dodge obstacles. But let me elaborate on that. This space beetle that you play is going at tremendous speeds, it may not look like it immediately but by the final level you're going mach 99 up in here. So while going this fast it isn't necessarily any easy task to be hitting beats and dodging obstacles. Thumper does a good job of easing you into new obstacles and gameplay parts without completely overwhelming you. You‚Äôll get the hang of the mechanics fairly fast, just in time for a new mechanic. It can be hard at times but you will learn it and master it. There's the turns where you hold down the spacebar and press A or D depending on the turn, there's the spikes where you hold down the spacebar to block them, there's the walls that you have to fly over, and much much more. I find it extremely fun, but also extremely difficult. All of these actions will have to be executed within milliseconds, sometimes it looks to be even less. So now you're probably wondering what happens when you die, since it'll be happening often.

It's not a big deal.

There's checkpoints pretty dang often, so if you die there's no level restarting or anything big, you'll just have to redo maybe the past one or two minutes. While I'm on that, levels are pretty long. Can be 15-20 minutes at times. You can save and quit in the middle though. Continuing, you have 2 lives. You come in with a big metal shield over your wings that can take one hit, and then there's just you which will die in another hit. Harsh but fair considering you can heal yourself. At every checkpoint there is a beat you can hit that refills your shield, and you can heal mid area by slamming on beats from the air. Again, harsh but generous.

So, to wrap things up, I like Thumper a lot. It was very hard, but addicting and fun. If you are up for the challenge then by all means go for it. It's a fast, exhilarating, nauseating ride. (BTW if you have any type of epilepsy, DO NOT BUY.) But yeah, I will totally play this again, and i didnt even talk about New Game+... 

Would face off against the big head man again.

9/10

review:

Worth mentioning that I am running this on integrated graphics and it still looks stunning. 

TLDR: game good, buy on sale

author: {'steamid': '76561197977610925', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 8335, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3284, 'last_played': 1707802899}
review: I loved the game ever since I have heard its soundtrack and saw the visuals. Thumper is an experience. Thumper is a life style. Thumper is the best rhythm game there is. If you thought you were good at (re)action games, this game will shame you to bits. But if you persevere, you will gradually improve, and not through memorisation, but by improving hand-eye coordination, you will beat the game. I got all S-ranks on all levels, and it feels good. If you want a game that makes you feel good after you conquer yet another level, this is the game for you. Loved it! A visceral experience! Full recommend!

author: {'steamid': '76561198372926237', 'num_games_owned': 295, 'num_reviews': 149, 'playtime_forever': 95, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 95, 'last_played': 1627825364}
review:
How this thing is marketed as a rhythm game is a mystery. The devs mention rhythm hell, and you know what? Yeah, that's about right, because if you have any musical training, this feels just like hell. Fundamentally this has a lot to do with the noise rock they went with, rather awful mixing choices, and wanting to be fancy and not just doing simple signatures like the old boring but tried and tested 4/4. How does this translate to the player? Simply as a quick reaction/muscle memory game. Because of the specific type of music, there's very little recognizable rhythm, and the obstacles don't sync at all with the background distorted drums.

Yes, it does play a music sting about a second before the obstacles appear... that is, for some of them, the turn barriers either don't have a sting or it's drowned out by the background music. For how pretty it looks, it kind of also get old quickly, at least measuring by the first levels, the final boss design is always the same. I really don't get who this is for, and I suspect most of the attention was due to it being different and quirky rather than being a genuinely good rhythm game.

review:
Thumper es un juego de ritmo violento, es ideal para jugarlo con auriculares y volumen al palo.
 Cuando llevas bien el ritmo del mapa que est√©s jugando te sentis literalmente Dios.
La verdad que recomiendo este juego al 100%, excelente banda sonora, se ve bien, jugabilidad buena, super adictivo y una curva de dificultad muy bien desarrollada.
 Lo unico a destacar es que si hubiera un modo de hacer mapas personalizados este juego definitivamente seria un 10/10. Pero mas all√° de eso lo super recomiendo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198398251477', 'num_games_owned': 71, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1265, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1164, 'last_played': 1707547061}

author: {'steamid': '76561198044263028', 'num_games_owned': 1256, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 54, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1625000907}
review:
Don't let my hours here say otherwise, I have played this game to greater lengths on the ps4.

I do, however, have a pressing need to mention here that this game really isn't a "rhythm" game by any stretch. 

Perhaps I was born without rhythm, but specifically talking about the more later stages the game starts to become less of getting into the rhythm of the music (even though there was almost no discernible, repeated beat for your ear to catch onto most of the time, save for some of the parts that actually repeat), and more about simply dodging obstacles hurtling towards your little, chrome beetle at a million miles per hour.

Is the game worse for that fact? Slightly, if you're expecting something in the lanes of Audiosurf or Spin Rhythm XD. I guess if you take the idea of a "rhythm violence" game, Thumper takes it to something akin to listening the music genre "noise" or avant garde when your go to genre is synth pop.

Ok, that's maybe an over-exaggeration, but my main point is that this is a rhythm game in the loosest way possible. It is however still very fun and "violent" with the speeds the later stages reach. The gameplay is also very tight, responsive and the visuals are great and unique. You'll surely be pulled in again and again to get S ranks on all levels, despite the sensory overload sometimes.

Edit:
I just realised the composer is from a noise-rock band, so that explains that. As a plus, I guess the non-linearity of the music helps with noise fatigue since a single stage with no failure/ restart is lengthy, but at the same time my issue of the game not really being rhythmic for the majority of the time is readily apparent.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990496181', 'num_games_owned': 129, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 541, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 305, 'last_played': 1685126416}
review:
Amazing music, the game is challenging, the beetle is oddly very cool to look at and the visuals are absolutely stunning. I'm not a huge fan of watching games but I saw a 10 minute video on youtube (10 minutes of Thumper gameplay: level 4) and rewatched it 5 times before I bought the game. Its an amazing game and highly recommend!! 
PS: I don't think there are many other rhythm games that come close to this, if this game had DLC to this day, I would bet $$ it would be Top 5 in 2021

author: {'steamid': '76561198099110331', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 229, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 229, 'last_played': 1625243063}
review:
Gameplay is alright. Plenty of tense moments and opportunities to get into a good groove.

Levels are inexplicably long. 20+ minutes if played perfectly. Significantly longer if you are struggling. Would have much preferred if they were broken into shorter segments. In the current state, it is impossible to casually pickup and play for 10 minutes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198169824954', 'num_games_owned': 251, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2566, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1074, 'last_played': 1683942421}
review:
El mejor juego de ritmo que jugu√© hasta ahora. No vas a encontrar canciones habituales, ya que el juego trata sobre aprender y seguir los ritmos intrincados que se te vienen encima, acompa√±ados de tambores y sonidos muy tensos, PERO, la m√∫sica le va al pelo con lo tenso que es el juego por su est√©tica y dificultad. 
 Como peque√±a descripci√≥n del juego, somos un escarabajo ¬ø? que avanza constantemente hacia adelante en una pista. Con √©l nos adentramos a un lugar cada vez m√°s terror√≠fico, el cu√°l enseguida captamos que no nos quieren ah√≠. Nos lo van a hacer saber con cada ritmo, jefe y dem√°s sorpresas que tiene el juego para complicarnos el paso a un punto ABRUMADOR (s√≠, hubo niveles que pas√©, pero con la boca abierta).
 Se juega con las flechas y el espacio, y todas las combinaciones que pueden dar esas teclas, cada una tiene una acci√≥n diferente que hay que realizar seg√∫n qu√© veas (o escuches) en la pista.
 Todos los juegos de ritmo se complican, tengan en cuenta eso, pasa que Thumper te pide un nivel de reflejo visual, adem√°s de un buen o√≠do capaz de distinguir distintos sonidos a un volumen bajito (estos sonidos, adem√°s de las cosas que vemos aparecer en la pista, anticipan el ritmo por venir), adem√°s de buena precisi√≥n ¬°Y! estar preparado para escuchar otros ritmos que no sean un 4/4 (Comp√°s que tienen la mayor√≠a de las canciones) porque en el juego exploran casi todos (si no es que todos) los compases habidos y por haber. 
 En base a lo recientemente dicho, puede que el juego no sea para todos. Pero si viniste ac√° por el hecho de que es un juego r√≠tmico, asumo que te interesa el reto que presenta el juego. Por si no entendiste te voy a decir lo que ten√©s: 
 Un apartado visual tan hermoso como escalofriante. M√∫sica de batalla constantemente, con ritmos loqu√≠simos. Una cantidad considerable de acciones y mec√°nicas (de personaje, de escenario y enemigos) para lo que es un juego de ritmo. Y la experiencia √∫nica que brinda la combinaci√≥n de todo. As√≠ que si te interesa el juego, realmente deber√≠as sentir lo que es jugarlo, porque es extremadamente disfrutable y dif√≠cil hasta el √∫ltimo segundo. Y si aceptaste el reto, no te rindas! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198281699975', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 125, 'last_played': 1625676466}

author: {'steamid': '76561198038621609', 'num_games_owned': 70, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 290, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1626782368}
review:
This is the most intense game I've ever played, and it's not even close.

The way difficulty scales from level to level is quite something. I love how you're allowed to choose how difficult you want to make the game for yourself by going for extra style points or just trying to struggle your way to the end of a level. I also love how quickly you can go from trying to chain slams and perfect turns together to the 'oh shit' survival mode (and back again!). Great game and it holds up even now. This experience is a pure adrenaline white-knuckle ride from start to finish, and after the initial few easy levels I found myself unable to play for more than a single level at a time. The ending part is also quite something else.

If I had something to complain about, it was that levels 7. 8 and 9 (not the bit at the end, that part is fine imo) had a few sections that were literally impossible to react to; generally corner walls that don't come into vision until it was too late or when the track crests a hill and there's a button you need to hit just over the top, although the latter isn't as bad since it doesn't do damage to you. Like I said before, the game's difficulty scaling is pretty much perfect and leaves you feeling challenged all the way through (man, going back to level 1 really throws you for a loop), so it feels especially jarring when you do run into one of these 'unfair' segments. Apart from that, I feel as though the controls on the multi-rail sections to be a bit sluggish (on keyboard) and it led to me skipping many of those sections as it was very difficult for me to navigate through those on reaction. Sure, both of these issues can be solved by a little bit of repetition, but I feel that Thumper is at its best when you DON'T know what is coming up and juuuuuust barely hanging on for dear life. Regardless, this is still a hard recommend from me. You may think level 1 is a bit easy, but rest assured it won't remain that way.

The overwhelming rush at the start with the ever increasing intensity of the soundtrack which ultimately  builds up to a sonic BOOM , Is probably one of the most euphoric feelings out there.  Haven't ever had sex , But im pretty sure its a close second when compared to this Monstrosity.

author: {'steamid': '76561198124647841', 'num_games_owned': 1851, 'num_reviews': 132, 'playtime_forever': 1313, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1313, 'last_played': 1624598473}
review:
Probably the best rythm game I played so far. Had to shut down my second monitor and favored night sessions to keep distractions to a minimum while playing it. A lot of work was put into how it feels, and it shows, it feels very brutal and physical. It makes the whole experience very immersive and once you're in the zone, it feels awesome.

It's pretty hard but not THAT much. 20h to S-rank all levels, which is pretty doable as you can repeat each section until you perfect it. That's also the point at which you get all achievements but there are leaderboards and play+ (no death and a bit speedier) mode if that's your thing once you're there, might try it if I ever finish my backlog (probably never ;_;).

author: {'steamid': '76561198126637199', 'num_games_owned': 327, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 912, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 909, 'last_played': 1681247881}
review:
Alright. I've got all the achievements in this game, I think I'm ready to review it.

Thumper has you cruising along one or sometimes several lanes, hitting blue pads, dodging enemies and making turns, all to the beat of the game's soundtrack. And let me tell you, this game is an experience and delivers incredible gameplay.

The graphics are great, it feels like you are drifting through some limbo world and the everything has this surreal tone to it.

The soundtrack is... well, it's maybe not a soundtrack, maybe not even music, but it has rythm. You could maybe call it a rythmic experience. Anyways, it's awesome. Lots of bass and  other tones that help you with timing your gameplay. Speaking of....

The gameplay is the bes part of this game (I guess it should be for a video-game...). But seriously, Thumper gives you some truly unique gameplay. It doesn't hold you hand: It throws you in cold turkey, but you get the hang of it easily. That and there are always certain tricks that the game doesn't tell you (some could really be explained, though). The game also introduces new mecahnics almost every new level, which there a 9 of, each with about 20-30 sublevels.
Thumper is a perfect example for "Easy to learn, hard to master". And let me tell you, one you've really gotten the hang of it, you are immediately sucked into the "Zone", meaning you come into this trance that has you react and play the game on a whole different level, completety escaping reality. Play it yourself if you don't believe me. And coupled with the "rythmic soundtrack", you experience something completely surreal.

The game gives you an New Game + option, so that's cool, and thank god you can go back to the last level you played to get that S grade. I wish there were a steam workshop for player-made levels, though. But it must be hard to implement given the fact that the levels are so awesome to look at.

But of course, there are a few things I didn't like.
When you get hit, the whole screen turns red, but more importantly, debris or something covers up a bit of the screen, making it hard for you to recover. This mean you'll get a worse grade at the end, which is pretty frustrating if you want an S on every level (like me)
The game can sometime also throw thing at you rather quickly, givign you no time to prepare. I know it's supposed to be challenging, but you should give the player a tiny bit of time to know what he's gonna do next. It's still completely managable though if you remember what the level throws at you.
Also, and this is my biggest gripe, is the fact that [spoiler]the last level doesn't tell you your grade. I played through level 9, beat the last boss and didn't see my grade. I thought that would mean that there is no grade, but no! I got an A. Which meant the whole level was given the grade A, snatching an achievement from me. Why? Because fuck me, that's why.[/spoiler]

All in all, Thumper gives you an amazing experience for a good price. There are a few flaws, but those are completely ignorable because you'll still have plenty of fun escaping reality and becoming the Thumper yourself. Buy this game if you want a new gaming experience.

9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198048832095', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 37, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 37, 'last_played': 1623814771}
review:
For a rhythm game it's incredibly un-rhythmic. Sure stuff happens on the beat, but the beats are all over the place. The goosebump-inducing gameplay-audio sync-ups are few and far between, though they do exist.

The visuals are awesome though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198371370682', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1601, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1189, 'last_played': 1703642457}
review:
I have had Thumper sitting in my steam library for longer than 90% of my games. Unfortunately, I only played it sparingly when I first got it, as my setup at the time was less than solid. Finally getting to play through the whole game on a setup that can run it has felt like uncovering a hidden gem, tucked away in plain sight. There isn't a game I own that has had me physically tense, on the edge of my seat, and entirely fixated during game play. Except Thumper. Mesmerizing visuals, on top of air- tight controls, with an invigorating, terrifying, and overall nightmarish soundtrack, all coming together to provide an experience so unique that in itself has defined a new genre of gaming. Rhythm Horror. I can say that it is the type of game to increasingly grab hold of your interests the more hours you have. With better skill, the songs and levels turn into Tony Hawk pro skater style combo fests, pushing you to hit every turn perfect, use the flying + ground pound as often as you can, and perfect the flow of each and every stage the game throws at you. Reaching mastery of Thumper is a test of timing, precision, dexterity, focus, and coordination of the fingers, and it is so worth while that I just had to write a Steam Review. 

Go out and thump some notes, space beetles

review:
I did it.

I finally beat Thumper.

Give this game a shot. I beg you. Its minimalistic art, visuals, and music may not be to everyone's liking, but as someone who greatly enjoys rhythm games, this one is greatly worth a playthrough, even if it's just a single time. I personally loved everything about it, and I find its implementation and use of top-notch rhythm and controls incredible.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035412591', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 393, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 363, 'last_played': 1622689663}
review:
This game is overwhelmingly challenging in a way I didn't expect for a rhythm game.... nothing stays in rhythm. I find myself missing marks a lot because of it. I used to be a musician and know how to keep time, so this kind of killed the game for me. I keep playing it hoping it to be better but I just keep getting met with disappointment. 

Visuals are okay, but I'm totally willing to give it a pass since it's an older game. But the colors are very distracting and make it tough to see markers. Kind of an eyesore, but if you like lots of flashing lights and colors then this'll be your jam.

For me, this game is 30% fun and 70% frustration, just ugh. :(

author: {'steamid': '76561198275204377', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 566, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 199, 'last_played': 1692134812}

author: {'steamid': '76561198090385657', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 986, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 763, 'last_played': 1701119890}
review: I had never had a game grab me by the eye sockets and scream "GET BETTER, FOOL" and actually wanted to until I played THUMPER. No guns, no blood, no fiery explosions, not even a single humanoid and yet it is the most viciously brutal game I have ever touched. And somehow, without a single word of dialogue or any indication of plot, it ends with a twist that no Hollywood director could ever rival.

author: {'steamid': '76561198361821357', 'num_games_owned': 146, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1246, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 968, 'last_played': 1667014544}
review: This game is bloody incredible and I would recommend it to pretty much everyone. This game doesn't have a heap of content in it, and finishing it took me a surprisingly short amount of time considering how hard it is, but there's always play+ and s ranking all of the original levels, both of which things I am in the process of doing right now. If you have any interest in this game, it's definitely worth a look.

author: {'steamid': '76561198284096675', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 233, 'last_played': 1691534153}
review:
This game is one of the best rhythm games I've ever played! Closely followed by "The Crypt of the Necrodancer."
It can be frustrating at times, because of how hard it can be...
But as you master all of the game mechanics it becomes much easier to play, without becoming frustrated that is...XD

The music is flawless, making you feel every part of it, and the game mechanics line up with it perfectly; something that not every rhythm game has, unfortunately.

The Visuals are amazing, beautifully designed to line up with the music that I've so highly praised.

If you have a good sense of rhythm, then I highly recommend this game.
to those who don't, get this game if you want a frustrating way of improving/perfecting it.

Hope this review helps you out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001558786', 'num_games_owned': 2051, 'num_reviews': 193, 'playtime_forever': 957, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 957, 'last_played': 1710797977}
review:
one of my favourite games of all time. i wouldnt go so far as to call it perfect because there is a lot of room for improvement; in everything generally, but here some accessibility settings would not go amiss at all.

theres not much i can add whats already been said but i will posit this for thought: this game is, unintentionally, the closest anyone has ever gotten to mimicking jeff minter/llamasoft's trademark gameplay style and visuals, albeit from completely different angles. its all there, when you think about it really. anyway, cant recommend it enough, goes cheap as chips on sales, you owe it to yourself to play this at least once.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047904352', 'num_games_owned': 413, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 607, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 525, 'last_played': 1644882371}

author: {'steamid': '76561198048668227', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1704, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1612, 'last_played': 1686938037}
review:
Rhythm games are always games of niche appeal by their very nature: They only provide enjoyment through a small handful of the ways that games are capable of. Usually, a rhythm is enjoyable on the basis of their often incredible music, the journey of mastery not unlike that of a musical instrument they promote, and sheer catharsis, but does little for players who want games to provide a narrative, a social experience, deep and complex strategies and mechanics or even immersion and escapism. 

Even within this already niche genre, Thumper takes the risk of alienating even more people because it is very difficult, has an oppressive, surreal atmosphere and all but strips out the music aspect of these games entirely, replacing it with industrial, instrumental tracks with strange, erratic rhythmic patterns. 

However, by making the bold decision to alienate some of its potential audience, Thumper becomes a deeply rewarding journey of mastery, which is made enjoyable by its heart-pounding, adrenaline fuelled tension and deeply satisfying game feel.

Despite Thumper being quite a difficult and sometimes punishing game I think it still succeeds in being accessible because it has a steady progression curve in which levels and sections get gradually more difficult with only Boss encounters to serve as major spikes in difficulty, and I think this is very important. 

Thumper is my favourite rhythm game to date (unless you count Sayonara: Wild Hearts, which I don't). I think it's a simple yet innovative idea that is worthy of your attention and is shockingly engaging. I think many people will enjoy this game more than they anticipate. I can certainly say for myself it's an experience I didn't at all know that I would enjoy even despite being a big fan of rhythm games and music in games in general. 

If you're looking for something different, a cathartic, challenging yet rewarding activity to sink some time into, I suggest giving Thumper a go. It's not for everyone, but it may well be for you and if it is, I think you'll be surprised at how fun it is.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980391455', 'num_games_owned': 619, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 622, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 200, 'last_played': 1619943990}
review:
Completionists need not apply, I am literally sucking the fun out of it by going for S ranks and repeating the same section 20 times in a row.  Probably a pretty enjoyable experience if you don't do that.

EDIT 4/28/21- I'm at like a sideways thumb right now.  By level 3 the call and response kind of cadence is gone and key sound effects start getting buried in the mix.  By level 4 they start introducing more and more mechanics that punish anything less than perfect play, so you're kind of forced towards S rank anyway.  By level 5 it's so fast you can't really blink any more.

I like blinking!

EDIT 4/29//21- Level 7 has reached ludicrous speed, I'm sure 8 and 9 will be even faster.  The patterns actually got easier but it's more interested in obfuscating the track so you can't see what's coming.  Like before, the audio cues aren't giving you much by now (they never told you for example which way to turn when a wall was coming up anyway).  At this point it's a reaction timing game instead of a rhythm game.  I dunno I wish I liked it and it's well made, give it a shot if you still think you'd be into it.

EDIT 4/30/21- The final part of Level 9 doesn't show you your score until after the credits have rolled and you can't restart it, so I get to do the entirety of level 9 over again because I got literally 27 S ranks and 1 B at the very end, so get bent devs this is now a negative review.

EDIT 6/6/22- They have apparently improved checkpoint restarting and the final part of level 9 will show your rank before the credits, but only for replays of it.  It's a step in the right direction absolutely, but it sounds like I would have had the same problem and had to restart level 9 entirely with the one B rank on my first playthrough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029605429', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 32, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 32, 'last_played': 1619459230}
review:
This is basically the dancing minigame from GTA san-andreas 

Very boring. People have talked about existential dread, well yes, but only because I feel like I'm imprisoned by a repetitive game. It's not as challenging or rewarding as playing an instrument IRL. I asked for a refund after beating level 2. There really isn't anything interesting or new about this game and you could probably make a decent clone of it yourself in an afternoon with unity.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083647299', 'num_games_owned': 1441, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 104, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 104, 'last_played': 1619396368}

author: {'steamid': '76561198219496856', 'num_games_owned': 205, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 4196, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2415, 'last_played': 1709931771}
review:
I understand that hearing "rhythm violence" or "rhythm horror" might be a bit concerning or confusing, so I am going to try to explain it. It is incredibly difficult to know what this game means by those things without trying it.

This game has no gore, no jumpscares, no typical horror tropes, no dismemberment, etc. What Thumper does is give you a feeling of tension and sheer adrenaline. Everything builds up to different points and then releases that tension, thus giving you that feeling of "dread" and adrenaline.

I like to compare playing this game to hitting a punching bag that is 10x bigger than you, but sometimes you punch through the punching bag.

Thumper is designed to make you feel small and trapped. You are stuck on a track and never stop moving and you have to prove your worth by surviving. Imagine what it is like to be a mouse seeing a large cat for the first time. That's how I would describe the "horror" aspect of Thumper. Everything is trying to break you, intimidate you, and kill you. The joy comes out of besting those things and again, proving you can survive in this world where everything is a predator.

Thumper is one of few rhythm games that is actually based off of audio rather than visual queues. I wouldn't put it past you to be able to play this game with your eyes closed.

The controls are very simple. You can play with controller or keyboard and mouse with pretty much equal comfort. This game is difficult, but I wouldn't call it a rage game. Rather than saying "I can't" it makes you say "I couldn't" because you get better and have fun with each attempt. I will say it is one of the few games where I have actually wanted to fail so I can get better. Though tons of players drop off each level, as seen by the achievement percents, if you can beat one level, I can guarantee you can beat the next. The difficulty rises gradually, but by the time you get to level 9 (the final level) you won't understand how you had trouble with previous levels. After I beat all of the levels once I never though I would be able to s rank every level, cause only 1% of players have done that. But I realized as soon as I started that s ranking level 1 was really just like playing a theoretical level 10; the difficulty increase was the same.

The Thumper community is also great. There is a discord server for the game, with currently in development custom levels, and just generally fun people who are never going to judge you for how good or bad you are.

I hope this has helped you make a decision on if you want Thumper or not! I personally love this game and think most people who try it would too, so give it a shot! :3

author: {'steamid': '76561198049830218', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2079, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1712, 'last_played': 1668793230}
review: This game is really intense. It's a great rhythm game, totally different from "traditional" rhythm games but really well made. Everything is incredibly polished and when you get a segment just right it feels soooo good. That said, it might not be for everyone, the levels are long and really intense (fast, loud, and increasingly complicated). NOT a relaxing game, but one that will make you feel like a god when you get it just right.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066932625', 'num_games_owned': 487, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 1034, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 881, 'last_played': 1648685250}
review:
The best way to describe THUMPER is that it's a constant adrenaline high, mixed with some acid. Extremely intense gameplay with a fantastic soundtrack and bizarre, dream-like visuals. It's hard to describe it as a nightmare, since...well, you CAN win. But it's like a fever dream almost, where the visuals constantly twist, contort, and defy understanding, while the soundtrack constantly reminds you of the danger that is navigating this twisted world.

Even the brief reprieves where the game allows you to breathe and soak in the visuals are still utterly haunting. The world is constantly twisting, changing, and turning, and the music isn't peaceful, it's more like the eye of the storm, where you can see the rest approaching on the horizon. Enjoy these breaks when they're offered; you will be thrown straight back into the fray.

Still one of the best rhythm games I've played.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024219982', 'num_games_owned': 490, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 15, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1618065494}
review:
You are the space beetle! The galaxy road is long, curvy and shiny! And... that is it; a rhythm game this feels not.

While the game seems simple and straight forward, generous on the difficulty as you can both have a few misses and not fail a level, plus a checkpoint system, as well as to get S ranks with a certain ease for that dopamine shot (Though true enough, I did not push that far into the game), I cannot feel the rhythm in this game.

Perhaps it's because I come from games like Nintendo's Rhythm series (Rhythm Heaven/Paradise, etc), where you can for the most part close your eyes and very clearly follow the game's music and sound cues to ask for your action, while here between the choice music genre, not always clear cues, and certain obstacles that while easy to avoid definitely require a bit more of visual reaction, I just can't feel the rhythm calling out to me. It does help explain why there's a certain leniency towards the timing requirements, but it's to the point that I felt more comfortable trying to use the visual cues than to rely on the sound which half defeats the purpose of a rhythm game.
Now naturally, this might be a matter of taste in music, but this one just didn't suit to me.

I did look at some videos post playing to see if I could expect some changes down the road, but sadly not.

Do admit that the visuals are funky, and I did try the game because it's recommended as part of the "VR Essentials" bundle, but as far as a VR experience it definitely did nothing to awe me, though unsure if that can be down to missing sight from an eye.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970843607', 'num_games_owned': 1129, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 581, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 581, 'last_played': 1617850639}
review:
Beautiful and scary in equal measure, brilliant aesthetics aside the highlight of Thumper is the purity of the mechanics. It's a rhythm game, but they've taken the essence of rhythm games and boiled them down to a fundamental point, then executed what was left - and I do not say this lightly - [i]flawlessly[/i]. 

Thumper is completely unique and while it can get extremely difficult I never once felt it was unfair. The Dark Souls of rhythm games might be an apt description, but really the devs nailed it already when they called it 'rhythm violence.'

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2444802964

It is definitely very stressful, frequently aggravating especially if you're going for S rank, and yet it remains strangely compelling the whole way through.

It's one of those types of games where failure comes often, but each time you get that little bit better. This in turn motivates you to keep going, to try and improve, and when you hit that goal it feels incredible. 
A positive feedback loop fed simultaneously by rage and endorphins, this game does have the tendency to put your brain into a somewhat different state - zen, flow, call it what you want but when you're in that zone you feel like an unstoppable gaming god.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2444711914

Fuck I love video games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198115820587', 'num_games_owned': 3074, 'num_reviews': 351, 'playtime_forever': 1176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1176, 'last_played': 1589978633}
review:
Jeu de rythme psych√©d√©lique.

Oubliez GuitarHero & cie, Thumper n'a pas grand chose √† voir avec les jeux musicaux classiques. Ici la "musique" est en fait une succession de bruits, et le gameplay se limite √† l'essentiel gauche/droite/haut/bas. Pas de couleurs chatoyantes ou de groupies hyst√©riques, dans Thumper tout est sombre, glauque, tentaculaire.

C'est d'ailleurs le gros point faible de Thumper: sa r√©p√©titivit√©. Les boucles de son se ressemblent toutes et sont souvent r√©utilis√©es dans les niveaux. Quelques m√©caniques de gameplay se rajoutent petit √† petit, mais trop peu. Les environnements sont tous identiques, trop peu de diff√©rences entre les diff√©rents mondes.

En dehors de √ßa il en reste un jeu tr√®s addictif, dont le gameplay est simple mais efficace, et avec un contenu tr√®s correct qui devrait contenter ceux qui veulent juste traverser les niveaux tout comme les acharn√©s du scoring.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054081583', 'num_games_owned': 256, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 841, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 759, 'last_played': 1620687569}
review:
i finally beat this game. I think this is genuinely one of the most interesting rhythm games ever made. You arent just pressing buttons to a song playing in the background you are MAKING the song with every correct input making it so much more satisfying. 
The gameplay is focused not so much on getting full combos but on finding the right way to get extra points out of a level like getting perfects or a difficult but rewarding way to combo inputs for extra points.
This is the only rhythm game with true boss battles. An aggressive challenge that will keep repeating as long as you keep failing. You HAVE to get it perfect to damage the boss and its always a unique twist on the theme the level has been about so far.
10/10 ez

author: {'steamid': '76561198069060649', 'num_games_owned': 239, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 216, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 70, 'last_played': 1696102855}
review:
I sat there after level 1 and 2 and thought, "Well this isn't bad, does it get any harder?", I've now learned to regret asking that. This game's soundtrack is amazing, the graphics and art style are magnificent, and the feel of the controls/actions are just fun. I've never been a big fan of bugs but, my lord, I never thought I'd focus so hard, constantly trying my best to anticipate the next rhythm to save a little beetle's life. As an avid rhythm game player for the past decade, this switches the game up on what I thought that genre was, and I can definitely recommend it.

(P.S I've only played this game in VR, and the immersion in the environment and atmosphere makes it much more intense. Seeing the walls and thumpers making their way straight into your face is amazing.)

author: {'steamid': '76561197985265250', 'num_games_owned': 385, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 84, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 84, 'last_played': 1614578083}

author: {'steamid': '76561198397144877', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 848, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 848, 'last_played': 1613777599}
review:
Thumper is a rhythm game about that requires only one button and direction for every input. You play as a beetle going down a track and you have to avoid obstacles and hit every pad on the way to the end of each stage. The game is very fast, especially the further you progress in every level. The game does teach every move required to S rank intuitively, either through on screen prompts or through context clues in the levels. All moves except one that is. While it isn't a move required to beat the level, it is required to S rank and I feel they didn't convey it very well. Regardless, the game was still extremely enjoyable, but it is pretty difficult, however you can retry each level in a stage as many times as you want by pressing the left bumper or R1 whenever you want. I was able to S rank every stage by doing this. After beating a stage (of which there are 9 with varying amounts of levels in them) you unlock "Play +" mode, which is the same as the normal levels but you can't retry stages.

Pros:
*Fast, fluid and fun rhythm gameplay
*Trippy, if you are into that sort of thing
*Fun and challenging Boss battles in the middle and end of each stage
*Difficult, but not overly so
*Good thumping soundtrack
*Would probably be great in VR if I had one

Cons:
*Trippy, if you are not into that sort of thing
*If you want music variety you aren't going to get that here

Overall, I'd give Thumper an 8/10. It was very fun, but a little too short in my opinion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094118449', 'num_games_owned': 180, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 632, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 494, 'last_played': 1709919837}

author: {'steamid': '76561198028952416', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 2013, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1962, 'last_played': 1620320036}
review:
Thumper is truly a work of art. The audio-visual experience is very enticing. It has a unique concept and style that is well executed. The music is very atmospheric and all the sounds in the game are very stimulating and rewarding. They just work flawlessly with the colorful graphics. The tempo rises gradually as you complete levels. Especially the later ones are very fast and require intense focus. This is my experience anyway.

I recommend this game to anyone who wants to experience life as a beautiful space beetle zooming relentlessly across fantastic dark dimensions. Are you the hero or the villain of this world? It doesn't matter. You exist. Free from human thinking, just intensely aware of the track and rhythm and flowing with it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974779606', 'num_games_owned': 423, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 600, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 527, 'last_played': 1699130445}
review:
While brilliant the entire way through, actually finishing thumper has caused me to not want to recommend it. There are mild spoilers ahead, but none of them reveal anything you don't see in level 1. 

The final boss, instead of being a gauntlet of all you'd learned, or even extremely fast as it implies just before the fight, but instead what they do is take away tempo and rhythm - literally entirely. It's a rhythm game and in the final fight, the music sputters and skips around wildly like someone manually speeding and slowing a record with their fat thumbs. This makes it go from an engaging, rhythmic entrancing final showdown to a bafflingly unengaging quick-time event where you are forced to carefully learn where each record skip is so you can pull the trigger in the middle of the insane time-jump forward. 

It's baffling to the point where it spoils the entire game before it. Like if the center of a tootsie roll pop had a cat turd. 

What's really sad is I love Lightning Bolt, the folks who did the music, and while you'd think it would be unsurprising for a noise rocker to abandon tempo for the last gasp and have it randomly swing to completely different BPMs, there is nothing to imply this would happen and it's a lazy choice for a final boss. 

I'd skip this and check out some of the other great music-related VR games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062332801', 'num_games_owned': 4116, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 970, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 771, 'last_played': 1639820871}
review:
Sure, you can beat the game easily by avoiding the scoring mechanics. Just avoid perfect slides, blue circles and ground slams entirely. But by doing that, you are now playing one of the most unsatisfying games ever, you feel like a cheater, why is the game letting you win by avoiding everything? 
  You can only TRULY ENJOY the game if you do it perfectly, and do the scoring mechanics. The only problem is... it's extremely difficult and frustrating. It has some hidden mechanics, like how you can bounce twice in a row on blue tiles to gain more air time, or how you can keep flying through one or multiple slides if you do the perfectly, I learned them, no problem. But putting everything into practice, PERFECTLY, at this ludicrous speed? You'd have to be a madman.

author: {'steamid': '76561198127981358', 'num_games_owned': 274, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 3015, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1214, 'last_played': 1645204037}
review:
[b]TL;DR[/b] Thumper is an incredibly elegantly designed rhythm game with a well balanced difficulty curve and exhilarating high speed gameplay. Don‚Äôt be daunted by the high difficulty, it‚Äôs not a tough as some reviewers are making out.
   
[b]Review:[/b]

Most rhythm games are incredibly simple: press buttons/tap touch screen/flail gyroscopic doodad in time with the music. You are rewarded for hitting the beats precisely, and penalized for sloppy timing. It can be quite a punishing system. Rhythm Paradise for example tasks the player with hitting every single beat in a given level [i]perfectly[/i] in order to get the highest rating.  

Thumper has a reputation for ‚Äòterrifying difficulty‚Äô as one reviewer put it. Yet it‚Äôs the least punishing rhythm game I‚Äôve played. Here‚Äôs why:

In Thumper there are two kinds of obstacles: 
1) Objects that deal damage but barely need to be timed at all.    
2) Objects that require more precise timing but can be missed with no consequences.

As soon as you see a Glowing Red Death Wall on the horizon you can start to turn, even if you‚Äôre several seconds ahead of the beat. Hitting turns with exact timing will give you extra score but you rarely need to do this to earn an S-Rank, let alone beat a level normally. Turning too late will result in swift and explosive obliteration, so it‚Äôs rarely worth risking it for those sweet swag points.

The blue Thump Pads require greater accuracy, but even those have far more lenient timing than say Rhythm Paradise, Elite Beat Agents or Guitar Hero (showing my age with these examples...) Unlike the walls, pads don‚Äôt give you more score for greater accuracy. You either hit em or you don‚Äôt.  

I finished the game, S-Ranked every level, and beat every level on Play+ mode (no checkpoints). While it was very challenging at times it was nowhere near the level of difficulty I was led to expect by reviews (Ikaruga this is not). It did make me wonder if some players were treating it like a normal rhythm game and trying to hit every single beat dead on even when it‚Äôs not necessary to do so. I also wonder how many players are using bluetooth controllers or speakers. The latency introduced by these renders the game basically unplayable as there are no lag calibration options unfortunately.  

I found the difficulty curve to be extremely well balance. During your first play through you‚Äôll just be trying to survive and not worrying too much about hitting every single Thump Pad or Flying Blue Ring. As long as you don‚Äôt crash into a wall you‚Äôre golden. The game slowly introduces new mechanics as you progress, such as the ability to fly long distances by jumping off a thump pad and then hitting perfect turns to increase your airtime. By the time you‚Äôve cleared the final level you‚Äôll have enough tricks up your sleeve to go back to earlier levels and start hitting the harder obstacles necessary to earn an S-Rank. Once you‚Äôve S-Ranked every level you‚Äôll know the layouts well enough to tackle the Play+ mode (no checkpoints). After you‚Äôve cleared level 9 without any checkpoints, S-Ranking level 1 without any checkpoints won‚Äôt seem so daunting. The difficulty slowly builds in this manner so that the next challenge is always tantalizingly within your reach. It‚Äôs structured so well that you won‚Äôt realise how much better you‚Äôve gotten until you go back to an earlier challenge and ace it standing on your head.

Some have criticised the game‚Äôs music for being too simplistic and repetitive. While I definitely won‚Äôt be buying the soundtrack any time soon I think that it perfectly complements the gameplay and visual aesthetic. The simplicity adds to the hypnotic nature of the game, anything more complex and attention grabbing would probably be distracting and diminish the overall effect. 
The visual design it very other-worldly, Thumpers version of hell is more alien than outright scary. Gameplay looks chaotic and hard to follow in trailers but when you‚Äôre actually playing it things are easy enough to follow. Obstacles are signposted well (blue = safe, red = danger) and you‚Äôre shown just enough of the track to be able to look ahead and prepare for what‚Äôs coming. Visual effects are bombastic but rarely distracting and mostly only appear when you go for combos. As you get better at the game the visuals get crazier which ramps up the intensity nicely. 

The most remarkable thing about Thumper is how quickly and consistently it‚Äôs able to hypnotize the player into a flow state. You know when you‚Äôre playing a game like Tetris and you suddenly realise you‚Äôve been racking up an insane high score for 20 minutes straight without even thinking about it? Or to use a real world analogy: when you‚Äôre in your car driving to a familiar destination and you suddenly just arrive and realise that you made the whole journey on autopilot? This is flow state. 

The main thing I want to do with this review is question the game‚Äôs reputation as cruel, gruelling, or brutal (all adjectives I‚Äôve seen reviewers use). Yes it is occasionally frustrating, but to me it was predominantly exhilarating and meditative. Like going down a steep hill on your bike with the wind screaming in your ears.

author: {'steamid': '76561198218375703', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 841, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 804, 'last_played': 1681681260}
review:
My opinion on this game is somewhat mixed but ultimately with a heavy heart I can't say I recommend this game as a rhythm game specifically.

Good things about it: The game is absolutely gorgeous, visually original, the sound effects work well for the setting, and the mechanics (the fact that you're a little bug jumping, sliding and hitting walls) are fun as well. Simply wonderfully unique.

Disappointing things about it: the game doesn't feel good to play, which, when it comes to rhythm games I would say is an absolute must. Rather than a rhythm game but I would call it a reflex check software more than anything. 

Let me explain what I mean by it: to me a good rhythm game is something with music/beat at its core - the sound/"song" should be intuitively driving your actions, the beat indicating what "sequences" or "actions" are coming. And then those "sequences" are getting turned into visual indicators to be hit. But most importantly: you FEEL that an action should be taken, and then when you nail it its satisfying.

When it comes to Thumper there is little to nothing of that sort. I can remember like 1 or perhaps 2 levels that truly feel satisfying as a rhythm game (mostly the early ones, but the further you progress the worse it gets). IMO The game works backwards: first and foremost it supplies you with visual indicators  - you have to heavily rely on your eyes to hit the marks and that's just not how a rhythm game should be. Most of the time hitting the sounds is a complete guesswork, as you strain your eyes to see what is coming at you, and the music, if you could call it that?? is no help at all.  There is a soft metronome in the background, but sadly whatever actions I'm taking seem completely out of sync anyway even if I nail them. Literally watch any of the "boss battles" on youtube and you'll understand what I mean.

So all in all, if you're looking for a rhythm experience where you can get into a "flow" (like OSU, beatsaber, musedash, geometry dash or crypt of the necrodancer or any other respectful rhythm game) this will not be it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967740595', 'num_games_owned': 387, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 196, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 196, 'last_played': 1610456896}
review:
I'm normally someone who enjoys both rhythm games and VR experiences with really over the top visuals and amazing sound tracks, but Thumper left me with mixed feelings. 

The gameplay here is very technical. Most rhythm games give you a few basic mechanics and the rest of the game is all about mastering those basic concepts, but Thumper just kept introducing more and more and more to the point where I felt mentally drained. I had a lot of fun in the first 3 levels or so, but the difficulty and complexity ramps up to such an extreme that my brain just couldn't handle it anymore.

The soundtrack was pretty good in the first hour of play, but it reaaaally starts to become anxiety inducing. I can normally enjoy heavily percussive music, but after playing 3 hours of it I desperately wanted some variation in the music, but it just never changed.

Playing in VR didn't really change the gameplay other than it feeling more immersive and having more appreciation for the scale of the visuals around me. You still need to play with a game pad just like everyone else, so gameplay is unaffected.

To summarize: If you want an intensely challenging, technical, and rhythmically complex game...this game is for you. If you just want to sit back and enjoy the sights and sounds of an abstract environment, with simple mechanics, then this isn't for you.

review: This game is a great advancement of the rhythm game genre. Unique visual style, mechanics, and soundtrack. People who are used to more bare-bones, mechanically focused rhythm games may get frustrated by visual distractions, or the fact that it can be hard to hear the music over the sound effects as you get better and better combos. This game is more about sight reading than memorizing. This game was a lot of fun, and the mechanics and getting large combos are incredibly satisfying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198106636677', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 107, 'last_played': 1610438485}
review: The actions don't really correspond to the beat, making the game purely visual. Because of this, the timing is overly lenient and there is little satisfaction in hitting a note with perfect timing like ddr. To make matters worse, there is no adjustable delay meaning your keyboard click will happen well before the game sound. It's fun, but they completely missed the mark in terms of a rhythm game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198879030546', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 248, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 111, 'last_played': 1674428564}
review:
This is already one of my favorite rhythm games, the way it throws new things at you is so intuitive, it feels natural. 
The kinetic visuals make me want to keep playing and experience the droning soundtrack even further, it's so surreal.

I love this game, I remember playing a demo in a Gamestop and it really stood out to me, I never really forgot about it. For a while I just assumed it was a PSN esclusive, but then one day I was searching the rhythm tag and found it on sale, I bought it immediately, no regrets.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970201230', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 754, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 59, 'last_played': 1672656285}
review:
Thumper VR is an absolute masterpiece. Few, if any, VR experiences have sucked me in as much and given me as much of a rush. The gameplay is both challenging and very gratifying. As such there is nothing missing here.

I love the music (musician myself), as well as the art and visual design, the whole procedural approach to the graphics, it all feels so coherent. No wonder it was made by just two guys. 

Did I mention the music? A unique mix of atonal orchestral soundscapes with industrial rhythms, so hypnotic. And the rhythms of the track make you feel like you're playing it like an instrument at times.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994526477', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 653, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 545, 'last_played': 1647131562}
review:
Well, this was a totally unexpected gem of a game. Extremely challenging - but masterable - levels press the limits of your dexterity and musical cue observation abilities. Introduction of different mechanics is consistent and sometimes overbearingly difficult until you take a step back and examine the way in which you need to approach the problem.

For being just as much a self-reflective game as a general challenge, Thumper gets top score from me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044113235', 'num_games_owned': 679, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 299, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 270, 'last_played': 1669786036}
review:
[i]Thumper[/i] is a fast-paced, trippy runner with a similar music-orientation to Audiosurf and Guitar Hero. You play as a space beetle hurtling forwards in the void, smashing through obstacles and defeating bosses of the unknown.

However, this is absolutely not a rhythm game. "Rhythm violence" is a loose term to say "somewhat music related but will punish non-perfectionists".

[h1]The Pros[/h1]
+ Asthetics are really unique. Not functional at all (addressed in cons), but unique.
+ Controls are simple and easy to execute. One button, one stick. That's it.
+ Really gratifying to pull off a combo, gets the dopamine going.
+ This is a music-oriented game with atmosphere - perhaps the first. The void is an enemy at it hates you, and it is unrelenting. Yet you, little beetle you, take your two points of health and conquer it out of spite.

[h1]The Cons[/h1]
- I haven't been in band since high school, but half of the obstacles don't fall on beats. While this is engaging, I'm not in a groove most of the time since the time signature of the obstacles is constantly changing relative to the background track. If the obstacles are the music, then why make so many of them optional if it derails the song? Why flood the player's ears with negative feedback?
- Half of the obstacles are hard to see (bent walls, snake things, tunnels are death traps), especially if you are playing well. The visuals are great, but they get in the way so, so often. Because of the aforementioned bullet, I'm reliant on visual cues which easily get lost in all the flair.
- Game likes to chastize you for not going for 100%. If you miss something optional it makes sure to make a loud audio cue that gets in the way of the ones that are important. By level 5, the game forces you to git gud by introducing some unwelcome sequences where you have to go for the optional points.
- Health doesn't really work. You only get health back if you get something perfect the first time - or in situations where you don't need it.
- Scoring system didn't seem to work either. Scraped through by the skin of your teeth? C. Missed 3 optional beats and took no damage? C.
- The devs are a bit too avant guarde, so while these issues could be easy to fix it goes against their design philosophy. No settings to turn the derailed background track music off. Can't turn the crazy visuals down. A nightmare for the colorblind.

[h1]The Indecisive[/h1]
‚Ä¢ No tutorial - first 3 levels are really good with how concepts are introduced. Later on I feel like I need practice but the only way to do so is to die over and over. I'm not one to enjoy hitting my head against a wall, but the game made me stubborn, so I kept playing even though it grew increasingly frustrating.
‚Ä¢ The background track doesn't get in the way, which is good. But it does so because it isn't anything special.
‚Ä¢ Every time you beat a level, it plays a really slow tune from The Shining.
‚Ä¢ No idea what the story is. Beetle goes boom boom swish.

Game warrants some criticism since there doesn't seem to be much on the Steam reviews. Is it a good game? Sure. It has a unique presentation and a really cool visual/audio aesthetic I haven't seen before. Is it the second coming of Christ? Absolutely not. It's a memorization-based runner with a steep learning curve and one of the few music-oriented games I've played which is not a relaxing experience. After the first two hours or so, it's a long, unblinking Simon Says sequence that only became more frustrating as I played it.

Again, the beginning of [i]Thumper[/i] is brilliant and it's one of those games that I'd love to show off to my friends. If you like going for S ratings on OSU  give this one a try. But $20 for a 2-hour novelty isn't something most of my friends would shell out.

[b]7.5 / 10[/b]

It's a good game, but I don't recommend it because all of my good memories of it dried up after level 4. Maybe I'm not good enough, but there's no fun way to practice.

author: {'steamid': '76561198134431832', 'num_games_owned': 186, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2247, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2224, 'last_played': 1672114544}
review:
This game is very difficult. But it also has some of the most satisfying gameplay I've ever seen. There's nothing quite like slamming down on a beat, hitting a turn just right, or managing to match the rhythm perfectly. It feels a bit like a sophisticated arcade game, which I like. It also has a hypnotic quality, and tends to put me in a trance when I play it. It can be quite relaxing for me, though it certainly could have a different effect on others.

I will say that I think this game could make some people motion sick. It has made me very dizzy before, to the point that I fell over, but I am prone to vertigo. If you also tend to have vertigo or motion sickness, I recommend playing this game in short bursts. Also, this game is definitely not for people who have photosensitive epilepsy -- the game has flashing lights throughout and I think could easily trigger a seizure.

Another note on gameplay: A controller is recommended to play Thumper but I played up to Level 5 on the keyboard, and it worked fine. I do think a controller makes it much easier though. Hard mode Thumper is playing it with a keyboard.

I'm currently going through the game a second time, trying to get S rank on all of the levels, and I'm having a blast. I've had the game for years at this point, and I continually come back to it. It's one of my absolute favorites. Have fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561198049771922', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 480, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 315, 'last_played': 1612128167}
review: Very visceral, adrenaline-pumping, stylish rush with addictive stop-start gameplay. Like playing Super Meat Boy while being launched into space. Unfortunately, after 30 minutes your eyes start bleeding and the base game offers no way to adjust visual density or audio mix, which is incomprehensible to me in a game like this. Scores at the end of levels are a bit bogus. Thumper might be a fun endurance test for some, but can easily become an inaccessible nuisance for others.

author: {'steamid': '76561198129048202', 'num_games_owned': 141, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 657, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 657, 'last_played': 1609813810}
review:
[h1] This game is hardly a rhythm game. You could almost make a false advertising claim.[/h1]

I used to somewhat like the game but upon recently trying to get S-rank on every level, I grew a hatred for it in an hour. 

There are 9 levels with between ~20 and ~30 stages in them. Some stages will be significantly longer than the stages before and after, for no reason. They will also end up being the most difficult stages in that level and, as previously stated, lasting 3-4x as long as the other stages.

If you still want to buy this, set a timer for 110 minutes before you start playing it so you can refund it if you don't like it. Level 4 is when the game begins to leave the baby level of difficulty. Because of how little content the game has, and how repetitive it can get, $10 or less would be the price I would wait for. 

Pretty good game for being made by only 2 people though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198348128946', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 978, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 749, 'last_played': 1629925574}
review:
Thumper is a rhythm game with little emphasis on music. The rhythm comes from your thumps and clanks, which sounds better with your skill. The game is extremely difficult, but never confusing. The tutorial does a perfect job at teaching you how the game works, and you'll figure out what what to do extremely easily (besides on levels when a new mechanic first appears, being the tutorial on that new mechanic)

Thumper has a heavy emphasis on timing and reaction, as you'll need to do specific inputs in rapid succession to avoid death in levels. This will be most difficult on tunnel stages, as you can't see very far on the rail up ahead. However, the game teaches certain segments of predictable obstacles, so you'll learn patterns in its level design that often get repeated again and again

If you're into games that are difficult but not unfair, or are into more arcade style gameplay, I can't recommend it enough. There are so few negatives if this is up your ally due to how well the game is designed and executed. However, if something that requires quick hand-eye coordination or repeating a level repeatedly (trial and error from death) isn't your thing, this probably won't bode well. If it seems like it's the type of thing you'd like, you probably will. If it isn't, I don't think this will change your mind on these types of games

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561197988085138', 'num_games_owned': 250, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 428, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 428, 'last_played': 1609115442}
review: Thumper brings the rhythmic genre to its maximum expression. It is tense, it is terrifying, it is challenging and rewarding and immersive in a way that I've rarely felt in a game before. I'm not sure if I'll ever be able to play it for longer than 30 minutes straight, but I'm sure I'll keep coming back to it whenever I need some adrenaline pumped into my synapses.

author: {'steamid': '76561198179225899', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 29, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29, 'last_played': 1609022011}
review:
Non-VR Review:
I played this game on PlayStation VR, loved it, and immediately bought it for PC after I saw it was on sale. I knew I was going to give this game a thumbs up... until I started it!

With either keyboard as well as PS4 and Xbox One controllers, I have a random and fluctuating input lag. Sometimes the input responds immediately, sometimes I have to press buttons about a second in advance. The pattern is so random that it's often pure chance to get the timing right when buttons need to be pressed in quick succession. Taking three curves in sequence is practically impossible, as I often have to take the third curve before I even get to the second curve.

I've fiddled around with the controller settings outside of the game, and with the sensitivity setting in the game. None of this made any difference.
My PC easily exceeds the requirements and other games and rhythm
games run without any issues.

In the hopes of eventually finding a solution to the problem, I will not be requesting a refund for the game. However, if the solution is not a simply forgotten check mark somewhere, this review will definitely remain with a thumbs down.

author: {'steamid': '76561198123093481', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 51, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1608996106}
review:
This is a weird game with weird visuals, unlike anything I've played before and impossible to describe to anyone who hasn't played it.  Those are it's good points.  On the downside the gameplay is limited, the difficulty ramps up too quickly for my taste and I'm sure it would have gotten old if I'd continued.

I'm sure there are players who will enjoy this, but not for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198887068967', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 737, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 199, 'last_played': 1647905830}
review: This game is FANTASTIC! It's really interesting visually. The game play is simple and difficult but not in a way that makes you hate the game. Probably my new favorite game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198389497159', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 513, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 244, 'last_played': 1623220948}
review: Thumper is a really intense experience. Like any rhythm game, its gameplay boils down to doing the right input at the right time. I should say that I'm not a huge rhythm game fan (I played a bit of Osu, kinda see the appeal, but didn't invest many hours in). However, Thumper really showcased how satisfying it is to nail a series of difficult input, at lightning speed, to the beat of the music, with some superb audio and visual feedback. The game's psychedelic aesthetic and crunchy sound effect also makes the basic actions less dull (compared to other rhythm games I tried). You are not just clicking buttons, you are steering this beetle thing through an obstacle course at a million miles per hour. As for the music, I'm not sure if I'd listen to it on its own, but it works perfectly here. The combined audio, visual and interactive experience just makes me zone out as if the game is all there is. I can only imagine how good it would be in VR.

author: {'steamid': '76561199109005076', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1311, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 92, 'last_played': 1679619335}
review: Accurate beetle simulator. Every step of the way is a hellscape trying to avoid death and suffering. The rhythm of life is brutal and unforgiving for beetles and other non-human animals. No one deserves this kind of life. Support animal rights. Live vegan.

author: {'steamid': '76561198262383081', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 115, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 115, 'last_played': 1566225768}
review:
After 4 years, this remains one of my all time favorite VR games.

The first time I finished this game was 4 years ago on christmas eve using Playstation VR, so when I noticed it on sale(I already own it) for the 2020 holiday sale, I felt it was a good time to review. 

To those with Playstation VR already, it is ABSOLUTELY WORTH BUYING AGAIN. To anyone with VR, it is a fantastic and challenging game that differs from most VR games/experiences.

NON-VR: I have this game on Xbox One & Windows store, which do not have a VR mode(Steam/Playstation offer both). It still looks really good, and I'm sure most people would argue it's the exact same in non-VR if you're sitting close to your screen in the dark. I find the input lag on my xbox/tv is frustrating, but even on my gaming monitor with freesync on pc with a keyboard, I don't find it nearly as enjoyable in non-VR, although that's not to say it's not good, just not as good as VR. I think it is easier to play in VR, as it requires really strong concentration and quick reflexes, and having any external distractions removed while wearing a helmet allows you to focus entirely on the game.If you haven't played in VR, then you will probably enjoying the flatscreen version more than if you have.

I would LOVE to see a sequel to this one day, a total gem of a game that is as weird as it is awesome
Virtual Reality Score: 11/10!
Standard Version Score: 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198053367648', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 412, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 55, 'last_played': 1704188357}
review:
really makes you feel like a rollercoaster space beetle

Seriously though, I played this on Game Pass (finished about 80-90% of it) and bought it today on the steam Xmas sale just to play it in VR. So far it's freaking sweet! The VR makes the bosses seem huge and ghastly. I don't think I've ever appropriately used 'ghastly' in a sentence before but there you go.

I'm a drummer and I really enjoy the syncopation and weird time signatures. Despite what others might say, everything IS to the beat, and there is usually a clear cue to what's next. It can be hard to wrap your head around but that's part of the weird fun. There's an unusual intensity to this game but strangely enough the VR makes it more zen for me. You get in a real flow...

I probs wouldn't spend full price for it as its a bit of a one-trick pony, but I got it for $6AUD which is an absolute f***ing steal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198822731009', 'num_games_owned': 130, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 282, 'last_played': 1593102190}
review:
5/10

I really wanted to love this game. I heard so many good things about it, so I figured I would give it a try. I got about 75% of the way through, then gave up on completing the game. I was expecting a god-tier soundtrack that I could vibe to, but instead it was "just ok" at best. I only held out for so long because I thought the music would get progressively better as the gameplay got more challenging, but instead all of the music just seemed to blend together and no soundtrack from any single level stands out as something I will remember. The visuals are amazing, I will give it that. Thumper just wasn't the game I thought it was. If you like it, fine, but this just wasn't the game for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198262626587', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 373, 'playtime_forever': 639, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 628, 'last_played': 1688136783}
review:
What is Thumper ?

Im not really into rhythm games at all but Thumper has something special about it, I just couldnt have enough of this amazing feel the game has, the sensation of speed that the game displays, the PERFECT sound design and soundtrack and the fact that the gameplay can be very challenging without feeling cheap, I dont know after a few levels It just clicked for me, I have a crappy reflection system and I normally sucks at games like this but Thumper you get into the flow really easy, I was pulling tricks I never imagined I could,  once the game grabs you then its hard to stop playing, its very addictive and the whole experience fills you with awe, its a very trippy game too visual-wise so the combinations of its feature just make it a very unique game and because of that I see no reason to not recommend it
