author: {'steamid': '76561198125492734', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1216, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 625, 'last_played': 1640914515}
review: Im bad with timing so rhythm games have never really been my thing, but Thumper's tutorial system taught me all the mechanics quickly and all without using a single word. The controls are simple, and easy to pick up but have an incredibly high skill ceiling. Even when i lose multiple times in the face of a hard boss, i dont find myself getting frustrated and leaving the game. Time and time again ill throw myself at that level and when you finally beat it, the game makes you feel like you deserve it. One of the most satisfying, challenging, and addicting games ive ever played. Definitely worth the buy

author: {'steamid': '76561198269164731', 'num_games_owned': 151, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 603, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 192, 'last_played': 1696128178}

author: {'steamid': '76561198046601290', 'num_games_owned': 542, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 347, 'last_played': 1677947725}
review:
I really wanted to love Thumper. There's no denying it's a very imaginative game, from the music to the concept. In fact, when the special effects get out of the way and the tracks let you thump to the actual rhythm, it can be bliss. But unfortunately that happens only occasionally and developer choices keep the game from being great and make it artificially frustrating.

One example is the changing lanes mechanic. According to the developer, whom I contacted, the game is meant to be played using just one joystick and one button. However, both drifting (which locks you into a lane) and switching lanes use the same left and right directions on the joystick. They have fundamentally opposite functions and conflict with each other in a game about high precision. A simple way of avoiding the issue while keeping the game's difficulty is to map the switching lanes to different buttons (such as the shoulder buttons) but the developers told me that it goes against their "philosophy" of button restrictions, and do not intend to implement button remapping. I guess developing a Metacritic userscore 7.3 game is also your "philosophy"?

Later on, the "challenge" comes not from more complex beats that one must feel and hit to score higher, but from memorizing and brute forcing your way through a track that's a mess of crazy distracting visual and sound effects that prevent you from seeing and feeling what's coming. Progression becomes less about rhythm as the game goes on. One level's mechanic, I kid you not, is to make sure you lose a life for not hitting a note, which previously would have only lowered your score. Mind you, some of these notes are not at all part of the music, not even a syncopated beat so you literally have to eyeball it. And this is barely halfway into the game.

All of this is artificial difficulty, purposefully lowering quality of life. Players will hit a difficulty wall and may fail to progress. That's when the game failed to stay fun or interesting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040757002', 'num_games_owned': 897, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 15, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1604722550}
review:
Right so this game is great. The visuals are great, I listened to the soundtrack first which is what brought me to look up and buy this game. If you like rhythm games, this game is EXCELLENT. So much in this game is absolutely insane- you're a beetle fighting ??? shapes??? Weird space beings?? Eldritch gods????
That said.
I am bad at rhythm games.
And the ominous and punishing nature of this game gave me a shitton of anxiety.
[u]This is a great game[/u] and I'm glad I bought it to support the devs and I hope they are making more games!!.. but I wont be playing any more of it.
if you have anxiety and aren't sure about rhythm games, maybe this isn't for you? maybe it still is? I don't know, I'm not your dad

review: This is the best rhythm game I've ever played. Well over a hundred hours sunk into the nine levels this game has to offer (level seven is the best one by the way), and I feel like I still have hundreds of hours left to go. I'm ready to jump into an alternate timeline where Drool publishes an official level eleven.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070689418', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 46, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 36, 'last_played': 1612654276}

author: {'steamid': '76561198801672165', 'num_games_owned': 26, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2776, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2061, 'last_played': 1707805723}
review:
I love this game.

The pictures steam provides don't do it justice.  Thumper is a beautiful game with an amazing soundtrack that gets you fully enveloped in the gameplay for hours at a time.  The controls are smooth, the audio matches the visuals, and the game doesn't have any lag that I've encountered.

While I haven't played many rhythm games, this is by far the best I've experienced, and I highly recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198126975019', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 754, 'playtime_forever': 163, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 163, 'last_played': 1600043799}
review:
A brutal, brutal experience.

This, at its core, is a rhythm game, it is a game of avoiding obstacles, gliding through rails, and flying as a bug of sorts.

You complete a series of sets through a track and then you regain a hit point if you need it.

Is fast, frantic, tense, fast paced, and empowering.

But it is also an extremely challenging experience.

For me personally it was a very difficult game, I couldn't go through with it, it was stressing me out too much.

But I can appreciate it, I do believe it's a good game, I also believe it could've/should've gotten some improvements, maybe some variation in the track's scenery, or a closer explanation of some of the game mechanics.

Like the game never tells you that if you nail a couple of perfect jumps you can also regain a hit point.

Overall it is a good game however, just not for me, too stressful really, goes beyond it being a hard game, it is a violent game, not because gore or anything like that, it isn't a gory or explicit game in that sense.

But it is a violent game because it's loud, and frantic, and as an end result, too much for me at times.

As of right now I'm nauseous after playing it for an hour or so.

review:
Thumper is a stupendous achievement of a rhythm game.

And then you put the VR headset on and multiply all of that by itself three times. Spectacular.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055980036', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 3028, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1284, 'last_played': 1632940777}
review:
thumper in its form is a hyper-reactionary rhythm game, something that i've never played before and it is totally up my alley as an experienced rhythm player. i've completed all s rank campaign within 21 hours, and will look forward to play+. but as much as i love the game, there are a few flaws that heavily detrimental towards my own experience, which may trouble you if you want to get into the game.

---------

the biggest issue that spawns a several problems is how the game heavily relies on the visual effects that hinders gameplay, giving a sense of complete unfairness of what i think should not be in a rhythm game. 

1: as you get hit, a massive red burst will block everything in your screen for a brief second. after that time-frame of recovery and getting that second chance, there's a high percentage of where i die quickly without the information i could've gathered during that time. 

2: the color of the notes can sometimes blend in the game environment, giving a cheap sneak attack.

3: and to add from #2, claustrophobic areas such as small tunnels and a specific boss  that is up your face will throw notes that is beyond the reaction i can do. therefore i have to rely on memorization rather than going with the reactionary flow.

4: to combat the game's camoflage notes and claustrophobic areas, there are sound cues and small visual cues to aid the player. i'm not against this idea, but it needs to be more clear and well developed. the sound cues most of the time will drown within the music. this makes it hard to discern between what is the sound cue or not. (also, the sound cues somewhere at level 3 is off-beat).

to sum up all of my feelings of this unfairness: i would rather happily use the restart function on a level due to my trash reaction plays than memorizing those tricky notes that ruins my flow that i have no information beforehand.

---------

despite these annoying flaws, i can see myself playing this game from time to time and at least have fun from it. the long levels has to be my favorite part since it tested both my endurance and reactionary skills. boss battles is not that great since it is pretty slow paced (except the last boss battle, since it tries to be different). but to recommend it to other players is pretty much a mixed bag of what they truly seek out of the game. if you want a hardcore rhythm game, by all means get it. though keep in mind of the flaws i mentioned, which may infuriate you that this could have been your rhythm game.

----------

edit: also from the review, it is my opinion based on those 21 hours. as i play more, it may change. for example: the thing where i have to memorize those fast moving notes is actually a good thing, and the gameplay changes so much when you try climbing up the leaderboards.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977904226', 'num_games_owned': 1151, 'num_reviews': 161, 'playtime_forever': 244, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 244, 'last_played': 1589072455}
review:
This rhythm game delivers some freshness to the genre. Thumper is laid on a simplistic gameplay core, making you time the twitchy manuevres over obstacles and for highest possible score at each level segment. The movements require quick reflexes and learning through trial-and-error at times but isn't too punishing, thanks to the check points and rechargable armor. 

The visuals are mainly dark, neon schemes with hell-like surrealism, mainly highlighted in the boss designs. The music you're playing to have a set rhythm defined by the orchestral timpani and synth overtones. It changes between levels but the great thing is that it unfolds new layers, reflected by your chain performance. 

Eventually, I got to try the VR mode on Thumper and find the immersion at its best, although latency optimization is a must for optimal experience. Neat work!

author: {'steamid': '76561198039652258', 'num_games_owned': 639, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 788, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 608, 'last_played': 1706572914}
review:
Absolutely love the game.

It's a perfect chill out game, especially for trained musicians. I've played music for my whole life and have both perfect pitch and perfect tempo, but my partner has zero musical ability (and is seriously tone deaf) and he has no issues playing this game either. We both love it.

I've got it on every system, even mobile, because I love it and want to support it. My favourite system is playing it on my PC on a Vive Pro headset.

For those wondering, there's no real lore about it. You are the "unnamed beetle" and the angry, progressively ugly skull you fight is named "crackhead". That's all I know.

review: This is easily the worst rhythm game I've ever played. Pointless, annoying visuals that add nothing to the experience and the "music", if you could stretch far enough to call it that, is non-existent. Compared to Guitar Hero, Parappa the Rapper and Gitaroo Man this is absolute trash. I was getting S ranks but there is zero enjoyment in it. Honestly I can't believe there are so many positive reviews for this. Instant refund.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034621399', 'num_games_owned': 529, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 10436, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3615, 'last_played': 1709711553}
review:
Thumper got me through the pandemic. 

Seriously. When nothing else could hold my attention for long and I felt my mental energy declining, Thumper was there. It was the equivalent of meditation for my anxiety-wracked, ADHD riddled brain, forcing me to get out of my head and be in the moment. It got me through horrible panic attacks, long nights of depression, it was there through multiple moves that were less than voluntary. The fast paced nightmare cacophany of New Game+ forced me to be present in my mind and not lost in a constant maelstrom of doomerism when everything in the world around me made no sense.

It's an extraordinary game and I cannot recommend it enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027353268', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 7, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7, 'last_played': 1594434288}
review: I guess this game is a testament to how far VR has come since it came out - nearly 4 years later, there are just far better rhythm game choices that make better use of the VR medium than this does. VR doesn't seem to add useful or interesting to this game - everything is controlled using the thumbsticks and buttons. Other VR rhythm games have you moving around and interacting with 3d space, but for this one I was just standing in the middle of my room stationary wondering when it would get interesting. If I didn't get this game as part of a bundle, I would refund it and spend the $20 on one of the many options instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198143347796', 'num_games_owned': 1114, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 186, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 186, 'last_played': 1596667953}
review:
Thumper is an on-rails rhythm game where you guide a beetle through countless obstacles in a psychedelic mess of unusual imagery. Visually, it's incredibly striking and the feedback has a phenomenal catharsis as every move has weight behind it. The music is this exhilarating blend of dark electronic music, ambience, and massive drums and feels extremely epic. Additionally, the obstacles do seem to line up with the tempo. Being someone with an appreciation of rhythm games, I truly wanted to love this title. Unfortunately, Thumper fails as a rhythm game due to sound design and speed.

The key issue with Thumper's design is that you're often unable to pick out the sound cues that indicate the upcoming obstacles as the mix leaves them buried. This often results in a reliance on laser-fast reflexes to survive. Often, you end up dying since you struggle to anticipate the upcoming traps and thus, lean more on memory to clear the segments.  There's no audio slider for just the sound cues, so you can't modify the mix at all to emphasize certain elements. Additionally, being someone with hearing issues when in loud settings, it became impossible at moments to even hear the cues as the soundscape was a haze of noise.

Moreover, if you slip-up and get hurt, the game keeps going with barely a moment to pause, so good luck getting back into the rhythm when the game is barrelling at absurd speeds. I found I often couldn't nail the timing perfectly so I would just die soon after to another hazard.

I also have to say that this game is perfect for a workshop to allow people to design their own custom levels with their music so it's a shame that no integration exists.

The ideas and core of an amazing game are present but they're heavily harmed by awful design with the audio that creates an almost impossible task of preparing for obstacles, making this game more of a visual, than an auditory experience, which is a major failure of a rhythm game, to say the least.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030199086', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 771, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 730, 'last_played': 1707315732}
review:
It's not your typical rhythm game in the sense that the music is the main focus.
I mean it does have "music" but Thumper plays out more like an action game, with each level having an end boss stage.
It's definitely not an easy game, but it's extremely satisfying to beat and really easy to keep trying.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996957748', 'num_games_owned': 326, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 763, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 487, 'last_played': 1638166731}
review:
Very simple mechanics, yet such fun game.
Amazing atmosphere and sometimes very challenging bosses (mini bosses are sometimes harder than final bosses I think).
They recommend controller, but playing with keyboard was more precise for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049402514', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 284, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2, 'playtime_at_review': 281, 'last_played': 1711669574}
review:
Thumper... Thumper... 

Thumper is an interessting game. In Thumper. You take the control of a metallic beetle... of a sort... in this weird, interessting spin on a rhythm game. It's not really music you're playing in sync with, but more of a beat. A heavy, dark, eerie beat in this trippy psychedelic world... like you're the kick drum of the music, I guess?

just like other rhythm games, you're on a straight line and have to time your moves to different obstacles, like flying over spikes, drifting during turns, jumping on... light? etc. I also realized the time signature is also the same as the level numbers, like 4/4 = level 4-4, 1/2 in level 1-2 and so on.

There's also bossfights, that you can only really damage by first going through the obstacles and then hit the final light. If you get hit, you'll lose some of your shell, and can only regain them back through a checkpoint or hitting one of those glowing lights.

Like I said, the music is basically just the rhythm, no melodies or something, like in Theaterythm, Parappa or even Rhythm Heaven.


One thing to take note of: This game can get brutal! It can get fast-paced! you really need to focus if you wanna get through some of the later levels.

There's probably more to be said, but I haven't managed to get as far, however, the times I did play it, I had fun with it :3 If you're into rhythm games, and high difficulty, you should concider checking this game out


7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197981180543', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 211, 'playtime_forever': 403, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 403, 'last_played': 1594703938}
review:
Like some others have indicated, I found the rhythm portion of this game to be lacking. Sometimes it's spot on, and when it is, it's extremely satisfying. Other times I felt like I was playing poorly because I was trying to follow what I believed was the rhythm. I adapted and the game really becomes more about visual queues, memorizing, and timing.

It's quite accessible up until the last set of levels, where the speed gets faster and faster, and whatever semblance of a rhythm game remained deteriorates into almost non-existence (quite intentionally I believe). I found myself wanting to give up twice, but I powered through and beat the game. I'm definitely glad I did.

Some issues. I think certain parts of the game that were not intended to be distracting were. When you take damage, there are visuals and a weird time distortion effect that make an already fast-paced and chaotic game worse. It makes it hard to recuperate, which is already hard enough in a rhythm game. As the game progressed, I found the normal visual effects and ambiance made it harder and harder to play, and though I know that it was intentional, it became almost a deal breaker towards the end.

Despite all of that, I found this game to be mostly enjoyable. It's not a total thumbs up, but worth playing.  At it's base price of $20 over six hours of gameplay, I'd say that's worth it. But if you can catch it even on a small sale, I'd pick it up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000020729', 'num_games_owned': 779, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 980, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 949, 'last_played': 1648563157}

author: {'steamid': '76561198015796854', 'num_games_owned': 195, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 654, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 654, 'last_played': 1594623684}
review:
Thumper is a "rhythm violence" game that's part Audiosurf, part Guitar Hero, part Lovecraftian horror death race, and part psychedelic acid rave where you drive a metal beetle into the depths of a nightmare.

If any part of that sounds appealing to you, you should play it. The controls are extremely tight by design, the audio presentation as a part of the game mechanics is fantastic, and of course, the music is a heart-pounding thrill ride.

Your twitch reflexes and rhythm awareness WILL be tested, and the game gets insanely hard at some points (I don't know how people are able to S-rank the whole game), but the whole experience is a unique take on the rhythm game genre that will have you fist pumping in satisfaction once you're able to take down the game's hardest demons.

review:
My hand hurts like hell after completing it but the game was pretty amazing. If you can endure some extreme difficulty and are good at memorizing patterns this wont let you down.

Would not say it's a rhythm game on itself but more like "musically oriented" game, you will get on a groove sometimes and the pattern themselves do have a rhythm, but you can't really rely on the music to help you or guide you, reflexes and memory are everything.

Sonic the hedgehog can't match this speed.

Now if you excuse me im gonna throw up, don't drink and thump.

author: {'steamid': '76561198999152106', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 697, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 675, 'last_played': 1649566464}
review:
You would imagine that as the game gets further along, it would get more fun. Instead, it just gets more and more annoying and the challenges just become unbearable. There are sections that are like 20% too fast, and when you go around a corner going like 150 mph, you're expected to hit a specific series of stuff that is impossible to know is there there unless you restart from a checkpoint and anticipate which specific corner it's behind. It's just artificial difficulty that serves no purpose other than to be a pain.

The visuals/music/premise is cool, but the developers checked every box except making the game actually fun. I wouldn't say it's a "bad" game, but it's a game I would definitely categorize as "frustrating" and "not enjoyable", so take that as you will.

Boo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004298803', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1716, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1710, 'last_played': 1598575559}
review:
I was going to give this game a good review until the very end of the game, when the game stop being a rhythm-based game and becomes a complete mess.

Overall, this game excels in one category only: visuals. It's a tripply-looking game with as unique a concept as you can imagine.

As far the "rhythm-based" part of the game, I'd say the game stop being innovative after level 4 (and there are 9 levels total). Level 4 is where you can finally hear what sounds like a coherent beat or rhythm. And it's fun.

But after level 4, the game devolves. It doesn't introduce any new interesting concepts and ultimately becomes a flat experience, with no discernable rhythms or patterns. It becomes a mess.

But what really broke me was the final level. I played this dumb game all the way through to earn the achievements. I earned an "S" rating on every sub-level of Level 9... until the very last passage where I earned an "A". At the end of the game, it *literally* stops being a rhythm game and becomes completely random. Despite having an "S" on every sub-level except one, my overall rating was an "A".

Uninstalled. Won't play again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198166398612', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1702119798}
review:

author: {'steamid': '76561197980515927', 'num_games_owned': 294, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 223, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 115, 'last_played': 1593269736}
review:
EDIT: I tried keyboard controls instead (ignoring the advice on the store page of "Notice: A traditional controller is strongly recommended to play Thumper.") and things are slightly better, but all my criticisms stand, aside from stick actions feeling imprecise.

A game that's almost good, but unfortunately ruins itself with a few core mechanics.

The worst of which are the turns, which are some of the most common obstacles. In principle the game wants you to nail the rhythm of the song, but the timing of the turns does not have a sharply defined start. To perfect turn you have to start turning at the start of the turn block, but this is much more of a guess compared to the obvious timing of the A button blocks for example. On the other hand to turn safely you need to turn earlier than the turn block, which means pressing buttons and moving the stick out of time with the song, throwing off your rhythm and timing.

To make this worse, the turns obscure what the next obstacles are, which is a big problem when you have turns in short succession. To make this worse again, the red stripe that visually indicates a turn often gets lost in backgrounds which are also red, as well as the screen turning red when you take damage (often from a preceding turn). To make it even worse, the audio cue for a turn is a clap which a) isn't high enough in the audio mix to be obvious and b) is a sound that most people will be used to hearing in the background of songs anyway.

All of this means that one of the most common obstacles in the game becomes guesswork that makes it harder to read ahead to see other obstacles coming up. The result of which means that the most nervous I was playing the game was seeing a lone turn coming up in the distance.

Add to this: 1. visually distorting the level when you take damage, meaning that you'll probably immediately take a second hit in areas with a lot of obstacles because you can't see what's coming next, 2. pausing the music for a moment when you succeed at some obstacles, meaning that your rhythm is thrown off, 3. having obstacles which each require you to hold the stick in different directions (turns and jumps) very close to each other, making the stick movement feel uncertain and imprecise, 4. some rhythms being very offbeat but not having clear enough audio cues to read the timing ahead of time, and as a result the good parts of this game get buried under frustration and things that spoil the flow you feel once you get into the rhythm.

There are definitely good points. The design of a lot of the visuals is very cool and often unsettling, the intensity you feel when you do get into the rhythms of the obstacles, the way it mixes previous obstacles with a new obstacle or action into a new level , are all good and enjoyable, and it can be very satisfying, but unfortunately the balance of fun and frustration tips too far to frustration.

The giant head final boss of each level also looks super goofy compared to all the rest of the designs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198112703611', 'num_games_owned': 204, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 847, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 704, 'last_played': 1596802493}
review:
This is the hardest game I've every played, that i then also finished. It requires you to play in ways I've never played any game and the game mechanics are perfectly designed to teach you this way. The music is awesome and fits the gameplay as it should.
I love this game. I absolutely recommend it to anyone, who's willing to put the time in to learn how to play this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198092197846', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 8177, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7367, 'last_played': 1710477520}
review:
Yes. Absolutely yes. Thank you Marc and Brian for this true masterpiece.

The first thing I want to address is one of the only things that I think brought on a lot of the negative reviews: The rhythms. Are weird. They're often spaced out and syncopated, 3 of the levels (one third of the game) are in asymmetric time, and they're just generally unexpected and complicated. This is NOT a groovy walk in the park. But it isn't supposed to be! It's meant to be a hellish, masochistic, surreal journey. As such, the beats are alien and freaky and weird! It all contributes to this really powerful feeling of kinda losing your hecking mind that the game creates. But there is a rhyme and reason to it all; the rhythms are still consistent, manageable, far from haphazardly placed, and align with the beats... contrary to what I've read in some of the negative reviews. You really think the bassist of Lightning Bolt is going to make a rhythm game with rhythms that don't line up with the music? fr? Excuse me for any hostility, I don't intend it, I do respect the [strike]misconceptions[/strike] opinions of people who didn't enjoy their experience, I just really love this game and reading negative reviews stirs up some... passion. in me. I mean, it's worth noting that there's a chance the rhythms are just too weird for you to enjoy the game. That's a real thing. It does get pretty dang odd sometimes. Unfortunately, though, there's really no way of knowing until you play it. I've always been fascinated by interesting rhythms and have spent some time learning about them, but I really don't think you need that background to get through the game and enjoy it. I think there's a much better chance -- if you stick with it and focus through the more challenging passages -- that you'll be able master the rhythms and love every second of doing so. This is probably the biggest barrier to entry. If you can get past this, the game is straight up outstanding. (To be clear, I also think these rhythms are part of what makes the game outstanding, but it just might be a difficult part to digest for some)

Also, don't expect this to be like Audiosurf where you can input your own music. That's not the point of Thumper; it's got a really fantastic soundtrack which together with the gameplay and visuals create a stunning and cohesive audio-visual experience. If you want a rhythm game you can customize with your own music, look elsewhere. There's plenty of games that advertise this and really are more fit to do so.

Okay, now that the negative review discussion is out of the way, I'd like to talk about why I love this game. The main thing I find so special about Thumper is the surrealism. The only recognizable things that one can draw connections to the real world through are the beetle and [spoiler]crakhed[/spoiler] (the protagonist and the antagonist) Everything else, the world they both exist in (and the world you can exist in, too, for only 19.99!), is as far from meatspace as one could possibly get. It's a twisting, cerebral maze through the fever dream of a fever dream. It takes everything we've known throughout our time on this Earth and throws it out to create something entirely new. And it's intensity will pull you in so that you, too, for the moments you spend playing it, will forget all the familiarities of the human experience. Until it's just you, the beetle, and the roaring infinite chasm in which you and her pierce through the thumps, the banks, the bars, the tentacles, the tunnels, and whatever other mind-bending shapes approach you from the darkness.

All the while, the gameplay remains utterly smooth and thoroughly engaging! The seemingly simple and few movement options you're initially introduced to quickly coalesce into a perfect and magical instrument. An instrument that must remain intimately entangled with the beat of the eternal hum behind you and the bend of the perpetual rail ahead of you if the beetle is not to lose her shell.

This perfect instrument is made up not only of the controls and the obstacles, but the environment's responses to your actions. By that I mean Thumper is really great at letting you know you're doing well even if you're not looking at the score. There's these wonderful light and sound cues, like the tiny blue gems that explode from things that give you points and hover around you for a moment, or the glow of the bonus thump and the little blue cue with a ding when you light it up, or the raising pitch of the rods and rings as you break them in a streak. It's this attention to subtleties that make the gameplay so cohesive, and by extension make the experience so engaging and hypnotizing. I mean, subtle cues like these are the kinds of things that have been a focus for video game developers for decades, so it's not exactly new, but this paragraph is more just a nod to the amazing craftsmanship on display from just two guys making their first game. It's really incredible work.

So now we have a perfect set of controls, obstacles, and interactions to have a really great time, but what about the macro? The long term? Did Drool turn this gameplay into a full game with stages and levels and an arc? That lasts quite a while and has replay value and a fucking fantastic difficulty curve? Yes. They 100% did. Each level thoroughly challenges what you've learned so far just to the edge of not being so hard you'll want to quit, and it maintains this curve over the course of 9 long levels, (each in the respective time signature of their name) until you're tearing through rhythmic labyrinths like Brian Gibson himself at a Lightning Bolt concert. Except as a beetle. On an unending track in an otherworldly hellscape. And each level introduces new visuals just as insane as the last, so those definitely won't leave you bored either. And once you're done, you can play it again to get S grades, or beat high scores, then you can try Plus mode, and beat those scores. I've got 120 hours in doing these things, which is well worth the price. I would probably spend 20$ to play through this just once if I had to. (Maybe not, I did buy the whole game, replayability and all, on sale for 10$... still, I think it's well worth the $20)

So yeah, Thump away in the vastness of this void! If it's not clear I love this game so much it's a masterpiece please give it a try if you can afford it thank god for Thumper and peace out

(extra note: You can totally ignore the controller rec. I have thoroughly enjoyed the whole thing through a keyboard)

TL;DR: fuck yeah.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998282606', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 1753, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1547, 'last_played': 1693830513}
review: This game is like a drug. It pummelled me into submission, into a trance-like state of mind where trying to consciously think my way through a level immediately led to mistakes - and I just couldn't get enough of it. You don't finish a level, you CONQUER it. With each level built around a different time signature there's a system to the chaos too, giving just enough of a mindfuck rhythmic framework to provide context for the audiovisual assault. I adore this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198099740607', 'num_games_owned': 787, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 59, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 59, 'last_played': 1573796218}
review:
Fun game, but lost me at 3-1 when a mechanic that has never been explained appeared.
Visual clue is not enough and barely any text explanations to mechanics, for example the arc that you can bump into when you take off, the take off mechanic, how it considers a turn a perfect one, lots of things boggled me.
Stiff control sometimes and makes you wonder how all the two-button-moves can be shrink down to one like every other rhythm game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010841661', 'num_games_owned': 520, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 455, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 244, 'last_played': 1670616979}
review:
Got this game on the Switch first, now getting it on PC for VR capabilities down the line. 

Still one of the most mesmerizing and unique rhythm games out there, probably best that it describes itself as something different. The abstract, ethereal visuals combined with the haunting soundtrack with lots of percussion make this an experience to play. I often feel myself getting sucked into the rhythm, trying to perfect my score.

Give this one a try if you're into rhythm games, but don't expect it to be like Beatsaber or Audiosurf, it's completely unique.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993394580', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1657, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1657, 'last_played': 1590248412}
review:
This game might not be for everyone, but then again I never thought I'd enjoy a "rhythm" game as much as I did enjoy Thumper. It's quite addictive, and so satisfying when you get in the groove. The first time I tried the game I was just trying to go through the levels and found it quite frustrating as I felt like I had barely time to learn a new move before something new came up. I then restarted trying to achieve "S" score for each level, which meant restarting some levels many time, but in the end I had more fun that way!
Oh, and if you suffer from epilepsy, or are worried that you might then don't even try, this game has more flashing lights than a 90s rave.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047391587', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 64, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 64, 'last_played': 1589855492}
review:
I bought Thumper because it kept popping up as I was doing research on rhythm games for an essay I'm working on. A lot of other rhythm game aficionados seemed to like it. I did not. After playing for an hour, I have already gotten a perfect score on a quarter of the game's content, and I do not feel like playing it anymore. I don't make a habit of writing a review for a game I've only played for an hour, but I already asked for a refund (a first for me on Steam).

Thumper is played with one joystick and one button. If you see a rectangle, you need to look at what's coming after to know if you should just tap the button (because another rectangle follows), hold it (because a turn or red lines follow), or hold up on the stick while you press and hold it to fly (because spikes or blue rings follow). These context-sensitive button prompts give me the same feeling I get when I need to make a blind jump in a platformer. It feels like I died because I couldn't guess where the off-screen platform was, not because I made a mistake.

The percussive soundtrack is unique and interesting, but the lack of a melody means you have to rely a lot more on the visuals to know when to press the button. Regular notes can be pressed a bit late, but never too early, while long notes (red bars, spikes, blue rings, turns) can be performed by holding the stick and/or button long in advance but never late. A strange inconsistency which makes this a game of reflexes much more than a rhythm game.

Each level is divided in short sections, and you are given a rank for each (S, A, B, C,...). You can very quickly restart the current or previous section. This system only made me want to retry each section until I got an S rank before moving to the next, but that really hurts the flow of the game and makes the soundtrack even less melodious. Whenever I missed an input, I found myself restarting a couple times to simply learn the sequence of buttons by heart until I could get it right. Thumper is a game of memorisation more than a rhythm game. To be fair, that's a problem with many rhythm games, but in those games there usually is a melody to remember.

So, long story short, it's not the game I expected or hoped for.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994397124', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 900, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 457, 'last_played': 1698609538}

author: {'steamid': '76561198215402907', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 2159, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1758, 'last_played': 1692757010}
review:
What a lovely experience this game has been for the past few days. I feel compelled to write this review after S ranking all levels. Didn't think I'd be doing it a couple days ago when I finished it but here we are. S+ though, neeeeeever gonna happen. Props to the madlads who actually did it.

[b] GAMEPLAY: [/b]

The gameplay is pretty standard rhythm game affair, with extremely tight controls. Hard as fuck though. Every single action feels tuned to perfection.

One complaint I have is that there's no proper quick restart button. You press a button and press down to select restart checkpoint. And there's input lag in the menu so a couple times I ended up pressing down twice and selecting restart previous checkpoint.

[b] MUSIC AND SOUND DESIGN: [/b]

The sound design is absolute perfection. Every thump, every perfect turn, breaking through bars, flying up and smashing down to score more points; it just sounds so good. Feels really good too. 

The music compliments the game and the levels perfectly but not always. In some levels it can go a bit off but I'm assuming that's by design. My only complaint regarding the music would be that it gets kinda repetitive some times. A bit more variety in the tracks would've been nice


[b] VISUALS: [/b]

Of course, it wouldn't be the game it is without its gorgeous psychedelic visuals. The game is, in one word, mesmerizing. Although, in some levels the visuals can be distracting especially in the red tunnels where it's really hard to see the turns. But once you start looking for them it's not that hard.

The bosses look so fuckin good it's insane.

[b] STORY: [/b]

About the story, you might've thought it's just a space beetle hurtling through a hellish void trying to take down a giant demonic head. That's where you're wrong. It's more than that. The answer is in the giant head's name. CRAKHED

Yes, the game is about a crakhed. Specifically, a crakhed you're trying to stop from doing more crak. You fly through the void helping and fighting through all the issues he had. Including his perception of his own image, hence the demonic face. Slight spoilers below:

Then you finally get through to him, all is okay for a bit until he starts to relapse, hence the last level with the speed warping. And yes, the true boss is a pyramid. A pyramid scheme. THE pyramid scheme that led to this crakhed's downfall. 

In the end you manage to take down the pyramid scheme and a glimmer of hope appears in the crakhed's future as you speed towards the light at the end of a very long tunnel.

The message is quite clear. Stay away from crak and pyramid schemes. They'll ruin your life.

[b] CONCLUSION: [/b]

So yeah, that's about it. As mentioned in other reviews, you can also play this with a keyboard, no need for a gamepad. It's even better too cuz then you can have a separate finger on each button instead of just a thumb on the dpad/thumbstick.

All in all, fantastic game, most likely even better in VR. Buy it please and hope for a sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998842655', 'num_games_owned': 192, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 1189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 414, 'last_played': 1700604762}
review:
It's a shame that the first review you see on the store page is a negative one by a guy who's basic comprehension of music got challenged by this game.

Thumper is an intense, euphoric and downright fucking insane. You fly trough crazy looking environments at lightning speed, in a dangerous looking world brimming with color and in which spiked skulls, worms and fucking mandalas are trying to kill you. The music evokes this "tribal" feeling where it's kill or be killed, and it almost feels like you're not playing by the rhythm and instead you're trying to destroy it. The game also gets hard half-way trough, especially the last level in which the game fucks with you in the most fitting way possible.

Buy this game.
Also buy me VR so i can play this in it and get an epileptic seizure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198862726998', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 2736, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2350, 'last_played': 1686432051}
review:
Overused phrases: Rhythm Violence, Psychedelic, Catharsis?

I mean, they describe the game very well and may be the only required terms to describe the game, but it's far more than that. It tells you a story without any words or text and it's on you to decide what you want to interpret it as.

Is the beetle an underdog cruising it's way up to the mean guys or is it a destruction hungry maniac?
You can try to be passive and dodge your way through without causing much chaos, but then the [spoiler]ring enemies require you to thump those beats to kill'em.[/spoiler]

Are crackhead, the shape-shifting bosses and the [spoiler]line needle[/spoiler] just stopping you from crossing the game's boundaries?

Now that my totally original analysis is over, I would say this is the best rhythm game I've played (even though the only rhythm games I've played prior to this are the Dance Central games on Kinect.) You just can't play this game without a dpad or a controller, atleast in the higher levels. It took me almost 18 hours to get all the achievements and then I spent time taking a stab at getting double-digits on the leaderboards.

You have 2 health states, like Super Mario. [u]In regular play,[/u] you regain the 'Mushroom' or [i]Silver Wings[/i] by hitting a powered block at the end of a level or alternatively making a powered block on your own by [b]ground-pounding[/b] a tile beforehand which creates a powered block in front of you. [u]In Play+,[/u] you no longer can regain the healthstate quite that easy. To get your [i]Golden Wings[/i] back, you need to reach [b]4x score multiplier[/b] with each multiplier increase making your perceived speed higher as well as increasing the tempo of the beats.

review:
Ce jeu est le sentiment m√™me du viol de cerveau, tu vas mourir mon gars, mais sec, mais tu vas pas vraiment rager pour reprendre une √©valuation d'un joueur, tu ne vas pas rager jusqu'√† jeter ton clavier par la fen√™tre mais √† des moments ton cerveau va juste bugger tellement les encha√Ænements sont monstrueux.
Le jeu en lui m√™me est psych√©d√©lique, et le sens du rythme est tr√®s fort, vous ne r√©ussirez les encha√Ænements difficiles qu'en les faisant en boucle. Le moment o√π je fais cette √©valuation, je n'ai pas termin√© le jeu et √† vrai dire √ßa va me prendre plusieurs mois √† le terminer, c'est pas le genre de jeu auquel vous jouez en boucle pendant des heures d'affil√©s, mais vous reviendrez dessus tellement c'est kiffant.
Vous allez suer vos darones tellement fort que l'on pourrait remplir un vase, c'est du die and retry.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043816164', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 168, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 168, 'last_played': 1573478628}
review: Probably the closest thing to a horror rhythm game, Thumper is difficult and insanely intense but never gets too frustrating and has a steep but manageable learning curve. If you're into good scoring and inventive sound design, then this is definitely the game for you. This is the closest a game has gotten at capturing the musical intensity akin to the final scene from Whiplash in which Miles Teller's character beats the shit out of his drum kit for 10 minutes. Definitely worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198107230372', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1723, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 216, 'last_played': 1586388834}
review: One of the few hardcore games that ever got me. I'm really easy to frustrate but Thumper has just the right learning curve to make it delightful to develop your skills and "practice" boss fights until you - often suprisingly - make it. Hard AND gratifying, As to sound and GFX it is clear that Thumper has created a subgenre of rhythm games of it's own. Iconic.

author: {'steamid': '76561198297214050', 'num_games_owned': 200, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 50, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 50, 'last_played': 1584776152}
review: There's no music.  It's a rhythm game with no music.  I got to the third level and it was still playing the same boring drum beat in the background with no other instruments.  And you'd think without a song playing in the background, it'd at least be easy to hear the audio cues, but unfortunately the audio cues are so soft they're practically inaudible.  Definitely not what I was hoping for when I purchased a rhythm game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198335551823', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1575666173}
review: I played this game on PSVR and decided it was cheap enough on sale and worth getting on steam. It's not what you'd expect from a VR game, but it's great! It's a rhythm game with your controls not being motion, but by the buttons and joystick. It's great to be honest. It shouldn't give people motion sickness. It's really well designed! It may be too hard for my mom (anything that requires you to press buttons and use a joystick is, haha) but it's great! I bought it twice, so it's worth it! Graphics are great and audio is great too! Nothing not to like. Great and relaxing.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971830466', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 848, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 787, 'last_played': 1654561119}
review:
I love rhythm games and I love fast-paced reflex games. Even after playing some of the levels several times, I enjoy that I still rely on my reflexes and sense of timing, and not memorization. It's very satisfying when you nail a rapid and complex sequence! 

My biggest complaint is the time dilation on successful "drops" drives me insane by interrupting the flow. It kinda makes sense for when you take damage because it gives you a second to catch up mentally, but still messes up your rhythm. I also wish there were options for adjusting the balance of the various tracks, because sometimes I have no clue at all what is happening in my ears despite getting everything right on screen. Some tracks just drown out and ruin the mix. There are some VFX that make seeing what's happening nigh impossible (especially after taking damage).

That's really it though.. everything else is amazing. I don't often go through games more than once, but I have with this one! I'd love to see updates, DLC, or a sequel that adds to/improves upon what's already here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049929971', 'num_games_owned': 805, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 748, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 322, 'last_played': 1614672522}

author: {'steamid': '76561198437110506', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2696, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1881, 'last_played': 1629400320}
review:
A highly responsive difficult game with a beautiful psychedelic look. 

The main objective of this game is to navigate through a stage by thumping beats, drifting around corners, flying over spike pits and swerving between lanes in fast succession. 

As the game progresses, lanes begin to twist and turn as hazards appear in multiple lanes. You'll find yourself frantically weaving between lanes as you dodge lasers, drift around corners and fly over spike pits. The player can achieve a combo through flawless reaction times to the obstacles, which in turn, improves the player's overall score at the end of the stage. If a player misses a beat or drift they lose their combo. The same applies when a player fails to react to an obstacle, such as a drift or spike pit. Combos alter the sound effects associated with drifting, thumping beats and flying. This is a nice touch. 

Midway through, as well as the end of a stage, the player will encounter a boss.  The player must thump beats in a sequence whilst avoiding obstacles in order to eliminate the bosses. The same sort of boss appears in the first few levels, but becomes more monstrous during the later stages as the game increases in difficulty. Bosses are able to obstruct the players vision by displaying a flashy pattern, manipulating the speed of time, or shooting lasers at the player. It is extremely difficult to react to the obstacles and hazards when a psychedelic pattern is displayed on a winding and twisting path. There are a number of unique bosses in this game which all have their own quirks. 

The nature of each level is different, as are the bosses. However, the increase in difficulty and the introduction of new features in the levels keeps the game interesting. The core game play features remain the same. (Thumping, drifting, flying and swerving between lanes). I cannot stress enough, more game play mechanics does not equal a good game, as this game does a wonderful job of utilising these few mechanics in a way which keeps it fresh and intense for the player. 

The levels of this game are broken down into individual stages which make up an entire level, meaning you can continue game play at the exact stage you left off at within any one of the nine levels. At the end of a stage, you are graded based upon the preciseness of your reaction time to the obstacles within each stage. This counts towards your overall grade at the end of the level. In order to achieve an S grade, you must achieve and S grade in most stages of the level. If you are an achievement hunter, competing all levels with an S grade will be quite the challenge. 

In terms of replay value, this game can become predictable after a while. However, the fast paced game play and solid game play mechanics are what kept me invested for so long. Each level feels unique and the difficulty of each proceeding level is scaled perfectly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050727802', 'num_games_owned': 408, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 186, 'last_played': 1701410481}
review:
[This is coming from someone with thousands of hours of his life put into rhythm games like StepMania]

-After level 2 it stops being a rhythm game and becomes a fucking annoying memorization game with very little room for error... only worth playing if you like giving yourself stockholm syndrome... by the time I hit level 3 (the point where the game stops being fun): I passed 2 hours of playtime and can't refund.

-Often the obstacles create basic beats that never last long enough to be satisfying.

-The soundtrack is so overpowering that you often can't even hear the audio ques that would imply what obstacle is coming up, leaving everything up to reaction time (if you're lucky and the level is slower) or memorization. The soundtrack is decent on its own though.


I would rate this game a 4/10, right at the threshold of being an ok game worth a try.... might be worth it during a sale....
The levels of disappointed I am in this game far outweigh the few legitimate pros of this game such as it's visuals and great controls....

review: It was a lot of fun until Stage 4, which seriously overstayed it's welcome, and Stage 5, which made it clear that seriously overstaying it's welcome would become the norm, along with an obsession with off-beats that make it near-impossible to get any sense of rhythm and turn it into a game of pure memorization. 5-25 was what finally made me realize that the game just isn't fun anymore once it started throwing me into tunnels full of near-asynchronous bullshit with lots of twists so I'd only have a tenth of a second to react to visual cues, AND playing loud droning noises to hide any of the audio cues.

author: {'steamid': '76561198281958902', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 708, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 658, 'last_played': 1694194964}

author: {'steamid': '76561198005264962', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 16, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1584148817}
review: This is a fever dream first and a rhythm game second. Hypnotic and pulsing, claustrophobic and too violently fast for comfort... Thumper doesn't just get your heart thumping... it pulses through your psyche. The soundtrack is phenomenal and perfectly compliments the dread that you know you are racing towards. The moments when you encounter that dread are terrifying and panic inducing. Given all of the dread, panic, violence, claustrophobia and discomfort that I describe... why subject yourself to this experience? The designs, the colors, the flow, the reflection of your pod, the satisfaction of combining movements to an inhuman perfection.... the fear... the fear won't let go. Existence is suffering. If you can, play this in VR and you'll never be the same.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076318805', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 28, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1524529800}
review:
I can understand what this game is trying to achieve, but it just wasn't for me. The VR gameplay wasn't anything to gawk at, and at a $20 price point, I'd recommend waiting for a sale if you're interested in trying this game. The music became grating quickly and the levels felt like a slog.

If you're someone who creams their pants at the word "synesthesia" you'll probably like this game, though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198214494183', 'num_games_owned': 153, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 139, 'last_played': 1641907404}
review:
Ein verdammt gutes Spiel. Thumper ist zwar einfach zu spielen, aber schwer zu Meistern. 

In den Anfangslevel hat man relativ keine Schwierigkeiten, aber je weiter man vorschreitet desto schwieriger werden die Level. 

Die Musik (wenn man sie so nennen m√∂chte, ich zumindest habe keine Probleme damit) ist sehr gut und passt perfekt in das Setting von Thumper. Diese Elektronische, sehr Bass lastigen t√∂ne sind perfekt. Sie zeigen auch hervorragend wann man die richtige Tastencombination dr√ºcken muss.

Die 20‚Ç¨ sind gut investiert, wenn man auf solche art von Spielen steht.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964351915', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 743, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 743, 'last_played': 1541264832}
review:
I don't think this game really has much rhythm and found it more of a memorisation game in most cases.

It is also much easier in VR as the camera doesn't jiggle about, unless you're into doing that with your head.

But it's really fun, and very satisfying to get right.

review:
My thumb is dead, my brain is fried, my contoller barely works, all worth it.

The speed, music, beats, its just all perfect. If you want to have a even bigger challenge than the already hard campaign, there is also a harder version of all the levels. Enjoy your torture.

Bought the game, installed it and I liked it more or less.  A bit too challenging for me (I had to play the same levels over and over) and lost fastly my interest in the game to play it frequently.  After some weeks I would give it another try but I could not start the game anymore.  Application error with a number behind it and that's it.
Shame.  I tried to reinstall the game but had no succes.  Maybe there is some way to fix it an other way  but I'm not so in love
with the game that I would like to loose more time fixing it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999599511', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 425, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 425, 'last_played': 1579561651}
review:
I really want to like this game, as I think the concept and style is cool, but the way it plays and is presented have stopped me from doing that. You control a beetle that is travelling down a track and use a button and directional inputs to avoid hazards all to rhythmic cues from the oncoming track. However, the backing music doesn't really match the cues that are given, and a combination of overlapping noises from both the current actions and upcoming ones means that it is hard to discern what could be approaching. On top of that, the "notes" you play to are so syncopated from the background music in Level 5 and onwards that it just becomes a guessing game as to what will appear. I also experienced sensory overload from the background visuals, especially in Level 7 where the midlevel boss twists the track to even further prevent you from seeing what is further down the track (this is where I have stopped playing as I don't want to waste any more time not enjoying myself).
The first time I played this was not long after it was released in 2016, and I blamed my inability to enjoy the game on my computer being unable to handle a static 60fps whilst playing. Now that I have a new computer and know that can't be the problem, it seems that it is just this rhythm game's lack of rhythm and overbearing visuals that prevent me from recommending it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198345377708', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 1236, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 906, 'last_played': 1601313581}
review:
It's hard to succinctly describe Thumper, though rhythm violence is one way to put it. For a rhythm game, Thumper has a hell of an intense atmosphere, with giant glowing heads and abstract congeries of swirling tentacles serving as bosses. The noise soundtrack is pretty unique, and the sound design in general is outstanding. 

In Thumper, you're a beetle and your objective is to get to the end of each stage whilst accruing as many points as you can 'thumping' pads, exploding out of walls and smashing obstacles. It's fairly simple, but the game gets a lot of mileage out of its mechanics. I'd highly recommend checking out some gameplay of the first level to see if you'll enjoy it. 

A draining game to play for long periods, so I I'd suggest taking regular breaks. I rarely finish a level in one sitting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016632416', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 295, 'playtime_forever': 18, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1552271674}
review: Thumper is a trippy rhythm game, guaranteed to get your blood pumping.  You are a beetle moving along a psychedelic roller-coaster and have to use your abilities to thwart both the track and enemies you come across.  You really cant put into words how overwhelming this experience is, especially in VR.  Think Tron meets Stomp and you have it.  Strap in, turn up your sound, and expect something unique.  Thumper is not one to miss!

author: {'steamid': '76561198021993903', 'num_games_owned': 316, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 80, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1577493900}
review:
If you asked a computer to design a difficult rhythm game where you had to time your actions to the rhythm of the sounds, it might design this game. 

The beats are designed to be difficult by their respective placement in the rhythm, not by the difficulty of the beat itself. To clarify: you're not busy thumping out insane, good sounding rhythms to a soundtrack, instead you're trying to hit two or three specific notes at 7/16th of a beat because 7/16th is "technically" still in the rhythm. The only way you know where these sounds are supposed to be hit is by a sometimes obscured visual cue and a sometimes audible audio cue, which gets easily drowned out by the other sounds in the game.

This game has so much potential, and there are a lot of good things about it (the idea itself, the setting, the design etc) but the way this game sees difficulty as making notes sounds random and out of place makes it very annoying to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050156715', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 675, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 77, 'last_played': 1686364199}
review:
Bear in mind I played this without VR, I can imagine that with VR it would be even more amazing than it already is. I also went into this game blind, looking through my collection of rhythm-based games I accumulated over time, which I think added to the wow-factor.

When going into this game, expect only abstract, adrenaline-packed, chaotic, space-odyssey-2001 fun-ride, and make sure to bring your bass-heavy headphones/speakers, because you will need them. I am only 3 levels in, because it's so intense that after 3 levels my focus was severely slipping, like feeling sick after eating too much good stuff, and I love it! I love the intensity, the sound design, the visual design, everything about it. 

What I wouldn't call it is a "rhytm" game per se. It has rhythm elements, but in the same way racing games are rhythm based. The rhythm of the soundtrack more or less complements the gameplay, and honestly I couldn't tell two two squats about the soundtrack beyond that it's fairly simple, and that's a good thing! The music, just like the visual design, is simple yet abstract in design, meant become absorbed by the background, to minimize the clutter while maximising it at the same time, but unlike games that use clutter to overwhelm you to keep you attentive, the clutter here is mostly aesthetic! It is a very risky design, as I can tell how it can make you feel sick after prolonged exposure, but you know what else makes you sick if you have too much of? Sugar. Because just like sugar, it's a treat to play! But just how with confectionery, keep it in moderation! 

The experience I would compare to a reaction-esque arcade racer, like Burnout Revenge/3 or Split Second, and it's one of the single digit games that made me say "holy shit" outloud, and possibly one of the only games that makes me feel glad when I lose, because I just don't want that experience to end. For the pessimists that feel obligated to be impressed and are going to be nitpicky, pass this title, but if you're looking for something to kick back, relax, get your adrenaline pumping, maybe a party game, or to test your VR, don't hesitate! You won't regret it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198027508578', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 13, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1576284239}
review:
Incredibly boring with nothing much happening.
Music is very bland.
I found no rhythm at work here.
Game aspect wasn't compelling.
Weak visuals considering what you could do with VR nowadays.
Most of the screen is black, you are railroaded, so why would you want turn around?
Why do I need a controller for this?
Congratulations to people who had fun with this, but 
I didn't buy a VR Headset for this tedium.

review: So...this game is a journey. Never played rhythm game before, this game did what others couldn't and brought me out of my usual game choices. This game is a trip, each mission getting more difficult and intense, with amazing visuals! Easy to get lost in this game for a couple hours. 20$ well worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970809816', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 454, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 454, 'last_played': 1570995171}
review:
Notice: I've played most of this in VR as it gave me a better view angle and overall experience.

This game. It's special. It's a cross between a religious experience and 70s arcade games.

It slowly pushes you along a psychedelic wavy track and introduces you to a series of abilities and obstacle patterns which feel oddly simple to remember. At first. The further your go through the game it gradually cranks up the speed into a frenetic high-octane warp-speed deathtrack that pumps up an adrenaline-fueled trance, with your reflexes oddly agreeing along a series of patterns that are both comfortably familiar and surprisingly deceptive. Then you die and try over and over until you finally get your brain to remember that surprise curve that you kept crashing into.

In other words it's technically a reflex-based arcade game with visuals and a soundtrack that make you feel like your at the edge of the cosmos racing into a forbidden dimension. It has 2 "difficulty" approaches, where you can just focus on surviving through the tracks or get the extra objectives they pepper throughout for extra points and rating. I compared it to 70s arcade games as in the gameplay's focus is pretty singular but can be quite addicting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198263273602', 'num_games_owned': 230, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 1807, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 272, 'playtime_at_review': 388, 'last_played': 1712430816}
review:
A tightly designed game with a beautiful execution of its very unique ideas. The gameplay is intense and sucks you in. You become immersed in the rhythm. Nailing a sequence of moves is super satisfying. Oh and also, it's the most visually impressive game I've ever played.

I'd give this game a 10/10, and I give very few games 10/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971395135', 'num_games_owned': 429, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1747, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 666, 'last_played': 1636864314}
review:
always loved rhythm games and this is one of the most satisfying & challenging ones I've ever played.

the game opens up much further once you understand how to rack up points with perfect turns and carefully planned pounding. S ranks are a bit unforgiving but completely attainable. I think the only thing I would have liked is if the S ranks were a just a little more challenging to get.

I also really appreciate the unconventional soundtrack as it emphasizes rhythm/patterns more than melody. and the visuals/intensity of this game are absolute madness. I love this game and can't believe how long I put off getting it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198107671191', 'num_games_owned': 364, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2681, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 728, 'last_played': 1695671033}
review:
This game is one of its kind. It falls under the cathegory of rythm games, but conveys a completely different atmosphere than any other rythm game I've ever played. The sounds and colors suck you in in a very strong way and don't let you go. It gives you a weirdly unpleasing feeling. The hard nature of the game strengthens that feeling even more, and when you fight the first boss you really feel as tiny as you are in this huge universe the game represents. 

The best summary I can think of would be: This is a horror rythm game.

Hugely recommend to play this game, it is worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051369293', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 493, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 432, 'last_played': 1648619702}
review:
I'd like to give this a Maybe or Neutral if there was an option for it.

The game is fun until you hit Level 5, then it throws you at breakneck speeds with insane turns, multi-tracks, metal rings that damage you if you miss a single beat, odd time changes, and annoying as hell metal centipedes will occasionally show up to ruin your day.

I went into this game with the energy and feeling that I could probably S Rank or at least complete everything, but that feeling quickly got stomped out once I hit Level 5 and I simply couldn't keep up with what they were expecting of me anymore. My patience had run out and limping through with B's and C's just made me feel like crap. The scoring seeming inconsistent at times (performing badly, taking damage, still getting an A or even S at times/do damn near perfect, miss a few things, suddenly a C) definitely soured my mood.

If you've got bullet-time levels of reflexes, go for it. Otherwise you're probably gonna find a wall of "This isn't fun anymore" like I did.

Edit: Completed Level 5 after writing this and I already see 6 is another Fresh Hell that I refuse to go into. My fun in this game ends at Level 4, clearly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080370646', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 87, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 87, 'last_played': 1575582922}
review: The soundtrack to this game is so minimalist and repetitive that it's almost like playing a rhythm game that doesn't have any music whatsoever. I played through the first 3 worlds (of the 8 in the game) and the music was barely there and barely changed throughout. The gameplay is tight and the game looks cool, but I never got the fun feeling of gaming along to the music that I've gotten from other rhythm games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082218675', 'num_games_owned': 500, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1532, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 802, 'last_played': 1697052086}
review:
I keep coming back to this game, again and again, for the adrenaline rush it provides. From the moment you hit "Play", Thumper does not let you breathe for a single second. The frantic drums, the lightning fast level and dramatic ambiance make for a truly unique and refreshing experience.

Expect your skills to be challenged too. The control scheme is easy as can be, since you only play with one joystick and one action button, but the speed and precision required by the last level will truly put your sanity to the test.

Finally, if you have the chance to own a VR headset, you really should give it a go. The added immersion and sense of speed really bring this amazing game to another level.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000979021', 'num_games_owned': 364, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 617, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 449, 'last_played': 1663719536}
review:
impeccably designed, excellent sound and music. i played it on a rift s and it has been my favorite VR game so far. 

Only part that didn't quite sit right was the final boss that seemed to forget what made the rest of the game such a blast to play. 

I liked it so much i bought it on the switch too so i can take play it portable as well. highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972670801', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 184, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 40, 'last_played': 1634326135}
review:
I was expecting to be turning inside out playing this in VR... the trailers look amazing, the music sounds great and the immersive promise of VR was very enticing - so I bought it.

I get a little motion sick playing Elite Dangerous in VR, a lot motion sick playing any smooth locomotion game, and even Euro Truck simulator makes me feel uneasy...

But somehow, flying at supersonic speed as a techno beetle has absolutely no negative effects in VR whatsoever. This game is exceptionally well designed - sound cues match visual cues, and both audio and video aspects are consistent and clear.

Definitely get it while it is on sale. Very good rhythm game, made me want to try and perfect every checkpoint starting from level 2. I play it seated, facing away from the monitor (the default camera position aims in a weird direction). I use a steam controller to play it as I was not facing my mouse and keyboard.

author: {'steamid': '76561199005520522', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2295, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1048, 'last_played': 1575090226}
review:
J'ai beaucoup aim√© mon exp√©rience sur Thumper.
C'est un jeu de rythme dans une ambiance horreur-psych√©d√©lique qui demandera une tr√®s grande pr√©cision.
Le moins que l'on puisse dire, c'est que c'est difficile mais c'est ce qui fait que lorsqu'on r√©ussit √† encha√Æner les inputs que le jeu nous envoie parfois sadiquement, hors du rythme, on ressent une intense satisfaction.
D'autant plus que le jeu n'est pas "coup√©" comme peuvent l'√™tre parfois les jeux du genre, ici on se lance dans des longs niveaux et apr√®s chaque checkpoint le jeu continue sans hacher le d√©roulement de la partie et on peut choisir de rejouer le CP pr√©c√©dent ou de reprendre encore plus t√¥t, on peut donc passer une trentaine de minutes d'affil√©e sur les derniers niveaux sans voir un menu et c'est tr√®s agr√©able.
La bande son est vraiment sympathique, mais ce sont vraiment les sons li√©s √† vos inputs qui font la diff√©rence et qui contribuent √† l'immersion et l'ambiance du jeu.

Si je devais faire une critique, c'est que le jeu est quand m√™me assez on√©reux au prix fort (20‚Ç¨, √† voir √† quel point vous comptez revenir dessus une fois termin√©), qu'il devient tr√®s vite difficile (un mode facile pour faciliter l'apprentissage des novices serait vraiment une super am√©lioration) et que dans l'ensemble il est assez lin√©aire.

author: {'steamid': '76561198272476856', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 3134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1944, 'last_played': 1682250296}
review:
So much yes.
More so with VR.
I own a pimax 5k and with the high resolution & wide field of view it feels like it was made for this kind of game.

The only unfortunate thing about this game is how early it ends. Level 9 feels like what the entire game was building up to, it feels complete, but then it ends there. I would gladly pay $60 for a full version of this game.

If you want a unique rhythm game with a great (and strange) atmosphere this is well worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993558156', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 14196, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4381, 'last_played': 1624652157}
review: This game is unique and amazing. I love how you can use the rhythm / music to complete the extreme challenges. I could really see a game like this used to assist in fighter pilot or motorcycle racing training. Your timing must be perfect, and the surreal and nightmarish dreamscape levels make this game one of the best ever made.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004390046', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2605, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2088, 'last_played': 1695664746}
review:
Thumper is a brutally hard rail-based rhythm hell game. The premise of the game is relatively simple, although obscured. You are a space beetle who goes straight down into some sort of rhythm hell. You need to sprint, dash and turn your way through 9 levels of brutal challenge. I found the game to be confoundingly hard, especially if you're trying to S-rank all the levels.

The game has a heavy reliance on the player's reflexes and sense of upcoming musical flow to tackle the obstacles. Hit the thump pads, crash through red barriers, hit blue rings with flight, and other things. The level ends with a boss fight against Krakhed, what I presume to be the warden of hell. It is a brutal, head-trip of an experience and I do recommend it if you have the heart, guts and reflexes for it.
