review:
Wow. Thumper est un jeu de rythme violent et psych√©d√©lique qui hypnotise et transporte un scarab√©e le long d'un rail. L'ambiance, la musique, le style graphique et le feedback sont le moteur de ce jeu instinctif, qui endort, frustre et euphorise √† la fois pendant 9 niveaux √† la difficult√© et √† la time signature croissante. 

M√™me si je suis mauvais √† ce jeu √† cause de mes r√©flexes et de mon sens du rythme aux fraises (ce qui m'aura amen√© √† 20h de jeu pour le finir), Thumper m'a marqu√© et j'ai ressenti des choses uniques en y jouant. author: {'steamid': '76561198043819023', 'num_games_owned': 101, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 158, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 158, 'last_played': 1573449944}
review: I am very familiar with rhythm games, and I enjoy them quite a bit. This game has a good idea going for it, however, a rhythm game with no calibration settings is a failed product. This wouldn't be an issue if the actions I take as a player exactly matched what was on screen and the audio in the music. This is not the case in Thumper, where my actions must precede what I hear by a large amount of time (by rhythm game standards). Because of this, Thumper is unfortunately unplayable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003874143', 'num_games_owned': 664, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 630, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 306, 'last_played': 1647482071}
review: i was able to get the platinum trophy on playstation, so my experience with this game comes with that perspective. i play this game when i'm stressed, because it lets me redirect that stress in a healthy way towards something entertaining and challenging. certainly the hardest rhythm game i've ever played, every level blasts away all the gunk built up in my brain to get at the raw center. the game leaves me relieved and exhausted, and feeling so much better every time. play this game if you want to feel like you're going to die in real life.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972833520', 'num_games_owned': 896, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 16, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16, 'last_played': 1572697401}
review:
Tried it with VR, which isn't a big plus but with this games visuals, it's nice to shut everything else out and look around when possible.

The game itself is weird, simple, entrancing, enjoyable and unlike anything else. It's not a true rythm game imo, as the tags suggest, the challenges and objects does pop-up in time with a beat, but a true rythm game needs you to react on the beat rather than later like in this one.

I can highly suggest to try it out, although I'm not sure I would suggest paying the full price for it. It is a nice experience, but it might not hook you and there's not a lot to it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110346176', 'num_games_owned': 158, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 2645, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 967, 'last_played': 1661190912}
review: Thumper is a really well crafted game that feels really good to play. The beats are foreign and interesting, and you will like it especially if you are into odd time signatures and that kind of stuff. The art is terrifying and amazing, because of the custom engine things are able to be warped in really weird mind bending ways that further reinforce general vibe that the game has. The game feels fast and intense and good to play, the mechanics are simple and the general level of polish on the game is great.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000172115', 'num_games_owned': 209, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 616, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 560, 'last_played': 1635902108}
review:
I love this game, the concept is unlike anything and the music is great, not your run of the mill rhythm game music for sure. To all those whining about poor design choices regarding how to play the game. Honestly this is one of those games that lets you figure it out on your own but it does give you some pretty obvious hints. At the beginning of each level there something sort of like a "tutorial" that you have to pass. It doesn't spell things out for you so you have to try stuff and I believe that was a deliberate decision by the developers so I't just how the game works it's not poor design and I personally think that if you can manage to explain how the game works through the actual gameplay, without a single written word then that is some of the best game design. Just pay attention and you should be good.

Anyways great graphics, great music and VR support! It's awesome in VR!

author: {'steamid': '76561198361201045', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 57, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 57, 'last_played': 1557654096}

author: {'steamid': '76561197998468467', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 717, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 710, 'last_played': 1571887827}
review:
I can't get all S ranks I don't even want to play anymore

lol but seriously this game is great
kinda speaks for itself. totally trippy but way too hard to play while high unless you stick to the first couple worlds. thumper does do a good job of teaching the player by slowly immersing them and scaling the difficulty just so, sometimes putting easier levels right after more difficult level to show you how much you've improved. you're the player dude, unless you only read about games and don't play them. there is one particular jump i can't figure out and the game never insists you do this trick, it's only for S ranks as far as I can tell, where you'll need to jump, land, and immediately jump again. Maybe because I'm on keyboard and not a controller, I've only accomplished this once. Makes me want to give up honestly even though Thumper completely allows you to take the scenic route and finish levels at a lower rank just to see the rest of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198447014957', 'num_games_owned': 238, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 3492, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3414, 'last_played': 1697797706}
review:
Best rhythm game I have ever played  ... well worth the money . Drool seems like they actually care of  their game .
I can say with certainty this game is a good thrill ride with lots of challenge. Graphics looks awesome and game play is almost perfect  . Plus, the sound track entices to play till infinity.
Nerves was flowed of adrenaline while the speed got faster and faster .

 This game needs patience in order to progress .
I am very proud to finish the whole game with a 100% achievement (19/19), especially level 9 S. It was a miracle to pass it . 
I wish Drool makes another game whatever genre was for more excitement and enjoyment .

author: {'steamid': '76561197997690137', 'num_games_owned': 593, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 87, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1566155531}
review:
Basicamente √© como se as bandas Tool e Sepultura tivessem tido um filho demon√≠aco que se manifestou na forma de jogo. 

Thumper √© uma viagem brutal e fascinante ao inferno sonoro. A arte psicod√©lica, a percurs√£o tribal, o tempo irregular das batidas, tudo funciona lindamente em conjunto e gera uma incr√≠vel atmosfera que consegue ser opressora e desconfort√°vel mas ao mesmo tempo empoderadora e viciante.

Os controles tamb√©m s√£o excelentes e possuem o grau perfeito de complexidade para serem facilmente entendidos mas dificilmente dominados.

Por enquanto a √∫nica cr√≠tica que tenho √© que o jogo √†s vezes √© um pouco repetitivo, mas por conta da experi√™ncia extremamente original que ele proporciona isso acaba n√£o atrapalhando muito.

9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198025349349', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 519, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 464, 'last_played': 1654382269}
review:
Detective: I'm so sorry, miss... we found him early yesterday morning. He was non responsive, slumped in his computer chair, mouth agape, pupils dilated. These are the tell-tale signs that he was a-

Mom: A ...  Thumper?

Detective: I'm afraid so, miss. I know lots of people only Thump from time to time, recreationally. Some people, though.... they get really into Thumping and ... sometimes the sensory experience of playing it gets to be too much for people. I'm sorry for your loss.

Mom: Thank you, Detective.

.... Hey one more thing, Detective?

Detective: Yes?

Mom: .... Did he at least have some S-ranks?

-----

Thumper is an excellent rhythm game for those who are fans of the genre. I find that I play it in little bursts from time to time. If you watch just a tiny bit of gameplay footage you will probably instantly know if it's your kind of thing. If you're on the fence, I'd say go for it. It's especially good in VR... just be careful not to become a Thumper.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087100153', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 103, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 103, 'last_played': 1565311602}
review: A rhythm game - VR coaster -  trippy equilizer - heart bounding - sweaty hand - out of body experience.  Must play for VR!

author: {'steamid': '76561198171434421', 'num_games_owned': 146, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 1246, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1064, 'last_played': 1643479416}
review: Absolutely wonderful. Rarely does a game put me in a state of absolute zen like this one does. It's difficult. It's overwhelming at times. But I was never frustrated with it because all of my deaths seemed fair, and all of my triumphs felt deserved. Get this game. You will not regret it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033200463', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 336, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 335, 'last_played': 1566666181}
review: Thumper is so different to everything else I have played. It's a rhythm game that has such a brutal ferocity it make it an entirely new thing. The game hurtles you through a percussion gauntlet at breakneck pace, sometimes so much so that it can be visually intensive to focus on its trippy demonic display. There is repetition between the levels and bosses and the checkpoints can be very inconsistently spaced, but all in all Thumper is just as hammering and violent as it claims to be.

author: {'steamid': '76561198847222602', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 114, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1567534484}
review: Picked this game up back during the Summer Sale and just got around to playing it.  I wished I had played it sooner.  Mind Blown.

review: Higly energetic rythm-based game. You'll sweat. You'll keep dying.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991090389', 'num_games_owned': 338, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 126, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 126, 'last_played': 1564538144}
review:
It gets old after the first few levels. I'm also one of the many people who got stuck on 5-1 and just can't pass it. It combines a timing change, an unfun mechanic (need to hit everything perfect or die), and a very unintuitive beat on top of gate sounds that don't match up with said beat.

I just wish I'd hit this level before reaching over 2 hours in the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994711468', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 72, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1564013384}
review: Beautiful artful game with a great thumping soundtrack, impressive graphic style and addictive and fun gameplay! I love it. Perfect game for short sessions and chill. Nice work!

author: {'steamid': '76561197984505368', 'num_games_owned': 1529, 'num_reviews': 226, 'playtime_forever': 390, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1563841460}
review:
Rhythm games work by asking the player to sync music and visuals with actions - effectively you 'play along' and your score indicates how well you brought everything together.

Thumper doesn't do this, sadly - outside of offering a tempo, it's music' is created by your actions instead of guiding them 

When the music doesn't tell you what's coming, you're waiting for the visual clues instead of anticipating them/learning the motifs etc.

If you're happy to practice and rote-learn - you'll find a challenge here AND the atmosphere is really quite cool

I find the need to learn an absolute chore tho - other games have shown this can be done SO much better (see the 'Bit Trip Runner' games in particular) - so it's a "Not Recommended" from me.

p.s. I also struggled with the feeling the game was out-of-sync - sadly, there's no in-game latency setting/testing that I can find which, in the era of wireless peripherals, multi-monitor setups and VR, isn't good enough either.

author: {'steamid': '76561198100121289', 'num_games_owned': 78, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 22342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 692, 'playtime_at_review': 408, 'last_played': 1712019409}
review: The game starts amazing, however at level 5-1 it becomes real hard, I did finish the whole game but level 5-1 IS THE HARDEST LEVEL EVER! Overall fantastic game and I wish for v2!

author: {'steamid': '76561198011736015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 427, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 174, 'last_played': 1594923105}
review:
Some of the levels seem to lack any feeling of rhythm for tiny portions (perhaps it's because you're hitting off beats, or I am just not getting the beat myself), but it's usually just the boss levels that feel that way. This game would be damn near impossible to play if you are color blind (I imagine) because even I was struggling to see notes every now and then (occasionally they match the ambient colors and it's difficult to see them); this problem is especially bad on certain bosses when the explosion from defeating them masks the bonus points note.

 A lot of this game is really just trial and error, because it's so ridiculously fast paced that I can't imagine anyone could do a good blind run on most levels. The boss levels feel very different from the rest of the game, and are noticeably easier (so far) which is a little counter intuitive.

I am currently on level 6 of 9 and I have S-ranked all levels so far.

Overall I would definitely recommend this game for fans of rhythm games or industrial music.

author: {'steamid': '76561198149842163', 'num_games_owned': 356, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 3078, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 844, 'last_played': 1610145474}
review:
I don't even know where to begin with this one,
It's a fucking rhythm game with a beetle.
This game is like guitar hero on acid, but without the guitar nor the acid,
Holy fucking pee pee this game is crazy.
If you like the Rhythm Heaven games, you'll probably like this one, although this one may 
be a bit more challenging as it requires faster reaction time. 
The notes sometimes can be asynchronous, but it's always on beat, so it remains consistent, 
but that doesn't mean it wont pull a fast one on you, in fact, %90 of your deaths will be
because of something you weren't expecting.
This game will occasionally have motifs per level that are more there for a quick refresher, 
like a break, and you look forward to seeing them as you know what to expect. 
Due to wanting to get S tier on many of the levels, and restarting often because of it, I
can't really tell you how long it will take you to beat the game on your first playthrough,
but I didn't officially beat the game until around 13 hours in. I still don't have S tier on 
all the levels, but I was playing this on my laptop, so I can expect myself to do better once 
I try this game on my desktop. This game runs well, over 100 frames per second on my laptop when the framerate cap is off. I was playing the steam version, as it offers all kind of support, such as Virtual Reality, controller, keyboard, and so on, but this game is available on other platforms too. There is even a phone version of it as well. 
If you were blind, you could beat this game, but it would be hard. It's not impossible, and you can hear cues ahead of time to indicate when you need to perform an action, however it isn't consistent, such as the rail snakes.
However, for a $20, I don't really see myself spending that kind of money for this kind of game.
Although its chock full of content, most of it is repetitive, and i feel that a $10 price point 
would be more reasonable for what the game is.
Fortunately the steam sale made it only $5, which i felt made this game %100 worth it. 
If you are a hardcore music lover slash rhythm game lover, go for it, but
if you are a regular gamer, wait for it to go on sale,
and if you are just a casual gamer, probably pick this up if it's $5, otherwise you 
probably wont get the full enjoyment from the game. 

To rate this, I'm going to give you an arbitrary number that has no meaning to anyone
else but myself of the number: 8.27

author: {'steamid': '76561198041230015', 'num_games_owned': 333, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1105, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 184, 'last_played': 1696746185}
review:
Thumper is a stressful, but extremely enjoyable experience. Playing it feels like driving 300 MPH on a crowded freeway with no brakes.  The game is deceptively simple on the surface, but quickly divulges into an intense and unforgiving challenge after it introduces you to the basic mechanics. The moment you feel like you grasp Thumper's rudiments, it immediately shifts the difficulty and pulls you out of your comfort zone again. Not only are new mechanics repeatedly introduced as you get up to speed with the playstyle, the rhythm itself is constantly changing between levels, making each one disorienting and strenuous to beat. Basically, the only elements in this game that's invariable across all levels is that it keeps you on your toes and feels extremely rewarding to beat every time.

As for the sound, this game is very aptly named. Every beat, hit and crash in Thumper seems explosively loud and violent. Aside from the feeling of accomplishment after surviving each level, the primary incentive to persevere through all of the challenge is getting to hear the amazingly satisfying percussion for as long as possible. In most rhythm games I've played, the music takes a sort of back seat to the gameplay and you're left to focus on the visuals to stay in step. In Thumper, your role is to [b][i]BE[/i][/b] the percussion, so maintaining the rhythm itself becomes the central gratifying goal of the game while the visuals actually try to divert (and kill) you.

It would be a mistake to compare this to any typical rhythm game. It plays differently and the satisfaction comes from different places. I would definitely recommend that anyone looking for a relaxing experience steer clear of this title. But you're interested in a highly intense rhythm game, you'll probably find that Thumper stands out from the rest in this genre. Buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994778560', 'num_games_owned': 316, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 169, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 96, 'last_played': 1609074729}

author: {'steamid': '76561198201233999', 'num_games_owned': 97, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 885, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 363, 'last_played': 1673150059}
review:
This game is chock-full of psychedelic beauty, making lots of use of some of the most trippy and creepy visuals I have ever seen. The game also has one of the best soundtracks I have ever heard, coming from Brian Gibson, an artist well-versed in dark, technical noise rock. These two things combined create an unparalleled experience that you have to try to understand, one totally deserving of its rhythm, horror, and action descriptors. You also haven't played this game until you've experienced it in VR, as the immersion in the headset is unreal. The game is slightly difficult, but still completely fair, and it has a nice difficulty curve to it. It also has endless replayability, with it's multiple game modes, ability to climb up the leaderboards, and high-score chasing gameplay. From the visuals, 
to the gameplay, to the music, and on and on, this game is everything I hoped for and more, and I would've paid full price for it (thankfully though, I got it on sale). Definitely pick this one up if you get a chance, this game will stand the test of time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041108401', 'num_games_owned': 1219, 'num_reviews': 496, 'playtime_forever': 155, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 97, 'last_played': 1592697495}
review:
[h1] This is not just a game, this is an experience! [/h1]
It is [b]so[/b] immersive by creating an awesome sound scenery of electronic dark ambient noise and classical orchestra. You can feel an upcoming evil just due to the music/sound immersion. It is a dark mysterious dreadful horror feeling I get while [strike]playing[/strike] journeying through this psychedelic nightmare fever. (The track while displaying the level results remembers me of the beginning of The Shining, main title soundtrack)
The visuals are stunningly weird undefineable shapes and add to what the audio does.
The gameplay actually sounds simple with one button and cardinal directions, but staying in the rythm gets harder quickly. And it feels just [i]soo[/i] good. When hitting your first blue dot on the track you know why this is called Thumper. That silver surfer bug thumps the beat and it's [i]really[/i] cool. 

Thumper does everything right and creates an immersion I am dragged into that seeks its equal. This is an awesome unique experience if you can feel this music.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970758866', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 34, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1675180216}
review:
Bought on Sale for 4.99 Euro.
Not worth the money(19.99 Euro) if you think Thumper is about Sound or Rythm. 
It's just a "reflexes" game with ok visuals and music (not tested VR version).
I would sink hours in such a game back in early 1990 as young child/kid, repetetive and simple gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198121546504', 'num_games_owned': 109, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1280, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 214, 'last_played': 1668308076}
review: Holy hell this game. Hell is actually the perfect description for it. It says "rhythm game" but Thumper far more than that. Thumper is a rapid descent into madness that gets more and more intense the more you play. Thumper tends to trick you into a rhythm then surprising you with a turn. It feels like you're in some Lovecraftian horror novel the whole way through with all the tentacles and weird visuals everywhere. Amazing game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198862375832', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 1547, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 142, 'last_played': 1670572793}
review:
Che dire, gioco assolutamente clamoroso. 
E' anche difficile da descrivere giochi del genere, rasenta l'assoluta perfezione. 
Musiche, suoni, immagini astratte che riportano inevitabilmente ad un misto tra frattali in stile sci-fi dei film degli anni '70/80 e le illustrazioni del film di The Wall, dall'omonimo album dei Pink Floyd, amalgamati e in perfetta sinergia tra loro. Impostato a difficolt√† graduale, si arriva sempre di pi√π a livelli di sfida veramente ostici ma incredibilmente soddisfacenti, che portano il giocatore sempre pi√π verso uno stato di trance onirico, causato dalla ripetizione quasi meccanica delle azioni da compiere ma senza mai ripetere veramente a memoria, in quanto √® richiesta molta concentrazione. Se ci aggiungiamo i frattali clamorosamente d'effetto scorrerci velocissimi davanti agli occhi, l'effetto complessivo porta ad uno stato di trance onirico molto simile ad un trip, che si traduce in un senso di profondo appagamento sensoriale.

Io ho LA FORTUNA di giocarlo in VR con un Oculus Rift S, perch√® √® qualcosa di assolutamente, clamorosamente, PAZZESCO, da lasciarmi totalmente a bocca aperta (mentre scrivo la recensione ho ancora i flash del gioco negli occhi). 
A guardarlo dalle immagini della pagina del prodotto verrebbe da dargli poca importanza, dando l'idea di un giochino indie simile a giochi da smartphone, in VR invece si tende a cercare l'esperienza con la graficona, infatti l'ho sempre tralasciato a favore di altri.. l'ho comprato solo adesso e che dire... SI MANGIA a colazione un sacco di altri giochi, √® un'esperienza talmente impattante che trovo sia un assoluto must-have per chiunque abbia un visore! Davvero, sto faticando a trovare le parole per descriverlo perch√® una cosa del genere la si riesce a comprendere solo provandola!

Sicuramente molto divertente se giocato su monitor, in VR per√≤ diventa un'esperienza ai limiti dell'assurdo. Psichedelia ai massimi livelli, un trip incredibilmente gratificante. Vi avviso per√≤, si arriveranno a livelli di sfida difficilissimi che vi porteranno anche a rifare 100,200, 300  volte la stessa operazione (ma non vi frustrer√† pi√π di tanto, se non esagerate, per via delle meraviglie che vi sfrecceranno davanti), soprattutto nelle bossfights. Quella del livello 3 mi ha costretto, penso, a 300 e oltre tentativi, a livelli avanzati la difficolt√† diventa folle ma mai impossibile, riderete addirittura per la situazione folle in cui vi trovate, ma non vi fermerete, sarete, ipnotizzati, ad andare avanti, a sfrecciare alla velocit√† della luce, anche se alcuni livelli vi sembreranno ai limiti dell'impossibile, causa movimenti pazzeschi e velocit√† supersonica che diventa sempre pi√π evidente, fino al punto da darvi alla testa. E' un gioco per chi vuol mettersi alla prova perch√® dar√† veramente tanto filo da torcere. Proseguendo per√≤, vi renderete conto che riuscirete sempre pi√π a fare cose che prima pensavate quasi impossibili, qui non √® lo scarabeo a migliorare tramite modifiche varie, qui siete VOI a prendere esperienza, √® come un linguaggio da apprendere, sarete voi stessi a migliorare e superare dei limiti, che, andando avanti, vi faranno percepire semplici degli scogli che prima erano quasi insormontabili. Vi sentirete quasi dei giocolieri a riuscire a fare, anche senza problemi dopo un p√≤, delle cose che, poche ore prima, vi avrebbero lasciato senzia fiato per la difficolt√†.

La perfezione, tra i giochi, anzi, chiamarlo gioco √® riduttivo, tra le esperienze pi√π pazzesche mai provate in VR e in generale, oserei dire che c'√® una mente geniale dietro questo titolo, costasse 60 euro lo comprerei ugualmente ad occhi chiusi. Potrebbe tranquillamente diventare uno dei miei giochi preferiti di sempre, di ogni tempo. 
Provar per credere.

author: {'steamid': '76561198156702647', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 873, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 315, 'last_played': 1673372942}
review:
First of all: For the love of everything that's holy, don't play this game if you have photosensitive epilepsy, after doing longer play session (and in this case longer means around 2 hours) my eyes felt like they were melting. Just a warning. Now, onto the game itself:

Note that I'll probably have a lot of trouble explaining my feelings because it's a very unique game.

I absolutely love Thumper. I'm not that into rhythm games, other than Thumper I played Audiosurf and another game similar to guitar hero which I cannot remember the name now but what I can say is that Thumper is fundamentally different than those other games. I would even go as far as to say Thumper is not really a rhythm game but rather a "reaction game". Music doesn't play that big of a role in Thumper, because what happens on the "track" is very often off-beat. It's a bit hard to explain. Music doesn't change throughout the game, it's really just a single tune but in different rhythm patterns, and on top of that, when the same rhythm is playing, different situations can occur on track, so reacting to the music itself won't get you anywhere. You have to observe the game, look ahead and to some extent even predict the next move you'll have to do. I don't want to spoil too much, but it makes sense because this gameplay mechanic is tied nicely to the plot. The beetle is actually fighting creatures and beings from higher dimensions etc. so it feels really satisfying when you're in the zone and predicting the next turn feels like your perception of reality is ascending to another level. (That's a small exaggeration obviously but you know what I mean :D)

This is how the game gives you some freedom in beating the levels: Your beetle has an iron shell protecting you from one mistake, after you lose it there is one way to regenerate it, a "stomp". It happens in a tutorial stage when you have to jump over a weird spike trap or something, and it's at that moment you regenerate your shell. What the game doesn't tell you about is that you can do the stomp at any time. Even when you don't need to jump over the trap. Another example, when the track splits into multiple lanes later on, you don't have to hit every corner ramp to progress, you may chose to grind on it, sure, but you can just ignore it and proceed just fine.

What made me change my opinion about Thumper from "Pretty good" to "Absolutely amazing" was the ending. It blew my mind a bit. It's also involving the plot so I cannot say anything in regards to that but, it was absolutely worth to play through the entire game, just for that one bit at the end. ;)

Does the game have flaws? Hmm, no, not really. I didn't encounter any bugs or design issues that made me enjoy the game less. Nothing of that matter occured at any point.

Thumper is amazing. Highly recommended if you enjoy electronic beats and sci-fi premise with a subtle yet interesting plot.
Oh, and the game has New Game +, which I'm going for next, wish my eyes luck, they're going to need it.

review: Thumper is absolutely fantastic. It is unforgiving, relentless, and invigorating to play. You will spend most of your time with this game in complete awe of the fantastic soundtrack and accompanying visuals. The game describes itself as 'Rythm Violence' and a more accurate description couldn't exist, this game uses the concepts of rythm to create a violent, heart-throbbing experience that will leave a lasting impression. In short, 10/10, would most definitely recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041070313', 'num_games_owned': 192, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 1487, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 753, 'last_played': 1693525447}
review:
It's a masochistically difficult adrenaline-rush rhythm game that left me feeling like I just ran a marathon. It looks incredible, it sounds incredible, and the gameplay is incredible. It admittedly doesn't feel like a rhythm game at many instances since the rhythms are often way too complex to predict accurately, and it instead feels like you're just trying to react to obstacles quick enough that you don't die, and in that sense it feels more like an endless runner than a rhythm game at times.

I admittedly don't understand the obsession that others felt with the aesthetics of this game. It's been mislabeled as horror by several, and people have suggested that it embodies some kind of "wrongness". The atmosphere is definitely somewhat dark and eerie, but it's not a horror game and the aesthetics aren't particularly thought-provoking, so if that was a draw factor, then I would put it aside. If you just want a difficult, loosely rhythm-based, reaction-heavy endless runner type game, then this will appeal to you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047019424', 'num_games_owned': 380, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 163, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1663023139}
review:
I played this game in VR. I've played my fair share of horror games, both in and out of VR. This game didn't make me feel scared, per se, but it gave me a creeping feeling of terror that I haven't experienced in anything else, in any other medium nor in real life. I am not religious in any way, shape or form, but while playing this game I had a primitive, instinctual part of my brain kind of whisper to me "this is the devil." 

So yeah, a damned good rhythm game that feels like you're fighting the great old ones and that Lovecraft was right all along.

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198042319526', 'num_games_owned': 303, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 91, 'last_played': 1615595479}
review:
I've never been a big fan of rythym games, but for some reason, this one really grabbed me. For one the theme of the game is amazing and really interesting, the game looks incredible visually, in the later levels it starts being really insane and there's just so many things flashing on screen, it's simply mesmerizing. The sound design is FANTASTIC, every good thing you do is extremely satisfying because of it. The controls feel amazing, never at one point did I feel like a death wasn't my fault, every action is very well telegraphed and has good visual and sound feedback. 

The game isn't that long, but it's just a fun game to play every so often. at it's base price it's worth it but right now it's on sale, and it's just such a good deal, I can't recommend it enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004918832', 'num_games_owned': 834, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 59, 'last_played': 1704205344}
review:
Super intense rhythm game!

I love the psychodelic visuals. But I'm a little disappointed that the boss enemy of each level is just a 'spooky face'. It's jarring and slightly immersion breaking to see so much abstract weirdness get suddenly thrown out for a clearly humanoid face as a boss enemy. And it's annoying that it's basically the same 'face head' thing as the final boss for every level...

The gameplay is fun though, and the music is awesome.

This is a game that wants to be played on LOUD volume!

author: {'steamid': '76561198027175022', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 576, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 441, 'last_played': 1670886705}
review:
TL;DR: 
Thumper is a stylish and fast paced rhythm game. In many ways it uses your typical rhythm game elements, but it does so in a way that feels unique and fresh. That said, this game is a damn bastard and the difficulty spikes HARD at times. Also, it is SUPER important to have a good controller that you might not mind wearing out the X/A button on.

PROS:
+Shiny visuals
+Interesting enemy and boss design
+Nice rhythm elements (obstacles are the sounds that complements the "beat", not just music tracks)

CONS:
-The difficulty (around level 4/5 there is a noticeable spike)
-Level select (you can select major levels 1-9, but not the 20+ checkpoints per level)

FULL REVIEW:
Thumper has been on my radar for a while now. I've always been interested in rhythm games and play them from time to time. The caveat being I'm no expert on this genre. I can handle myself in games like Beat Saber at a Hard (sometimes Expert) level but anything more than that and my brain just can't handle it. Thumper just kind of naturally progresses to that point as the game goes along. Around level 4/5 there is a noticeable spike in difficulty. I was able to S rank levels 1-3, but quickly gave up after seeing what gets thrown at you in later levels. There's only maybe 5-6 actions you have to do, but the game starts throwing them at you at EXTREMELY high speeds and in brain bending combinations. Around level 8 and 9 things started to get more frustrating than fun, but persevering through all the nonsense felt fantastic.

author: {'steamid': '76561198287842052', 'num_games_owned': 98, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 38, 'last_played': 1561867255}

author: {'steamid': '76561198031349851', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 265, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 217, 'last_played': 1676237736}
review:
Definitely enjoyable as a rhythm game. It's a bit simple compared to other games you'll find out there, but I think that works in its favor. Despite there being fewer gimmicks than your standard fare for rhythm games (or perhaps because of it), the game still packs quite a challenge in the later stages. 

One thing that might turn people off from it is that there are a lot of audio cues that have to be heard over the soundtrack playing. If you can't hear them, you'll be forced to rely on trial and error, and that can be a little rough and sap you of enjoyment. 

And as an aside, you definitely should give the soundtrack a listen before you dive in if you can! The music isn't really what you'd usually get in a rhythm game, and they're straight up not fun if you don't enjoy the music.

review:
VR

GORGEOUS

author: {'steamid': '76561198131775248', 'num_games_owned': 68, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2216, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1954, 'last_played': 1649532652}
review:
Got this game while it was on sale (just as I got everything in my life). So yeah... In Thumper you travel through the void itself as a space beetle, where you mash the space bar on every blue/green square, avoid smashing into evil curves, spikes, centipede snakes, defeat skulls with spikes and try not to anger murderous metallic donuts while desperately restraining from itching yourself. Anyway, this game makes you feel like on drugs, but the good kind. I would definitely recommend Thumper to everyone who enjoy a good challenge unless flashing colors make you sick. Play in the dark or with vr. It's epic.

There are 9 levels in total. After completing them you unlock play+ which contains the same 9 levels except on hardcore mode with light speed and permadeath. You also get to play as a golden beetle there, yay.

Btw please add more levels! I completed everything S rank but I want more!

Conclusion: yes

review:
Straordinario nella sua semplicit√†. Se dovessi descriverlo con un solo aggettivo, sarebbe "ipnotico".
 Visivamente √® affascinante, i livelli trasmettono un senso di imponenza quasi religioso e la musica, di cui il giocatore √® partecipe con i propri movimenti ingame, fa il resto del lavoro. 
Non si sa bene cosa tu stia facendo, perch√® c'√® un insetto spaziale che corre velocissimo su di una sorta di monorotaria galleggiante nel vuoto in un ambiente onirico che deve raggiungere una sorta di testa svolazzante. Ma non importa. Quello che stai facendo √® importante e tutto il resto pu√≤ aspettare. Hai fame? Lo stomaco pu√≤ aspettare. Devi dormire che domani lavori? Hai cose pi√π importanti da fare. Fa cos√¨ caldo che il tuo sudore sta impuzzolendo l'intero visore? Non √® importante. Qualunque cosa tu stia facendo in quella monorotaria deve essere fatta ADESSO.

Per una migliore fruizione del gioco, provatelo per la prima volta dopo esser tornati a casa mezzi sversi per l'alcol. Ma √® molto bello anche da sobri XD

author: {'steamid': '76561198111912384', 'num_games_owned': 499, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 308, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 32, 'last_played': 1642438169}
review:
There has to be some black magic at work that's been preventing any motion sickness in VR. 

But seriously, I watched the programmer's GDC talk about the development of this game, and since then I was itching to give the game a shot. The way the game's engine has been refined over the years was really interesting, and having played Thumper now, I think it paid off. There's something very hypnotic and otherworldly playing it in VR, and I love how monolithic everything seems (I haven't played any VR games yet which create such a sense of scale). The game also has a really smart use of diegetic sound, which I haven't really seen used to this extent in rhythm games before.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074788149', 'num_games_owned': 60, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 115, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 111, 'last_played': 1561813104}
review:
I love this game, I got it on sale, but after playing it I'd gladly have paid full price (But I didn't ! YAY !)

It's hard to describe the game play coupled with the experience; 

It's a Rhythm mechanic based ultra precision interactive music video inspired by gonzo Synthwave fantasy-future aesthetics that I found reminiscent of Rush's 2112 experimental album, Star One - Earth That Was, The Heavy Metal series, The Mirror Universe from Dr.Strange and the fight with Dormamu, or obviously going to a planetariums laser light show absolutely stoned into another dimension.
 
It's like playing a musical instrument that you pulled out of a glowing crystal meteorite that landed in your backyard, that you've never seen before, then suddenly finding yourself in a life or death jam session against the elder evils that dwell in the darkness between the stars. 

I'm pretty sure if you beat this game with a 90% or higher you'll be drafted into some alien war to bring peace to some distant nebula filled with sentient space beetles. This isn't VR, this is first contact, a test to see if we are worthy to make contact with. I will name my beetle wife or husband Janet, I don't know if they have ears though, so I've also prepared a ceremonial hand gesture. My egg spawn will be the next generation of mighty warriors and carry on my legacy. 

Anyway It's a ton of fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042907979', 'num_games_owned': 498, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 34, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1561589979}
review:
This... is unique... This is an... experience.
Never have I felt so exhilarated yet so resoundingly uncomfortable on an instinctual level.
The music and visuals combine to form a journey that cannot be put into words, you have to experience it yourself to truly understand it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009312125', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 127, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 56, 'last_played': 1637124837}
review:
THIS IS NOT A RHYTHM GAME!
This is a journey through an eldritch dimension that hates you and is actively throwing curveballs to try and kill you.

When I say this is not a rhythm game I'm serious. There's no consistent beat you can bob your head to. There's no zone you can get into that will help you feel and predict what's coming next. There is only a constant drumming that acts as a reminder of just how unwelcome you truly are. Patter sequences are largely reaction based and will at times mimic a beat only to immediately break into something else once you get too comfortable.

This is not a game you play before bed to relax. This is a game you grow to hate and actively need to conquer.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970516292', 'num_games_owned': 320, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 31, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1561509488}
review:
Simplistic rhythm game that confuses visual distortion with being interesting. 

Unfortunately, the game focuses harder on being visually difficult to decode instead of focusing on presenting interesting rhythms to emulate and create. 

All in all I bought it on sale and left not even feeling as if I had my money's worth.

author: {'steamid': '76561198090783767', 'num_games_owned': 264, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 906, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 867, 'last_played': 1575040048}
review:
Just going to say that if you have epilepsy or if you struggle with eye pain from staring at the screen too much this game probably isn't for you sadly.

Thumper is an awesome rythm psychedelic fast-paced experience. It requires you to enter a trance like stage if you are like me who likes to get S-ratings at every stage.

I can only explain the soundtrack as a high speed, sinister orchestral score. While not always having a easy to make out rythm in some stages, you will feel immensely satisfied when you can clearly hear it and execute everything perfectly.

The controls are easy to remember and understand, what's hard in this game is reaction skills to hit every note and turn.  As mentioned I like to get S-ratings on every stage, and I am very happy to see the "restart from checkpoint" option which allows you to restart from the current checkpoint you are on if you know you are not going to get an S-rating. Or you can choose the previous checkpoint if you didn't realise you missed a note and need to go back.

One complaint I have is that it is [u] very [/u] hard to make out what's happening when you thump a "super note" from the air, or when you take damage as the color saturation on screen bump up to 1000% when either of these two things happen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080365533', 'num_games_owned': 732, 'num_reviews': 126, 'playtime_forever': 54, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1559531534}
review:
While Thumper looks absolutely stunning, it's sooo weird and cryptic. It's like Groove Coaster but nothing makes sense. I'm at level 3 now and I have so many questions built up and unanswered, I can't even focus on the game itself anymore.

The blocks that I press A on, let's just call them blocks, why are they sometimes green and sometimes blue? I noticed that blocks tend to be more green when I'm fighting a boss, but then blue blocks also appear in these sections, so are they different? Should I care?

Some blocks glow more than others do, let's call them glowing blocks. I noticed that green glowing blocks launch an attack to whatever I'm fighting, and blue glowing blocks often mark the end of levels, but then the same blue glowing blocks also occasionally appear in the middle of levels, among non-glowing blocks. What does the glow mean exactly?

The blue rings. If I hold up and A, my avatar - I assume it's THE thumper - crashes through them and makes a sound effect. If I do nothing, my thumper goes through the rings without getting hurt. Should I just ignore the rings then? What purpose do they serve?

I sometimes see blue little gems to the top-left and top-right of my thumper. Sometimes they just float there, sometimes they get absorbed by my thumper. What are they? What do they do? Are they related to the blue gem counter at the end of levels? Should I get more of them? How do I get more of them?

I sometimes see "1x", "2x" and "3x" on the right side. It tends to go up as I play but drops back to "1x" when I miss something. What is it? Is it good when it says "2x" or "3x"? How exactly do I make it "2x" or "3x"?

The blocks, I press A on them, level 1 told me that. But then level 3 begins and it says nope, that's wrong, actually you should press down on them, and it sends some sort of a shockwave. You need to do that to unlock the lock-ish things that block bosses at times. But it's the same block. So there are 2 ways to deal with a block now? Should I press A or press down? Should I press down when there are locks but press A on other occasions?
developer_response:
Hey! Thanks for the review :)  check out our instruction manual here, it should answer all of your questions:
https://steamcdn-a.akamaihd.net/steam/apps/356400/manuals/ThumperInstructionManual.pdf?t=1543412957

author: {'steamid': '76561197967437557', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1640, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1548, 'last_played': 1559598443}
review:
Trance-inducing. If you have the discipline & patience this game asks of you, the state of mind it can produce is sublime. 

Wonderfully dark industrial tribal drum & bass tracks that reek of atmosphere, amplified by the haunting psychedelic imagery. Rock-solid graphic performance; I have never experienced anything but buttery smooth perfection.

Starts with baby steps and ramps up to blistering mania. Rhythm sections progressively build into more and more complex structures that always seem to maintain an element of organic uncertainty, yet can absolutely be memorized.

Routine checkpoint system with fair scoring. If you find this too managable, there's an extra level of difficulty added with the free 'Director's Cut' update, challenging you to complete entire levels (nine of them, ranging from 10 to 25 minutes), at even higher potential speeds, without exploding (permadeath).

Deceptively simple, razor sharp, delightfully intuitive controls. Subtlety hidden gameplay mechanics taught by suggestion rather than explanation ("I must be missing something, what if I try... oh, snap!"). I agree with the recommendation to play with a gamepad. 

Take care not to blame the game for the sake of your own ego. They call this Rhythm Violence for good reason :D Enjoy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002134811', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 188, 'playtime_forever': 420, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 397, 'last_played': 1559156629}
review:
Thumper is the rhythm game I didn't know I needed. It starts off simple, and quickly ramps up to some seriously challenging action. Progress across the nine levels is divided into smaller stages, which gives you fairly frequent checkpoints. In the later levels you might need many, many attempts to get through one section, especially the bosses. The controls stay simple, and timing is everything. Make a few too many mistakes, and you'll start over from your last gate.

The crazy visuals in this game just elevate the whole experience of the pulsing music and rushing obstacles. The music is mostly percussion, and it focuses on driving the intense atmosphere. I found myself totally transfixed by this game at times, it can really make you focus and zone in to make it through without taking damage. The relief and adrenaline rush of getting through a tough part of a level can feel on par with beating a tough boss in Soulsborne games. If you're the competitive type, there are leaderboards to compete for top scores, adding a whole lot of replayability.

If the aesthetic of the game appeals to you, and you like something to make your heart race, then this game is for you. Highly recommended.

review:
does anyone remember streakloop, the toy from the 80s? you have to be old if you do. 
when i was a child i had a dentist gas trip, i was flying down the streakloop track of infinity to a destination where i was wrapped around a spinning singularity and blasted out into a pain corridor of echoing mirrors. 

welcome to thumper.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013288876', 'num_games_owned': 1732, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 40, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 40, 'last_played': 1553654937}
review:
I was really up for trying this game out and hoping to enjoy it, but no. This just feels to me like another example of a game being hard for being hard's sake. Maybe it's just how my brain is wired but I can't deal with the amount of information it's throwing at me at one go, and the lengths of the levels are tortuous. 15 parts to level one alone is just way too much.

I'll be honest I feel like people who like this game only do because it means they have the bragging rights that other people don't. This just does not feel like fun to me.

And the lack of being able to remap the alternate controls (arrow keys feel far more comfortable for me in this sort of game) is illogical, especially as you got the turning the wrong way round!

author: {'steamid': '76561198053285729', 'num_games_owned': 167, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 128, 'last_played': 1552023915}
review:
I love this game. Bought it for PC, Switch, and my phone. I played the hell out of it and enjoyed every second of it.

But people kept describing it as rhythm "horror." I didn't get it. Sure, it had trippy visuals and got a little Lovecraftian sometimes, but I never thought it was scary, let alone horror.

Then I put on my VR headset.

I have see the face of God and he was screaming.




Good game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198857437927', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 879, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 358, 'last_played': 1705206349}
review:
This game is good; I only played 20 minutes to try it out--I'm not ready to commit and play it all the way through yet (still trying to beat Enter the Gungeon) but it's definitely next on my list.

I thought it would be a rhythm game where you try to match beats, but in Thumper you *create* the beats, hitting obstacles to match the tempo. You have to follow visual and audio cues, so while some effects may be distracting (hitting several blue bits and heading right into a turn) it comes together into a crazy, awesome experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027925242', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 476, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 476, 'last_played': 1550383688}
review:
Thumper pulls you in and doesn't let go. 

It is one of the few games I've played where I actually have to sit back a little and breathe - that's even without VR.. 

The visuals, mixed with the simple, but engaging gameplay that leads to some fun thumb gymnastics or the ability to keep it simple and less stressful combine to make a game that's fun and as challenging as you want it to be. Although I don't usually care about scores, Thumper made me want to try off combos and hit every beat(?) until I was frustrated and had to go on knowing I wasn't ready.

After a complete play-through though, it's really cool to see the tricks and timing I was forced to pull off and could pull off which makes running back through my missed opportunities and stages for S rankings. 

The best part about Thumper? If you aren't great at rhythm games it doesn't really matter. You can hop in for the 4-8 hours of tight gameplay it offers, get sucked in like me and because of the "Action" aspect, not need to time as much as be reactionary or learn the stage's pattern.

My only complaints lie in the difficulty in seeing obstacles at points with how things meshed against the level design as well as gimmicky bits that you can't see coming and almost certainly will lose a few runs until you memorize the pattern.

I loved this experience and hope to see more innovation like Thumper in the Rhythm genre. 

9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198235163508', 'num_games_owned': 502, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 326, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 111, 'last_played': 1672488839}

author: {'steamid': '76561197970502040', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 379, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 379, 'last_played': 1550058472}
review:
I really wanted to like this game, the music and art are very cool. Unfortunately there's an unearned confidence in the legibility of the visual design that makes the difficulty feel unfair. If you didn't see a curve coming because you're in a tunnel, too bad, start all over. I bounced at launch, and then came back a couple years later to give it a second chance. Still nope. This game leaves me feeling anxious and frustrated, and the failures don't feel like my own.

I'm shocked there's no casual mode that removes death and lets me get into a flow without restarting every time some weird rhythm or hidden obstacle kills me. Seems like an easy win for accessibility.

Sorry, Thumper. Your aesthetic rules, but your inflexible game design stresses me out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198263138700', 'num_games_owned': 644, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3607, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2157, 'last_played': 1646349969}
review:
VR Review

This is one of my all time favorite VR games. A VR essential everyone should have. I play a lot of VR games and this one is one of the few that I consistently keep going back to play. It is an older style front facing VR game that requires a game-pad but do not let deter you. This game is amazing and still holds up today. I can spend hours zoning out in this fast paced beautiful world. 

====Issues/Suggestions for improvement====
Game runs smoothly. 0 issues to report 
Is there a Thumper 2 in the future?

====Game Mechanics/Physics====
New mechanics are added gradually every level so as not to overwhelm you but the game really shines once all the game elements are in use. Levels 6-9 I don't think I will ever get sick of replaying.
Tip: If your having trouble with the down smash mechanic introduced in level 5. Try using the d-pad instead of the joystick on your game pad.

====Replay-ability====
Just getting though the levels is one thing. Getting though the levels with a score of S is a challenge. This game has leader boards for those up to the challenge.

Not into the added challenge? This game is fun to just site back, relax and play though a level or two at a time. For me it's been the perfect break game from whatever active VR game I'm stuck on at the time.

====Graphics====
Visually breathtaking and beautiful. I've missed many turns and jumps being detracted by the visuals all around me. 

====Play length====
9 Levels with 20-30 sections each. It takes about 20 to 30 mins per level if you've gotten good enough to play though without dying much. My initial play-though on PSVR took several months to beat. Good amount of content here.

====Physical Activity Level====
0 - Sit down and relax with a gamepad

====Worth buying?====
This game is worth every penny and then some of it's $20 asking price. I've paid full price twice (PSVR and Steam) for this game and have no regrets.

Die Musik k√∂nnte man meiner Meinung nach in Horrorspielen oder √§hnlichem verwenden und ich kann es nicht l√§nger als 30 Minuten spielen ohne mich k√∂rperlich ersch√∂pft zu f√ºhlen aber es macht trotzdem viel Spa√ü zu versuchen auf jedem Abschnitt  einen S-Rang zu erhalten.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028407515', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 4475, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2186, 'last_played': 1598666177}
review:
Do not let the few negative reviews for this game put you off as they aren't very accurate.

The music matches the beat and when it does not, it is INTENTIONAL. Upcoming thumps, turns, rings etc. have specific sounds, letting you know that they are coming up and help with blind corners. The beat of the song actually speeds up and slows down sometimes, causing desynchronization and adding to that sense of dread building as you make your way through a level.

If you are bored, then you obviously haven't made it through very many levels. I say this because each one has its own theme/song. Each stage adds a little bit more, slowly teaching you how to traverse the track until you are able to go back and earn that S rank.

Once you think you have a good grasp of the game, here comes level 5 and teaches you that you've been playing like a toddler the entire time. No I don't mean the speed at which your're traveling or the frequency of maneuvers needed to barely survive. I'll just say that you'll need to go back and play levels 1-4 but use Perfect Turning/flight to combo into your ground slams to get that score up.

The visuals and beats are great with the exception of the recycled skull boss theme. That's just a visual though and doesn't have anything to do with the variety of boss fight mechanics.

For those of you complaining that it takes memorization to make progress, I will not disagree. But why would you want to fumble your way through this game when you could take the time and really enjoy the precision and beauty?

L'√©quilibrage est juste parfait, on a l'impression d'un jeu qui a √©t√© calibr√© et recalibr√© encore et encore pour arriver au plus confortable, plus challenge, plus impreignant, tu dois te concentrer, mais tu peux admirer, tu dois te planter, mais tu peux trouver mieux, plus pr√©cis, plus percutant pour plus de fun.

On te donne le rythme, √† toi de le r√©p√©ter. Et puis juste au moment o√π tu commence √† le comprendre, on t'en retire quelques bribres que tu vas commencer √† compl√©ter, t'en rajouter, t'en insinuer pour que tu r√©pondre naturellement sans r√©fl√©chir.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077251038', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 126, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 85, 'last_played': 1594631922}
review:
If I had one of those dreams that is heavy with dread but mysterious of intent, about being a strange metal beetle racing against impending doom, that dream would be this game. The music is the soundtrack of my deepest but most interesting fears, the kind that you cannot look away from. The visuals are what the inside of my mind looks like when I am almost asleep, but not quite awake.

The controls are simple, but the play is challenging, and finding "the zone" is choosing to stare into the abyss.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985336244', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 175, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 100, 'last_played': 1640262482}
review: Love the music in Thumper. It's not exactly a traditional 'style' of music but if you enjoy cinematic/industrial/'heavy' sounding stuff then you will likely enjoy it. It's clear that the people who made this game put a lot of care into making something that feels 'a bit different' while still being, at it's core, something that is very simple to understand. Very much recommended for people who love atmpospheric audio and appreciate games that make as much effort with the soundtrack as with the visuals and gameplay. And yes - it's challenging and fun too!

author: {'steamid': '76561198387003136', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 419, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 93, 'last_played': 1690522962}
review:
Very simple yet very cool game, music is amazing, it will be much better if you have a sound system that is is good quality. First time I played this was on the demo disc included with the PSVR, it was the game that made me feel less sick and dizzy than the other games included on that disc and was pretty fun. Since then, I moved on and sold my PSVR as I was not using it as much as I wanted to justify its purchase. The other day I found it on sale and was really happy to finally purchase it for my PC.

To sum up, this game is great, music is amazing, and the concept might look a little bit dump at first, it is some sort of bettle that moves along a veryyyy long track, but it gets more and more engaging as you play. I really recommend it! (I haven't tested the VR version on PC, based on the PS version, I assume is great as well.

Side note: The game supports wide screen! I have a 32:9 monitor and looks great. I am really unsatisfied with developers that do not add this mode into their games, how difficult can it be if some modder can do it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003699722', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 167, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 167, 'last_played': 1547877543}
review:
Only 2.4 hours logged, but I'm finding it is best to play in relatively short bursts. Also, this was a recent purchase, and keep in mind, was bought for I think $6 on sale. If I were to have purchased this at full price, for the $20 asking, I can't at all say I'd be disappointed. Very simply presented, yes, as you are a techo-sentient beetle of sorts riding along this resplendent, winding, metallic track - Everything appears hypervivid, simultaneously exploding visions of sublime wonder and chaotic turmoil, being led at nearly impossible speed through unrelenting danger, a hair's edge away from oblivion. So yeah, pretty sick concept and its execution is done to, in my opinion, actual perfection. Running into a game like Thumper is quite a treat, I must say. The gameplay can be challenging to the point of frustration, but does reward diligence and concentration, so I have nothing negative to say about its overall design. It is a pleasure playing this well-conceived of title - Will be very curious what else this developer has in store. [May very well expand this review as I'm genuinely fascinated by Thumper, but would like to progress further before I do that]. Would absolutely recommend. Also, I don't think it hurts to add maybe wishlist the game and wait for its next sale, not because it isn't worth the original asking price, but because of the backlog I'm sure many of you have. I've been ramping up the 'wishlist' and it's actually helped a lot in nabbing good deals from games in my peripheral when I know sales are going on or just randomly scrolling around.

Anyhow - Thumper, yes, do buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976058476', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 174, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 172, 'last_played': 1577758784}
review:
I had fun with this and would have given it a middling score but cant recommend it so its has to be a thumbs down.

The visuals are neat and the core gameplay is good but the things that let it down IMO are; the actions often dont sync with the tune which is kind of a big deal in a "rhythm" game, during the harder times I had to do my best to ignore the sound track and focus on my actions to provide a beat I could play with. 
The second thing is, for a game that for the most part has a very clean simplistic visual appearance there are certain things that add way to much clutter to the screen at the wrong times, like mess up once and they basically blind you, if it happens to be during a complicated portion of the path good luck trying to recover, same for the over charge thing that happens once in a while.
A more minor gripe is that its just the same background track throughout the game (or at least close enough to it that I didn't notice a difference), it would have been nice to have some variation.

It wouldn't have taken much to make it a great game but for now, for me, its just meh.

author: {'steamid': '76561198163723574', 'num_games_owned': 39, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 17183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3339, 'last_played': 1704262829}
review: Absolutely fantastic. Every aspect. The sound design is spectacular, and I often find myself humming the violent metal clanking that's in sync with an other-worldly war drum beat. The visuals will send you into another world. With every stage that you pass, you feel as though you're not supposed to be going this far. That the game is out to get you, and its trying everything in it's power to stop you. Its by far one of the most immersive games I've played, and very cathartic. If I could, I'd give it an 11 out of 10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032632811', 'num_games_owned': 888, 'num_reviews': 758, 'playtime_forever': 1525, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1227, 'last_played': 1703467771}
review:
[h1]It‚Äôs a good thing that the ear is faster than the eye.[/h1]

Thumper is a different type of rhythm game. If anything, it feels more like a fighting game with the level of concentration, execution, adrenaline, and reflexes it demands. When the tribal stomping and surreal visuals awaken a part of the human psyche that‚Äôs ready to deliver on those demands, Thumper becomes a roller coaster.

The soundscape is terrifying. Each level runs in a different time signature which makes for some uncommon sounds. New obstacles feed into the noise as the ‚Äòorchestra‚Äô grows in both size and challenge.

Upon becoming more confident with ‚Äòflying/thumping‚Äô, levels open up and the game loses part of its ‚Äòcall-and-response‚Äô rigidity. The risk/reward in going for points/health requires another channel of thought that enhances your involvement. Like an instrument, you pick up intricacies as you progress.

The game could do without the occasion deafening BGM listen-skill-gates, blinding damage animation, and those out-of-place and repetitive ‚Äòsnakes‚Äô that add nothing to the music and little to the gameplay.

There are only nine levels in the game. While that‚Äôs certainly enough (trust me), it means there‚Äôs no quick way to practice when you‚Äôre stuck since your only option is to dive back into the [i]start[/i] of a previous level. NG+ is an alright extra, but imagine what a procedurally generated ‚Äòendless‚Äô mode would do for replayability.

Thumper is addictively hard to put down. Whenever I revisit the game, I usually lose the afternoon and end up going to bed with mangled thumbs.

[i]It should be noted that the game works exceptionally well in VR: 3D visuals, 360-degree audio, 90 Hertz display, and quick response time. [/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198029929136', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 350, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 191, 'last_played': 1561584958}
review:
Okay, so if you have a VR headset and a controller, you need this game. Let me explain.

Thumper is a rhythm game where you're a bug travelling along a track to dramatic, percussive music. All of your movements sync perfectly with the song, and it feels like you're the one orchestrating the whole thing.
In VR, you really feel the speed of the track, although not in a motion-sickness way. It just all feels very frantic as you hit the input at the last second. That's the reason why this game is so good. I expected to be bored after a few worlds without any new main mechanics, but surprisiingly, It never felt dull because of the feel of the game. 

Now, the story in Thumper is fairly nonexistent, you may piece something small together but probably not. Where the game really stood out is in the boss fights. A giant pyramid appears, and then you start travelling in a seemingly infinite downward curve. Then, the boss slowly comes into view, looming over top of you. All of the bosses are variations of each other, except one, that get increasingly disturbing as the game progresses. By the end I was absolutely terrified as it came into view. The final boss isn't scary, per se, but it introduces a fresh new mechanic that feels really slick, and builds on it until you beat it at its own game.

Overview:
Scary rhythm game with spooky music and really enjoyable core gameplay. Don't play right before ging to sleep.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970314107', 'num_games_owned': 2304, 'num_reviews': 917, 'playtime_forever': 230, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 230, 'last_played': 1547192383}
review:
What does the phrase ‚Äúrhythm violence‚Äù mean to you? Could be a lot of things‚Ä¶ could be beating people up to the beat, could be clobbering clods with a musical instrument, could be composing a song whose notes cause agony. In Thumper, ‚Äúrhythm violence‚Äù refers to the intensity of the action set to absolutely crushing beats, a brutal combination of high-speed maneuvers and pounding music. It‚Äôs a rare title that outstrips the expectations set by such a high-minded presentation, and it manages to pack in just enough challenge and content to make the battle worth it.

I‚Äôm just going to pull from the game‚Äôs own description here: ‚ÄúYou are a space beetle. Brave the hellish void and confront a maniacal giant head from the future.‚Äù That‚Äôs it, that‚Äôs all the plot you get. Thumper has you controlling said space beetle down a nigh-endless track twisting in the nether. The track itself seems to be alive, pulsating with fractal appendages and blistering with spikes. Blasting through the many obstacles along the way will get you to the boss of each level, an evolving skull that seeks to expunge you from the trail. Keeping up with the beat will help you beat him and the mini-bosses you encounter along the way, but each of the nine levels is going to make it harder and harder to hang with the rhythm.

The controls are quite simple, but the moves you‚Äôre expected to pull off with them can become flabbergasting by the finale. You have one button and one stick, and the button triggers panels on the track when pressed and gives you the power to bust through barriers when held. You‚Äôll also need to hold it when you drift along walls, along with the direction you‚Äôre drifting in. You can launch off of panels into the air, and slam back down to clear certain obstacles. All of these mechanics are introduced gradually over the levels, including some more complex ones I didn‚Äôt mention, so the ramp-up of concepts is at least quite manageable. Your beetle is also armored enough to take a hit and keep going, and there are ways to get that free hit back during levels.

Your only real objective is to survive the level, which is usually broken down to twenty or so checkpointed segments. It‚Äôs not too tricky to dodge or drift through everything, at least at first, but you‚Äôre going to want to be hitting all the panels and blowing through all the rings and spikes for points, just to prove your worth in this mad race. There‚Äôs a combo system based on not missing obstacles and chaining jumps and slams together, and once you work out the basics you can add significant flourish to your runs for big points. The score aspect is an important part of the replay value here, since the nine levels are essentially static.

That‚Äôs not much of a knock against the game, considering the content of the levels. On every leg of your journey you‚Äôll have the pulse-pounding soundtrack in your ear, and the spectacle of your space beetle tearing along at impossible speed. The game often feels like Burnout with permanent boost, a barely-controllable rocket of destruction. But you have to control it, and careful reactions are crucial for helping you grind along deadly walls and smash through glowing spikes. Between the undulating background, the intense flashes and explosions of navigating, and the thunderous music that‚Äôs partly produced by your actions, you‚Äôre sure to find yourself utterly focused on your brutal task until your brain fatigues too much to keep up with it.

Thumper is not an easy game, pushing you to the limits of your reflexes by the madcap final level. But conquering its challenges is so, so sweet, accompanied by bursts of sound and color and the accolades of the beat rolling on. It‚Äôs an easy game to pick up, but depending on your skill level it could take anywhere from five hours to a dozen to work your way through. And there‚Äôs even a hard mode that ups the intensity to inconceivable levels and gives you a single life to survive each marathon level with. This is an absolute no-brainer for fans of rhythm games, and lovers of intense action and even some horror fans will find a lot to appreciate in its presentation.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/11322459/]curation page[/url]!

author: {'steamid': '76561198008750465', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 422, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 253, 'last_played': 1678749700}
review:
Thumper is a super fast-paced rhythm game that is quite innovative. Rather than simply bashing blocks or blocking spheres you are treated to an arcade-like racing/adventure experience.

If you ever played Tempest, this is like that on steroids and magic mushrooms. It's very fun and I'm glad to see something that hasn't been done before. The only downside is the use of a controller, but only a small gripe.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987788431', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 29, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29, 'last_played': 1547161409}
review:
The game runs well and has neat visuals. However, the gameplay becomes boring, repetitive, and outright dull quite quickly.

Additionally, I would have wanted more from the VR mode. Playing in VR adds nothing to the experience. This could be aided by adding more visuals to the surroundings... As it stands, you only get the track running behind you - nothing "extra" in your peripherals or rear.

review: pretty fun little rhythm game. a couple things though, the music is repetitive after awhile, and sometimes the beat goes all over the place, making it unpredictable. In one sense, unpredictable is good, but there often is no auditory indicator that something is about to happen, making it a visual connection to make it on beat. Most of the time, you as the beetle are the one making the beat happen. I would have liked to see more indicators so it feels less random. But overall pretty fun game. Would pick up if you like to get hEaDy and its on sale

author: {'steamid': '76561198099052928', 'num_games_owned': 154, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 244, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 66, 'last_played': 1587090379}
review:
So I enjoy this game. it is very fun, and hard. The visuals are very pretty, and I was very immersed.
The only problem I have with this game is the VR mode. 
if you have any form of motion sickness than this game hurts. I personally dont have terrible motion sickness, but playing it with a headach gives the same feeling. 
Also, the controls are not shown to you very well in VR. It gets worse because you cant see your hands in the game.
overall. its a pretty cool game. would not get it for full price tho. Get it off G2A or somthing.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962207750', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 130, 'playtime_forever': 254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 205, 'last_played': 1547491773}
review:
Just to say, negative comments about the sound and game not syncing aren't right from my experience.

If you make an error, then yes of course it all goes out and you get no help from the music in that... you're in trouble.

But if you keep it clean then you find it all clicks and you go faster too.

But it's a game, so there is literally the odd curve thrown in without a musical clue. But that's the challenge, keep your eyes and ears open.

Had this on my wishlist for ages, finally sprung for it at the right time and price. Fun :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197988883421', 'num_games_owned': 911, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 735, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 114, 'last_played': 1579735692}
review:
Wow, this is one of the best game i have bought in a while! It's easy to play and hard to master! The incredible Design is the absolute 10 / 10 for me! Abstract Worlds that melt together the Evironment, Rythm and You! I think even tho there have been a few Rythm-Type-Games, this one is very unique! Dont rate the game based on a screenshot or a video, because if you play it yourself, it will absorb you into its crazy abstract world! 

I NEVER thought a 500MB game could deliver in such a BIG way! Heavily recommended!
