author: {'steamid': '76561198001401028', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1089, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 265, 'last_played': 1555788879}
review: Intense, exhilarating, awesome.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062712916', 'num_games_owned': 296, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 1077, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 978, 'last_played': 1551756874}
review: The game feels amazing, and I think the pacing of the content is really good. Every level teaches you something new or introduces some spin to the base concept, and the game has a lot of cool surprises up its sleeve. Completing this game took a lot of time and effort. 16 hours, most of which were really tense praying I would survive. I think the $20 point would probably feel like a bit too much for a lot of players, but for $10 or 15 it would be a great value.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029446778', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 119, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 119, 'last_played': 1546491696}
review:
take "rhythm" out of the tags.
Half of the charts from levels 1-3 (as far as I got before requesting a refund) are not synced to the music. For half of the levels, it appears as though the developers threw cool patterns into random spots.
The fact that your action takes a second to actually activate also detracts from everything. Instead of trying to react to things quickly, I end up holding down action a lot and replaying maps multiple times until I memorize them... Sightreading being impossible is not an indicator of a good rhythm game imo.
It's a shame cause this game is fucking amazing in every other regard

review: This game has a serious issue when it comes to speed. The game speed is so fast it is impossible to judge what comes next when weaving through the colour overload exploding in your face.  It takes 2 hits for you to die before starting the level over and during the first hit there is so much going on the screen that you cannot focus especially with such a speed and this is only on the third world (1 hour in the game). Sorry but I had to refund, the music did not align and it disorients me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994535505', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 138, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 138, 'last_played': 1546257788}
review:
BLUF: Great idea and occasionally feels good but is too hard, and not in an enjoyable way. A rhythm game, but you have to ignore the music?

I think this is probably going to come off as a butthurt review because I need to 'git gud' at this hard game. I love rhythm games and I love hard games - when they are fair. When I play Cuphead or Meatboy or Dark Souls and I die, I can go 'oh damn, I was supposed to be doing that and I wasn't'. In Thumper, you will press what you are positive are the right buttons at the right times, and you will die over and over. It will not be clear what you are doing wrong. Then you get to do the whole level again. Mess up at the same spot again because you still don't understand why the rhythm is wrong? Guess what start again and you've got the whole level to worry about that split second you get to try and work out why you went wrong. The game sucks when you are not doing well. I think the music is actually UNhelpful. When I've had stretches doing well and hitting the beats, and kind of get into it and the music, then I always end up messing up. You have to listen for the ting of the bits you've got to hit, not the actual music.

Also, if the deaths were like Hotline Miami (another game I love) where you're just up and doing straight away, then that would be fine. You can play through the fun part of the level up to where you died and try and work out the mistake - go in slower, scout it out, try a different approach. But not in Thumper. Black screen and slow slow restart into the level again, and you're desperately trying to make sure you ace the level and keep your health so you can maybe just power through the part you went wrong. A lot of the deaths feel very cheap too. I don't know if it's my eyesight (I have astigmatism) but it was almost impossible to see the corners in the tunnels - especially if in quick succession. Now I just press the opposite arrow after every corner just in case. At least you're not punished for that.

Maybe I'll try and finish it but it's out of spite more than enjoyment.

review:
PRESSION, IMMERSION, ABSOLUTION. 

Mettez un bon kit audio avec ce jeu, l'important c'est de bien ressentir les basses qui donnent le rythme et participe √©norm√©ment √† l'immersion et la pression impos√©e par le jeu. Vous comprendrez vite tout le sens de l'absolution dans ce jeu, vos erreurs ne seront que de fausses notes dans le rythme, la difficult√© est l√† elle se ressent mais n'est pas du tout punitive on a envie d'essayer et r√©essayer, chaque nouvel essai est transparent, pas de bouton √† appuyer, pas de game over, pas de vie, on r√©essaie en illimit√© et on se laisse emport√© par le jeu. J'ADORE ! Aucun regret et je n'ai pas encore essay√© en VR, quand je l'ai test√© sur mon √©cran j'√©tais d√©j√† envout√© par le jeu, h√¢te de voir ce que √ßa donne en VR ! :D 

A acheter les yeux ferm√©s, obtenu √† -70% aux soldes Steam, c'est LA BONNE AFFAIRE et LA TROUVAILLE pour moi.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042740819', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 154, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 100, 'last_played': 1599554988}
review:
(review based on playing through first full stage including omega) Game play fast and smooth in both 2-D and VR modes, using a WMR HMD. I didnt initially think I would enjoy this games simplistic control style, but it's all the better for it for when things start getting dicey you need to be able to concentrate on a few key moves.

Sound is of course trancey and engaging and I didnt find an issue with syncing with the beat(s) , like some people have stated. Overall a satsisfying game and "experience"...Have you ever been experienced? I have.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053661434', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 485, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 474, 'last_played': 1546140161}
review:
I really wanted to like this game, but it isn't quite right.

First off, the rythm of the music doesn't always align with the actual button pressing you're doing, which can be extremely obnoxious/disorienting. Even having the beats one second separated from what you're doing can ruin your rythm. Due to this I eventually took to playing muted. It was easier to judge the pattern based off of the vibrations of the controller and the visuals alone, as the music ultimately became a distraction.

You can imagine how bad of a problem this is for a fast-paced rythm game.

Worsening things is the (unintended?) penalty for taking damage. You can take two hits; one that destroys your shell and one that then kills you. The first hit that you take also 1) clouds the screen with some debris  2) tints everything red and  3) slows the game down for a few moments. The overall effect is that it becomes extremely hard to see what you need to press next and your rythm is completely ruined by the sudden slow-mo. This means that one hit often becomes two right away, killing you almost instantly. This is in spite of a brief period of invulnerabilty, which goes away faster than the visual effects do. Some levels in the late game more or less require perfect runs because of this, as the moment you take your first hit you're blinded and at the mercy of whatever hazards were right ahead.

Ultimately, these two flaws alone are fatal for a lightning quick rythm game. They really hold back what was an otherwise compelling experience. I look forward to one day seeing a game like Thumper with better aligned music and a better sense of how to implement damage/penalties. So, I guess "Thumper but good."

Most DEFINITELY do not buy at full price. I got it for $6 and I still feel let down. I might have recommended it if it had cost me $3 or thereabouts

author: {'steamid': '76561198062699365', 'num_games_owned': 253, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 2306, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 771, 'last_played': 1638453515}
review:
Thumper is challenging and thematically rewarding, but there's some quality of life stuff missing that should be standard in fast-paced, precision based games like this. In games where you are going to be restarting a lot (and you are going to be restarting a lot), the lack of a bindable quick restart button is disappointing. Even worse is when the restart option is multiple buttons away in the menu and that menu does not respond as quick as the game, making for multiple times where you are trying to restart but keep resuming because it's not picking up your inputs fast enough.

Just a few minor gripes about an otherwise fantastic game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065372468', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 175, 'playtime_forever': 459, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 361, 'last_played': 1668223918}

author: {'steamid': '76561198053102631', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 123, 'playtime_forever': 60, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 47, 'last_played': 1562062956}
review: Personally not a fan so far. The music gets grating before each level ends and doesn't really mesh with the gameplay as you'd expect. Gameplay feels a bit more like Simon says than a rhythm game; most of the time each action is coreographed by sounds seemingly overlayed on top of the music track, then the player repeats the sequence a second or so later. Occasionally the game will throw in an extra note without coreographing it first to keep the player on their toes. As a result, it doesn't really feel like you're playing the music or creating the music, just repeating a sequence over and over again with slight variations. The visuals are pretty cool, though. It's not a terrible game, but the gameplay and music aren't very engaging.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010996493', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 3309, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2897, 'last_played': 1692566354}
review:
I've played a lot of rhythm games over the past couple of decades, but this is the first one I've ever really just lost myself in (thanks VR). It's unforgivingly challenging at certain points without ever feeling cheap (there are audible and visual context clues of sorts to let you know what's coming), so when you lose your shield or your beetle is destroyed, you can basically chalk it up to being your own fault.

It took me around 15 hours to get S ranking on every standard level. You can see how much I've continued to play the game beyond that. I keep coming back, even if for no other reason than to attempt new combo chains and try to boost my score up just a little further beyond where it currently sits.

I still haven't beaten Level 9+ yet. No checkpoints hurts my soul, BUT IT HURTS SO GOOD.

Easily 10/10 for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198351380326', 'num_games_owned': 344, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 3398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1192, 'last_played': 1702706445}
review:
I am one of those stupid people who thought this was a pod racing game until i played it. the gameplay felt too oriented to the soundtrack i realized the track and the song was one in the same. at this point i think i am the only stupid one. 

i was never much into rhythm games, but thumper is so unique, with it's own style of aggressive soundtrack which will get you hooked for hours.

you take on the role of a metallic beetle, which is blazing fast and runs on a track which twists and turns when you play the music according to what you hear. but this is "rhythm violence" so you're the anti-christ, the bringer of death with the game doing all in its power to stop you.

eerie, scary soundtrack which will keep you on your toes and will make you feel powerful at the same time, there was one time in the boss fights where the beat becomes so good it's the symphony of a real battle.

shiny graphics. oh yeah, this game is shiny. and beautiful, and terrifying.

the game is worth it. on its full price. you may still enjoy it if you don't like rhythm games, even I didn't like rhythm games until i played thumper.

beetles/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197989742076', 'num_games_owned': 345, 'num_reviews': 170, 'playtime_forever': 3322, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3205, 'last_played': 1605413310}
review: A twisted, intense, sound warped journey through the 3rd dimension. Thumper remains as one of my favorite games, and I've played through countless of all types. The visuals, the intense, fast-paced gameplay, and the sound all combine perfectly into what I look for in my ideal video game. Please, please put out a sequel.

review: I originally played this on PSVR and absolutely loved it. The game is addictive and fun in normal 2D but in VR its mind blowing.  Its essentially a rhythm game where you time specific hits while travelling down a tunnel. It sounds weird but its bloody brilliant! I completed the whole game on the PS4 and wanted to experience it on the PC on Oculus Rift. The graphical fidelity is definitely improved and its just such a fun game to play. One of the best VR games ive played and this doesnt cause nausea either which is a major plus! Highly recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561198096789925', 'num_games_owned': 794, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1569, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1419, 'last_played': 1705562911}
review:
The most intense rhythm game I have ever played. Thumper is an absolute blast from start to finish. 
This game manages to captivate in ways that many other conventional rhythm games are unable to. Its a rollercoaster, a frightening one, where any mistake could be your last. This is survival horror disguised as a music game.

Its a short game, containing only 9 levels, but each level is increasingly more difficult than the last. You'll be sure to spend hours trying to perfect this game if that's your kind of thing. And if you didnt hate yourself enough, the game has an even more difficult Play+ mode, where everything is even less forgiving.

Thumper is not for the faint of heart, but if you enjoy rhythm games, i would say its absoultely worth the experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072010737', 'num_games_owned': 1215, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 461, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 122, 'last_played': 1642102663}

author: {'steamid': '76561198073750945', 'num_games_owned': 1264, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 686, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 582, 'last_played': 1692726049}
review:
Me encanta la saga de Rhythm Paradise, pero este Thumper ha hecho que vea los juegos r√≠tmicos desde otro punto de vista. Ya no lo veo como algo que suene bonito, sea vistoso o simplemente pegadizo, sino por la experiencia que brinda Thumper.

¬øY qu√© es la experiencia Thumper?

La importancia de la geometr√≠a y los fractales, una experiencia psicod√©lica infinita.
La importancia de la dificultad. El hecho de ir aprendiendo poco a poco, perfeccionando cada uno de tus movimientos.
La importancia de las pesadillas y su terror absoluto.
La importancia del sonido. Un sonido que infunde terror y agobio, pero no deja de ser r√≠tmico.

Una experiencia √∫nica, diferente e incre√≠ble. Muy recomendado para jugar con auriculares.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056180145', 'num_games_owned': 324, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 529, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 29, 'playtime_at_review': 392, 'last_played': 1711333735}
review:
[b] Epilepsy Warning: There are many flashing neon lights throughout the game [/b]

Thumper, while it has the visual appearance of an on-rails racing game, is at its core a rhythm game, much like Audiosurf. As a consequence, the game flows excellently and benefits from precisely tuned level design and mechanics; as of yet I have not seen anything that even approaches a bug in the gameplay or a defect in the visuals. On the other hand, however, audio cues are absolutely vital to gameplay, and I can imagine that it would be nearly impossible to play higher levels with the sound turned off.

Each level that you progress through will introduce new movement mechanics and musical motifs, making a very gradual rise in difficulty that thankfully avoids spikes and frustrating stages. A few of the movements, like slams, are extremely precise and are difficult to do if using a joystick, but they are thankfully rare and only really become a problem in bossfights.

Overall, the game is really well designed and relatively short to get through, and while I don't see it as having much replay value due to its nature as a rhythm game with no ability to play new stages once you've completed it all, I think the experience of the first playthrough alone is plenty fun enough for the price.

review:
I got this on sale for 70% off so I had a lower bar set just a heads up, read a few other reviews for a better idea.

Awesome game besides these things:
1. Visuals were over the top and distracting at times
2. Some sound cues were hard to make out, as I played I got better at hearing them though
3. If you want lots of content from this game, you need to go for S ranks. If you breeze through it it will seem short.

Everything else was good. 8/10: If you like rhythm games, give this a try.

review: This game is stunningly beautiful. To be honest, it is not always perfectly clear what you are supposed to do, but really, who cares. Everything is moving, you rush at a great speed somewhere up (or forward?), the music and special effects put you in a trance. Overall, great experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198107279702', 'num_games_owned': 153, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 805, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 533, 'last_played': 1655407599}
review: Thumper is truly a rollercoaster of a game. It's slow build up of showing you how it works within its first levels. And it decends into a whirl wind of madness and difficulty. It's fast pace gameplay keeps you are you toes, and with something new being thrown into each level and each level having its own beat.  It keeps the game refreshing and a challenge to master. Along with the beautiful, unique, and trippy visuals, the moments where thumper slows down and shows you the beauty of it's self is a nice touch and is used very well it just a few spots. While my only complaint is the thumper only lets you do things at it's own pace. Meaning that you can't be a quick as you can be, you can only be as fast as the game allows you to be. But with how fast some levles are, this problem doesn't a rise much at all. And this leads up, to a great rythem game experience.

review:
Thumper is a rhythm game with a slight twist to the normal formula. 
The music is a more stripped down almost raw sound that with the visuals pulls you into the strange world of Thumper.
The better you do the more challenging the level becomes as the speed ramps up.

A definite must if you're looking for a fresh take on rhythm based games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026840458', 'num_games_owned': 1359, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 949, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 581, 'last_played': 1653069054}
review:
Have you ever wanted to try LSD but weren't able to afford it? Then come closer, I have something that might interest ya.

Thumper is a trip. A rhythmic, psychedelic, unsettling trip.

You are a bug, on a mission. What is your mission? Hell if I know, but what do I care, you have to move on, they are watching, they won't wait. You can do it, little guy.

What am I even saying anymore? The game is great. It really gives you a creppy atmosphere rhythm games don't usually have. It's simple to understand and it gets harder and more intense as it goes on, as always with these types of games. This one, however, can be very unforgiving at times. Only pr0 g4m3rz allowed.

I haven't tried all levels yet, I'm on level 6 of 9, each levelis divided in a bunch of part with checkpoints in between, so that should entertain you for a bit. Haven't heard that much variety when it comes to music scores though, but I still find the overall music tracks very satisfying to play! 

This rhythm game is simple but sweet, it knows what to do and it does it well.

Overall I give this game 8/10 trips to hell.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036171667', 'num_games_owned': 451, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 2144, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1036, 'last_played': 1600855755}
review:
"[...] it's like you're on a motorcycle at midnight, no lights but somehow you don't need them, blasting out along a cliff-high stretch of coast highway, so fast that you hang there in a cone of silence, the bike's thunder lost behind you. Everything, lost behind you. [...] Amazing. Freedom and death, right there, right there, razor's edge, forever." - Excerpt from The Winter Market, by William Gibson.

Thumper's not quite that visceral. But it certainly is angry. It throws you down that cold steel track at a million miles an hour, and plays its rhythm on the devil's own drumset. You clang off of corners like a pinball, a sharp metal on metal sound as your shell sends sparks into the nothingness. Smash through a barrier like a hammer through bone. Leap a set of spikes and slam down on the far end, sending a rippling shockwave along the track that makes the tendrils that grow there scream and wither...

Something I quite like about the score grading system here is that it allows for various levels of play: the newcomer, who holds down A and prays as they're violently smacked into the walls, but still comes out alive (this was me, when the speed and difficulty started ramping up around level 5 or so), the adept, who is willing to actually play to the beat and try for some cool scores, the arcade heroes, who are out for that highscore spot and pull off crazy back to back perfect turns and smashes and mid-air clangs off of the guardrails... I don't think I've ever gripped my controller quite as tight as in those moments of pure stunt trickery.

It's a wonderful and terrifying experience. Some of the levels might feel dragged out at times, but it makes for a better learning curve. There might not be enough mechanics for some among you, but I think the relative simplicity lets Thumper focus on what it already has. Mastery and highscores will keep the content-hungry satiated. If you're of strong will and a hellish attitude, buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012929961', 'num_games_owned': 382, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 96, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 96, 'last_played': 1540692619}
review: Visuals too distracting to allow the player to actually see what they're supposed to do, and the audio cues are drowned out by other sound effects. The actions didn't seem to complement the background "beat" in my opinion. Even when I was able to flawlessly execute a certain sequence, I didn't get the same satisfaction I got when I did the same in other rhythm based games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057533179', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 115, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 115, 'last_played': 1540445227}
review:
I love music, I love Audiosurf, and I was pretty sure I would love Thumper but boy was I dissapointed. And it wasn't a case of just 'I didn't like it as much as I thought I would', I REALLY didn't like it. I'm surprised by how overrated this game is, perhaps its the novelty factor?

First of all, I expected the gameplay actions to be synced with the music, this being a preset thing and all. This is barely the case - sure there is a degree of syncronisation between the actions and music but there are a lot of random actions that don't feel lined up with the soundtrack in any significant way. Far too often I had to memorise and time my actions while trying to ignore the music, because it would throw me off when I based my timing on the musical beat.

As far as the music goes, what you hear in the trailer is pretty much all you're gonna hear. Lots of quiet droning parts too. I actually listen to a fair bit of drone music, but there is definitely a limit as to how much of that fits in a rythm game. The music gets very boring very quickly. The gameplay actions are boring. The visuals are novel but also get very boring. All round... a very boring game, I'm sad to say. 

If you're here for the music, you're better off just sticking to Audiosurf, which has lots of different game modes and you can choose your own music. If you're here for gameplay... I can't actually think of many recommendations but I would personally also go to Audiosurf. It definitely isn't perfect as far as rythm syncing goes, but it often does a very good job of matching game speed to the differently paced parts of a song, and the track undulations do a much better job of making you 'feel' the music than Thumper does. If you're here for the visuals, just watch some gameplay videos until you get bored.

Its a no from me for Thumper, unfortunately.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037471001', 'num_games_owned': 315, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 98, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 98, 'last_played': 1540177331}
review: The levels are too long for their own good. Of course you want more game, but the 15-20 or so minutes it takes to beat a single level is ridiculous. Why didnt they split them up? I found myself basically dozing off half way through level 4, since it was so repedetive. By the time I got to the boss of level 4, I wanted to just stop playing already! I played in VR, and it definately looks very cool especially the mini bosses (I thought the actual bosses would be cool like the first, but its just the same design slightly changed). The "soundtrack" is basically nonexistant aside from the drums and low synth, and the sounds of the gameplay cues which are in every track. I bought it on sale for 5 dollars and I absolutely think its worth that much. Would not reccommend full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992391928', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 505, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 373, 'last_played': 1542541573}
review:
After spending hours with the Switch, PC and VR versions, I'm confident in saying that Thumper is one of the finest rhythm games ever made. Much like the pounding music, and visuals that oscillate between hellish and psychedelic, the game's mechanics and speed seem overwhelming at first. But the more you play, the more the game's audiovisual cues nudge you towards mastering the (literal) twists and turns of Thumper's intricate note highways.

While song-based Rhythm games like Rock Band utilize a largely static set of rules, Thumper's stages constantly find intersting ways to evolve or modify the experience; shields need to be destroyed before a boss is vulnerable to attacks, a laser-equipped sentry penalizes your for missing notes, and worms invade the highway forcing you to switch lanes. 

Thumper is beautiful, visceral and rewarding. As soon as you make it to the end of a stage with a perfectly timed ground pound, you'll fall in love with this outstanding rhythm game.

review:
Thumper ofrece al usuario una forma rapida de... ¬øMatar el tiempo?
 Permitanme resumirlo: Hermosos detalles, musica genial, jugabilidad perfecta y adictiva, y lo mejor de todo, es capaz de ofrecerle un desaf√≠o al jugador con pocas mecanicas. Por ejemplo, la saga Souls es reconocida por plantearle al jugador un infierno, donde debe acostumbrarse a que morir puede llegar en cualquier momento, pero debido a la complicidad del juego no es siempre disfrutable, a veces solo quieres relajarte, disfrutar de musica y divertirte jugando a un juego que te proponga un reto pero sin irse al otro extremo. Thumper permite ser disfrutado en cualquier momento. Personalmente ame este juego por esos peque√±os detalles que lo brindan de un carisma como pocos. Cien porciento recomendable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032654445', 'num_games_owned': 387, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 713, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 537, 'last_played': 1631532765}
review:
I stayed up until 6.30am the first time I played this because I was so blown away I couldn't sleep.

This is, to me, the best game ever made.
It has everything I could ever want from a game - sweet visuals, simple yet deep controls, tight gameplay, a wicked soundtrack, and amazing sound design.

VISUALS: A wonderous, nightmarish acid trip with some nice non-euclidian stuff going on. Play it in VR if you can.
CONTROLS: You literally only use the left analog stick and either A/X or RB/R1. That's it. Somehow this still feels like a lot to keep track of when you're playing.
GAMEPLAY: This is one of those games where you know with certainty, every time you die, that it was your fault. It's so incredibly responsive, and every action you take gives you clear feedback.
SOUNDTRACK: I never knew I wanted a rhythm game with a noise rock/ambient electronic soundtrack, but here we are, and it's stunning.
SOUND DESIGN: The incidental sounds of this game are actually part of the sountrack, almost more so than the music itself. Slamming down on a final note in a boss battle feels like something from Lethal League, with a massive riser emphasising the hit lag before the shot goes rocketing down the track.

Thumper makes you feel terrified and incredibly powerful all at once, and I love it. Get it at full price, it's so worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067389027', 'num_games_owned': 333, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 886, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 115, 'last_played': 1667157046}
review:
[i][NB : √©valuation √©crite apr√®s une partie compl√®te sur la version Nintendo Switch][/i]


J'ai pass√© un excellent moment sur Thumper.

Petit jeu de rythme assez particulier, Thumper est dot√© d‚Äôune personnalit√© vraiment forte : Thumper est sombre, Thumper est violent, Thumper est jouissif.

Alors bien entendu, on ne parle pas de violence √† base de meurtres et de sang, mais de rythme, de percussions, de sonorit√©s et de vitesse.

Je vous invite vraiment √† regarder le trailer qui donne tr√®s bien le ton. Le joueur incarne ici un scarab√©e qui suit un rail et devra valider tout un tas d‚Äôobstacles pour ne pas y laisser sa carapace.
Artistiquement, c‚Äôest √† la fois intense et fascinant. C'est "juste" un jeu de rythme, mais dans le genre il se d√©brouille tr√®s bien, virant parfois √† l‚Äôhypnotique tellement passer les obstacles devient au bout d‚Äôun moment un r√©flexe animal, captur√© que l‚Äôon est par ces sonorit√©s √† base de drums et d'ambiances √©lectroniques inqui√©tantes, tandis que de leur c√¥t√© les interactions du joueur prennent la forme de bruitages tr√®s violents qui donnent un peps fou √† l‚Äôensemble. Comment ne pas devenir addict devant une telle proposition ?

Les obstacles consistent √† activer des pastilles bleues, prendre activement des virages, faire des sauts, √©viter des obstacles, atterrir sur des points pr√©cis‚Ä¶ 
Bien entendu, chaque obstacle r√©pond √† un mouvement cl√© : action + cot√©, action + saut, bas‚Ä¶ Rien de bien compliqu√© sur le papier et c‚Äôest tant mieux : un gameplay accessible √† tout un chacun sera toujours un atout.
Apr√®s, c‚Äôest la mani√®re dont le jeu va demander de sortir ces actions qui va faire tout le sel de la partie. Si le d√©but est plut√¥t simple, vous comprendrez petit √† petit que plus on avance, plus les enchainements se font fourbes, et plus la vitesse du scarab√©e augmente. En r√©sulte un gameplay devenant tr√®s exigeant voire technique, malgr√© sa simplicit√© de prise en main. En un mot, le cocktail parfait. 

Le jeu est structur√© en 9 mondes, chaque monde contenant entre 15 et 30 niveaux (= checkpoints) et √©tant ponctu√© de quelques mid-boss et d‚Äôun boss final. Les boss demandent √† √™tre √©limin√©s en leur balan√ßant 4 ondes de choc, correspondant √† autant de s√©quences. Chaque onde ne peut sortir qu'√† la condition de faire un perfect sur ladite s√©quence. Si sur les niveaux normaux les pastilles sont bleues, chez les boss elles sont vertes. Tant que les pastilles √† d√©gommer restent vertes, c‚Äôest qu‚Äôil n‚Äôy a pas d‚Äôerreur. Si les pastilles deviennent bleues, c'est qu‚Äôune pastille a √©t√© rat√©e, et donc la s√©quence enti√®re sera √† refaire et tournera en boucle jusqu'√† ce que le joueur y arrive. Si on y arrive du premier coup, une pastille bonus redonnera un bouclier s‚Äôil est perdu.
Pour les mondes normaux, louper une pastille ne sera pas grave (√† part pour le combo et pour le score, bien √©videmment) : √ßa n‚Äôemp√™chera pas de finir le niveau.
Bref √ßa a l‚Äôair compliqu√© dit comme √ßa, mais c‚Äôest super sympa √† jouer manette en main.

Une fois les 9 mondes boucl√©s, il existe √©galement un New Game + pour faire durer le plaisir, mais il reste accessoire : 0 checkpoint, r√©cup√©ration de son bouclier perdu possible seulement au multiplicateur maximal (qui passe pour l‚Äôoccasion de x3 √† x4), etc.

En comptant principalement le jeu de base + un chouilla de NG+, je me suis occup√© dessus 45h, ce qui est loin d‚Äô√™tre n√©gligeable.

Apr√®s le jeu n‚Äôen est pas parfait pour autant. 

Le principal reproche que l‚Äôon pourrait lui faire est celui d‚Äôune certaine confusion sur sa mani√®re de communiquer avec le joueur. Personnellement j‚Äôai accroch√© donc je me suis investi et j‚Äôai fini par tout comprendre √† la longue, mais pour un nouveau venu qui joue √† la cool, il peut exister quelques obstacles :
- Les r√®gles pour commencer, qui ne sont pas forc√©ment tr√®s claires les premi√®res fois que l'on tombe dessus. Certains patterns peuvent faire paniquer et hurler au hasard alors qu‚Äôen fait, il y a toujours une solution. Par exemple, un pattern oblige √† prendre les virages √† la derni√®re microseconde pour se valider, et un son -discret- indique lorsque c'est OK : √ßa personne ne le dit, il faut t√¢tonner pour le comprendre ;
- De la m√™me mani√®re, ces virages pris √† la derni√®re seconde jouent √©galement sur le score. C‚Äôest en d√©couvrant que je pouvais atteindre le grade S+ (au-dessus de S, donc) juste en jouant dessus que j‚Äôai d√©couvert √ßa ;
- Quelques soucis de lisibilit√© √©galement dans certains tunnels ou d√©nivel√©s (surtout dans les derniers mondes o√π √ßa va tr√®s vite), n√©cessitant de pas mal connaitre le niveau pour anticiper les points critiques. Mais apr√®s √ßa, c'est tous les jeux j'ai envie de dire ;
- J‚Äôai not√© un pattern compl√®tement sous exploit√©. Pour bien comprendre, √† chaque nouveau monde le jeu nous instruit sur des nouvelles m√©caniques afin de pouvoir les placer √† l‚Äôenvi sur toute la suite de la partie. Sauf pour le vol long : on gal√®re pour l‚Äôapprendre (oui car encore une fois le tutoriel ici n‚Äôest pas d‚Äôune limpidit√© exemplaire), on est ravi quand enfin on le maitrise puis‚Ä¶ plus rien. De tout le jeu. Ca sent l‚Äôid√©e impl√©ment√©e √† la derni√®re minute mais sans suite sur le produit fini (manque de temps ?). 

Enfin, pour √™tre tout √† fait complet et objectif, petit b√©mol sur le manque de vari√©t√© concernant l'ambiance visuelle. Une atmosph√®re psych√©d√©lique et abstraite pourquoi pas, mais √ßa tourne un peu en rond de ce c√¥t√©, c'est dommage. Je pense qu‚Äôon pouvait rester dans le th√®me tout en explorant des choses nouvelles par monde.
Et c‚Äôest un peu le m√™me discours cot√© sonore. Sans aller jusqu‚Äô√† r√©clamer forc√©ment une musique digne de ce nom, mais au moins s‚Äôil pouvait exister une ambiance sonore plus appuy√©e, comme le jeu sait pourtant en offrir parfois (mais trop rarement), rendant ces moments d‚Äôautant plus exceptionnels.

Bref je ne suis pas tr√®s rythm-games, mais malgr√© ses petits couacs celui-ci m'a bien plu, de par ses sensations in√©dites, sa tr√®s forte personnalit√© et le r√©el sentiment de satisfaction lorsqu‚Äôon r√©ussit un run parfait.

Une r√©ussite !

review: O jogo tem uma premissa fant√°stica, por√©m conforme v√£o passando as fases, voc√™ percebe que ao inv√©s de usar o ritmo da m√∫sica para avan√ßar, voc√™ acaba memorizando as sequ√™ncias. author: {'steamid': '76561198115430638', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 82092, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4827, 'last_played': 1701129174}
review:
Phenomal game for those looking for a challenge. Thumper is touted as a rhythm-violence game and boy does it not disappoint. The intense drum tracks, metallic noises from crashing off turns, and the atmosphere really drive home the feel of "you do not belong in this world. Try to survive".
Definitely would recommend a stereo system with good bass capabilities or a quality headset for full audio immersion.

Great replay value across all 9 stages. S rank is already quite tough, and then doing S+ in the Play+ mode is even harder. there's always room for improvement. Try for high scores on the online leaderboards too!

WARNING: you will legit get mentally tired and even feel exhausted after playing an entire level nonstop due to the high stress in puts on your reactions and visual perception. Do not play this game if you are photosensitive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002898010', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 286, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 286, 'last_played': 1539550844}
review: An incredible audio-visual experience. Thoroughly enjoyed it, kept me entertained for 4-5 hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068816831', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 361, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 224, 'last_played': 1548910794}
review:
Thumper is such an amazing game with beautifully psychedelic graphics, a kickass soundtrack (something absolutely necessary for a Rhythm game),  and incredibly fast-paced gameplay. The simplicity of a game like this makes it so much fun to play. Im only on level 3 and nothing has gotten stale or repetitive. It seems that each level has something fresh to add to the table. 

I recommend this for people who not only enjoy rhythm games but also game that dont mess around and punish you for mistake while also rewarding you for trying harder. Finishing each level and hitting every note feels so good as the the music beats along to each button you press or move you make from side to side or up and down. Everything flows perfectly.

 I would highly recommend a controller because the movements you make are very similar and I personally would think doing the, on a keyboard would start to get uncomfortable.

review:
Have you ever asked yourself "I wonder what AudioSurf would be like if I took like 400ug of acid beforehand and played it to the tune of the devil beating me over the head with war drums?" You haven't ever wondered that? Too bad, Thumper exists anyway. 

And it's somehow even more fun then you would imagine. 

PS, ignore that thing it says about absolutely needing a controller. It plays just fine on a keyboard and I greatly prefer it that way.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116637933', 'num_games_owned': 1372, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 198, 'last_played': 1692180942}
review:
I probably should wait until I have completed the game, but I just don't want to wait!

Basically, [b]you know a game is great when failing only makes you excited to try again![/b]

[i]Thumper[/i] with its amazing soundtrack, surreal and unique art style and challenging gameplay does exactly that. The concept isn't anything new, but [i]Thumper[/i] takes an approach to it that I personally haven't seen before. Levels get noticeably more difficult as you progress through the game, but that doesn't mean that not everybody can complete it. The game offers a variety of playstyles, ranging from the perfectionist who wants to hit every perfect turn to the casual gamer who enjoys getting emerged in this virtual world.

The price tag may be seen as a bit too high, so I recommend maybe waiting for a sale. But if you have the money to spare, this game will offer you an experience you otherwise would probably only be able to get illegally!

author: {'steamid': '76561198020125851', 'num_games_owned': 15680, 'num_reviews': 840, 'playtime_forever': 1299, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1194, 'last_played': 1543358171}
review:
[h1]Insanely Fast Rhythm Action Game[/h1]
https://youtu.be/VODvGYEDlVY

Using a controller, the only buttons you need are the left stick and the A button. The entire game is played with two buttons as you travel at blazing speeds trying to avoid obstacles as a "Space Beetle"

+ The gameplay is AMAZING. If you are looking for a sense of speed, this game will give you the adrenaline rush this is the game for you!
+ Incredible abstract "visualizations"  that create a wonderful abstract journey.
+ Challenging, as you progress new mechanics are introduces relying on you to make split second decisions. It can be frustrating at times, but oh so rewarding when you complete a segment.
+ Great soundtrack that is in sync with the obsctacles in the game which sounds great! 
+ Leaderboards that may increase replaybility

- Ridiculous difficulty, good luck getting past level 3



Side Note: This is one of the most unique and equally enjoyable indie games that I've played in years. If you enjoy rhythm games, endless runners, or racing games you may find the same level of enjoyment as I did.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996194046', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 89, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 89, 'last_played': 1539286501}
review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bMUDU_PEyfs

Thumper is a surreal rhythm game for the Rift and Vive, by developer drool. This is also a pancake game, but as always I‚Äôm gonna be critiquing from the point of view of its VR adaptation.

So as indie gems go, you might have overlooked Thumper, or possibly even seen it but passed over it due to not knowing what the hell the game is actually about. Well let me clarify that for you; You play a metallic beetle ripping through some god-forsaken hellish void, trying to overcome a groundhog day style purgatory by completing a series of violent rhythmic beats to a hellish soundscape, whilst some maniacal and abstract godlike entities intimidate you throughout the process.

Are you weirded out? Because this game is fucking weird. Thumper is one of the most bizarre concepts I‚Äôve come across in VR, and even more bizarre by the fact that it‚Äôs actually executed extremely well. The maddest thing is that it‚Äôs so simple; You play with one button. Yes, just one button, A, and the thumbstick. As obstacles come down the track, the player must overcome them by timing the relevant action perfectly that involves some combination of the thumbstick and A. And that‚Äôs it.

Stripping off all the oddity, it‚Äôs a memory and rhythm game at its heart, but that oddity is not so easily removed as it is so integral to the effectiveness of the game. The driving force, the music, can hardly even be called music; It‚Äôs more like a collection of weird sounds that beat to a rhythm. And yes, I realize this is an oxymoron but it‚Äôs kind analogous to this game; A complex and thought provoking rhythm game with an outlandishly simple execution. Though lacking the familiarity of traditional music, the soundtrack is fantastically effective, creating an aggressive and violent soundscape, whilst the player‚Äôs successfully timed hits create noise that contribute seamlessly to the soundtrack.

Even though the game is always forward facing, the VR element of the game is excellent. Being immersed in the environment gives a great sense of speed and intensity, and the voidscape itself is both beautiful and dreadful, like an abstract painting.

Folks who I think will not enjoy Thumper are those who are expecting a more traditional rhythm game, or enjoy playing to the beat of more familiar music. It‚Äôs also not a game for the easily frustrated, as this game is hard and unapologetic about it. The game usually retails for $20 but I‚Äôve often seen it drop to $5, which is a steal. So, if you‚Äôve been looking for a game that includes tearing through timespace, metallic beetles and existential dread, finally, here‚Äôs a game for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970610256', 'num_games_owned': 428, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 299, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 159, 'last_played': 1677169297}
review:
Reviewing VR version - Oculus Rift.

Wooow with the feeling of a Tron like world, with ones head strapped down on the nose cone of some sort of beetle craft you have the induced experience of the brain going into hyperdrive. 

I love this game, it's you on this twisty alien like construct that resembles some sort of track that seems alive and relentless. The music track this game is fueled on really spurs the imagination and with its tempo and weird tones makes for a even better experience.

This is about quick reflexes, steady concentration it will provide a simple yet compelling game.

For a VR experience its unique and well worth it, I had no feeling of nausea either which did pleasantly surprise me considering how fast the game plays at. Has about 12 levels split into sub levels.. There is enough to keep you coming back and retrying to better your performance.

All we need now is for this to become a music induced experience, supply us with an editor and we would probably have one the best visual music games (Beat Saber pretty damn good ) on the market for VR. 

We can but pray... :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198364632422', 'num_games_owned': 111, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 86, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 72, 'last_played': 1558730735}
review:
TL;DR Great game, meh soundtrack, and overall difficult, but fun game play.

I love this game. I love the environment, the timing, and the game play. But what I love most is the visuals. Its hyper-colored visuals paired with a very trippy level design allow for a colorful, clam experience. Until it isn't very clam anymore. This game will let you enjoy its very nice level design, but then surprise you by throwing you into intense sequence. Another comment I would like to make is difficulty. This game is both easy, and difficult. At the start of the game, you wont even break a sweat for the first level, but then there is a large spike in difficulty. Normally I would complain about this, but I actually quiet like it. Overall I would say the game is a 8.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198154297074', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 98, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 59, 'last_played': 1621571351}
review:
Crank up the volume and get your fingers ready on a controller, you're about to go on a ride of your life. This game is a rhythm game that pushes your hand-eye-ear coordination to almost it's absolute limits (more on the ears than eyes). The visuals are gorgeus that each level has it's own theme. The visuals and music combined forms this very perfect composition that really gives your mind the sense of urgency to go fast and get the rhythm perfect; it gives you the sense of panic that you'd get from a horror game the more you delve into this game. 

At first, the visuals may be overwhelming; but soon enough as you delve deeper into the game, you realize that relying solely on eyes is a mistake. Eventually, you'll come to master the visuals, music, and rhythm altogether, and the levels will blend together with you and your controlling harmously. This is seriously a wild ride you don't want to miss out on, and it'll leave your heart beating for more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198303993330', 'num_games_owned': 1425, 'num_reviews': 136, 'playtime_forever': 1613, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 913, 'last_played': 1615861496}
review:
Thumper advertises itself as a rhythm horror game, but I believe the true horror here is how incredibly difficult and painfully unfair this game can feel at times - especially for being a rhythm game. Go into this game knowing what (quite literal) hell you're in for, and it'll be even more fun when you've finished. Thumper is one of those games that's hard to really put into words that make it sound spectacular. It's just like any other rhythm game, but it's also not. In favor of honing your skills and practicing songs in a relaxing and low-stress environment, Thumper turns what makes a rhythm game casual into what can make a rhythm game downright terrifying in multiple different ways.

You play as a little beetle with two hit points, running down an endless track separated by levels. You hit beatpads (beats), make turns, fly over obsticals and into rings to gain points. Missing turns, running into obsticals, or encountering other hazards will make you take damage. Two hits, and you start the track/level over. There are "boss fights" you encounter through each set of levels, requiring you to perfectly complete the level's stages to deal damage to the boss. All the while, you're introduced to new mechanics, new rhythms, new hazards, and new ways to realize Thumper will be the death of you.

This game will start you off gently, giving you a few beat pads and turns to hit, satisfying your curiousity for what you have coming. New mechanics are introduced, the rhythm changes pattern and pace Similar to the old tale of boiling a frog in water, suddenly you realize the game has gotten so hard you don't know if you can beat it anymore. You're far enough into it though, that putting it down at this point will feel like a waste and you're [i]just so close to that ending[/i]. By the time you do get to the ending, when you're face to face with the final boss, yet again a new mechanic is introduced that you have to learn while you cry out over and over again with each failure. Thumper is the embodiment of a casual rage game, and how it feels to slowly become a masochist.

In all seriousness, Thumper is a great rhythm game and accomplishes being a unique addition to the genre. It does start out quite slow and easy, gradually ramping the difficulty up to near impossible levels. The music, while nice to listen to and somewhat interesting when you first hear it, didn't really help me hit the beats like it should've been doing. This leaves you to somewhat fend for yourself and learn as you go, rather than having a crutch to work off of. The music playing in each level felt more like a background track to a rhythm you had to come up with on your own via trial and error rather than music that provided you with a template to hit beats off of. The beats do have unique audio cues, but the rather unhelpful music hides most of them, and you really have to listen, watch, or both in order to hit the beats correctly. For some people this is a great thing, and for others it may turn them away from the game completely. Put simply, this is what makes the game so difficult.

My biggest issues with Thumper are many small points that add up to one glaring issue. Overall I felt like the pairing of the music to the beats could've been done much better, which for a rhythm game is really important. A lot of the gameplay involved very bright, flashy visuals that distracted and sometimes even covered upcoming beats, causing me to lose track of what was coming and take damage I would've otherwise avoided. As I mentioned in the last section, you can't hear the cue for the beats, because of the music that doesn't help you in the first place. At times, my controller just wouldn't respond to all the inputs I had to layer on. The lineup of hazards and beats would be going by so fast that trying to turn or shift lanes just wouldn't respond because there were so many other things being input. Each of these small points add up to a major problem, creating difficulty not just because you may be bad at the game, but because the game is working against you to make it harder. Making a game like Thumper difficult didn't need these extra steps, a lot of the levels are already difficult as they are. However, even with all these parts of the game working against me, even I (who has never played a real rhyhtm game before) could beat Thumper with minimal issue - just a lot of frustration.

If you don't mind a rhythm game that will make you rage a little bit, try Thumper. If you like to challenge yourself and want something casual to do it with, this is your game. While advertised as horror, it's more of a rhythm rage game - though I could see it being "scary" with a VR set. Even for it's flaws it's still a unique experience that makes you feel amazing for completing it, and gives a strong sense of accomplishment knowing practice paid off.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981889286', 'num_games_owned': 691, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 61, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1539207539}
review:
I never write reviews but I've never been more disappionted.

The audio is a mess. There is one Master volume slider. The problem you have with that for this game is there are a lot of different types of sound and the mixing is garbage. The music feels way to slow half the time because there's a suprising amount of sleepy time Drone that the trailer and most reviews never mention. The noises your beetle make for doing something good drowns out everything. Audio cues get drowned out by everything (honestly that doesn't matter because this game is more about remembering the course since when to do a thing is so disconnected from the Music you can literally play on mute and lose nothing because this is not a rhythem game)

To me a Rhythem game is when the music and when to do an action feel connected, and in a really good Rhythm game you feel like you could be blind and pull it all off because the sync between what you're doing and what you're hearing feels so damn good. This is not that game. 

By an hour and a half I was just tired of "racing", aka just rembering a course, over bedtime music with almost no sync all while not hearing audios ques and dreading to do perfect turns because the chime was so damn loud and happy.

Oh but it looks pretty so that's nice (because the most important thing in a Rhythm game is how good it looks)

author: {'steamid': '76561198334538238', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 8, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1539196160}
review: Seemed so much fun. But as someone who like to play percussion on music for 15 years its anoying its not really tight on the rhytm you must be but more early. played 8 minutes and just had to stop because of this. Will still recomend it but not if you dont want to loose your timing. Ofcourse its consequent and it could be a lesson to be consequent not on the rhytm which is somehow still a lesson but i really got anoyed and just couldnt play it anymore. It makes me want to punch the screen for being so anoyingly not on the rhytm.

review: Wow!... just wow. Never played a game like this. Difficult and immersive, unforgiving, yet rewarding. I laugh a lot in this game. On sale for 5 bucks?!?! What a deal, can't be mad even if it's not your thang. I love this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973757379', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 305, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 305, 'last_played': 1538951065}
review:
As someone who is pretty familiar with challenging rhythm gaming I was pleasantly surprised that this gave me a run for my money. It gets legitimately difficult, especially if you are trying to keep up combos (instead of "just surviving"). Later stages will frequently put you in twisting tunnels that give you very little time to react visually to what is approaching, so you'll benefit to listening to the sounds each obstacle makes as it activates a certain distance away.

The game is forgiving in the sense that death only resets you to the last checkpoint (which are around a minute long each) but not in the sense that it makes the section you're dying on much easier. There were a couple sections I had to take 5-10 tries at.

To enjoy (and beat) Thumper you will need:
‚Ä¢ A standard-style game controller
‚Ä¢ Quite high reaction speed
‚Ä¢ Ability to quickly pick up on rhythms and audio queues
‚Ä¢ Ability to focus through many overlapping visual effects
‚Ä¢ Patience, if you are lacking any of these

I played in VR on Rift, and it certainly made it more interesting, though I don't think it's necessary to enjoy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198158411686', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1447, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1019, 'last_played': 1661330561}
review:
A beautiful game with amazing mechanics and the most fantastic ending stages. The beginning levels of the game do a wonderful job teaching you the basics- its a classic example of difficulty increasing with player skill. For me, it never was too boring, predictive or easy, as each session I had with Thumper was always thrilling and rewarding. At no point was it so difficult to the point where I was frustrated or stuck for long- nor did I ever feel as if the game was too unfair. It was perfectly balanced in terms of difficulty throughout the levels, and it had many checkpoints so you could go back and try again without wasting your time. 
The art is abstract, and makes you wonder about what hidden meaning there is with the bosses (the heads, and the final boss of level 9). There were times where the music along with the visuals and colours made me feel anxious, at awe, dread or eerie (for example before you fight a boss), and  I absolutely love how the developers were able to convey such strong emotions from me. The colours while beautiful can understandably distract players from being able to see the notes/turns, however its definitely not a game breaker and after getting used to the visuals, you'll be able to make out the notes and turns with specific animations and audio queues. The game's ending is honestly the most satisfying experience I have had in a rhythm game- most likely due to it's strong emotional nature. 
For anyone who is interested in playing the game, please keep in mind that a controller is most ideal. Playing with a keyboard is pretty much impossible after level 4 (trust me I tried). Also keep in mind that each checkpoint can fluctuate with difficulty (for example level 5.5 is slightly harder then level 5.6). If you are unable to beat a level checkpoint and are beginning to get frustrated, take a break or stop playing for the night. I found that if I was starting to get slightly frustrated with a checkpoint I was not able to beat after many tries, I was able to beat it first try the next day. Overall, Thumper is a fantastic game worth the full 20 Canadian dollars. Stay determined to finish the game and it will not disappoint.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042545967', 'num_games_owned': 379, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 1619, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1436, 'last_played': 1658020919}
review:
A good challenge. I highly recommend playing it in VR. I'd say it's a shame it only has 9 levels, but they're all really long (really it's 9 worlds with around 20-30 levels of varying length each, since you can stop and come back at any time once you've reached a checkpoint.)
It doesn't have many mechanics but if it had any more I'm pretty sure it'd be too complicated to be fun.
My only complaint is that the levels seem to be out of order in regards to difficulty; I think the one I had the most trouble with was Level 7, and I completed most of Level 9's checkpoints on the first or second try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198278963042', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1667, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1446, 'last_played': 1642191188}
review:
Alors, par o√π commencer ? Un jeu unique en son genre m√©langeant une esth√©tique psych√©d√©lique avec une exigeance √©lev√©e afin de r√©ellement r√©ussir.

Un jeu de rythme sans concurrent. A jouer a la MANETTE. 

Le jeu est divis√© en 9 Niveaux, que j'apellerai Mondes car Ils sont divis√© en un nombre de r√©els niveaux propre a chaque monde. L'int√©r√™t de cette division en monde est que chacun apporte une nouvelle m√©canique. Les niveaux quant √† eux sont s√©par√©s par des checkpoints, vos points de r√©aparition.

Si l'on veut juste le terminer, le jeu ne repr√©sente pas une √©preuve tr√®s compliqu√©e except√© les Boss que l'on est oblig√© de faire sans erreur pour leur administrer des d√©g√¢ts qui, au nombre de 4 vous feront passer le niveau du boss.
Seulement, a mon sens le sel du jeu r√©side dans la compl√©tion des succ√®s, une m√©canique parfois inutile sur certains jeux mais qui, bien utilis√©e vous fera d√©couvrir les m√©andres d'un jeu. 

Le sel du jeu r√©side donc dans la compl√©tion des niveaux en rang S, c'est-√†-dire que, entre chaque checkpoint il ne faut faire aucune erreur, pour cela il faudra parfois faire et refaire des niveaux afin d'acqu√©rir une dext√©rit√© qui vous servira plus tard car certains passages se retrouvent a travers plusieurs niveaux.
Seultement pour compl√©ter un niveau en S, vous ne pouvez pas faire l'impasse pour le refaire plus tard, ce serait trop simple. Vous devez donc r√©essayez jusqu'a r√©ussir car vous ne pouvez refaire au maximum que le niveau effectu√© pr√©c√©demment et le niveau en cours.
De plus la compl√©tion en S FAIT LA MUSIQUE, quand un obstacle appara√Æt, il √©met une note et quand vous l'outrepassez il en √©met une autre qui, bien entendu s'accorde avec le "th√®me" du niveau. Comme sur un Dark Souls arriver a passez un passage sur lequel on rame donne un sentiment de SATISFACTION incomparable.
En compl√©tant un niveau en S vous gagnez donc : 
-De la satisfaction
-Vous profitez r√©ellement de l'ambiance du niveau
-Vous vous pr√©parez pour la suite du jeu
-Les boss vous para√Ætront juste des niveau plus long

Ce jeu, de part sa DA vous aspire et rend presque euphorique sans aucune drogue en demandant une dext√©rit√© exceptionnelle c'est indescriptible... Alors en VR, je n'imagine pas. 
Un MUST-HAVE dans son unique genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198220636009', 'num_games_owned': 191, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 836, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 326, 'last_played': 1685615023}
review:
It's very challenging like guitar hero or something like that because there's a rhythm to the gameplay but the rhythm fluctuates. 
Simple contols just u/d/l/r and one button. 
You must read ahead at what's coming your way and respond correctly or be punished. 
There are tricks to getting really high scores by flying between and then pounding on the blue pads while stringing together perfectly timed turns and twanging the blue rings. 
You can also extend your flight through turns if done perfectly and this all requires a bit of strategy in order to optimise your score. 
Things get more hectic as the game progresses but none of it is unfair and the difficulty curve isn't too steep that you'll give up but, you will die lots and restart often until muscle memories develop. 
As well a being a really unique and sometimes quite creepy looking game, I found the soundtrack the most intriguing and immersive part. It's not tracks of music but more of a cinematic and dynamic score. I'd describe it as similar to those scary build up moments in horror movies that are accompanied by screechy violins that all lead to a climax except this games score seems to constantly be building towards a climax like the "Shepard Tone". This is accompanied by industrial sounding percussion that doesn't necessarily follow any particular time signature but does sound constantly ominous and puts me on edge. 
It really is very addictive and I can play for long sessions but when I stop playing I sometimes feel a bit exhausted from the whole experience, especially the later levels with the snakes and lasers. 
I play using a Fighstick because it is supported and also if you have VR it's just incredible. 
I really would like to add some negative comments about this game but for once I have nothing to say. 

The whole experience keeps you on your toes at the same time as wanting to hide away and close your eyes. The visuals and soundscape exist together perfectly. The controls are fair and easy to learn but it takes some hardcore finesse to get good scores. 

It gives me constant goose bumps while playing. I'd say just get it now because then you can say that you own THUMPER a very unique experience and one that you could return to quite often or even to again in a few years. It's a future classic. Accessible to all. The only reason not to own THUMPER is to be oblivious to its existence.

author: {'steamid': '76561198109764429', 'num_games_owned': 575, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 2729, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 572, 'last_played': 1689882072}

author: {'steamid': '76561198030337265', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 371, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 277, 'last_played': 1573875439}
review:
An intense rythm game that's all about getting into a groove and transcending your mortal visage.

This thing gets really intense. The difficulty is very well paced though, so you don't have to get it all down on your first few runs. The many mechanics for handling your ship are all introduced slowly, giving you just enough time to master each one before the next pops in and challenges you in new and unpredictable ways. 

All highways have the same basic aesthetic and similar cadence, only they obviously get progressively harder. Bosses will appear at certain points and shake things up a bit. Basically, wether on a boss or on a regular stage, you are only allowed to screw up once. Die twice and that's it, you gotta go back to the start of that section. There are ways to get your extra life back, but for the most part, the game wants you to get things right the whole way through.

A very important facet to the fast gameplay is that the game lets you play suboptimally without punishing you in any way (unless you care about high score). What I mean by this is that the game gives you a bonus if you make turns and moves at the last possible frame before an obstacle. While it looks really cool when you do it, it can be hard for inexperienced players to pull off. Thankfully, you're allowed to complete a level doing all your turns ahead of time, without worrying about constantly hitting the sweet spots. Later on in the game though, things do get more demanding, so don't get too comfortable.

This game is amazing to play when it's just you, a dark room, and maybe a few drinks in. You just go crazy in there, man.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026410504', 'num_games_owned': 268, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 719, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 566, 'last_played': 1614732796}
review:
Just finished this game. Definitely an awesome ride.

Beautiful visuals tied in with super fluid and rewarding rhythm gameplay. Different time signatures for those looking for a different kind of challenge. Overall a completely solid game and very fun to play.

Until the final boss. [b]Never[/b] in my life have I played a game with a worse final boss. The game sets you up to understand the rhythm of each level until you are proficient and feel like you have mastered it. The final boss throws all of that out the window and is frustrating, obnoxious, gimmicky, and anti-climactic.

Fortunately the final boss is not enough to detract from how good this game is overall. Definitely worth the price tag, super fun if you are into intense rhythm games.

review:

Thumper √© um jogo de corrida, por√©m de r√≠tmo musical, mas por√©m de chefes e fases, mas por√©m, muito no entanto, √© um jogo de plataforma. √â tudo realmente muito misturado, tornando uma jogatina √∫nica. √â prazeroso fazer os comandos e o entra e sai dos t√∫nnels torna-nos boquiabertos com a din√¢mica e velocidade com que tudo acontece. √â um daqueles jogos at√© legais de assistir pelo seu fren√©tico desafio e engenhosos combos de comando.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026861905', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 2281, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1531, 'last_played': 1566261487}
review:
Oh I'm loving this game ! Really reminds me of my childhood where I used to grind so hard to perfect the level. This game makes me relive those memories. Anyway, this is my first rhythm type game , so my expectations were, "oh I gues I have to listen to the music and press certain buttons to finish the level" However, this was tottally the opposite of that ! It starts really nice and slow but it gets super confusing and complex as you progress. Also, the game doesn't teach you certain mechanics/moves like "perfect turns" or "double jump" and all that, so you have to figure it out yourself. It's almost like you're in this universe and try to find out new moves to past bosses/final bosses. This way the game really puts you in a "discovery mode" where you can go off script and try new things and beat your high score. Other than mechanics, the soundtrack and the atmosphere really put you in the mood. There are some goosebumpy moments where you can literally get that "chilling feeling" before you face the final boss. In conclusion, this is a must buy whether you like rhythm games or not.

Score: 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198066590240', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2800, 'playtime_forever': 238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 105, 'last_played': 1593149542}
review:
[h1] Experienced on the Oculus Rift with Xbox 360 gamepad. VR Review Only. [/h1]

So this is the still the best music rhythm [b] game [/b] in VR (emphasis on game). This game slowly but surely ramps up the difficulty. Throwing more and more at you as you go along and always faster. The amazing part of this game is how the game action perfectly syncs with the music. 

For whatever reason, the vast majority of music rhythm games completely miss on this. Beat Saber is another one that gets this formula right. Make every action you make be part of the beat of the music. So you always have an audio cue as to the timing while you get a visual cue as to what action to perform. It's like playing a Guitar Hero or Rock Band plastic guitar but with your controller, synced up to this boss destroying beetle.

The levels are basically training tutorials for the upcoming boss fights. Master those levels and the boss fights just become a showcase performance for your mastery. Beware: you do get audio and visual overload so anyone who is sensitive to lights or sounds may not enjoy this title. 

The title is also punishing soon after the first few levels, as timing is everything ... just like Guitar Hero or Rock Band, but on expert mode on a difficult song. The good thing is that repetition does make the game easier and as long as you have a musical ear you should be fine. Get a good controller though. 

Rate 9/10. Almost perfection. The only flaw I could think of is that there are no difficulty options so the game would be open to a wider audience. 

[i]p.s. Would love to see a version of this game dune for roomscale movement (your hands and feet are the movements - side to side and crouch up and down with a First Person view where you are the beetle) [/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198004701225', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 130, 'playtime_forever': 69, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1534030895}
review:
So, if the style and aesthetics of the preview video don't strike you as "cool" or something similar, you probably won't like this. This game's value rides on its aesthetics, being some weird techno music outerspace lightshow thingy.

As far as a rhythm game goes, the difficulty curve is well made. It starts off very slow like the first area of the first level of Rez, and the intensity takes a while to ramp up, lots of reptition built into the stages to make sure you understand the needed techniques. Levels are made up of 20-ish parts, the parts are 40 seconds or so long, and if you fail (two mistakes, with a short invincibility window to get back on your feet after the first mistake), you start back at the beginning of the 40 second part. There's a hardcore mode for being more hardcore about it if you want to be hardcore about it, too.

There's some aspects to it that feel a little cheap, like the boss enemy being visually the same every level (note: I'm only on level 3) and the lack of background visuals at times. As a rhythm game with very simple inputs though, it's a pretty exciting game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198096255780', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 31, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1534018722}
review: I really wish i could like this game but its just too headache inducing

author: {'steamid': '76561198006575550', 'num_games_owned': 1631, 'num_reviews': 625, 'playtime_forever': 298, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 298, 'last_played': 1530244441}
review:
Thumper is one of the best but you need to love failure. It's so hard! You'll also need impeccable timing to hit those beats. I think I broke out in a sweat. It's somewhere between a rhythm game and a twitch action. I think I could play without the audio but I wouldn't want to.

It might be difficult but it generously starts you back at a checkpoint when you fail. You don't lose too much progress, you just lose score. It provides the player an opportunity to complete the game without worrying about the score. It still stings though when you do poorly. It's one of the reasons I got as far as I did and still went back and replayed levels.

This is a top tier game, I loved it!

Note: only 5% of people finish! I'm not one of them :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197983891596', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 413, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 413, 'last_played': 1536699633}
review:
One of the best VR experiences i've had (not without it's flaws)

As a fan of industrial music, and games - this seemed right up my street.

Catchy demonic beats run in the background as your eyes fill up with empty space and a single track to ride on. Starting off simply - the catch is to press buttons in rhythm to what you see on the screen. A very simple concept, but extremely satisfying.
Soon this game becomes very challenging among the 9 'worlds' and the levels in them, with a slight increase in difficulty and complexity, adding new tricks your little space bug can do to navigate the obstacles presented.

I will try not to spoil anything, but the last few levels of the game brought me to wonder why the first 8 worlds offered so little in terms of diversity in the world and music around it. I think some additional concepts (that were tried at the end) could have been brought forward to liven up the repetitive auditory and visual landscape of the first 7/8ths of the game. However, this would have come with its downsides, and would probably have left me feeling a little less ecstatic at the end at how freaking awesome it was..

Speaking of 7/8ths, I have heard rumours of the level/world number (e.g level 3 world 4) would have itself represented by its music being in that time signature (3/4). I did notice sometimes this could be the case, but could rarely concentrate solely on the time signatures as you really need to focus to beat a level. Either way, it's a cool concept, that even if half-executed (to not sacrifice gameplay) is just a really cool addition to the game.

I feel that anybody who has a VR headset, and is at least interested in industrial music should give this a go, as it is so cheap but can offer hours of intense entertainment. I would literally come out of sessions feeling a sense of intense satisfaction.

I say game, but it feels more like an interactive experience. This is the one 'experience' i've had on VR which I believe will truly stick with my as one of my favourites.

Still yet to play NG+ though!

author: {'steamid': '76561198026481254', 'num_games_owned': 202, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 752, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 270, 'last_played': 1571497977}
review:
This is some next gen shitt! The design in this game has so many levels to it it gives me a hard on just thinking about it.
Thumper should be a must play for any gamedesigner and will probaly become an all timer.
As for suggestions on improvements I wish the scoreboard appeared quicker after level finish. The time window between looking at the score and playing the next level is short and distracting. I also struggled to understand the introduction of the dash ability, seen other people aswell and although there clearly is a popup telling you what to do I feel like there is potential for improving it's readability.

-I give Thumper, nine and a half out of ten potatos

review:
Brutal but logical gameplay, simplistic but gorgeous visual and audio style, punishing but also rewarding gameplay and a steep difficulty curve to climb.
If you're into tough but rewarding games, and especially if you like rhythm-based gameplay, do NOT miss out on playing Thumper.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976514014', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 290, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 209, 'last_played': 1638335131}
review:
An awesome rhythm game that's great on tv but even better in VR. Originally played this on PSVR and it ran fine but definitely looked rough in vr. With PCVR though, it looks great and can easily turn up SS to 2.0 with no issues.

It does have a steep learning curve but it overall pretty forgiving (unless you are trying to S rank everything).

Overall I've bought this at full price twice and have no regrets, hoping we get a second one someday!

review:
A great and challenging game that musicians and those that love rhythm games should absolutely pick up. Full of great levels, awe-inspiring visuals, and mechanical nuance. If you're new to this type of game, however, there are probably better, less intense entrypoints into the genre.
Also, if you're prone to any kind of epilepsy or visually-triggered seizures, you might wanna avoid...

10/10 would ride through geometry hell again
