author: {'steamid': '76561197984812495', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 179, 'last_played': 1600212541}
review: This is one of the few new games to exhibit that special "WHOA‚Ä¶. Video Game Magic".  Unique IP, yet familiar enough to dig its retro-hooks in. Combining the tone and elements of Tempest, MDK, Tron, Star Fox, F-Zero on rollercoaster rails on Space Mountain with a retro-future synth-y sci-fi industrial soundtrack. It creates an immersive sense of speed and tension. Boss battles are menacing and psychedelic. Frustrating and rewarding, all with simple D-pad plus a single button. What a treat.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984627665', 'num_games_owned': 7152, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 289, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 209, 'last_played': 1584790617}
review: It's a thriller music game. Turn up your music loud and push yourself to the limit in this exciting rhythm game. You're constantly reacting to the obstacles on screen and immersing yourself into this very psychedelic world of horror. While the game itself can be completed in about 10 hours, replaying it for high scores is a must. VR is a plus and an absolute roar to play. Recommend this game at full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198358037154', 'num_games_owned': 43, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 868, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 194, 'last_played': 1657487370}
review: I won this game through the Steam Summer Sale 2018 and finally got around to playing it. I'm playing it without any VR, so just keyboard controls, but it's still a relatively easy game to handle and definitely an amazing one to see. The visuals are amazing, I wish there were more gaps in gameplay so I could take more screenshots! It does seem that the effects increase with perfect streaks, and sometimes the colors make it hard to see the action panels, but it's easy to restart from the individual checkpoints/sublevels to earn S on them to get the S achievement for the entire level. It does get hard having to learn all the different actions and to remember/do them under pressure towards the end of the levels but with some time and restarts, it's doable. Definitely would recommend even just for a casual game

author: {'steamid': '76561198014300429', 'num_games_owned': 284, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 592, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 369, 'last_played': 1597118221}
review:
A really great game for people who love rhythm games and tough challenges, and pushing yourself to see how well you can perform in graded segments. However, there is one issue that keeps cropping up for me in this game: that it seemingly wants to make you fail it, not by any fault of your gameplay, but by the game design itself.

At first the game sends out beats with signature sounds for each type of move you should make, and you repeat those moves as they arrive; it's pretty much a classic call-and-response, and even when it layers over itself it's fun to play along with. However, the game soon becomes so noisy, both visually and aurally, that you can't hear the "call" part of the call-and-response anymore. You're stuck with working by sight and your own rhythm--not necessarily a bad thing, but disappointing that you lose that feature so soon.

The real problem is when the game goes off-beat, which is in two cases: first, you only have one free hit in this game, and if you get hit twice, you're done. But when you first get hit, the game [i]slows down[/i] for a second and, again, brings visual clutter into play. You do get a small moment of invincibility, but more often than not the fact that the game intentionally goes off-beat is enough to kill you, not to mention that the red filter over the screen doesn't leave for several seconds, in a game where several correct movements per second are necessary to not die.

The second time the game goes off-beat is when you perform a "slam" on a beat, which turns an upcoming beat into a bonus beat. If you slam the bonus beat, the game pauses for a moment, much like hit-lag in a fighting game to show a devastating blow, and then continues. I mean, it is a cool effect and it gets the point across--but again, adding a pause into a rhythm game with so many rapid successive movements just seems short-sighted. I can maybe understand the argument for getting hit that it [i]should[/i] be a detriment and it's your fault if you can't recover; but getting punished for performing a move to gather more points? The risk for that maneuver should be setting up the slam itself, not the successful result of the slam.

I know I spend most of this review complaining, but despite these things, do I still recommend the game? Yes. Is that because I still have a fucking blast getting into the rhythm and beating a level after several futile attempts? Hell yes. It's damn good if you're up for the difficulty, and there's no denying it. These are just a couple things that could make it even better if they were fixed, and if there is a sequel I'd hope that its design strictly enforces no rhythm changes onto the player. If you'd be into this game otherwise, it's up to you to decide if that's enough to deter you from enjoying it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104069162', 'num_games_owned': 349, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 463, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 246, 'last_played': 1686206926}

review: The game is gorgeous, it has very nice visuals and awesome sound. But it's hard like hell. And I mean it has such a steep learning curve to learning these steep curves that it gets frustrating and annoying too much, too soon. Also be prepared to bury your space button, because it will die, R.I.P. I stopped playing at level 2-13 because it was too frustrating and I can't seriously recommend such a game to anybody. What's the point to make an awesome game if it's only for the select few pro-arcaders?

review:
Sehr sch√∂nes Action-Reaktionsspiel. Man gleitet auf einer futuristischen Bahn dahin, rutscht mit Gamepadeinsatz scharf um die Kurven und springt √ºber Hindernisse. Nebenbei durchbricht man Barrieren und stampft nach einem Sprung heftig auf den Boden, um Sto√üwellen in Richtung des Feindes zu senden. Das Ganze l√§uft in rasender Geschwindigkeit mit teils wundersch√∂nem Farbspiel in klar strukturierter Grafik ab. Begleitend h√∂rt man rhythmische Kl√§nge die perfekt mit den Hindernissen auf der Bahn synchronisiert sind. Wer klein wenig Rhythmusgef√ºhl besitzt hat hier Vorteile.
F√ºr alle mit schnellen Reflexen eine klare Kaufempfehlung meinerseits.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976389888', 'num_games_owned': 413, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 419, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 108, 'last_played': 1680432402}
review:
I heard this game was good but nobody told me it was [i]this[/i] good. It's like Stanley Kubrick made a rhythm game whilst on a monstrous DMT binge.

Dark electronic music and psychadelic visuals set you up to get into a mad flow state required to finish levels. They're broken up into small chunks too so it's quite easy to pick up and put down. I can't get enough of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057865632', 'num_games_owned': 210, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1634, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1540, 'last_played': 1549928314}
review:
[h1] To put it simply, THUMPER is flawless. [/h1]

That doesn't mean everyone will like it though. In fact, a lot of people wouldn't even be able to see it to the end because of how teeth-grinding hard this game gets.

What I mean by [i] flawless [/i] is that one cannot point at a single detail of this game and say with certainty that it is out of place. Every single piece of this maze falls just in the right spot to provide one of the most unique and memorable experience in gaming [b]ever[/b].

Thumper is an uncompromising and merciless assault on your senses. If this doesn't sound like your jam, don't even bother.  However, if you are that kind of masochist, you will love it to death.

[i] P.S. No one says that online, but the ending is [b] excellent [/b] in every sense of the word. Please finish this game.
[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198028607576', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2754, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1568, 'last_played': 1704770783}
review: Never in a million years would I have thought that one day, I would find myself feeling sorry for a poor little space beetle who is trapped in a nightmarish hellscape for all eternity. But here I am. Nightmare inducing, seizure causing, pulse pounding, and ridiculously addictive. I bought this on the cheap through the summer sale, but I honestly think it is WELL worth the full price. If you are even remotely in to rhythm games. Buy this. Immediately.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061510196', 'num_games_owned': 259, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 116, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 40, 'last_played': 1589363079}

author: {'steamid': '76561197994365694', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 160, 'playtime_forever': 65, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 32, 'last_played': 1572584197}
review:
If you've got VR you have to play this game. If not you should try it as well.

 It  looks beautiful, and it's fun and original, even the music which is some kind of industrial music which is a very welcome change from the traditional electronica and/or synth that you'd expect in a game that looks like this.

One thing to keep in mind is that it's not a traditional Rythm game. You don't really press buttons based on a musical cue but rather you need to react to what you see coming towards you but you don't need to be precise to get a good rank.

I like the gameplay because I am bad at traditional Rythm games where the only way get good scores is by practicing the stage over and over again and memorising it, which I hate. Here you can get along with just  reflexes, at least in the levels I have played so far.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010217378', 'num_games_owned': 929, 'num_reviews': 249, 'playtime_forever': 492, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 492, 'last_played': 1528838874}
review:
[i]Thumper[/i] is an addictive rhythm game about a metallic bug flying through space. It's far from simple, but has a smooth learning curve, and the slick visuals draw you in. 

Literally: the bosses are always ahead of you, so you seem to be constantly trying to get into their mouths, which is an image fittingly surreal and horrifying for the game's aesthetics.

If you're looking for a rhythm game, this is a good one, that doesn't distract you from the fast-paced action with unnecessary fluff. Also, space bugs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025388508', 'num_games_owned': 628, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 4262, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1640, 'last_played': 1686412177}
review:
this game.... is indeed one of the best rhythm games ever.
the trailer doesn't even show much of how satisfying and badass the rhythm and sounds from it get, but it's indeed just as violent and fast as it seems there (i'd suggest watching bits of gameplay to get a better feel but even that doesn't show how satisfying it is to play)

furthermore, i'd say the game has some replayability cause f yeah i wanna experience the rhythm from all the levels again, and admire the backgrounds

but yeah its pretty tough, specially if you wanna S rank everything, and from observing some friends play i realized a good sense of rhythm and timing is essential. if you're not very good at rhythmic games, you'll probably suffer and get frustrated (unless you intend on merely surviving, then you'll be okay... till the RING OF JUDGEMENT comes to make you pay for your mistakes)

EDIT: so i've completed it, and wow what a trip, transcendental like "2001 space odyssey" yet it makes more sense > POSSIBLE SPOILERS AHEAD > from what i read someone say, you're a representation of our mortal lane, and the bosses are gods of reality, untethered from our plane, able to distort it

author: {'steamid': '76561197990725997', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 360, 'playtime_forever': 88, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 50, 'last_played': 1643803647}
review:
I've only played it for 30+ minutes, but I am already in love with this game. You have plenty of other reviews to read, but my only description of this game is like driving a psychadelic car down a dooming freeway as you try to avoid a wreck. The sounds are close to hearing the sounds of a well rehearsed drum circle trying to intimidate you into you a drug-induced trip so that you lose.

I love it. 

I recommend high.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043244241', 'num_games_owned': 173, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 693, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 592, 'last_played': 1703659330}
review: I found this game a while ago while I was looking for good rhythm games to play, and let me tell you, I was NOT disappointed. Thumper is a rhythm game with a twist--as you play, you're fighting. What you're fighting or avoiding depends on the level and where you are, but at the end of each level, there's always a big bad boss. The rhythm games I HAVE played are mostly just "hit the right notes, don't miss" and/or "here's a thing or two to avoid", but Thumper adds more to that. There's plenty of obstacles, plenty of mechanics, and plenty of challenge. Taking a long break from this game and coming back is HARD--you have to remember all the controls, and then get back to the quick rhythm of the game. The farther you get, the more challenging it gets. Overall, I really love this game, and totally recommend it to anyone looking for a good challenge (and anyone willing to try again and again to beat one (1) checkpoint).

author: {'steamid': '76561198115760557', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 2243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1249, 'last_played': 1703850393}
review:
This game was the first in a long time that really challenged my faith in myself and in everything else.

It is sometimes so difficult that you go crazy and think nobody and by all means not you could ever do this ("why is the controller so bad, I need a new one", "the developer is crazy!!!", "is there a way to just cheat for one second more time...", "why does Steam say people made it????").
Then you try again and again and again and again.... and in the end you make it and you get the feeling of pure joy, that you did make it (after just 2 hours :).... just to fail again in the next level :P

If you like to struggle to get to the next level in a game while enjoying beautiful and mesmerizing graphics and music plus the feeling of joy when you did make it you should right away get this game!!!

Also you can play this game on your (mid-range, business) laptop without a "real" graphics card (i5, Intel 550 Iris Pro) which is really cool :D

EDIT 07.2020: This game runs super smooth even when playing it on Linux via Proton and with all settings maximized.

EDIT 07.2020 (2): The skill ceiling is real. I don't think I will ever get S-Rank on 8,9 but I got it on all levels below (warning: 5 S-Rank, 6 S-Rank and 7 S-Rank are much more difficult than 1-4).

author: {'steamid': '76561198037079805', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 124, 'playtime_forever': 210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 64, 'last_played': 1678594647}
review:
I really want to like this, but it's hampered by terrible accessibility. No control options, poor mastering of sound where important things are way too quiet, and you have to have really good reaction times for some sections because you literally cannot see what's coming at all. 

If the game is being fair and you're feeling what little abstract rhythm there is, then it's spectacular, but if not, then it falls apart.

This feels like a musican made an audiosurf in order to torment you, you've got to learn it and the disjointed music but the process of doing so is rewarding when you're in the mood to crank it up and kick back.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978351587', 'num_games_owned': 445, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 788, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 660, 'last_played': 1689733204}
review:
Thumper is one of the best games ever. It is a pure, visceral experience. Inarguably the pinnacle of its genre.

The lesson of the game is to never stop pushing ahead, toward your goals. 
You eventually learn to empathize with the little Space Beetle and share in its struggle to fight the future.

Never give up. I love this game, please please play it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198344779594', 'num_games_owned': 97, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 145, 'last_played': 1647733030}
review:
At first it seemed real cool. That's because it IS very cool. It's a very nice looking game with great attention to visual and audio elements. The biggest issue here is there is just too much going on at once for my taste. I enjoy rhythm games where you can actually hear the audio cues in time with the music. 

This is just kinda crazy jungle background beats with random sounds added, which signals the next obstacle to avoid/hit. The cues are progressively VERY difficult to hear. If there was an option for this alone, I would recommend this game. But, especially for ¬£15.00, I wouldn't recommend it to the unknowing rhythm-enthusiast. Grab on sale if you're curious.

Pros:
Great visuals
Attention to ambience
Simple, but difficult
There is a VR option!

Cons: 
Audio-visual overload dramatically causes gameplay issues
Not as rhymic as I'd like.

Maybe I should just git gud.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987467007', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1509, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1120, 'last_played': 1687468417}
review:
Thumper is absolutely amazing. It's a very pure video game that can appeal to anyone due to its accessibility‚Äîyou only need to use a d-pad/analog stick and one button‚Äîand its simple premise.  You're a space beetle, and you have to overcome every challenge the game throws at you to make it to the end. You won't meet any boring characters, you won't sit through hours of cutscenes, you don't have to pretend to care about a clich√© story. You just play.

The main Play mode is easy to work through because you're only sent back to the beginning of your current level if you die, but its Play+ mode provides a hardcore challenge that will keep you coming back for more. 

The whole thing is a masterpiece, both conceptually and aesthetically, and it stands out among the sea of generic FPS games, uninspired RPGs, and unfinished indie trash that clutter this bandwagon-prone industry. This game is a quasi-psychedelic experience you aren't going to forget. 

I hope the two-man team that is Drool continues to make games this gripping and exhilarating, because I think they really proved themselves with Thumper.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961712745', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 1627, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1189, 'last_played': 1547971114}
review:
Gespielt mit Logitech Rumble Pad 2 und HTC Vive:
Das Spielt ist der Wahnsinn. Ich dachte schon Wipeout damals war schnell auf Rapier, aber Thumper toppt alles an Speed was ich bisher erlebt habe. Dazu kommt eine innovative Art von Gameplay, die Hindernisse, Spr√ºnge usw kommen im Takt der finsteren Elektro-Musik auf einen zu und man entwickelt wahnwitzige Reflexe mit der Zeit und gibt sich v√∂llig einem instinktiven Rausch hin.
Die Optik ist ziemlich psychedelisch, wobei man bem√ºht ist einen Tunnelblick auf die Strecke zu wahren um sich nicht ablenken zu lassen, was das Gef√ºhl einer irren Reise tief in die apokalyptischen Techno-Welten noch verst√§rkt.
Zu bem√§ngeln habe ich, dass es keine eingebaute Joypad-Unterst√ºtzung gibt - die Steuerung mit dem Vive-Controller ist nicht zu empfehlen bei den kurzen Reaktionszeiten kommt man damit nicht weit, und mit Tastatur zu spielen in VR ist ebenfalls unpraktisch. (das frei konfigurierbare Logitech-Pad als Tastatur-Ersatz ist f√ºr mich die beste L√∂sung in VR).
Ausserdem k√∂nnten die End-Bosse optisch etwas unterschiedlicher gestaltet sein, klar kommt es in erster Linie auf das spielerische an, aber es ist trotzdem unbefriedigend zum x-ten mal den selben D√§monenkopf zu sehen.

Abgesehen davon ist das Spiel ein echter Knaller f√ºr jeden mit einem Hang zu Geschwindigkeitsrausch und guten Reflexen.

9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198003473030', 'num_games_owned': 353, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 423, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 423, 'last_played': 1528328938}
review:
From its title screen alone, with the background music swelling and the camera flying down an empty track into a desolate void, it‚Äôs clear that Thumper is something that‚Äôs rather unique. It‚Äôs a strange rhythm action title, trying to invoke from you feelings of awe and dread in equal measure. It's closest counterpart would probably be the cult classic Rez - but even then, the differences between the two are evident at first glance. In short, it‚Äôs a bit of an odd one.  

Despite its surreal appearance, however, the actual gameplay at work in Thumper is remarkably straightforward. As your ship glides along, you press the action button to hit beats, hold it to smash through obstacles, or hold it and tilt the control stick to successfully navigate sharp corners or fly over hazards. There‚Äôs deeper mechanics at work as well (some of which the game unfortunately doesn‚Äôt do a stellar job at explaining to you), but the same base elements are always in play no matter the situation.

Such simplicity doesn‚Äôt make things any less satisfying, however. Once things start flowing this becomes an intense audio-visual experience; the beat relentlessly pulsing and pounding, colours blurring and whizzing around everywhere, everything hypnotically drawing you in to its weird world. At points, when everything clicks together just right, it‚Äôs easily possible to enter a moment of Zen ‚Äì an odd sensation where it feels as if you stop [i]reacting[/i] to the obstacles around you, and instead begin [i]sensing[/i] them instead. It‚Äôs something that's hard to process in words, but this is when Thumper truly shines; that moment where you become one with the machine, and everything else seems irrelevant in comparison. 

It‚Äôs frustrating, then, that there‚Äôs so many barriers preventing this experience from happening, the first coming with the intense difficulty level on show here. It‚Äôs a clear design choice to make everything a brutal and terrifying endeavour, with later levels hurling a screaming sense of speed and a relentless cascade of obstacles in your direction. And, to its credit, at times it feels like it works ‚Äì you‚Äôre instilled with a sense of dread at what‚Äôs coming that fits nicely into the game's tone, and the challenge of a difficult level really pulls out the classic ‚ÄúOne more go‚Äù factor that makes eventual victory ever the sweeter. 

Yet the problem comes with the fact that the constant stream of deaths before those small victories viciously cuts into the game‚Äôs overall flow. It becomes increasingly difficult to break into that golden trance-like state whereupon everything goes perfectly, and even when you do manage to pull it off, rest assured you‚Äôll be slapped back down to Earth by a new challenge sooner rather than later. In many ways I wish the game had chosen a path that was perhaps slightly less vindictive, and I do think the earlier levels are actually the strongest and most refined, if only because those don‚Äôt feel like they‚Äôre resorting to flinging you around with reckless abandon. 

Difficultly and the inevitable cries of ‚ÄúGet good‚Äù aside, what proves to be a bigger and more inexcusable issue is the sheer mass of audiovisual confusion that can occur all too frequently.  To provide an example ‚Äì level backgrounds can sometimes be filled with a deep red, and corners you need to navigate or die are denoted with the exact same colour. Given enough time, it would be easy enough to differentiate the two... But zooming around at warp speeds doesn‚Äôt really allow for those precious moments that you need. Taking the single hit of damage you‚Äôre allowed per stage creates the same problem; filling your screen with so much clutter the chances of a second, fatal mistake are drastically ‚Äì and frustratingly - increased.  

The real maddening example to me, however, and one the game seems to take glee on constantly pulling, is hiding obstacles immediately after sharp corners on the track. It creates a situation where a threat only really appears in your view fractions of a second before you‚Äôre meant to react to it, and the chances are that unless your reflexes are superhuman it‚Äôs going to catch you out. There are audio cues for the appearance of each obstacle where are designed to mitigate this, but even these just don‚Äôt feel all that distinct - all too often being lost or muted within the game‚Äôs musical beat. 

Put all these things together, and it creates scenarios where making progress seems like a trial and error process, more than something that relies on actual skill. It ceases to feel like the organic and flowing experience that forms the game‚Äôs brilliance, and instead becomes a pattern memorisation exercise that easily holds the potential to make your blood pressure rise rapidly. 

It‚Äôs a crying shame that this is the case, because it feels like Thumper could have been much better than what it actually is... But don‚Äôt take this to mean that this is an experience you should be ignoring. The real truth is that the game's uniqueness and strangely captivating manner deserve your attention, and those blissful moments where you enter into a true moment of Zen are worth the price of admission alone. So, if you‚Äôre any way interested, make sense to check this out ‚Äì you may have to work to truly see it, but there‚Äôs a thumping good time to be had.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104606646', 'num_games_owned': 524, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 626, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 350, 'last_played': 1582388278}
review:
I may have only played about 75 min at the time of this review... but man is this a fun game.

Saw it in my recommended list on steam and I saw a couple gameplays on YT before so I thought, i'd give it a try.
This game is just awesome. there are no cons for me in this game (and that's a 1st...)

- The feeling you're on a LDS trip
- Music that gives you the feeling a massive boss from like Monster Hunter is about to appear.
- visually amazing
- noticable difficulties as you move on to the next level, or even the next stage of your level.
- Generally fun to play, if you can catch the beat
- [spoiler]If you get a perfect score half way through the level, the music and speed increases[/spoiler]

Worth the full price. 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198091074678', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 687, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 366, 'last_played': 1697211129}
review:
I've always had a soft spot for rhythm games, and I was quite anticipating playing Thumper. However, there was one fatal flaw that made me stop playing it: audiovisual overload.

You see, Thumper has a mechanic where incoming obstacles are telegraphed by unique sound cues. Sometimes these cues are the only feasible way to predict hazards without memorization (this becomes very apparent in the vision-blocking tunnels, for example). But it sounds fair, right?

The problem is that half the time I can't even [i]hear[/i] these cues. Why? Because there's an intense backing track playing throught every level, as well as the sound effects from your own inputs and various other noises. You can't make these cues louder, either; the game only has one master volume slider.

So, whenever there was an incoming obstacle that I couldn't see, I'd take a hit. In the earlier levels, it's not too much of an issue; there's not a lot of them, and you can memorize them when they occasionally show up. But they become more and more frequent as you progress, By two-thirds into the game, they're not only more common, but the game starts throwing in visual distortions to make things even worse.

It was at this point that I decided to stop playing. From where the game was headed, things were probably just going to get more frustrating. Considering the game's short length, it's not a rather good sign that I couldn't be bothered to finish it.

(Years-later Edit: I did come back to the game, picked up right where I left off in the middle of level 7, and beat it in a couple of days. Nothing really changed at all. And that sucks, because I really want to like this game. I'll admit 100% that it feels fantastic to nail a satisfying beat.)

FINAL VERDICT:

10 ‚Äì Nearly Flawless

9 ‚Äì Fantastic

8 ‚Äì Great

7 ‚Äì Good

6 ‚Äì Above Average

[b][u]5 ‚Äì Average[/u][/b]

4 ‚Äì Below Average

3 ‚Äì Bad

2 ‚Äì Terrible

1 ‚Äì Worthless


Side note: Discrediting reviews because you think the reviewer sucks at the game is stupid. Firstly, I've enjoyed plenty of hard games (Cuphead) as well as games that I suck at (Rocket League). What's different about those games is that the challenge is fair and/or there's an enjoyable desire to keep playing and improving. If neither of these conditions are met, then the difficulty just becomes frustrating. Secondly, game reviews are always subjective by nature. If you got more mileage out of a game because you were better at it, that's totally fine. I'm not the end-all authority on games; I'm just trying to give you my opinion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015097516', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 746, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 228, 'last_played': 1671928611}
review:
Very challenging little game, absolutely worth its' price.

I highly recommend for those gamers, who have something musical (or I can say rhythmical) sense background, because without it the game can be really annoying and very hard. You have to listen carefully for every little sound, and still there are situations when you find yourself in a nasty situation, because there is another object that you didn't hear previously. 

It's a little bit pity, that you can't select yourself which checkpoint you want to restart (I mean from all of them), but it's not even a problem.

SHUT UP AND TAKE YOUR MONEY! ;D

Still a badass game in 2019!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198099769042', 'num_games_owned': 192, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 11236, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4810, 'last_played': 1699048332}
review:
This game is not for everyone, and I'm going to start off this review by saying that there is not much content there for the price. However, I enjoyed this game and have spent a lot of time with it, and I'm sure you can enjoy it too if it fits your preferences. 

In short, Thumper is a simplistic rhythm game that challenges the players quick thinking and the ability to judge what actions to take in order to get the biggest combo and score possible. As the game grows more hectic, the player is quickly forced to take in account also their health and overall survival. Even though the game is quite short, it includes enough mechanics and sufficient difficulty to keep things interesting.

Pros:

+ Stunning visuals and effects. Despite the immense feeling of speed and quick changes in direction, the game does not feel blurry or visually distracting. 

+ Amazing soundtrack. The name fits the game really well, and the thumping, rhytmic music really brings the experience to another level. The challenges and actions that the player makes also fit the soundtrack and it truly feels that you can depend on the rhythm to proceed.

+ VR support. (I have not tested this aspect myself, but have heard that it is stunning to look at.)

+ Good performance.

+ The game can be played in many ways. There are seemingly impossible challenges for the perfectionists hunting the perfect score, yet people who are not that familiar with the genre can survive and admire the view through the journey. 

+ New game plus-like levels that bring the difficulty up a notch, and satisfy the need for pure survival instead of gathering points, as they only grant you one life. 

+ Fluid and rewarding combo system with many tricks to utilize in boosting your score. It never feels dull to stomp on a note and feel the bass as you regain a life and improve your combo.


Cons:

- There is no that much content for people who are not interested in replaying levels. I would estimate that "completing the game" as in playing every single level will take 5 to 10 hours depending on skill. New game plus extends the game a bit, but includes the same levels.

- A big part of the game feels like a tutorial. The first 5 levels out of 9 constantly bring new mechanics to the table.

- Points, health and perfect turns are not explained well enough in the game. For example you need to time a turn perfectly to keep your wings open, but the game never tells you this as far as I'm aware.

- Long levels make it hard to replay your favourite parts of the game.


This game truly is a great rhythm game, and very fun for some people. If you like violent, responsive action I would recommend this for you. If you feel like the visuals of the game intrique you try it out, they make a great adventure. Do the war drums make your blood pump? Give it a go. If you are not a fan of rhythm games, or value your hard earned money, wait for a sale. Most importantly, if the trailers do not spark anything inside you, pass this one. There is not much more in the game that what it is shown in the trailers.

9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198071876796', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1627, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1308, 'last_played': 1549216190}
review:
Thumper gets so fast that your mind can't keep up with what is happening on screen while your hands still keep reacting.

From the first level onwards you are being trained to react instantly to the obstacles without even realizing and once you get into the flow, the game makes you fall into a trance like state where you don't even think about it.
You just ride the line and feel the rythm of the clashing metal

author: {'steamid': '76561197962665686', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 343, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 272, 'last_played': 1654561062}
review:
Not an easy rythm game, but a great one. The controls are simple, there is one button and a joystick (I use the Dpad).
The music and the visuals are really great, it really puts you in the mood to continue the level (they are long).

I'm not a big fan of rythm games, but this is a great one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004468758', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 280, 'playtime_forever': 39, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 39, 'last_played': 1514789955}
review:
This was an intense ride. I seriously doubted the psychological horror tag everyone had told me about, and I was wrong to do so. Core summery; You're a bug, you have 1 free hit before you die. Get hit, you lose your shell. After that, good luck. 

Admittedly, this game isn't a horror game by any means, but it is very weird. At times you may be uncomfortable and borderline freaked out. Specially if you're playing this in VR. All of this only really applies to VR. 

Anyway, there isn't much to this game. It's another rythm game, and an intensely challenging one at that. Most of the music is either electonic and / or base, so if that's your style you'll enjoy this game. You'll be hearing the track a lot, since you'll die a lot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045716689', 'num_games_owned': 1047, 'num_reviews': 144, 'playtime_forever': 922, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 637, 'last_played': 1665641727}
review:
This is a fantastic rhythm game which really nails the difficulty curve. It does a great job of easing you into mechanics and then building on them in a natural way. It does this to the degree that once you complete later levels, going back and clearing S-Tier on older ones becomes much less daunting. The control scheme is simple to learn, but difficult to master. Obstacles are very clearly telegraphed, so you can learn to anticipate what is coming next, but levels are also really generous with checkpoints, so even if you don't have the reflexes to "sight read" levels on the first go you can always grind through a section and feel like you've made real progress. The game also takes the occasional time-out to reward progress with psychedelic interludes, which are a fun break while still keeping you in the flow-state. (The game is also good about quickly reloading if you die or restart, which is also very important for this type of game.)

For players who don't need to grind through a section repeatedly just to pass, there are also optional next-level strats to clear levels on S-Tier. Clearing a boss can feel rewarding on your first time through; straight [i]crushing[/i] them when you're grooving with full understanding of the control set can be cathartic. There is also an online leader board can encourage you to push beyond that, which adds some further replayability.

Importantly, this will also run at 60 fps on a potato. With my GTX 1070 I could pull down over 1000 fps with the framerate unlocked. Real talk.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054374957', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 56, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 36, 'last_played': 1610836575}
review: An amazing sensory experience. Between the haunting background ambiant sounds, the incessantly beautiful, pulsing soundtrack, and the pops and flashes of light, I felt quickly drawn in as my mind tried to catch up to this insane beetle as it speeds down an infinite and terrifying track. Easily one of the best rhythm I've ever played. The only tragedy of Thumper is that I get so focused on the track and not dying that I don't always get the chance to marvel at the stunning and very trippy visuals going on around the track and in the background.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076745415', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 276, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 162, 'last_played': 1553567638}

author: {'steamid': '76561198403579744', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 645, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 497, 'last_played': 1527193512}
review:
Thumper is definitaly rhymic music game like on other. With its increadible soundtrack and fast Paced game play, its definitaly worhing picking up. Labeled as a Rthymic horror game, its not that big on horror unless you count in the weird boss designs and the ridiculous backround effects. 

What to expect: 
This is a game that get difficult very fast paced, so it best to repeat the first two levels until you feel that you can continue.
PREPARE TO FAIL alot! In this games later levels its gets extremly difficult and decisions must be made in a split second in order to get a perfect score. 

I rate this game 9.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198021338660', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 161, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 91, 'last_played': 1668741099}
review:
I played this when I had my PS4 and made it to level 4 or 5 I think. When I saw they had it for VR I HAD to try. 

Oh My God what a trip. I can only imagine that this is wet a dubstep artist's wet dream looks like. Color and sound all right there in your face while you're trying to watch what's happening in front of you. I loved it. It gets hard around the end of level 3 going into 4 but it's still fun. Plus the controller feedback makes it extremely satisfying when you hit the stuff for some reason.

Honestly, if you want to shut your brain off for an hour or so and just put yourself on auto pilot, this is the way to do it. It's also fun to get a couple of friends together and try to beat eachother's highscores. 9.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198060431824', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 755, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 350, 'last_played': 1711048196}
review:
Ni siquiera intentes pensar rapido, no pienses, solo reacciona... RAPIDO!

Habiendolo ganado hace una hora, tengo que decir que este es de esos juegos que sencillamente no podes levantarte del asiento, te da tanta satisfaccion haber terminado el nivel anterior que queres entrar al siguiente inmediatamente. Los minibosses, los niveles, los jefes finales, las visuales, el SONIDO! POR DIOS EL SONIDO es impresionante, cabe aclarar que tengo un home theatre en la pc y suena increible, un buen sonido grave en este juego le da la violencia de la que habla su creador.

Bien, llendo a la jugabilidad, fluido, sin glitches ni retardos en la respuesta, todo responde perfecto. 4 direcciones y 1 solo boton es todo lo que necesita este juego para obligarte a concentrarte y casi no poder pestanear de lo rapido que es.
Para perfeccionistas, tienen de sobra para mejorar su puntuacion ya que para estar en tops altos se requiere una gran tecnica y reflejos para poder juntar todos los puntos.

Lo recomiendo? si no te gustan los juegos rapidos, no.
Si te gusta la musica, los juegos de ritmo, los juegos rapidos, juegos tipo arcade o algo que puedas jugar en unos pocos minutos y conseguir progreso, bueno definitivamente Thumper es perfecto.

Para resumir, Thumper me hizo recordar a Nex Machina, un arcade dificil, de respeto a velocidad frenetica y sonido brutal. QUE ESPERAN PARA PONERLO EN LOS ARCADES? que no ven que se llenaria de gente? :facepalm:

author: {'steamid': '76561197994904389', 'num_games_owned': 483, 'num_reviews': 142, 'playtime_forever': 678, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 678, 'last_played': 1558890657}
review:
In simplest words, it is BIT.TRIP Runner combined with Audiosurf and loud cosmic horror atmosphere...

If you are fan of the various rhythm and music games, this should already cue you in now how the game plays out. If you are not familiar or you need refreshment, then I would say that Thumper isn't really your typical game of this genre, because there is hardly any music to synchronize with. It's not like your actions need to be bound to overarching rhythm (like in Crypt of the Necrodancer or Space Channel 5), it's your actions against obstacles [i]create[/i] rhythm and music in patterns that are later repeated in sequences of harder and harder challenges.

There are musical cues for the dangers forward, but those quickly suffocate in the loud noise of the sound design, so your better off relying on your reflexes, pattern recognition and muscle memory first and foremost, just like BIT.TRIP Runner. This doesn't make Thumper a bad game, but it's something to keep in mind to not be disappointed by the design chosen for it.

Music that is not generated by stomps, grinds and dashes of your little space-ship-beetle-things, is mostly used to create an atmosphere of tension and oppression. This game is a series or consecutive crescendo events, that become faster and more dangerous with every second and violent strings and drums during all of that make a fantastic job with reinforcing this theme. Game is fast, dangerous and keeps you one the high alert for extensive amounts of this, making an interesting audio-visual experience that is quite unique to its contemporaries.

Thumper's main issues lie mostly in expectations for the perceived design. Somebody might be disappointed that there is no "real" music to speak of and attune to for the duration of the gameplay. Again, that doesn't mean that the game is not worth recommending, far from it, but buying Thumper you need to be aware of that it really tries to achieve.

There is also a noticeable problem with tutorials and difficulty curve. Tutorial for the stomping mechanic was for me and many others (check forums) quite an irritating trial-and-error. Game tries to explain it to you, but the exact controls used for it can be hard to grasp of. Also, Level 6 out of 9 is noticeably harder than the rest of the game. Final level is not a cakewalk either, but high difficulty for it is expected. Level 6 doesn't have any justifications while it's far more difficult than others.

Overall, I had a plenty of good fun with Thumper and I can recommend it to fans of aforementioned games that are similar to it and action-game fans in general. However, its 20 dollar price tag is quite steep for 6-8 hours of content, but getting it on small/decent sale shouldn't be a problem.

author: {'steamid': '76561198090983403', 'num_games_owned': 98, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1081, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 750, 'last_played': 1573974154}
review:
Very fun and unbelievably satisfying rhythm game with a perfect (in my opinion) difficulty curve. The game also happens to be optimized enough that I was able to play half of the game on my 2013 craptop, but despite that the graphic style still holds up today.

Also play this with a controller with rumble, it adds to the experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097996356', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 206, 'last_played': 1667132826}
review:
This game is.... wow. Its a pretty unique experience.

Rythmic Violence sums it up pretty nicely and i can say its unlike everything i played before.
(i have waaaay more games outside steam)

I bought it on a whim after following on the sidelines for the last 2 years when it was on sale after i forgot about it for some time, and i can say it was worth the money ;)

And its challenging from time to time, other times its just awesome graphics and sounds... 

The most important/funny aspect i experienced myself with this game is how it gets you to WANT to avoid making mistakes while playing. Its not like in Guitar Hero when you miss.... this is wholly different.
You actually make the sounds yourself to the rythm (partwise yeah, but ... atleast for me this sums it up better than any explanation i could write out and strech through many many lines)

So

Just a THANKS to the developers of this game.

Its cool ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198032158092', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 919, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 766, 'last_played': 1706908974}
review: A horror game disguised as a Rhythm game, this is probably the only game of it's genre that I'm aware of that has this peculiar atmosphere: dreadful, oppressive and downright hostile towards the player. The game is better to be consumed in bursts and not in long plays since it leaves you emotionally and mentally tired after every level with how high intensity it is, but it's also one of the most immersive experience that you can find in it's genre, and can provide a big sense of catharsis if you are feeling down or angry. Completely reccomended.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972086456', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 70, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 70, 'last_played': 1524443239}
review:
I've played Thumper for around an hour and a half and I doubt I'll be getting much further into it. I love the concept and I thought it was an excellent game for the first level or two, but the reptitiveness of the music, in a rythm game of all things, means that the increasingly complex controls really have no payoff. You don't unlock new music or visuals the further you get in the game, just increased difficulty. 

If all you want is the thrill of mastering the conrols and getting perfect sequences then you'll probably enjoy this game. If you want changing scenery or music, or a sense of progress, you're out of luck. What you get in the first five minutes is pretty much what you're getting for the rest of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024876271', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 163, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 163, 'last_played': 1524457338}
review: This game has an exhilirating sense of speed and intensity that I haven't found in any other game. The forward momentum never lets up and moments of this game recal some of the best bits of Rez. The controls are supeer responsive and there's a definite 'one more try' kind of groove you'll get in to. Don't let the ease of the first level fool you either--more game mechanics and techniques are introduced as the game goes on and man does this game get HARD. This game rules. Can't say enough good things about it. Oh, and if you have some decent speakers and a sub woofer then crank them up. Sound is everything in this game. Blast forward and enjoy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000895832', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 1071, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 470, 'last_played': 1635725097}
review:
Played in VR and it was a pretty amazing experience. So much so that I immediately started playing it again after I beat it. I wasn't sure I'd like the music, and while it's not something I'd just put on to listen to, it works really well for the game.

I'd also highly recommend ignoring the notice about the controller. This game plays significantly better on a keyboard than a controller.  It's a lot more fun on keyboard too since it's much easier to get the perfect timings.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992675648', 'num_games_owned': 96, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 74, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 74, 'last_played': 1524049428}
review:
TL DR: Ultimately I refunded this game. It's pretty boring and the music is awful and grating. It's too easy, it's a rhythm game for people who are no good at rhythm games.

I love rhythm games, they are some of my favorite experiences in the realm of video games.  I was really expecting to love this game, but I do not.  I waited for it to go on sale for over a year and a half and finally downloaded it after seeing it recomended to me over and over, as well as watching videos on YouTube like the Game Grumps. I've been really excited for this game for a long time in the gaming world, only to be bitterly disapointed.

I only played it for an hour and 20 minutes and got half way through level 4/10 before realizing that the game has nothing to offer me, and anything it has to offer to anyone else already owns it.  It's a simple rhythm game. That's it. The visuals are pretty cool sometimes but get very old - very quickly - and the music (if you can really call it that) is harsh and grating and most ashamedly of all; boring and uninteresting.

The music, first and foremost, isn't music. It's an atmospheric drone, something that builds tension as you progress your way through the stages, then releases once you reach the end of the level. Over, and over, and over, and over, for every level just grating and scraping and then it starts over again!  I know why the devs chose this, it fits with the game's "psychadelic" tag pretty well in terms of if you were watching a movie and needed something to watch the visuals with, but as a game it's extremely tedious. It also lends itself well to the overall soundscape of the game (that despite all my problems with it is actually pretty good) if only because it takes a comfortable seat in the background so that you can hear the ques for the upcoming inputs - but it's SO boring.  It's a sin how boring the music is in this game. In my mind this  is a minimum of -3 points from the "out of 10" concept. It's unacceptable.

The game itself is no Taiko Drum Master. It's no Osu. It's no DDR. It's no Bit.Trip Runner. It's no Guitar Hero. It's no Impossible game. It's no GeoDash. It's not even a low end newgrounds rhythm game. Much of it's problem is the core game mechanics that dictate the games inputs were not well thought out by the team at Drool, in part it plays somewhat like a driving game, which could be really cool, but when you can hold a turn well before it comes while also holding a dash to break through the bars on the track the rhythm part of the rhythm game becomes irrelevent. The game never demands that you return to a "neutral stance" you just can if you feel like it, or ar trying to get a higher score, but even then it doesn't matter.

It also suffers from nonsense complexity that is clearly shoehorned into the game to make it feel more compelling than it really is. The bold text on the store page: "Notice: A traditional controller is strongly recommended to play Thumper" makes it seem like the game has some complexity to it that may benefit from a controller layout. Nope. The gameplay mechanics are so simple that they would be in no way hindered if they were converted to a tablet. Hold right, left, up, or tap down while ocassionally tapping, but mostly holding, the A button. In the case of many rhythm games this is a boon, like in GeoDash, a game that came to it's own in the mobile market, but in the case of Thumper it makes the game feel cheaply made and poorly thought out.

In my admittedly short time within the game I was able to achieve several S ranks while simultaneously angry at the poor control decisions, bored by the gameplay, and absolutely furious at the terrible sound design. I'm done with it.

With all of that said, I thouroughly expect other people to enjoy this game - ultimately it is quite compelling.  And while I figure that anyone who might enjoy it already owns it, it's possible that someone might not, in which case I'll leave you with this: If the music in you rhythm game is important, run! Don't walk away from this game; RUN! As fast as your legs can carry you! For everyone else you might as well give it a shot. Or don't. I don't care what you do, I'm not your mom.

review: A relentlessly surreal, rhythmic and psychedelic experience.  Very well crafted, polished and most of all extremely well thought out.  Vaguely similar to Audiosurf, but only in the sense that both are presented as a vessel (that you control) on a winding path, influenced, or guided by music or rhythm.  No choosing your own music here, as the whole experience is crafted to drag you with and suck you in.  Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198315479361', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 195, 'last_played': 1523366459}
review:
Thumper is the kind of game I come back to for an hour or two every once and a while. The controls are pretty intuitive, so you can jump in and out with ease. It's one of these 'easy to learn, hard to master' games, at least starting level 4, which separates the casual player, who just wants to complete the game, from the dedicated one who's going for that rank S, taking many more risks.

I saw many comments about the rhythm being off tempo. For some reason, there are som off beat sections in the first two levels, but none in the later stages. When it feels off tempo, it's either because of the rhythm itself that's weird - as in unconventional for non musician ears, or, most likely, because of you, playing just slightly inaccurately. The margin of error reduces with time, of course, as the tempo gets faster and faster, and the rhythms more intricate.
For instance, at the start of level 5, the game teaches you a new 'mechanic': some sections you'll have to play perfectly or else you'll lose a life (you have 2 per checkpoint). Except it doesn't say anything on screen. All it shows you is an iron gate and the usual blue dots on your way. You'll almost for sure miss the last part of the rhythm at least on your first try: the iron gate will come and zap you. 

That's one aspect I particularly like about the game: it doesn't want to help you. Tbf, if you're not going for max score, the game is pretty easy anyway, and if you're taking the time to endure the fails of perfect turns and sequences, trying to get that S, you don't need much help.

Other than that, the soundtrack is obviously fire. Wish the downloadable additional soundtrack had the alternate versions of the tracks but it's great as it is anyway. The visuals are actually immersive: you get lost in this infinite universe of red, green and yellow. There was this one moment when everything turned green I actually got chills from the visuals alone, and I'm only level 5.

So far so good, but it is missing some key elements.
~No multiplayer nor workshop. Everybody's asking for these two. Make it happen. Custom maps, custom tracks, multiplayer gamemodes (like 1v1 survival with some special powerups that refill with your score, for example).
~No 'endless' mode. Procedurally generated, with selectable stable difficulties or evolutive ones. Every game like this one needs that.
~Customization, because why not.
~Mutators (+ or - speed, blinded/half blinded [thinking of brutal mode in Guitar Hero], no sound...).

I bought the game for $5 or $10, and I don't regret it. 20 euros seems pricey for a single player game, and although the graphics and audio explain the cost, I can definitely see people rebuked by the price.

Thanks for reading!

author: {'steamid': '76561197999233349', 'num_games_owned': 508, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 835, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 480, 'last_played': 1700497594}
review:
Have you ever wanted a game that would bludgeon you senseless against the curb, leave you there so it could have a smoke, and then come back to beat you to a pulp some more just for good measure?

Thumper's like that. Its tagline is "rhythm violence" and it follows it without a fault. The background music is primal, you could almost expect demonic chanting to fade in at any point during it. It doesn't get in the way, and at the same time it floods the senses in a way that induces a very simple, aggressive euphoria. The percussion gives you hints as to what obstacles are coming up next, which is more of a useful tool than you'd think.

One could say that Thumper's just a game about reacting to obstacles. They'd be right, although there's more than a one-dimensional approach to them. For example, if you have two notes coming towards you, you could either smash both of them, or fly off of the first one to smash the second one even harder. It takes a special finesse to spot these sorts of options, and the game's much better once you find them.

Thumper manages to build off of its core very well, too. Many obstacles tend to build off others - for example, when there's more than one lane, worms can snake down one of the lanes and make it dangerous, causing you to shift back and forth. Or perhaps I could wring back in that fly-smash option I mentioned earlier - if you do those, you'll send blast waves along th track. Those waves can break certain barriers that might prevent bosses from being hit.

It doesn't hugely matter what platform you buy Thumper on. Just buy it. Seriously.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028806392', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 610, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 610, 'last_played': 1522974682}
review:
Every moment of Thumper is a heart-pounding, sweat-inducing nightmare of extradimensional shapes and sounds and after a gruelling slog through an hour long level from start to finish it really made me step back and think about why I play games like this.

Am I having fun? That's what games are about, right? Do I just want to beat it out of completionism? Would I be much better off and far more relaxed going for a walk in the wondrous beauty of nature?

The answers respectively: no, not necessarily, yes, maybe. But even though many would not consider Thumper a traditionally "fun" game, it's still a game that I feel deserves to be experienced. The levels are long, it reminds me of my fever dreams as a kid shoved through a kaleidoscope, it can get hard as balls, but that's the point.

And so I went and played another two entire levels. I need a lie down.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040335013', 'num_games_owned': 80, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 5182, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1236, 'last_played': 1620090457}
review:
This might be the first game I saw and then immediately set out to buy. There's not a lot of games that click with me like this, but this is one of them.

It's not primarily a music or traditional rhythm game. It was rhythms, it has beats, sure, it has plenty of patterns, and, as someone else put it, "it doesn't try to trick you." It does go along to a semi-predictable pattern, and you can start to "feel" when you have to do certain things. But it keeps you on your toes, and is supposed to be difficult, oftentimes relying on quick reflexes and sometimes memorization. It makes you feel as if you earned every ounce of your progress, and just feels great.

The difficulty curve is pretty smooth, but at lvl 5 it seemed steeper than the earlier levels. Lvl 7 felt faster than the others before it, and didn't exactly make things harder, but just faster paced and more fun. It's one of my favorites by far, and when I really realized how much I love this game.

The controls are extremely simple, but there's a lot you can do with them, and a ton of ways to raise your score. Definitely would recommend a controller for this though, the keyboard controls never really worked for me.

The levels have a great amount of replayability if you care about getting the S-ranks or climbing up on the scoreboard. Just running thorugh the game to beat it will proably take around 9 hours or so, I'd think.

Though it's simple and seemingly pointless, there is a kind of story present. Things get stronger, and there's a final boss that brings the whole thing to a really nice wrap. Maybe I thought too much into it, but it really kind of blew me away. After that, the beetle seemed more like a character than a souless moving piece for the game.

There's only one thing I don't like, and it's that the scoreboard doesn't tell you out of how many people you're placed, just where you are. So you have no idea in what percentile your score is in. It'd be awesome to see like 100/5000 or something to know just how impressive your score really is, and if you're above average or not. It takes a bit too long to scroll to the bottom of the leaderboards to see when they end.

Overall an exellent game, though. It really takes you on a journey, and is an experience I don't think anyone who's a fan of these kinds of games should miss. Just don't expect it to be a music game, because it's its own thing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002757060', 'num_games_owned': 224, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 128, 'last_played': 1519347631}
review:
This is a rhythm game where obstacles are out of rhythm most of the time. I'm halfway through the game and I have only heard one song, and it's really hard to even call it a song instead of just ambient noise.

The tutorials teach you how to handle some of the obstacles, but not all of them, and also fail to show you there are multiple ways to pass some obstacles. Then the game throws in some 2D worms that don't move at the same speed as the other obstacles.

You do everything with just one button and the analog stick, but sometimes you simply can't know if you're supposed to tap or hold the button, because you can't see the obstacles yet. Sometimes obstacles make different sounds depending on what you do, but the game never tells you what is the correct way.

The game tries to be minimalistic but it's just confusing because you don't know what's happening. At random points the level changes and you see your score, and I have no clue what the "kills" are on the scoreboard.

There are obstacles you can only pass by memorizing them, but the levels have no memorable spots to build memories around. It's just the same obstacles in the same sequences over and over again. Same backgrounds, same looping music, same everything.

The bottom line is: I didn't enjoy my 2 hours. I genuinely feel like I wasted my money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198128169336', 'num_games_owned': 223, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2625, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 469, 'last_played': 1710864910}
review:
Do you like dark music? Do you like playing rythm games? Do you want your thumb bleed all the time? THEN THIS GAME IS FOR YOU!!!

Honestly, when I heard about this game, I felt very hype that causes me a mental breakdown. A very fast-paced rythm hell can definetly be challenging and fun at the same time.

Although, I wish this game that you can able to upload or use custom music that can be edited by level editor. Sadly I have music that could fit this game and use it for own entertainment. But overall, I am loving and enjoying the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066021649', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 939, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 939, 'last_played': 1519065835}
review:
NOT PLAYED IN VR  (tho it'd probably be even wilder)

Thumper is great.  16 hours to S rank 100% at 20$ is pretty solid.  Challenging and fun, I haven't played anything like it before and the visuals are a real treat.  Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989575030', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 234, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 200, 'last_played': 1558347947}
review:
Intense, fast paced rhythm game. I've only played this in VR mode and let me just say wow.. The visuals in the stage designs are wierd trippy and really, really pretty, the games just too bloody fast to have a good look at them without crashing! The game starts off pretty easy but soon ramps up in difficulty! The gameplay is really fun with new mechanics and elements implemented with each stage. 

Obviously music is subjective but in my opinion the soundtrack is banging.

Overall great game and worth the purchase, I picked this up in the current Rez (Another I'd highly reccomend) and Thumper valentines offer and can honestly say I'd buy it full price in a heartbeat if it werent on sale!

Side note: Although not listed this works perfectly with a Windows Mixed Reality headset and also runs perfectly on my lower end PC (GPU esspecially!)

Running on:
-AMD FX 8320
-R7 360
-16GB RAM

author: {'steamid': '76561197995493019', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1517621054}
review:
The game looks gorgeous, but doesn't sound that good. What you hear in the trailer is what you can expect to hear the entire game. Big thumping drum beats, tense percussion hits, and... nothing else. Most damningly, the rhythm just doesn't feel right. I get the feeling that the music might not be synced with the gameplay. Maybe it's just that the music is super minimal (heard 0 melodies so far), but whatever the cause, I find I have to rely exclusively on my eyes.

It's not all bad though, after a 20 minute session I feel nicely exhausted. A really relaxed sort of exhaustion, like my brain just did yoga.

Get it on sale. It's interesting, but you can get a lot more bang for your buck elsewhere.

author: {'steamid': '76561198314468342', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 268, 'last_played': 1516898706}
review:
I like the game usually, not when it peaks in difficulty. Thumper will give you 5 levels of resonable challenge then fuck you in the eyesocket for one checkpoint with some levels being 5 or 6 times longer than the one before.
Why are some levels in a chrome tube so you can't see whats ahead?
Why does the left and right turn indicator sound so similar?
Why do I need to be 2x to get health back with a ground stomp?
Why does the 2x not have a constant indicator so I know I'm allowed to get health back?
Why do bosses no give health back inbetween phases unless you are perfect?
Why does the lazer ring exist in bosses if I have to retry the phase if I miss anything anyway?
Why am I not guarenteed health back after I complete a stage, leading to me missing the health then dying in the next stage?
Apart from that, fun game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025876140', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 198, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 152, 'last_played': 1705814148}
review:
Thumper is an interesting experiment, but it feels unfinished. It lacks sub-frame input detection and it's missing any kind of delay calibration, features which come standard in most rhythm games (even free ones). Then again, Thumper isn't really a rhythm game, at least not in the traditional sense. Most of the challenge comes from having to react extremely quickly as similar-looking obstacles come barreling towards you. Occasionaly I was killed without really knowing why, only to later discover that a projectile I was supposed to be avoiding happened to be the exact same color as the track.

The mechanics create a constant feeling of uncertainty, because the main button must be held down to perform many of the game's actions, yet at the same time you are frequently required to tap the button to hit the bars that come down the track. This means you're constantly second-guessing yourself about if you should be keeping it held down or not. Some people might find this to be valuble gameplay, but to me it broke the flow of the game and made it more stressful than fun.

The atmosphere created by the game is dark and forboding, which is an appreciated change of pace from the neon colored-rave that many rhythm games (there's that term again) seem stuck in. Unfortunately, it's largely this one note the whole way though (at least as far as I got), and the various stages seem almost indistinguishable from each other. Sometimes there are long, unskippable stretches where literally nothing happens, as if you're supposed to be so enraptured by whatever weird tentacle tunnel thing is ahead of you that you'll forget that there's nothing to do.

I wouldn't say Thumper is a bad game. I wouldn't even say it's a badly made game. I would, and will, however, say that it isn't nearly good enough to justify the current $20 price tag, given its simplistic gameplay, embarassingly baren settings menu, and lack of variety.

By the way, if you play on KB+M, I highly reccomend that you try mapping one of the mouse buttons to the main action instead of the spacebar. Unfortunately, you'll need to use third party software to do this, because the game doesn't allow mapping to mouse clicks. Sigh.

author: {'steamid': '76561198112336784', 'num_games_owned': 67, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 586, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 586, 'last_played': 1516392343}

author: {'steamid': '76561198385476551', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 165, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 140, 'last_played': 1521386426}
review:
Something about this game is both mesmerising and extremely unsettling. The audio and visuals match perfctly and the rythm gets me right in my chest every single time. I first saw the game on you tube and it doesn't do it justice. I highly reccomend experiencing this masterpiece for yourself. 

One thing I found so alluring about this game is the way it makes you feel both powerful and vulnerable at the same time. The unsettling build up to bosses which send shivers up your spine in anticipation are beautifully placed. The minimalistic design is an interesting and, in my opinion, a great choice, simple yet just enough detail to keep the eye entertained when the break periods come, but not so much that it distracts from the gameplay. Last little detail I loved are the little break periods which come once every level, they really do give your brain, eyes and hands a much needed rest which was a nice touch.

Final bit about the technical aspects of the game, I have one tiny complaint and It's that sometimes turns are hard to see when you're in tunnels if there are 2 or more one after another. Though I will admit that as the game progresses and your skills improve you'll start to pick up on audio cues telling you which obstacles and how many are ahead of you. Other than that, the controls are a dream, easy to catch on to and a challenge to master. a nice balance of difficulty and fun.

All in all and absolutely incredible game to test your reaction times and skills in a fun and exhillerating way. A work of art. Enjoy!

review:
This game is as fun as it is challenging and its unique in its simplicity. 
If you are a fan of rhythmic games like Audiosurf, then you should definitely get this one. Ive yet to beat it due to the challenge imposed at the stage Im on, however I can say it is a game worth playing to the end. It rewards you for paying close attenion to your own actions and punishes you for trying to spam buttons, so button mashers beware!

author: {'steamid': '76561198010024843', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 60, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 60, 'last_played': 1516325014}
review: This is a good enough game, but expect an almost N64-type low texture buffer feel to the landscape. It feels cheap. The music is odd, too. It has a wierdly satisfying uniqueness to it, though. You'd never listen to it anywhere else, but it's pretty good. This is almost like what would happen if you time-transported a 2017 dev rig to a mid-1980s game company.

review: What a fantastic game, very challenging but also very rewarding if you manage to hit optional objectives and get a good score. Very immersive, beautifully made and scored. Two complaints - final bosses seem out of place in terms of design, I feel like some geometric enemies (like mini bosses) would suit better. Also, when you make a mistake and lose armor, screen keeps shaking and debris obstructs your view for so long that sometimes it's impossible to recover because I can't see the track ahead, so I immediately die afterwards.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996672395', 'num_games_owned': 247, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 535, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 456, 'last_played': 1553312236}
review:
I only looked a little into the game before buying. I wanted to experience most of it myself. But the game didn't turn out how I was expecting. The first surprise is that this game is very hard. There are only 9 levels and a final boss, and the game starts getting hard around level 4. The next surprise is that it isn't really comparable to other rhythm games. The songs are minimalist, the rhythm of your actions doesn't always fit the beat, and you can't always see what's coming ahead of time. It also gets blisteringly fast. So the game is more based on trial-and-error. Trying to compare it to a rhythm game doesn't make it look good, either.

Custom Songs? No.
Modding? No.
Playing songs on different speeds? Practice mode? No.
Multiplayer? No.
Plans for more content? None at this time.

This is why I think it's better to think of the game as an experimental indie game, with an emphasis on the experience. The visuals and music definitely make for a strange experience. I haven't beaten the game yet, and I don't know if I will. I'm on Level 7. However, some people have really gotten into this game. Some people can S-Rank the hardest stages. But for me, it's too hard.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052815812', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 236, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 161, 'last_played': 1590230527}
review:
Thumper is NOT a rhythm game. 

I am only two hours in at the time of writing this, and I can garantee it's not a rhythm game.
You time your button presses based on the visual obstacles you see at the front. Sometimes, you can anticipate the obstacle according to the beats and claps as they set up ahead of you. And if you do the combo correctly, you will create a beat. 

What the dev absolutely, 100% accurately worded, is that it's a rhythm VIOLENCE game. 

You'll get slapped around left and right by neon walls and every sound of failed timing will hit you harder than actually losing a life. The game is rutheless in the way it switches up obstacles and doesn't intend to give you a break. I want to tear my hair out for all the C-ranks I earned on more than half the tracks, but I take consolation in knowing that, at least, I finished a level. The learning curve is insanely steep.

But despite all that, I love it and recommend it. 

Definitely not a game for perfectionst, cause it'll drive you NUTS.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031106404', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 565, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 565, 'last_played': 1514961650}
review:
Coming from someone who never plays rhythm games, Thumper was awesome. The first day I played it was the most fun I've had in a game in awhile.

Mechanics are simple, straightforward, very visible in levels, and very satisfying (especially perfect turns).
You can clearly tell how each death is your fault, and that's great. No stupid RNG or unreasonable sequences.

Level design is absolutely stellar. They don't just throw bullshit at you left and right and expect you to have perfect reaction time. Intuitive and sensible patterns are established in early levels, then reused and adapted in different orders for later levels.

The difficulty progression (difficulty relating to the order and density of sequences and the difficulty of sequences used) is incredibly smooth. There wasn't a single arbitrary difficulty spike in any level transition. Bosses were great; hard but reasonable.

Last but not least, the aesthetic. The intense, grating, horrific visuals and audio are beautifully unique for the genre, and they really take Thumper far. Having your senses assaulted feels great.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004671144', 'num_games_owned': 390, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 881, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 800, 'last_played': 1696375551}
