author: {'steamid': '76561198028199189', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 2251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2136, 'last_played': 1673676303}
review:
This game is basically perfect.

I'm not joking.

It's one of the few games that lives up to and then goes beyond your expectations, and the game description says EXACTLY what it is (isn't that a shocker). It's a horror themed rhythm game that makes you feel like you are on a rollercoaster avoiding hard to visually decipher obstacles, asking you to pick up on audio cues for the much needed assistance. I maintain you could play this game with the sound off even and have a good time, but it would be much much more difficult, and trust me when I say you don't want this game to be more difficult... It's a ball-breaker, and if merely beating the game wasn't hard enough, the true and blue gamer in you will be upset with the meagre score you got, and you will end up demanding that you replay the whole game, chapter by chapter enhancing your chapter scores, which is a motivational practice games haven't used since the atari days... or I guess just... other rhythm games...

To close out my review, the game is entirely enjoyable because of the bizarre nature of the aesthetic and theme, and is the most solid action-rhythm game I have ever played... If you like rhythm games, it is a must have. If you like mechanically solid games, it is a must have. If you like interesting themes, sound, atmosphere, and aesthetic, it is a must have. It is a game where I am convinced the only people who would not recommend this game are baby-people that can't beat the second chapter...

Buy this game, play it, beat it, beat it again and raise your high score, and then tell me you weren't rewarded for your time and effort. I dare you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198123651921', 'num_games_owned': 213, 'num_reviews': 122, 'playtime_forever': 439, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 394, 'last_played': 1533749833}

author: {'steamid': '76561198004214429', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 198, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 198, 'last_played': 1519505702}
review:
This game will make you sweat, it will make you cry, it will give you boosts of adrenaline, and it will make you feel like a king. It does a great job at being a rhythm game while also innovating with new features and mechanics on every level. At first you might feel that the game is pretty easy, but trust me when I say that it gets a lot more difficult around halfway through playing. The speed, tempo of everything increases rapidly and you'll be begging for mercy.

I wish I had given this game a try earlier, because it was well worth the purchase. Despite being developed by only one programmer and one composer it manages to look, sound, and play great. It's like a fever dream except it has all the annoying aspects of it removed.

[b]TL;DR[/b] this is a great rhythm, fast action-paced game with a high difficulty skill ceiling on the later levels and with very rewarding gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970512270', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 95, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 80, 'last_played': 1606013725}
review:
I saw this game on a list of "Great Games You Missed in 2017!" I'm a long time fan of rhythm games, producer of electronic music, and fan of cosmic horror. How could I not love it? Turns out this is one of the rare times I've really regretted buying a game on steam.

First off, this is the most arrhythmic "rhythm game" I've ever played. How it calls itself a rhythm game I dont know. It's a Simon Says/QTE game and your actions **sometimes** create musical moments after you input them. You won't be using your ears to input commands, you will be using your eyes, which is awful since a lot of the prompts are not even visible. You can input commands wrong/skip commands entirely and not be punished at all, but then die to a wall not even visible until the second you need to respond to it. 

The music is 100% forgetable and at no point do you feel a part of it. As I think back on my time playing, I remember the same boring kick drum, same boring snare, and a seemingly random placed preset synth for over an hour. 

If you want the better version of this game, it was made over 15 years ago and is called REZ. It's on steam. Spend your money on that and not this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025696276', 'num_games_owned': 865, 'num_reviews': 207, 'playtime_forever': 156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1700349336}
review:
I had to come post this as soon as I finished playing, because this game wowed me so much (though I should mention I this is more my initial impressions, since I only played about an hour). It's not often you see a game with such a unique premise as this, and even less often you see one so well executed. Everything is excellent, from the music to the visuals to the controls (even on keyboard). The music and visuals speak for themselves from the trailer, but I do really praise the controls. They feel so precise that when you inevitably mess up you have no one to blame but yourself. The difficulty curve too, is perfect. It starts you off slowly, and as soon as I found myself thinking, "I feel like I could take on a bit more," there it was. So far nothing has felt bullshit either, everything has been very fair and when I mess up it's my fault.

The only nitpicks I have are: 
1. It took me much to long to figure out how to recenter my headset
2. The synth-y non percussive elements of the music could be a bit louder, I sometimes have to focus to hear them and you can't afford extra focus in this game
3. The first two bosses look nearly identical. Maybe it's just the first two but it would be disappointing if such an excellent visual style was wasted on only a weird tiki head looking dude.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028441712', 'num_games_owned': 1349, 'num_reviews': 147, 'playtime_forever': 868, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 773, 'last_played': 1705148703}
review:
[h1]80 / 100[/h1]

[b]Thumper[/b] has a subline, dreamy design focus where the artwork, music, sound effects & streamlined gameplay combine to set the tone, altering your perceptions of reality. It's trance-inducing, beautiful & strange, but the void is full of surprises.

[b]Be one with the Space Beetle[/b]; it all starts out calm, introducing you to the basic control scheme through the first set of stages & how to combine them, but your peaceful existence quickly ramps up. Before you know it, it's a hardcore, ludicrously fast challenge of your reflexes. As with other rhythm based games, the longer you go without mistakes the higher your score will become. Mistakes don't often spell the end of the run, but too many in sequence & the [b]Space Beetle[/b] will not be happy.

All the controls are boiled down to a single button & directional input combinations. Although simple, it did feel a little counter-intuitive for me, taking a short while to get a grip on the timings & position of the hit zones. Using both press & hold actions for the button adds some complexity as you transition between flying above or gliding on the track. Whichever move you make, they all have a great tactile response. Grinds feel heavy, jumps hit the ground with the impact of a super hero & glides through the air have that light touch.

[b]Pure Rhythm?[/b] There are sections very precise with the rhythm timings but as it speeds up & the adrenaline pumps it loses some cohesion. Relying on the rhythm for your action timing can become problematic in later stages & throw you out. The music adds a massive amount to the experience, but does veer away from being more pure rhythm based gameplay as it gets harder. Outside of the alignment to the music, the levels are well designed and generally flow well.

Although I enjoy a challenge, the main drawback with [b]Thumper[/b]  [i](for me)[/i] is the overall difficulty level increased too quickly. It goes from very easy to crazy fast in just a few levels, which limits the level variation you can access without pushing through. If you are a mere mortal & get stuck like I did a lot [i](& still am!)[/i], then the repetition of the levels may discourage frequent replays & just lead to abandonment. I still like to come back and play as it is truly a great game, but wish a "Play[b]-[/b]" mode was added for those less rhymically inclined like myself to at least experience the full game. For the price, it‚Äôs a little light on the content; more levels or random mode would also be welcomed.

Most aptly titled, [b]Thumper[/b]  certainly lives up to its name. Thumpin' audio & visuals & Thumpin' physics & controls, it‚Äôs a one-of-a-kind experience that will melt your synapses!


[url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6857016/]If you enjoyed reading this review, please follow [u]True Blue Reviews[/u] for more recommendations![/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561198173053369', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 436, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 263, 'last_played': 1687494119}
review:
To sum it up, this game is wonderful. The controls are responsive, the graphics feel like you are on a drug trip yet manage to stay good. And the music! The music goes perfectly with the beats from the gameplay making it so much easier to get a grasp on how to play and do successfully in the game. There is a feeling of reward after hitting a beat, and and even better feeling of reward after a perfect, this is because it makes different sounds based on how you land it. Normal for normal, enhanced for perfect. The different ranks/grades will motivate you to strive for a S or an S+ (Depending on the mode). There is an extreme amount of replay value making it so much worth the amount you pay for it.

In my opinion, this is for sure worth the buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198143592931', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1884, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1658, 'last_played': 1616530969}
review:
Thumper is awesome and beautiful. The tension is structured so well that although it is frustrating, I forgive the game within minutes while playing it. I went through levels 1 to 3 on keyboard and went for S rank. Succeeded through determination. When I tried level 4 I could not keep that up at any sublevel/part of level 4 (read checkpoint). I got through those hard and awe inspiring levels this way but the final boss was so hard I had to beat him with a traditional controller. 
Staying adapted to the switching of lanes was possible because of it.

If there are any professionals out there that can finish this game without a controller I would like to see them try. Just don't wreck your keyboard. Thumper looks unique and is the only rhythm game that stood out to me enough to buy, but don't risk breaking your keyboard over it. 

This requires a traditional controller to keep going for a longer time at your best skill. The only game I have that requires that controller to a greater degree is Attack on Titan: Wings of Freedom.

Also, the certainty of having a failed turn when you could have sworn you had that perfect turn is a reccuring event akin to and more common than the "can't place that there milord"s of a stronghold game. It just doesn't have the same semi pleasant sound to it.  But the almost explosion like movements going on when you take damage (just what flies of of your beetle, it doesn't affect your control) looks amazing. The death explosion looks incredible too.

Frustration, beauty and sound come together to lure you into and pull you out of gaming. It also gives a pretty consistent adrenaline rush. I don't know how to compare it to another game and that is why I nominated Thumper for defying discription.

author: {'steamid': '76561198247371564', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 53, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 39, 'last_played': 1554524875}
review:
Bought this to play on the HTC Vive. It is probably fun on the PC, but it is really, REALLY not set up for VR yet. The commands aren't really explained at all, so you have to just fumble around trying random things until something works. When a command does work, it does not work consistently. They suggest that you play with a gamepad or keyboard, but obviously you can't SEE a gamepad or keyboard while in the VR headset, which complicates gameplay.

Not hating on the game-- I just think people considering buying Thumper to play in VR should receive fair warning.

review: Great take on a rhythm game! Minimal but gorgeous art style and a somehow drastic atmosphere. It's hard to describe or show people what makes this game so appealing, so if you're into rhythm games, I recommend you check this out. It definitely has that "just one more try" factor to it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960462483', 'num_games_owned': 10581, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 163, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 163, 'last_played': 1492666053}
review:
Thumper is a very zen-like game with a great soundtrack and visuals that lull you into a very "chill" space as you play, though still demands fast reflexes to do well. 

You speed along a track with various turns and obsticals which you must navigate either by steering appropriately or hitting an action button to speed up, jump or other actions. All these are timed with the game's electronica soundtrack (making it much in the vein of Rez or Frequency/Amplitude).  The game can be difficult - most stages only give you one allowed mistake and you're forced to repeat it. The stages don't change in terms of layout, so mastering some requires learning the track's actions. Along the way there are opportunities for grabbing bonus elements that can restore that one mistaken if you get several, but some require very careful timing.

It also has creative boss battles that use the same type of collection aspect to launch attacks against the boss. 

The whole game is minimalist in instruction, so there is some learn-as-you-go elements, but the stages and checkpoints are frequent enough to not be frustrating.

This is the perfect type of game to slip on some headphones and play through when you just need to relax, since it readily immerses you into the sights and sounds of the game. It's not necessarily a groundbreaking title, but production-wise it is excellently done.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040723146', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 651, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 452, 'last_played': 1648184164}
review: If you wish to take over my mind, give me a controller and make me play this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068936422', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1904, 'last_played': 1607399677}
review: Thumper is the rhythm game that has it all - satisfyingly tight gameplay, beautifully eerie visuals, and incredible sound design.  The audio cues for upcoming obstacles can be pure sensory overload at first, but the game never feels unfair in its design.  Plus, earlier levels gain extra replayability from abilities and tricks learned in later levels.  The additional "plus" levels offer an intense challenge... but once you're in the zone, it's one of the most rewarding rhythm game experiences you'll have, hands down.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999260983', 'num_games_owned': 575, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 108, 'last_played': 1572074515}
review: Speeding towards certain doom you see the horrifying maw eager to destroy you. With every jump, slide and ricochet you push forward on a singular path knowing that was lies ahead is victory or death. The Drums beat, the back of your skull tingles and you think for a moment that you can do it. Gliding ever closer towards the inevitable your timing grows more precise; with every failure your reflexes sharpen until finally you reach the end. Your not certain what was achieved but you know it was good.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023560303', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1309, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1262, 'last_played': 1647840563}
review:
I played Rez on the Dreamcast in 2001. Then again, later, with the PS2 and 360 rereleases, and again this year with the Steam release. I largely consider the game incomparable, with nothing else I've played since quite matching its style, but if there ever were an heir to Rez's legacy, it would be Thumper. 
Rez came out 16 years ago and still feels futuristic, in a distinctly zen-cyberpunk sort of way. Thumper, though barely a year old, carves out a similarly fresh niche with its unsettlingly organic surreal-futurist hellscape. More than anything else, Thumper feels intense. Thumper makes your palms sweat and your heart race. At once mercilessly unforgiving in its execution and yet completely fair in its rules, Thumper teaches you everything you need to know and then expects that you will learn and understand. Thumper throws a tremendous amount of light and noise and motion and discordancy and trusts that you will sort out the information that you need from all of the madness and push through the maelstrom it sends your way. 
And then there's the last level. Christ, the last level. It may be brutal but it's worth the entire effort of the rest of the game to see how the last level subverts all the rules you've learnt up to that point. 
If you enjoy the merest concept of a rhythm game that effects an actual physical response from the player, play Thumper. Just don't play it on a keyboard unless you've got a decent orthopedic surgeon.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030919282', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 542, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 44, 'last_played': 1517588941}

author: {'steamid': '76561197972384613', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 5256, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3570, 'last_played': 1707817196}
review:
First of all, I'm an enormous fan of music and rhythm games, and if they're available for Steam, I have probably played them.  Everyone's tastes differ, obviously, but I'd like to say I know what I'm talking about!

This is probably my most favourite rhythm game of all time - for the super-satisfying, visceral, heart-pounding experience, for the exciting but fair challenge, for its crazy abstract aesthetic, but also for being a really excellent GAME.  EVERYTHING about it is good - the visuals, the controls, the challenge, the soundtrack, the game design.  More on that later...

*****************************
WILL I LIKE THUMPER??

- If you enjoy rhythm or music games, Thumper may be for you.
- If you enjoy feeling a fast-paced, highly visceral connection to what you're playing, Thumper may be for you.
- If you enjoy psychedelic imagery and abstract, transcendant experiences, Thumper may be for you.
- Check out gameplay videos of Thumper on YouTube - does it excite you, or give you ASMR-like satisfaction just from watching it?  Thumper may be for you.

It did all of these things for me.  I was dying to love Thumper, but will I ACTUALLY like it??

As far as I can tell, people who wanted to like it, but didn't enjoy Thumper mostly have a problem with the fast-paced nature of the game - they claim it requires memorization or unreasonably fast reflexes.  I **strongly** disagree.  I had this problem with the game Cosmophony - the final level required careful memorization and practice, and could only be done through painfully learning the sneaky parts that WILL kill you the first time.  I like hard games - challenge isn't the issue - but having to memorize passages defeats the purpose of music games for me - I want to respond and react to the sounds as they happen, not be concerning myself memorizing button sequences.

Easy solution!  Watch a YouTube video of the final level of Thumper, Level 9.  Notice you can hear audio cues ahead of time for each obstacle, as well as clearly see where obstacles appear further down the track most of the time.  This is as hard as the game gets.  If you're interested in Thumper, and it seems reasonably doable to you, GET THE GAME.  ITS SO GOOD.

There's also another portion of "didn't like Thumper" because they didn't like the soundtrack.  Again, just watch a bit of it, and decide for yourself if that's something you can get into.

*****************************

Thumper is an **excellent** game with a carefully constructed difficulty curve.  There are tricky passages of course, but you have the equivalent of two hit points, and if you lose any, you have the ability to gain them back with skill.  There are also regular checkpoints, so you never have to grind levels from the beginning.  The controls are beautifully simple and approachable - Left Right Up Down X - and yet you'll find there's a lot you can do with those basic buttons if you really want to get into it.

Ultimately, it's fairly simple to learn the basics and sail through the levels and simply survive, but there is a ton of room for precision and expertise - if you want to up your challenge, you don't even need to try different play modes.  Thumper lets you make it harder on yourself just by attempting trickier moves.  For example, don't just survive the corners - perfect them for stacking bonuses!  But if you mess up the timing, you might die.  Do you just get by, or do you risk going for the bonuses?  

The better you get at the game, the more challenge it has to offer, and is extremely satisfying to "get right."  I can't recommend this game enough.  My ONLY warning is some people have problems "seeing" the track ahead of time - just check it out on YouTube first!

Oh, and a note on controllers: YOU DON'T NEED A CONTROLLER.  The visceral feedback from controller vibration is awesome and super satisfying, but I actually find keyboard to be a much better for this game.  You need accuracy and precision if you really want to master the game, and I find the millimeter I need to twich my finger faster and easier than having to roll my thumb around on a D-pad or joystick.  Or maybe I just have tiny thumbs.  Whatever.  Point is, controllers not required.

Please support this game.  Aside from it being an awesome game, I had some technical difficulties and lost my game file due to an unrelated computer problem - the developer promptly addressed my problems and sent me a replacement file so I didn't lose any progress.  They seem awesome.  Just buy it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197965596494', 'num_games_owned': 1452, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 76, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 76, 'last_played': 1513519539}
review:
As someone who has had many incidents with medical, prescribed drugs, and general physical side effects, I have only ever experienced something this intense in my worst fever dreams.

You can be forgiven to think this is a simple rhythm game. Each boom and note plays with your sanity, the visuals mesmerise you into a false sense of hope, yet gameplay wise each and every move is in the name of survival.

My first experience with this game was on the PSVR Demo disk. I was taken on one of the darkest rides that exceeded anything from American McGee‚Äôs Alice, and no matter how hard I wanted to, I simply could not stop.

Worth it at any price. Beyond worth it with VR, if you got the constitution to hold out :)
.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999355453', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 653, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 653, 'last_played': 1511437587}
review:
An extraordinary rhythm game that will melt your mind. It's like BIT.TRIP, If the creators of BIT.TRIP.RUNNER doused themselves in LSD and injected acid into their eyeballs.

Pros
+ Soundtrack is S+
+ The Feel
+ Visuals
+ Game Mechanics

Cons
- Difficult to pick up
- Unforgiving

Overall a great game, better than I expected. Definitely worth the price, specially if you're high as a kite.

8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198041616520', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1418, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1307, 'last_played': 1522879757}
review:
My god, have I ever found a game I've fallen in love with to this extent? I've always been a huge racing fan, Anti-grav ones that reach overwhelming speeds. And then there's the part where I'm ok with rhythm games, not my favorite. But you take high speeds, add a pounding soundtrack, and then add in all the powerful pounding you require to do in the game, and god do you have a complete win of heart from me. 

The game is, beware, VERY addicting.
The controls are tight.
Every moment of each beat is powerfully satisfying.
While the levels get harder, they become only more enjoyable. Level 9, it's final sub-levels and it's final boss segment have ultimately become my favorite part of the game.

This whole thing is so satisfying to play. Downsides?
I suppose the difficulty curve at level 6 may seem a bit steep, may discourage some people. But if you bust through that, the game gets so much better.

I have to highly encourage, reach the end of the game. You won't regret it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198273817002', 'num_games_owned': 168, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1344, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 622, 'last_played': 1684187403}
review:
This is a pretty dang good game. I find it challenging and addictive, its particularly hard if you're trying for perfect S scores like me. So far I've gotten a bit into level 5 and sometimes I question my willpower on getting the S rank. I've had to take a break but I will be giving it another shot real soon. I will get every acheivement!
That said, if you're not into self-inflicted mental torture it's still good. A lot of it is memorizing patterns rather than pressing buttons to the beat, but even then it's real satisfying when you thump and slide to the drums. The music is great and you will feel it in your core, especially when you die. 
Some cons I find in the game is that sometimes it feels off, like to not miss the "thumps" I find myself having to press the button a bit before the beat, which is slightly annoying but eventually you kind of get use to it and its not as bad. I found this mostly a problem in level 1-2 when it's slower and not as complex. 
There's also been times when the track waves quite a bit (like during boss fights and special moves) and it waves so much that it hurts the beetle. This did get annoying, particularly on difficult levels that I had to do over and over again. I would finally make progress and this wave that acts like a turn hurts me and ruins the score. Perhaps this wouldn't be so bad if it was consistent but sometimes it doesn't happen. I'm not even sure if you can turn as there is practically no warning.
Overall I found this game worth the money. If you like rythm games this is the game for you, and if you want a challenge go for S ranks, if not, then don't. I'd probably would have finished the game by now if I wasn't going for perfect ranks. Previosuly I gotten half way through level 4 in two or three hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991019822', 'num_games_owned': 992, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 154, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 154, 'last_played': 1485977035}
review:
It's like if Audiosurf held a pistol to your head and said "THIS IS MY MUSIC NOW" while cackling maniacally.

It's good.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003530570', 'num_games_owned': 1302, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1296, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1156, 'last_played': 1629647483}
review:
There's something quite unique about this game. Through the steam store video, screenshots, youtube let's plays and etc, it is clear that it has an identity of its own: surreal graphics, a peculiar soundtrack, a simple rhythm game; What wasn't clear to me was that this game would give me a weird rush playing it, almost adrenaline-like.
Each time the space beetle would collide with a wall, each time I made it jump and land and shoot, each time a boss was killed, it just made me want to play more, and more, and more. I wasn't expecting to become "addicted" to this game the way I did, so that was a nice surprise.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002062454', 'num_games_owned': 1484, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 901, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 901, 'last_played': 1509904602}
review:
I really loved this at the beginning, then it kept dragging out without new mechanics and totally similar levels for so long that i dropped it multiple times.
The difficulty is the main weak point as you can simply "survive" the levels without too much effort except for bosses, the only challenge comes from scoring ranks S but it's really frustrating being mostly mnemonical and with some checkpoints being so far away.
It's not even a real rhythm game, as there rarely is any music to follow, you ARE the beat yourself with a lot of cool repeating patterns and buildups, but this makes you rely on visual clues that can be pretty hard to spot with the oversaturated graphics.
That being said the gameplay is fresh, and it looks and plays perfectly. I'm really torn on this one.

+ Tight controls and fresh gameplay
+ Trippy aesthetics
+ Groovy soundtrack
+ Perfect 21:9 support
+ VR support

- Really overstays its welcome with 9 world that all look and play the same
- Rhythm is often hard to follow, visual clues are unconsistent
- Difficulty mostly comes from trying to get high scores

3/5

My one complaint is that I wish the xbox 360 controller I use rumbled more during game play. This game is heavy on the beats and I want to feel it when I hit the corners and jump up and down. some more rumbling would boom nicely with the low bass in the headphones.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013348609', 'num_games_owned': 836, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 561, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 284, 'last_played': 1525148711}
review:
Up until Level 6-Œ© this game is a 10/10 for me. The visuals, sound design and music are truly outstanding, well done Drool.  

But the final boss of 6-Œ© is just bullshit that changes everything you learnt so far because its "obstacles" are off beat, you are better off playing this battle without sound, which in my opinion just a terrible design choice. After about 90 minutes of nonstop trying I finally managed to beat the boss but frankly I dont even know why I kept trying for so long? Maybe to just prove myself that I dont suck as a gamer? I dunno but one thing is for sure Im not going back to this game after this stupid gimmick boss battle, it sucked so hard it deleted my whole motivation to finish this game. 
If you are patient gamer that loves a (bullshit) challenge then go ahead buy it and have your fun with it because this game is amazing. BUT I cannot give this game a thumbs up with a clean conscience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198153529314', 'num_games_owned': 100, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 560, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 143, 'last_played': 1669885176}
review:
Oh. My. God.
It's one of the most sensibly difficult rhythm games I've played so far. I say sensibly because most rely on rapidfire keypresses, whereas every death was purely of my own doing. The controls are smooth and responsive, the visuals are colorful and amazing (if not confusing as hell during the later stages) and the music. It's a constant anxiety rousing drumline that changes with each sequence you need to remember. Each individual obstacle has a sound signature in the background, and if you don't pay attention, you'll get blown to billions of shreds. I've never felt actually compelled by a rhythm game, let alone an on rail style game in general. 8/10.

review:
I played this in VR, so my experience will be wildly different from someone just playing on a screen. 

This game, is insane. I don't think I've ever had such a tron-like experience in any VR game I've ever played. It's wildly simple, and yet challenging. 

I needed a moment to get my bearings after taking off the headset. If you own a VR headset you owe it to yourself to play this game. The audio experience alone is worth the price tag.

[h1]AT FULL VOLUME[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198319440015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 1102, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 970, 'last_played': 1688495321}
review: This game was fun. For me it was a challenge all of the colors and speed and having to hit spots perfectly made me only do a level at a time because my brain wasn't able to keep up. I thank God for the Ultrawide support for this game and with headseat in the dark with all of those colors was intense. It was the perfect game to get me out of my gaming draught. I got it on sale and it was worth it. I think it's worth the $20 but i would wait for another sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070569026', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 314, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 272, 'last_played': 1700807300}
review:
Absolutely fantastic. I was really afraid that it would make me sick, but not at all. I haven't had a single second of nausea throughout any of my first few hours.

It starts very easy, teaching you the basics of how to play, and then takes you on a full ride of skill. The musics (or rather the ambiances) are really good, the graphics are amazing (I love the GLOW), and the challenges get harder and harder after each level.

This is definitely one of my best purchases on Steam, and the absolute best VR experience I have tested so far.

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198009877085', 'num_games_owned': 616, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1163, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 902, 'last_played': 1600101204}
review: Thumper is sustained tension and dread in rhythm game form, condensing the sense of being in an out-of-control vehicle and barely staying fully conscious into a small metal scarab flying down an interdimensional highway. It‚Äôs unfamiliar and troubling, but striking and hypnotic and hella fun. Onlookers will think you‚Äôre opening a portal to Cool Hell.

Í≤åÏûÑÏùÑ ÌïòÎã§Î≥¥Î©¥ Î™®Îì† ÏãúÏã†Í≤ΩÏù¥ Í≥§ÎëêÏä§Îäî ÎäêÎÇåÏù¥Îã§.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043819759', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 571, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 379, 'last_played': 1525521028}
review:
Thumper es un juego r√≠tmico que se desarrolla en una pesadilla psicod√©lica. Manejamos a un escarabajo que se desplaza a toda velocidad por una v√≠a infinita en el hiperespacio y debe sortear obst√°culos dispuestos seg√∫n un ritmo musical infernal hasta enfrentarse, al final de cada nivel, a una cabeza alien√≠gena demon√≠aca gigante. Es tan alucinante como suena.

El juego tiene un control sencill√≠simo, podr√≠a manejarse literalmente con un mando de una consola antigua de Atari: necesitamos un stick de control (recomiendo pararse en las opciones para ajustar un poco la sensibilidad de la palanca) y un bot√≥n de acci√≥n. A medida que nuestro escarabajo se desplaza por los ra√≠les, aparecer√°n unos indicadores luminosos siguiendo el ritmo de la m√∫sica: si presionamos el bot√≥n de acci√≥n cuando estemos encima de ellos, aumentaremos nuestra puntuaci√≥n al final del segmento del nivel, y si encadenamos varios indicadores lograremos cadenas de combos que aumentar√°n a√∫n m√°s esta puntuaci√≥n. Estas cadenas de combos, por cierto, son la √∫nica manera que tendremos de derrotar a los jefes: tenemos que "clavar" cuatro secciones para lanzar cuatro disparos al enemigo y derrotarlo, sin fallos.

A medida que pasamos niveles se van a√±adiendo nuevos obst√°culos que requerir√°n distintos movimientos, y aqu√≠ entra de nuevo el bot√≥n de acci√≥n: si lo presionamos, protegemos a nuestro escabajo, y esto es imprescindible para sortear las curvas, recodos y trampas del escenario. Pero no podemos mantener presionado todo el rato el bot√≥n: primero porque sino jam√°s lograremos cadenas de combos, y segundo porque mientras estemos protegidos el escabajo estar√° fijado en uno de los ra√≠les (y por tanto, en el momento en que haya m√°s de uno en pantalla tendremos un problema). Tambi√©n podemos hacer que vuele el escarabajo moviendo el stick hacia arriba, y as√≠ podremos desplazarnos incluso estando protegidos manteniendo el bot√≥n de acci√≥n; y si movemos el stick hacia abajo para aterrizar justo cuando estemos encima de un indicador luminoso lanzaremos un disparo (imprescindible para eliminar unos escudos que aparecen a veces para proteger a los jefes).

Como vemos, el control se basa principalmente en moverse a los lados (y en determinados momentos arriba y abajo) con el stick manteniendo pulsado o no el bot√≥n de acci√≥n. Es muy sencillo, y sin embargo el juego est√° tan bien dise√±ado que constantemente despliega situaciones variadas y complejas. Es un juego muy dif√≠cil y exigente: no depende tanto de seguir el ritmo (aunque esto es imprescindible para alcanzar las mayores puntuaciones) como de tener buenos reflejos... y algo m√°s que buenos reflejos en los tramos m√°s traicioneros.

Yo no tengo gafas de RV, pero no las he necesitado para disfrutar del juego; si alg√∫n d√≠a las tengo ser√° un incentivo para volver a jugarlo. Da igual c√≥mo lo jugu√©is: es una experiencia audivisual terror√≠fica y alucinante. Hay que verlo para creerlo.

Totalmente recomendado.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075374479', 'num_games_owned': 676, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 606, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 201, 'last_played': 1526078800}
review:
I normally don't really play rythm games, regardless of the music, I've never found myself to entralled by them. This one hooked me in when I first saw glimpses of gameplay. Perhaps it is due to my lack of experience in the genre, but this game feels like it does everything in it's power to have the gameplay/movement and visuals directly correlate to the music/beat. 

It starts off nice and easy to get you into the mood, then after a while it ramps up difficulty and chaos just enough to still be fun. The visuals are great and complement the music which can be hectic yet still have a sort of luring pattern to it. 

My only complaint is that in the later levels (I've only made it to level 4 btw), the music and beat become very sperratic and the gameplay turns into a constant test of reaction time more than following the beat (which may become drowned out by the sound effects in-game). 

Overall, it is a game that feels very satisfying when you play well. I recommend it to anyone who has the money to drop (and a controller, the added vibration makes it much more cathartic).

author: {'steamid': '76561198306602665', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 66, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 66, 'last_played': 1505337419}
review:
Thumper was simply not for me. It felt very boring. I felt like the only thing the game required me to do was to press buttons to the tune of some boring music. The difficulty gradually increases as you complete the first few levels but price-wise (¬£16) it was not fun enough for me to continue playing or justify keeping the game in my collection. If the price was less than ¬£5 I'd have probably given it a second chance. 

The VR support was lame because there was no roomscale or motion-controller support, but even if there was, I don't know how that would have made the game any better. Perhaps if I could sit in the cockpit of an actual Space beetle in VR mode and make it jump, turn, strafe, dive etc to the tune of the music using the motion controllers or the HMD then may be I could have probably justified the price. 

For both VR and non-VR you can get more interesting rhythm-based games for less than ¬£10 (Polynomial 2, Soundboxing, Chroma Lab, etc).

Having said all that, if you are a big fan of rhythm-based music games and don't have VR, then buy it on sale if it ever goes below ¬£5.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021016212', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 886, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 390, 'last_played': 1507594310}
review: Finally, a game I feel I didn't waste money on. I‚Äôm late and everyone has said everything that needs to be said. One of the faster games out there, seriously. Whaaaaaat? Sliding difficulty and I love how sloppy the turns can feel on the controller. I'd play it. Standard courses are more fun than the boss fights. 5 hours in and it has left more expression and lasting memory than anything in the recent past. Also worth noting this game seems to expose a common thread in modern videogames that require story and narrative before the industry takes itself seriously. A game that shows videogames is a combination of button presses and continues to build on itself. My problem with many games out there is how they introduce something and that's it. This game asks more of you as a player than a spectator.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988545123', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1916, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1915, 'last_played': 1523178320}
review:
I've been playing video games for 25+ years and Thumper might be my favorite ever. The way the game assaults your senses is both exhausting and immensely satisfying. My play sessions were usually not much longer than an hour because I started to have trouble focusing after a while due to the intensity. This also meant that I never felt bored or like I was grinding. The 30ish hours I played feel like much much longer due to that intensity.

My first casual playthrough was a great experience on it own. I encountered a difficulty spike somewhere in the middle and another one later on but eventually got past it. When I replayed for S-ranks I started to appreciate the game on a whole new level. On my first playthrough I was just focused on surviving, which was tense enough as it was at my skill-level. When playing for S-ranks you have to play near-perfectly and you have to learn a bunch of new techniques that you didn't need when playing casually. I really got to appreciate how the levels slowly teach you new concepts and then just keep building on them more and more. It was also funny how on my first playthrough the bosses were the most difficult, but with S-ranks it was the levels themselves and the bosses almost felt like a break where you could relax a bit.

I usually don't replay games and the reason I did for Thumper was because its actions were so satisfying to perform and the state of mind I had to be in. If I got too stressed or frustrated I would make too many mistakes and would be unable to proceed. I had to remain calm in the face of repeated failure and the sensory overload the game throws at you. Every time I tried to learn a bit more or improve my muscle memory. That calm combined with the amazing sound, visuals and speed has made it one of my best experiences in gaming.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047371910', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 130, 'last_played': 1482986681}
review: The game is alright honestly, but I find the gameplay to be somewhat boring and it evolves slowly. Even when you get to some of the more diffifult levels it doesn't seem that crazy because the music is essentially just percussion. I was hoping more types of music and more colors would be a part of the game. It's ok but I can't recommend it for 20 dollars.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007002372', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 981, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 876, 'last_played': 1597629418}
review:
Pros:

- Very good pacing overall. It has enough small breaks and it switches between long and short levels often. 
- Music based game done well, for the most part.
- Visually unique.
- Very responsive and intuitive controls.
- The first game that actually made me want to S-Rank clear every level. This never happens to me.
- Very nice overall atmosphere and "world" design.

Cons:

- Sometimes the rhythm is all over the place, as in: It changes too much sometimes.
- In some levels (especially the last ones) the visuals are over the top making it hard to see the jumping pads.
- Some later levels seem easier than earlier levels. This can just be me being weird though. Difficulty is a subjective term to an extend after all.


Overall score: 8.2/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198016305560', 'num_games_owned': 706, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 1879, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1125, 'last_played': 1672549354}
review:
Strange, hostile, intense, relentless. The only rhythm game to ever push you into the flow state by telling you that you aren't welcome. No matter, you're here, and you're going to break the universe one thump at a time.

Made my thumbs cramp after ten minutes, and I loved it.

Les contr√¥les sont tr√®s faciles √† prendre en main car il ne faut utiliser que " A " et le joystick gauche de la manette (du moins l√† o√π je suis rendu dans le jeu).

review:

The gorgeous visuals and the intense, violent soundtrack induce a drug-like state of focus and disconnect while your fingers somehow do the right thing, and finally clearing that level to get a wonderful yellow S-rank is an amazing discharge of tension.

Great game. Not relaxing. 144fps recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000626756', 'num_games_owned': 2642, 'num_reviews': 136, 'playtime_forever': 84, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 83, 'last_played': 1658774987}
review:
I played the first third of it (three worlds out of nine) and then received a refund.

The inputs it prompts you for rarely exhibit any consistent sense of musical rhythm; and I found there was not enough notice for many prompts, which made failure frustrating rather than success fair or rewarding. It's also got a very harsh, repetitive, constantly noisy soundscape, which removed from the sense of music even further, and only served to ensure a headache.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045115651', 'num_games_owned': 369, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1532, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1157, 'last_played': 1561429220}

author: {'steamid': '76561198271734635', 'num_games_owned': 301, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 124, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 89, 'last_played': 1548564092}
review:
TL;DR BUY THIS GAME. THIS GAME IS WORTH IT.

I actually discovered this game through a demo that PS4 had in Best Buy. I spent at least an hour or more at Best Buy so I can play the demo of this game. When this game was released, I was dying to play it and relive the fun, short moments I had during my time with the demo. This game will challenge you as you progress through the levels, and it will fustrate you sometimes. Keep in mind that you need to be focused on the screen on later levels because there's a chance that you might miss a "block" if you aren't careful.  Also I used a PS4 Controller on the earlier levels and used my keyboard for the rest, and tbh, I would recommend a keyboard since I was able to hit some "moves" that weren't possible for me when I used the PS4 controller (or I was just really bad). This game is amazing in terms of graphics, soundtrack and gameplay.  The mechanics are addictive and will keep you busy for hours.  I rate this game 8/10 must buy!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198040094111', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1643, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 778, 'last_played': 1547140098}
review:
Smal disclaimer: I haven't beaten the game, but I'm up to the 7th level of 9 and I feel like I can speak for the game's quality. Also, I got it on sale for 11 or 12$ and haven't played with VR.

If you like what you see in the trailers, then you'll probably like what Thumper has to offer.

Thumper's a rhythm game centered around just pressing button prompts in response to various threats and signals. There's barely a story to speak of and the most I've seen so far is a recurring boss that kind of changes with each level. I've seen Thumper constantly compared to rhythm games, but it's not really like any other rhythm game I've ever played. There are no standout tracks and rarely any moments where I find myself bobbing along the rhythm. Instead, Thumper just commands your attention with these heavy metallic drum noises that dictate almost all of the game's music, and instead of feeling like you're playing a song, it feels like the great music is more of a byproduct of you playing the game.

That's not a bad thing, though, because Thumper is a unique premise with excellent execution. It has all the simplicity of the Runner games with all the intensity of something like the new DOOM. Think of super simple gameplay with a very harsh atmosphere and brutal difficulty. And by brutal difficulty, I mean repeating whole sections over and over because you didn't pull off a sequence of button presses without making a mistake. This brings up one of my only problems with Thumper: the game is so hard at times, you're forced to memorize levels which leads to a trial-and-error sort of gameplay. I feel like this is a side effect of simply not being very good at the game and not paying attention to certain cues, but I can see it turning off some players. If you don't like repeating yourself like in Super Meat Boy, Runner, or 1001 Spikes, you might not love the game's later levels.

But if you DO like punishing gameplay and everything you see in the trailer, then I'd say Thumper is worth your time. Not only is the main campaign tough as nails, getting S rank on every level will def keep you occupied. And there's even a NG+ which basically adds permadeath to each level with no healing and makes you start from the beginning of the level if you quit. That may sound ridiculous, but I LOVE that it's a feature because it fits the hardcore nature of this game so well. And just to cover all bases, the game looks and sounds good, runs great, the controls feel tight, and the atmosphere is very unique. My only problems are the tougher bosses and the fact that, during long play sessions, you can get a little burnt out because the game CONSTANTLY demands your attention. I guess that's what happens when you play Breath of the Wild for 3 weeks and then move to something like this. LOL

I like Thumper.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998466241', 'num_games_owned': 578, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 207, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1604384785}
review:
TL;DR : Game is beautiful, Runs well, fantastic rythmic early stages, non-existant rythm midgame-endgame, uses "cheap/bad" hardcore mechanics; game is based on sound and uses sound to throw you off later on and just becomes irritating (you're almost better off muting the game later on, but that defeats the purpose of this game right?
).
If I could do a mixed review I would. I'm only giving a thumbsdown to help personally balance the game from currently a very positive to either Mostly Positive or at most Mixed.

     The game presents itself as a psychedelic hardcore rhythm game. It certainly is beautiful and very engaging to the eye, but it doesn't feel like any rhythm game at all. Each stage has it's own kind of beat and feel to the rhythm, so each stage does feel unique; but personally only the first 3ish stages had rhythms that I could predict/feel. After the first few stages the beat doesn't seem... "there". 

      The first 3 stages I can tap my foot to and almost predict what is going to come up next and how it'll sound; it's generally pleasing to my ears. The next 4 stages I got to feels like there's no beat, and takes a kind of "dubstep" feel to how the notes are placed, I can't for the love of me find a beat to tap/nod to, doesn't feel satisfying once you hit all the notes and "complete" the song, and doesn't actually sound like anything but random instruments/pots&pans banging about; every note comes as a suprise to me and I end up playing the game not by following the rythm, but by trial and error and just memorizing the placement of objects (no rythm needed). 

     There's a slight neutral nitpick and that's the preemptive sound for each note. In the background you'll hear a note play to what's about to come up, and you kind of gauge when to hit that note; In the first few stages this is used along with the sound of you hitting the notes to make a nice beat/song to play along to. Later on the game gets faster paced and has more notes to hit, so it comes to a point where you just hear background notes overlapping and obstructing what beats you're hitting and just generally ruining the "song" that the game is trying to get you to make.

     One finally nitpick is turns. For the life of me some turns feel like they're programmed differently than others. You hold Actionbutton ([A] on controller) then left/right for what direction you're turning. You can also wait til the exact moment to actually hit the turn button for extra points and a nice "ping" sound that makes the song sound better. Some turns feel like their exact moment to hit the turn perfectly is placed differently than others. 90% of the turns seem to have a general rule on when to exactly hit the turn, and some feel like they're way sooner than before, making me take damage and costing me a retry or death. This can get very infuriating later game when all the sounds of preemptive notes and notes you're hitting overlap adding to the bad design type of difficulty; making it feel like the game isn't a skill-based hardcore where I can learn from mistakes, but rather a game that changes core rules randomly to make you hit a small bump to artificially impede progress.

     I want to like this game, but the only thing I can like about it is the sound (when they work), and the beautiful graphics; with that it is less of a game and more of something just to watch someone play than to play yourself. (5/10)
If I was to grade the game soley on the first 3 stages and the rest of the stages were made like the first 3, I would easily give a 9/10 or a 10/10 if the turns were more consitent.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046262385', 'num_games_owned': 213, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 492, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 396, 'last_played': 1646526132}
review: Pretty cool game. The only thing that I would like to suggest is not make the game slow down so much if you mess up the first time. Although I prefer to get no-miss runthroughs, I like to see how far I can get when "sightreading" and slowing the game for me to miss half a beat will definitely end my run. I probably wouldn't recommend this game to casual rhythm game players, and I don't mean that in a bad way. If you're expecting to listen to the music and coast through the levels, then you're probably not going to have fun. The beat is pretty hard to keep track of, and I found myself attempting to tap my foot in time and failing at certain sections. There were times in the track where I had to basically guess where the beat was and go from there. Speaking of the track, there isn't much to listen to. There's barely any lyrical sections of the music within the tribal drums. I would say that this game is close to something like being in a drumline or auxillary-only percussion ensemble. It's a lot of call and response in which the call inputs get so convoluted that you have to depend on reactions and muscle memory. In all, I would say that this is a great game - the whole "story" of the game is pretty vague, but I'll let that slide since this is primarily a rhythm game after all. The graphics get kinda weird, but I guess they wanted to make this a horror game. I found myself really apreciating the different cadences the developers used, so thumbs up for that. Thanks for the great game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198024812228', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 4182, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2013, 'last_played': 1642898114}
review:
[u]Disclaimer: [/u] This review is considerably lengthy. The abridged version is: [b]buy it[/b]. I have been obsessed with this game for the past few days and that train, much like the space beetle you play as, is not stopping anytime soon. If you‚Äôre interested in reading about how I believe Thumper applies play conditioning, minimalism and cosmic horror to create a brilliant game filled with gorgeous graphics, an intense score and absurd replay value ‚Äì go ahead!
 
This strange game is an incredibly satisfying trifecta of psychedelic art, rhythm-based play and horror tension. Seriously, somehow developers Drool have managed to make a game described as, [i]a space beetle travelling through the void[/i], a uniquely terrifying and intense experience. I want to focus the majority of my review on a concept I think Thumper executes brilliantly. It‚Äôs a term known as [b]play conditioning[/b], and it‚Äôs not mine ‚Äì I first heard its use by film and games essayist [b]Hbomberguy[/b]. He coined the term vis-√†-vis Thumper; so, with this in mind, I believe it to be intellectually honest for me to present his argument given that I will proceed to apply, expand and comment on it.

[b]Hbomberguy[/b] argues that Thumper is a difficult and unforgiving game. As a space beetle, you are constantly speeding through a nightmarish void filled with traps, aggressive abstract geometry and horrific giant heads. It‚Äôs like a racing game ‚Äì only you‚Äôre a beetle with two lives and you will relentlessly respawn at the beginning of each level because in this game, the dead shall rise again until you escape hell. It‚Äôs a fast-paced adventure that requires great reaction time in a psychedelic environment that constantly assaults your senses. Nevertheless, Thumper is made in such a way that the more you play it the more intuitive the controls become. Your actions match the score in the background and, if done well, sync and contrast with the environment around you in such a way that it feels [i]good[/i] to pass a course with an S ranking. 

From a technical standpoint, [b]play conditioning[/b] is where, why and how should buttons reflect in-game actions. Thumper achieves such that with the help of mechanical minimalism the player is conditioned to play a fast, aggressive, relentless and intuitive game -- or so at least it is designed. Your controls are simple, WASD and SPACE BAR, but the combinations of moves and trap responses are almost infinite. Yet, throughout all that, your hand is comfortably numb, clicking away up to five keys to safely speed through a course in a truly melodic way. By the end of a course, the overall sync of action, score, color and learning curve resemble the moment when a guitarist learns a new song. That has been my experience ‚Äì I have been obsessed with this game. It has tapped into my completionist vein and I will relentlessly redo a course until I get the highest mark. [b]Why?[/b] Because of this game‚Äôs incredible application of [b]play conditioning[/b]. The way the game mechanics are built promotes a type of gameplay that is challenging, rewarding, and ultimately, highly enjoyable. I have more fun failing a course over and over again, with each new time learning the course's inner mechanics like a new song, until I finally complete it with the highest mark than simply breezing through each score, ignoring certain optional obstacles, losing lives and achieving C, B or A marks.

Thumper also has an actual effective training method to introduce you to what we‚Äôll call ‚Äúthe level‚Äôs learning curve‚Äù. At the beginning of each level, the first few courses focus on showing you a particular new skill or combination of actions ‚Äì usually with a HUD display that will indicate exactly when to do what. Moreover, as the level progresses it incorporates learned skills, with current skills and the occasional unreferenced unlearned skill. It‚Äôs a way of avoiding monotony, increase replay value and keeping an element of surprise during each level (which has approximately twenty courses). All in all ‚Äì great game, gorgeous graphics, intense score, beautiful mechanics and arguably one of the most recent games where mood, theme and immersion have nothing to do with story or characters.

[h1]If you enjoy the way I review games, join and follow my curator group! It comes with a fun discord channel for horror fans to chill and game. [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/malkavianmadness]Malkavian Madness[/url][/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561197972118157', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 122, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 60, 'last_played': 1527558371}
review:
I have just finished the second "Level" in the game. 

I am a beetle endlessly screaming along a track to oblivion, dodging horrors along the way.

This game frustrates me to no end, and yet I keep playing just to get a little bit further along and receive even more punishing sequences that I fail, and fail again.

The music can best be described as punishing, a cacophony akin to listening to an airplane drone along while a toddler bangs pots and pans in time to the game action.

This is the most brilliant subversion of a rhythm game that I've ever played.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066673553', 'num_games_owned': 560, 'num_reviews': 235, 'playtime_forever': 789, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 789, 'last_played': 1500675850}
review:
Thumper‚Äôs brutal, breakneck speed and precision-based musical action kept me entranced for all nine of its bizarre, nightmarish stages, which contained enough nuanced high score-chasing tricks to demand several replays already. To really master Thumper‚Äôs many layers of rhythm-based mechanisms would take much more time than the 10 or so hours it takes to complete the first time ‚Äì and that‚Äôs a challenge that I eagerly accept.

Menacing boss fights that manage to stay interesting despite a relatively linear structure and a strange, chrome-plated brand of cosmic horror that‚Äôs as fascinating as it is frightening make repeat trips easy and exciting. But it‚Äôs the music and sounds of Thumper that will stick with me the most, beckoning me back to that terrifying abyss for several more hours to come. 5/5

author: {'steamid': '76561198198219921', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1677, 'last_played': 1708289883}
review:
First off, this is an excellent game. I've played through all of Play and three stages of Play+, and my initial feelings of awe and excitement have not dwindled. The issues I have with this game are so few that I have to list them specifically to fill out my cons side.

Graphics: 

Pros:
While I don't play on VR, the game itself is not demanding. With a GTX 1070, I've pushed 8x MSAA with 4K rendering at 144hz, and I haven't seen a frame dropped yet. Aesthetics, as others have mentioned, are very trippy. Bright lights and flashing objects fill the screen in a compact pleasing manner. I find this to be one of the key parts of the game, offering powerful imagery. 

Con:
At some instances, mainly the last stage in Play+, the visuals get so intense and saturated that it becomes nearly impossible to see. 

Audio: 

Pros:
For me, the music is a standout from other rhythm games. Where most other games will hardly ever tour away from straight 4/4 rhythm, this game has no qualms in handing out the grungiest offtime, polyrhythmic, additive timing beats. It's a refreshing breath of air, and I wish other reviewers understood the timing was on purpose. The mixing of the soundtrack gives it enourmous space, strengthening the games aesthetics. 

Cons:
Without a good audio setup the drums can get washed out in the reverberations and game's hits, making it difficult to play ontime. The snakes in the game appear with a high hissing sound, when they appear multiple at a time, any speaker set with a high frequency range can hurt your ears from the intensity. I recommend gamers play two decibals down from their max listening volume, to save on ear coverage.

Gameplay: 

Pros:
The gameplay is tight and responsive, and hitting notes are very satisfying, The game's difficulty curve is very smooth, except for stage 7 which I found the most difficulty in beating. The general opinion differs from stage to stage though, so I feel that it's a personal issue. General movements across the menus is fluid and fast. 

Cons:
Sometimes the stages can feel a bit repetitive. My biggest qualm comes from turns. Getting perfect timings on them can be frustrating because it's so unforgiving for pressing late. I've raged more than a few times repeatedly dying to turns that I feel I've hit properly.

My rating: 8.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198064672068', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 333, 'last_played': 1536516973}
review:
As everyone knows the game looks badass as fuck so here's my comment on something else.

Concidering the games aesthetic I was pleasently supprised about how easy it was to get into, the learning curve is actually pretty pleasant. At the start of each level you're introduced to the perils that lie before you in the abyss, and slowly eased into the level itself. 
Well.. that's up until level 5, when that piece of shit lazer cockring starts blasting your ass like the death star, while kicking you off beat with it's skrillex soundboard. God I hate that thing. But after a blood sacrifice and some really hard headbanging I managed to become one with Satan's bongobeats and, while jumping around in my couch like a disgruntled teen on a cybergoth concert, kicked level 5's ass into oblivion.

The music, which usually is the main focus in rythm based games, is suprisingly lacking in this one. The tracks aren't bad in any sense, don't get me wrong. But concidering that the visuals of the game really just punch you right in the tit with their fantastic sci-fi interpretation of Dante's Inferno, I'm very suprised that the music lacks the same kick. In comparison it at times feels, flat, monotone and quiet. That's of course understandable in the "pause" parts of each level, but when the action's on I'm really missing some hard clear rythm. I would really expect more bass and robotic rape noises. Go search up the noices the reapers in mass effect make, that's the kind of sound I was looking for with this music. In really intense parts of the game this problem kinda disapears because the sounds from all the obstacles you're smashing through just becomes a nice rhytmical beat in and of itself. The background music is just a bit pale when compared to the visuals is my point. 

For serious though I truly am enjoying this game, even though the learningcurve breaks after level 4 and that the music isn't as heavy as I'd like I would still recommend it to anyone that thinks Dark Souls isn't pissing them off enough, cause boy is this shit unfair at times. 

7/10 highly enjoyable and frustrating, will play it more

author: {'steamid': '76561198042481186', 'num_games_owned': 1084, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 261, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 84, 'last_played': 1644892893}
review:
I bought this game thinking it was just a simple movey vroom like F-zero or something

OH MY GOD WAS I WRONG

This game took my senses. My sense of sight and hearing, My sense of touch and jsut molested them in a blender on full blend. Mixed them together and brought my into the heaven that is ART. This is proof that God exists. This game is insane, I would recommend you pump up the volume and put on some headphones. I am STUNNED how this simple idea with the correct visuals has taken me into such a captivating experience. I could not recommend this game enough. Seriously.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047095349', 'num_games_owned': 405, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 207, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 107, 'last_played': 1647774339}
review:
[h1]Thumper[/h1]
/*Heavy Drums*/

[b][i]game[/i]
           
1. A visual and audiual satisfaction similar to that of the climax of 
sexual excitement, (org@sm) however characterized by intensely 
pleasurable feelings in the mind.[/b]
"That orchestra felt so much like Thumper I nearly ejaculated
in my seat." [b]

2. An artificial imitation of hallucinations induced by taking
psychedelic drugs.[/b]
"This thumper makes me want to have drugs." [b]

3. An experience in which absolutely bonkers sh!t start to feel
somewhat normal and instead, you reach the 4th dimension.[/b]
"Dude that party was so thumper I started tasting the skulls of 
my ex girlfriends."
[strike]Dave has gone crazy[/strike] [i]we called the cops...[/i]
[spoiler]Nah we killed him for a sacrifice to omega[/spoiler][b]

4. A mixture of the emotions; anger, desire, determination
and [i]insanity.[/i][/b]


[h1]I Recommend this game *thumbs up*[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561197970896371', 'num_games_owned': 530, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 861, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 781, 'last_played': 1705958896}
review:
Thumper is a rhymthm game similar to Bit.Trip Runner: press buttons quickly and with precise timing to clear a series of stages. The music, sound effects, and visuals all give cues to when buttons should get pressed. The difficulty ramps up quickly and the game takes practice to beat.

The main innovations are in the atmosphere and the well-designed (though not well-explained) scoring system. High scoring requires a mix of excellent timing and good routing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052352928', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 618, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 473, 'last_played': 1577766071}
review:
Most rhythm games tend to be fairly bright and friendly, often leveraging colorful and relatively simple designs. The action might get a little frantic at times but the games in this genre usually aren‚Äôt actively trying to induce heart attacks in their players.

And then there‚Äôs Thumper, a nightmarish rollercoaster through a psychedelic hellscape. This game hates you and it isn‚Äôt trying to hide it. The graphics are steeped in bloody reds, the action crunches and screeches violently, and the music radiates intensity as you race headlong into sudden doom.

Gameplay uses up/down/left/right movement plus a single button which can be tapped or held for a few different effects in various situations. Each level ramps up the difficulty through several rounds and then hits you with a couple of malevolent bosses towering over increasingly fiendish tracks. It isn‚Äôt overly complicated but it‚Äôs plenty challenging.

Everything looks and sounds amazing, and the game has a pretty cool feel once you get the hang of it. Just be prepared for an experience that combines all the best qualities of a car accident and a heart attack.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045567704', 'num_games_owned': 148, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 2083, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 884, 'last_played': 1656109014}
review:
TL;DR: Buy this game.  Period.  It's one of the best of it's genre as of now.  10/10.  Also now giving it the 2017 "Mom's Spaghetti" award.

I originally found out about this game via The Beetles Of The People a.k.a. Jim Sterling.
I just had to have this game!
If the difficulty dissuades you, fear not!  It actually starts out fairly gentle and progressively gets more intense as you ride along.

Thumper is Audiosurf meets... anything dark and space-themed.
(The dark side(s) of Star Trek/Star Wars immediately come to mind...or perhaps Batman...)
I once read that the beetle in this game was inspired by some album art.

Good music, stellar sound design and cues, sleek and shiny visuals, responsive performance... what's not to like?

And finally, in case hemiola and odd rhythms (syncopation) aren't enough for you, this game has odd time signatures as well.  Think about it: isn't 4/4 a bit overused in this day and age?  Playing in 5/4 and 7/4 is so refreshing (but 5/8 and 7/8 are so challenging!).

author: {'steamid': '76561198258786389', 'num_games_owned': 1183, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 273, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1607005073}
review:
Thumper is the most fitting title for this game, as is its caption as "A Rhythm Violence Game".

It's a game made by two very angry men. It features a beatle on a rail ramming itself into walls and  shit, 'fighting' giant polyhedral tentacle shapes and a big Day-of-the-Dead-meets-punk-rock skull. I say 'fighting', because as far as I know the 'notes' are actually enemies and/or attacks. I don't know nor care. It's glorious.
The gameplay is enormously satisfying, every hit 'note' and wall grind punching a beat right into your ears, every missed 'note' breaking a window instead. The rhythms are complex, the soundtrack so utterly heavy and percussive. It's like an angst-filled teen with a drumkit and some talent. 
Some gameplay elements (e.g. how to hit certain 'notes') are either not explained in too much detail, or I was too busy pummeling my hands into the soundtrack. I bought the game alone first off, and bought the soundtrack later, if that's any indication of how satisfying the beats are.

Definitely play it with a controller though.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962174877', 'num_games_owned': 1365, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 23, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16, 'last_played': 1501966897}
review: Real conversation with my wife: "I'm not sure there are words in the English language to describe what I'm seeing. It's like I'm playing an episode of Nightvale."

author: {'steamid': '76561197960451234', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 325, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 221, 'last_played': 1619953355}
review: This is precisely the kind of game that would emerge if the Bit Trip series went 3D. Stunning demoscene-style graphics, non-trivial but intuitive controls, fantastic punchy feedback. The music is a bit grimy and unmemorable, though: lots of drums and dissonance with very little melody or harmony to catch your ear. More critically, the audio cues aren't always evident. I think the best rhythm games can almost be played with your eyes closed, and this one falls a bit short of the mark -- especially once you get to the off-beat stuff past level 3. Still, this game is great fun and a must-play for fans of the rhythm genre!

author: {'steamid': '76561197961867555', 'num_games_owned': 148, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 3153, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1748, 'last_played': 1696399775}
review:
10/10

This is what video games are about

The visuals are absolutely enthralling and emersive. Gets better the bigger screen you put it on, there is no shortage of eye candy, drugs recommended. 

The music goes hand in hand with the visuals, errie, spookie, and visceral. The music and colors create a primal experience of fear and adrenaline that every good game tries to match.

The game gets more complex with each level, reaching points of rage and frustration but with the perfect one more try incentive and feel. The game is punishing, but not cruel. The game achieves levels of complexity and difficulty that are hard to find in todays sea of interactive movie walkthroughs, yet, Checkpoints are numerous.

This game is well worth whatever price they have it at at the time you want to buy it tbh. It will be a classic, something everyone should own and experience. 

If you are really unsure, a youtube video will tell you what you need to know.
