review:
Nice artwork. I like it. 

Gameplay: Press, hold release the buttons the right time. If you push them without failure then the sound effects fits to the music. I guess it's similar to those guitar games. You can't switch the music but get some really cool artwork instead.

Regarding VR:
Immersion caused from VR is not that strong. It's some "sit-down-VR" but a good one. If you turn your head backwards then there's just some endless black. That's ok because the firework and all that effect blending happens in front of you. If you played it in VR and if you don't own a really huge monitor then it's hard to go back to a normal monitor because this game likes a big screen.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984468715', 'num_games_owned': 2025, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 81, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 81, 'last_played': 1498906206}
review:
Thumper presents itself as a rhythm game, but gets so much of the design behind rhythm games wrong that I cannot in good conscious recommend it to fans of the genre. There are plenty of other rhythm games that I'd recommend over Thumper. I list some of them in the sections below.

[h1]Music Selection[/h1]

Let's start with the music: It's droning percussion without a lot of variation or movement. Find a youtube video of someone playing Thumper. If you like what you hear, then great, maybe this game is for you. If you don't like what you hear, bad news: that's basically all you're going to be hearing the whole game. Most rhythm games have a selection of songs that you can play at your leisure; if there's a song you don't like, no big deal: just don't pick that song, and instead pick the songs you [i]do[/i] like. Unfortunately Thumper is structured as a linear game where you play the levels in order, one after the other. And you can't play level N until you've beaten level N-1.

[b]Games that did it better:[/b] The Bemani series (Dance Dance Revolution, Beatmania/IIDX, Guitar Freaks, DrumMania, etc.), Rock Band, Guitar Hero, etc. all have varied song lists in different genres and style, and let you pick which songs you want to play.

[h1]Graphics/Aesthetics[/h1]

This is arguably Thumper's strongest selling point, but graphics are only enjoyable insofar that you get to see them. And to see them, you have to actually play through the game. That might sound tautological, but there are rhythm games which understood that a core appeal of their game were the trippy graphics and the synesthetic experience, and thus let you just coast through the game, even if you did extremely poorly, so that you can enjoy the full experience. In contrast, Thumper is fairly unforgiving: your beetle has 2 hit points, and if you make 2 "mistakes" (failling to turn, crashing into a barrier, failing to jump over an obstacle, etc.), you "die" and are sent back to a previous checkpoint.

[b]Games that did it better:[/b] Rez has beautiful visuals that evolve with the music, and shares a similar aesthetic style (though its tone is less gloomy than Thumper's).

[h1]Mechanics[/h1]

The core mechanic behind Thumper is call-and-response. The game will present a rhythm involving both audio and visual cues, and then you're supposed to perform the rhythm back to the game. Unfortunately, there are several flaws with the way Thumper implements this mechanic that makes it unsuitable for fans of rhythm games.

First of all, of the 5 or so different cues that the game presents, only 1 or 2 (depending on how you count them) involve timing. That is to say, the majority of the gameplay in Thumper does [i]not[/i] involve rhythm. There are 5 possible inputs that you can send to the game: Up, down, left, right and action. When there is a glowing spot on the floor, then you need to press the Action button just as the glowing spot passes underneath your beetle. And when you need to perform a stomp-maneuver on the glowing spot, then you need to press the Down button just as it passes underneath your beetle. That's it. For every other cue, you can send the input way in advance of the cue's arrival, and if there are several such cues in a row, you can just keep the relevant button held down to trigger all of them.

For example, there's a horizontal barrier which you can only "break through" if you're holding down the Action button. It's not unusual for these barriers to appear in a syncopated rhythm (e.g. note note pause note pause note note note), but it's not clear what the point of that rhythm is, because what you're supposed to do when you encounter such a cue is to just hold down the Action button through the whole thing.

[b]Games that did it better:[/b] The Rhythm Heaven series is kind of like a Wario Ware for rhythm games: Each song/stage uses the controls in different ways, as if a completely different mini-game. While some of the games might have a "just have the input be held down", they do so for variety's sake, and the majority of the games do ask you to actually perform your input to a rhythm.

[h1]Input Timing[/h1]

This is somewhat related to the previous sections of mechanics, but the input timing on Thumper is completely off, and the reason it's completely off is a direct result of the design decision they made that the inputs should be "held down ahead of time" as opposed to activated as per the rhythm of the music. Find a video of someone playing the first level of Thumper, and then tap your hands on the quarter notes of the song. While you're doing this, pay attention to when the beetle performs a turning maneuvre.

Notice that the beetle turns, and then as the turn ends, a chime plays, and this chime is on the quarter note beat (i.e. synchronized with when you tapped). This is the [i]end[/i] of the turning maneuvre, which means that this is the point at which it's okay for the player to actually release the inputs. Which means the player [i]must[/i] have entered the input at some earlier time, not on the beat.

The game essentially forces you to enter in your inputs "not on the beat", which is very frustrating for a rhythm game. I completely understand their desire to have the chime sound effect land on the beat, or else the game would be frustrating for auditory rather than tactile reasons, but it seems like they could have fixed this design flaw by simply having the chime occur at the [i]start[/i] of the turn, rather than at the end, and have the player perform the inputs for the turn on the beat of the song.

[b]Games that did it better:[/b] Dance Dance Revolution, In The Groove, Beatmania/IIDX, Guitar Hero, etc. all have some concept of "holding down the input". However, they ensured that both the start and the end of these inputs occur on the beat. Further more, they ensured that the "attack" (the moment the player actually presses the input) must occur on the beat (as opposed to Thumper's approach to let the player press the input at any arbitrary point before the beetle needs to perform the maneuvre), which leads to a much more satisfying input experience.

[h1]Cues[/h1]

Probably Thumper's weakest point as a rhythm game is the quality of its cues. The game uses both audio and visual cues in its call and response system. The audio cues by themselves are not unique enough that you can solely rely on them to play the game without memorization. For example, a "turn" will be signaled by a handclap sound effect. However, you won't know, from just hearing the sound clap, whether you need to turn left or right. And again, Thumper only lets you make 2 mistakes before your beetle dies and is sent back, so simply guessing based on the audio cues is not sufficient.

Then what about the visual cues? Here, Thumper struggles due to overprioritizing its aesthetics. The beetle is travelling along a narrow corridor with opaque walls, and the corridor twists and turns. While visually interesting, the end result of this is that when the corridor turns, it blocks the player's view of the upcoming cues. The level design seems to be unaware of this problem, as it repeatedly uses an anti-pattern in several of its stages where the beetle is cued to turn to one side, and immediately needing to turn in the opposite side with no warning (because the cue for the second turn was hidden behind the walls of the curving corridor). When this happens, Thumper is no longer a rhythm game. It becomes a game of reaction time, and/or memorization as you die and then replay that section, but now knowing that two (or three or four) turns in quick succession are going to come.

[b]Games that did it better:[/b] Groove Coaster is a rhythm game in which your avatar follows a curving path. However, it's able to avoid the pitfall that Thumper falls into by having the path be a simple line with no walls, and thus nothing to "block" the cues.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960397413', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 28, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1498771953}
review:
I don't understand why I'm having no trouble with the other rhythmic elements, but I cannot make the turns. I play piano and I'm very good at other rhythm games (Guitar Hero, Rhythm heaven, Osu! Tatakae! Ouendan), but in this game I just cannot make turns go "correctly". Since they must be coded exactly to the beat, I wonder if their visual feedback is somehow off or where the problem is. 

Also, I find it infuriating that the game slows down when you take a hit, because it causes my sense of rhythm go off. Visually, the game is stunning... in the first ten or so levels I was able to complete. As it is, I regret buying the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072152768', 'num_games_owned': 338, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 88, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 86, 'last_played': 1662078015}
review:
Thumper presented itself (and was misinterpreted) as the wrong genre. [b]While it is a great runner, it is a terrible rhythm game.[/b] The levels designs prioritize being challenging over matching the background music, and the sounds they made are usually not musical at all. Worse still, because each obstacle makes the same sound every time, what music they can create is very simplistic and repetitive, think a drum set except only one drum can be played at any given time and there is a short delay between any two drum hits. Thumper also progressively add more obstacles to the levels as the player gets more experienced, which is good as a difficulty curve but also mean the music gets even more monotone at the beginning.
[b]However, that doesn't mean it's not fun.[/b] The game is very responsive (as a runner should), the obstacles are intuitive, the UI is clean, and the presentation is very stylish to say the least. If a runner is what you want, Thumper will satisfy that need very well.

Edit: I'm changing my verdict to be positive. I still insist that the music in this game is bad, but once I set my expectation right, the sound effects become very cathartic.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989236581', 'num_games_owned': 254, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 324, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 319, 'last_played': 1525469959}
review:
Thumper is evil. It gets to you in a way that I dont think any other game has managed to. It builds this constant progressive dread that seems to never end up to a never reaching climax. And it does that just by asking you to hit a button when a blue square reaches you, slide on some walls and fly over some obstacles.
I wouldnt go as far to call Thumper a horror game as in its not trying to scare you like Resident Evil or Outlast would, but its a compelling candidate for existential horror, the kind of horror Lovecraft was so enamoured with. And it manages to accomplish this just by the abstraction of its aestethic and its incredible sound design and  industrial techno soundtrack.
In Thumper you are in control of a silver beetle stuck on a track on its journey to the beyond. The game clearly establishes very early on that this is serious business just by the tone of the music playing and it gives you a very brief tutorial before sending you on your way, without much care if you will survive or not. Very quickly you will be struggling to press the button on time with the blue notes that pass by you and the music simply wont let up.
But up until this point, the only punishment you seem to get out of missing these notes is a reduced score. No big deal.
Then, real danger starts to show up. You will have to turn the beettle in time with the turns of the road, and hold down the button when some barriers show up alongside the track. You fail to do this, you lose the beetle's armor. You fail to do this twice, you are dead.
The great thing about Thumper is that the control scheme is very minimal and easy to understand, so the game takes that opportunity and throws you the most violent sequences of notes and obstacles to deal with, leaving you in a constant state of (positive) stress. Sometimes it seems impossible, but the game always gives visual and sound indications of what the next obstacle is, so you soon learn how to deal with it and its immensely satisfying to get an S-Rank on a segment.
The game also has bosses that truly test your skill up to that point and really stand as a barrier to those who arent ready for the next level. The final boss does what great final bosses do: test your skills to the max while also providing a new challenge to overcome not seen in the whole game up to that point.  
Its an amazing and thrilling experience with some of the best surrealist visuals and music to complement it. It leaves you in a state of trance where you stop seeing the notes and just start guessing and predicting where they will be by sound alone, and thats the best compliment I can give to a Rhythm game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997850900', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 117, 'last_played': 1613270442}
review:
It's discounted below the magic HKD100 mark for me and been on my wishlist a while. If you enjoy any beat-driven game, Cytus (if you have an ipad you MUST get Cytus), Audiosurf, anything with a beat, then get this game now. 

A really nice benefit is you can play any level you like, it's not like a shitty arcade game where you have to start from the beginning each time. If you even decide to quit halfway though a level, it will save your checkpoint. 

The difficulty and pace of the game is set just right, slowly building up to more complex manouvres and you never have to start too far back if you die. 

It doesn't reinvent the wheel, but it's a solid, entertaining game for anyone who likes to hit things to a beat!

author: {'steamid': '76561198068458641', 'num_games_owned': 181, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1095, 'last_played': 1499212132}
review:
I feel like this game was made for me. 



PROS

-Feels good to play (responsive, never feel cheated out of a life)

-High and stable FPS (nice on 144hz monitors)

-Intuitive. There's no real walkthrough or in game guide, but it's easy to catch on to (almost) everything

-Wide skill range. This game isn't as hard as some of the noobies that left negative reviews might convince you to believe. With a controller and a little bit of time and practice you can beat the game in less than a week, AND there is a high skill ceiling if you want to go for all S rank, AND a much higher skill ceiling if you want to improve your score on the leaderboards (and of course the much more unforgiving newgame+)

-Visuals. The atmosphere is just amazing, fast, and scary just like I never knew I wanted it to be.

-Sound. The sound is 70% of everything good in this game. I cannot give the sound guy enough props. It gets the adrenaline pumping while keeping you on beat and letting you know the beat to come. Brilliant.



CONS

-I wish there were more levels, or at least user made levels. I beat the game twice in <20hrs (1st playthrough + S rank) and even left the game open for a few hours. There's still newgame+, but they're all linear levels. Good for practicing, but it does kill the replayability a bit.

-Lack of an in-game guide. This isn't a deal-breaker for me, but trying to figure out how to stay in the air during turns to hit those high arches consistently was a bit difficult without a guide. Everything else was mostly covered at points in the early levels. 
Note: There is a PDF guide if you right click the game. I found it after I beat it the second time.

OVERALL: 9.5/10

Should you get it?
Yeah. (unless you absolutely hate rhythm games)

author: {'steamid': '76561198381509511', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 373, 'last_played': 1498411556}
review: Casual gamers stay away from this. At first it seems like its fun but  right around stage 5 it gets unfair. The only reason I'm still playing is because I just want to complete it. Now it feels like a chore ratrher than fun. Graphics are not the best thing to look at and game play is ok but will be frustrating as hell to begginers unless you are fans of games like rock band or guitar heroes stay away.  I know its gotten rave reviews but I found it to be not quite as fun as I hoped and more difficult than I imagine. the check points are ok but I really wish the Beetle could take more damage or have a health bar. I just completed stage 5 the moves was so fast that I just ignore most of them and just suvived until the boss battles. if I complete this game I most likely will never play it again.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972603130', 'num_games_owned': 537, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 10, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10, 'last_played': 1498279679}
review:
The controls at least with the VIVE are unresponsive and don't really work. There's not a lot to them but they're unreliable - fully charged, try to do a turn and it may or may not work.
The rhythm of the music doesn't always sync with the control rhythm - kind of a cardinal sin for this kind of game.
The gameplay itself is relatively shallow - there's not much motiviation to get past the above.

It looks kinda cool though!

author: {'steamid': '76561197978421236', 'num_games_owned': 464, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2446, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 228, 'last_played': 1588962966}
review:
"Guttural" is the first thing I think of when I try to describe Thumper. There's something deeply instinctive about it. I feel like I'm not playing with my brain so much as my heartbeat. Like when I play it I become a mass of reacting nerves. 

There's not a lot of games that can make me feel that way. I'd recommend playing with headphones on in a dark room.

author: {'steamid': '76561198327480737', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 22, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1498360707}
review:
Fired up this game and began demoing it for friends.  The complete lack of a cohesive tutorial is the first thing you're confronted with, following a frustrating, repetitive sequence of attempts to try and figure out how the controllers work.  I did a search online and found out I wasn't the only person experiencing this issue.   Even the developers say:

"The Vive controller scheme is a little tricky to explain and we really recommend a traditional gamepad (or the keyboard) over the Vive controllers. We include support for completeness, but it's just not well suited to our game."

In other words, this is another game that's been hastilly hacked to be "VR compatible" but doesn't really cut it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001758597', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 169, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 169, 'last_played': 1498331898}
review: Just the perfect way to get my daily dose of seizures!

author: {'steamid': '76561198127781090', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 6003, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4616, 'last_played': 1611390768}
review:
Pros:
-The game has amazing visuals. so color vibrant and trippy!.
-If you are wanting to fully beat this game with all achievements.. good luck.. it took me a while to do so!.
-Adding on top of that. the soundtrack is unbelievable its so heavy and fits so well for what this game stands for.
-And even with the +Levels you cant get enough of this game even if you are trying to fully beat it or not.


Cons:
-I wish there was more variety in stuff we had to hit/dodge. but i guess the speed makes up for that.
-It felt like when i tried to land to hit a note it didn't work sometimes.. as if i just skiped over it..
-(i wouldn't really consider this a bad thing. but maybe just being lazy). near the end of the game Boss: Level 9 just seemed really easy. and even in i think it was Level: 9-23 or Level: 8-23 they just copyed and pasted the first half from the last stage. kinda a stupid thing to complain about but i feel like it just makes the game easier.


overall the game isn't bad and if someone told me if they should buy this game, YES!! buy this game its so worth it if you are just gonna have a fun time! 9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198027959239', 'num_games_owned': 380, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 451, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 284, 'last_played': 1690063509}
review: If you took the ideas of cacophony and sensory unpleasantness and turned it into a game, you'd get Thumper.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021887339', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 793, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 182, 'last_played': 1589400270}
review:
Bought the game yesterday cuz of sale and I love good rhythm games. I didn't buy it before because price was too high to gamble on it, but after playing the first two levels I must say I would have bought full price! Perhaps a demo would beneficial for sales.

Anyway, the games seems spectacularily thematic and in both the first levels the pace/intensity of the level picks up (and gets harder) and it feels really good nailing the sections. Really good. I'm used to rhythm games so it was quite easy to pick up the new things the game threw at me so far, though for some people it might take some practice/getting used to. There are music ques that you hear before you get to it, so you can use audio ques to know whats coming even if you don't see it. Sometimes its hard to pick up, mostly when you are doing some moves (which makes noise) while the ques ahead are still playing. The overlap is short and workable so far, I'm confident with more playing of the levels I can pick up on the ques while doing stuff at the same time.

Game sounds great on my bose speakers/subwoofer. Pretty good through my cheap sony extra bass headphones too.
If you like rhythm games, pick this up! For reference, some rhythm games I like are Crypt of the Necrodancer and the Hatsune Miku series.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997857849', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 66, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 47, 'last_played': 1499481927}
review: wow....the game is pretty awesome.  Amazing gaming experience with Vive + Xbox controller....the rhymth timing is flawless... the tribal feel is just energizing.  Soooooooo good.

review:
So far I've completed 2 levels and got at least three angry boners. I can't remember the last time a game would make me this angry without actually making me want to ragequit. 

Weirdly enough, this is also the first game that I'd actually rather play in VR. And on drugs.

Good game, 10/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198133292408', 'num_games_owned': 235, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1313, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 679, 'last_played': 1682773446}
review:
I'm a real rhythm game addict. This game takes the "falling notes" formula (think games like beatmania, pop'n, sound voltex) and turns it into a very original and astonishing cool game. In the beginning it starts of simple and not really rhythm heavy, but it does this to introduce you to the game in a good way. Then around level 3 the speed and rhythms start really to take off and from there, it only get's more epic. And I haven't even started the plus mode. This game get's pretty intense.

It has amazing graphics and good paced gameplay.
The only downside I can think of, is if you play on keyboard that it will take some time to get used to the timings with the spacebar.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083242838', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1523, 'last_played': 1654645001}

author: {'steamid': '76561198044002317', 'num_games_owned': 253, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1195, 'last_played': 1499217713}
review:
To put it simply...

This game is for you if you like; 

-Rhythmic mastery
-Trippy, cosmic atmosphere
-Replayability

It's not for you if you dislike;

-Memorizing levels extensively
-Bright flashing lights

It's amazing how much depth a game get out of using only 1 button and the stick. Thumper is the story of a young beetle hopping his way through the universe to stop Andross or something.

I'd recommend to buy this game at regular price. It was incredibly addicting from the very first note I hit.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042853440', 'num_games_owned': 248, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2565, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2167, 'last_played': 1622174765}
review:
I just simply can't express how much I really love this game, Thumper is just what my steam library was missing.
While this game is not for everyone, I can honestly consider it as one of my all time favourites.
Try to get some good headphones and try to play it during moments when you are alone and you have nothing to do, the game will suck you in like a hallucination and by the time you're done with it you will realize at least 1 hour has passed.
At the moment of writing this, I have finally completed all the levels with an S rank in about 23 hours of gameplay and I still want to play more.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967383217', 'num_games_owned': 367, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 964, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 904, 'last_played': 1572542764}
review:
Thumper est un jeu de rythme fr√©n√©tique et addictif avec beaucoup de personnalit√©. Son mode VR est aussi l'un des meilleurs que j'ai pu essayer, dopant les r√©flexes et √©trangement pas plus fatiguant qu'en mode normal. 

La difficult√© n'est pas trop √©lev√©e du d√©but √† la fin. Le vrai challenge √©tant pour les perfectionnistes de d√©crocher les rangs S des diff√©rents niveaux, et l√† clairement, il faut tout de m√™me pr√©voir une petite bouteille d'eau avant de se lancer dans une partie, car vous aller suer et pas qu'un peu.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996185519', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 256, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 168, 'last_played': 1595551526}
review:
There is a reason only 10% of the players of this 9-level game make it past level 5. If you find other rhythm games too easy, this is the game for you. It's tough as nails and demands both a perfect sense of timing and lightning reflexes. Even with unlimited lives, your chances of making it to level 5 without ragequitting are statistically quite slim.

Still, I recommend it wholeheartedly to those who are looking for the most intense rhythm game yet released. It's extremely fun on a normal monitor, and a blast in VR.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038641929', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 48, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 48, 'last_played': 1495542034}

author: {'steamid': '76561198000555757', 'num_games_owned': 370, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 533, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 533, 'last_played': 1496230097}
review:
Driving beats: ‚úî
Psychedelic visuals: ‚úî
Challenging rhythm gameplay that requires non-selective hearing: ‚úî
snakes and angry spiky skulls: ‚úî
existential dread: ‚úî‚úî‚úî

the level of concentration this game needs will make any itch on your face 20x more noticeable

the best time to scratch your nose is when there are snakes on screen

Anyway, listen to the soundtrack to see if you're into the ambient beats. I say its good but maybe your sense of music is different. This game's tough as balls and you'll need to make sure you can identify what percussion element is what in order to advance, and that the atmospheric sounds sit well with you.

This game really forces you to use your ears as well as your eyes. If you're listening well enough you'll be able to identify upcoming obstacles before your eyes can even register them (which is important cause auditory reaction time is almost always faster than visual reaction time in humans) and you'll be able to identify rhythmic patterns instead of treating each impulse or bank as an individual element.

Honestly that's where a lot of the negative reviews come from--the failure to augment their reactions with audio cues. Some later levels are intentionally designed so you CANNOT see what comes at the end of a sequence--you have to listen for it, and trying to do it visually is pushing the limits of human reaction time. E.g. if you hear 3 'slaps' you'll know you have to bank 3 times and when you have to, even though you can only see the first turn.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034063391', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 13, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1496037283}
review: After reading all the reviews of how great this game is, it didn't live up to my expectations in the slightest.  Firstly, there is no reason this needs to be a VR game.  You are on a track that doesn't deviate from looking forward.  Looking around presents you with nothing.  The rhythm portion of the game is ok, but grows boring fairly quickly.  The visuals are alright, but nothing fantastic.  The audio is OK but not up to par for a rhythm game.  I was really thinking this game was going to be good, but overall it was a big let down.

author: {'steamid': '76561198311133609', 'num_games_owned': 264, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 437, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 397, 'last_played': 1648419660}
review:
10/10 This game is original, good, and difficult. Listen to the track before you buy to make sure you are into the type of music in the game. If you aren't, that will be a problem. Unlike other rythm games, this one is not built around diverse choices of music, different songs, etc. There is really only one "song" in this game, and it plays the through the entire game.  This does not detract at all from the experience, since this game really masters the atmosphere it is trying to create. See if that atmosphere looks awesome, and if it does, you will like this game. 

Also, a warning that this game is challenging. I have beaten the first 7 levels and the 7th took me a couple of hours. Rythm alone will not help you succeed in the later levels, because there are tons of off-beats and minor fluctuations to keep you off balance, and you have very little visual time, or audio cues to react to these changes since everything is moving very fast, and sometimes appearing from around a corner. In order to beat the uber-boss on level 7 I had to memorize the pattern. This has turned some people off from the game, but I can say that if you are looking for a challenge, then this game rewards you with intensity, frustration, and that wonderful satisfaction when you finally get that S rank on a difficult part. 

I give the game a 10/10 not because it is the best game ever, but because it does what it intends to do, and does it very well. Also bonus points for originality.

author: {'steamid': '76561198195858328', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 106, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 106, 'last_played': 1495773156}
review: I consider myself a very musical person. Rhythm games come very naturally to me and I enjoy them. However thumper IS NOT A RHYTHM GAME. Your understanding and love for music should not be the sole factor to buy this game. At first it was managable, then it started to get ridiculous and unfair. It does not play music while you play and create a level based on the song like real rhythm games do, it just plays droning irritating sounds. There is an audio queue for the upcoming actions that you have to perform, but those those sounds that are KEY TO PLAYING THE GAME ARE DROWNED IN THE GROSS "ATMOSPHERE" this game has. Don't waste your time and money. Just play Osu or something.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043346855', 'num_games_owned': 425, 'num_reviews': 630, 'playtime_forever': 680, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 664, 'last_played': 1657240910}
review:
I regret buying Thumper.  It's uniquely mesmerizing as advertised, but I didn't anticipate how stressful and demanding it really was.  Taken together, I found myself asking why I was still playing at all, because it wasn't fun.

Rhythm game fans might feel lured in, but a heavy emphasis on playing by quick instinct instead of clearer telegraphs makes for grueling play.  Either you guess a series of inputs based on something you heard or saw 0.5 seconds ago, or you blow up.  Extremely long levels just add insult to the injury.

Thumper is fun when it feels like solving a math problem on the fly, but it often feels like difficulty for difficulty's sake, which doesn't amount to much.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960780122', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 594, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 592, 'last_played': 1495169771}
review:
‚ÄúYou are a space beetle.‚Äù It seems helpful to clear that up sooner than later. Certainly not a common choice for video game protagonist, but a unique one that also serves to hint at the feel and art of this game. Featuring a space beetle travelling across a three-dimensional music visualization while battling a disembodied mechanical monster head, Drool‚Äôs avant-garde release Thumper is seemingly built on originality. From its self-ascribed ‚Äúrhythm violence‚Äù gameplay, to the atmospheric and mind-boggling visuals that beckon to you right in the start screen, this game was undoubtedly intended to transcend conventional gaming. In many ways, Thumper accomplishes that goal; unfortunately, it falls short in other areas, resulting in a game that I really wanted to love, but just couldn‚Äôt.

Read more at https://tiny-spaceship.com/2017/05/25/thumper-2/

review:
This is a seriously intense game. It is very easy to get into, but very difficult to beat, and the more you play the more you'll want to train yourself with it.

It is a rhythm game. The noise soundtrack is superb, and you time your key/button pushing to different beats (your timing is helped greatly if you are familiar with rhythm/beat, and if you're good at this game and don't play percussion/piano, you should seriously consider it). There's not much to it, but it is fast, fun, and visually stunning. 

Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992556689', 'num_games_owned': 596, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 51, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1495590319}
review:
Nauseating, unrelenting. I'm okay with games that are extremely hard, but I don't really care for games that never give you a breather, and don't give you any way to control the pace of the action.

In the Vive, it gave me a killer headache. But even outside of comfort issues, I'm really not sold on the gameplay. It feels like a minigame - in fact, it reminds me almost exactly of one of the minigames/activities from Saints Row IV. Not enough to do, just not interesting enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198193206533', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 6346, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4807, 'last_played': 1706810602}
review:
The title doesn't lie: This game makes your heart pound! 

PROS:
- Very simple controls for your brain to click to what you see coming at you
- Tests your perception and reflexes
- Immersive graphics and music (the soundtrack is pretty fun)
- Very replayable with challenges that really test your concentration
- Playable for short bursts of time. If you want something that tests your mind for maybe 15 minutes, this game should do the trick.  

CONS
(Note: these are only my opinions on what others may not like)
-  Not the best game for casual players -> unless you like exploding, you'd best be awake and alert when playing this game :P
- Not much variety: the aforementioned challenges comes from replaying the game's levels. Not very fun for people who find tedium in seeing or hearing repeated patterns.
- Very different soundtrack. I personally view this as a good game feature, but it is possible that the music and visuals can be off-putting to some.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966036503', 'num_games_owned': 349, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 598, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 575, 'last_played': 1666638597}
review:
Si le jeu Audiosurf r√©veille un tant soit peu la lumi√®re dans vos petits yeux de joueurs chevronn√©s, le contenu de ce test devrait vous plaire. Pour les autres, sachez que le jeu √©tait un jeu de puzzle et de rythme. Oui, je vous recommande plut√¥t de regarder une vid√©o pour comprendre le concept si vous ne connaissez pas le titre du studio Invisible Handlebar en 2008‚Ä¶ surtout qu‚Äôavec le temps, AudioSurf est devenu un jeu culte et il n‚Äôy a qu‚Äô√† voir les review Steam pour s‚Äôen convaincre.
‚Äã
Bref, tout √ßa pour vous dire que Thumper est dans la forme un cousin √©loign√© d‚ÄôAudioSurf. Mais attention, si on regarde de plus pr√®s, le cousin est un toxicomane sous LSD qui aime rouler √† 300 kilom√®tres sur l‚Äôautoroute, sans ceinture de s√©curit√© et qui montre son majeur √† tout va, bref √ßa vend du r√™ve et rien que pour √ßa, Thumper m√©rite votre plus grand respect.

Petite pr√©cision qui a son importance, autant ne pas acheter le titre si vous √™tes √©pileptique. Thumper est √† bannir, car c‚Äôest un jeu qui vous fera faire en crise en moins de 3 minutes chrono. Maintenant que je vous ai parl√© des pr√©cautions d‚Äôusages, il est temps de boucler vos ceintures de s√©curit√©, car croyez-moi, √ßa va pulser s√©v√®re‚Ä¶
‚Äã
On prend le contr√¥le d‚Äôun vaisseau (qui ressemble d‚Äôailleurs √† un gros scarab√©e m√©canique) lancer √† une allure folle sur une sorte de rail cosmique et le but sera de parvenir √† passer en rythme chaque obstacle pr√©sent sur votre chemin. Thumper vous demandera d‚Äôavoir des r√©flexes d‚Äôun mutant et d‚Äôavoir le rythme dans la peau pour arriver √† boucler les 9 chapitres pr√©sents dans le jeu. Les amateurs de scoring seront ravis d‚Äôapprendre que le jeu vous donne un indice de performance sur chaque portion que comporte le chapitre en cours  et les plus talentueux et les plus acharn√©s d‚Äôentre vous chercheront √† obtenir la note la plus √©lev√©e qui soit. (Un mutant aura le score de ¬´ S ¬ª et le plus mauvais aura ¬´ C ¬ª et tout cela devrait plaire √©norm√©ment aux amateurs de scoring)
 
Le gameplay est exigeant et ne laisse pas le droit √† l‚Äôerreur, mais il est simple et il ne faut que quelques minutes pour prendre main notre scarab√©e m√©tallique. Une manette est quasi-obligatoire et je vous conseille d‚Äô√©viter le combo clavier-souris sous peine de faire une crise de nerfs tr√®s rapidement‚Ä¶ La vitesse d‚Äôanimation est vraiment tr√®s impressionnante et le jeu avec ses d√©cors propose une aventure quasi hypnotique. Il faut √™tre tr√®s concentr√© pendant ses sessions et 20 minutes suffisent √† √™tre tr√®s √©prouvante, c‚Äôest le moins qui puisse dire. Thumper vous bouscule et vous demandera de la coordination, de la concentration pour passer chaque chapitre et il est difficile de d√©crocher tellement le gameplay est brutal et intense. Thumper ne s‚Äôembarrasse pas avec l‚Äôhistoire et se concentre sur l‚Äôexp√©rience et sur les sensations que le joueur va avoir et il faut dire que de ce c√¥t√©-l√†, le pari est gagn√©.

Concernant les graphismes, l‚Äôensemble est tr√®s color√© et surtout psych√©d√©lique, mais il n‚Äôy a pas de faute de go√ªt et Thumper propose une belle palette graphique et c‚Äôest du tr√®s bon travail de la part des d√©veloppeurs. La bande-son est comme l‚Äôensemble du jeu, minimaliste, mais coh√©rent avec les variations d‚Äôintensit√© qu‚Äôoffrent les segments ¬´ tr√®s speed ¬ª de certains chapitres.
 
√Ä chaque fin de level, un boss se dressera devant votre passage et pour le tuer, il faudra taper sur les cases dans un rythme bien pr√©cis pour d√©bloquer un tir qui tuera √† force de r√©p√©tition le vilain pas beau se dressant sur votre chemin. La dur√©e de vie du titre d√©pend tr√®s clairement de votre niveau et de votre dext√©rit√© avec vos paluches manette en main, mais compter en moyenne 9 heures pour arriver au bout de l‚Äôaventure.

√Ä mon sens, le jeu ne poss√®de pas de d√©fauts √† part son prix relativement prohibitif et 20‚Ç¨ sont, je pense, un poil trop cher, mais il est √©vident que pendant les soldes de Steam, Thumper va certainement faire un vrai carton en termes de ventes. C‚Äôest √©videmment tout le mal que l‚Äôon souhaite aux 2 d√©veloppeurs qui ont r√©ussi √† sortir un jeu compl√®tement barr√©, mais vraiment r√©ussi‚Ä¶
‚Äã
Pour ma part, c‚Äôest l‚Äôun de mes coups de c≈ìur 2017 sur PC.

POSITIFS :
Un gameplay qui secoue 
Vitesse d‚Äôanimation qui pulse 
Une excellente dur√©e de vie 
Une difficult√© progressive et adapt√©e
Novateur 
Belle direction artistique 

N√âGATIFS :
Manette obligatoire 

Thumper est une belle claque vid√©oludique. Hardcore, violent et hypnotisant, le jeu ne vous laissera aucun r√©pit et rare sont les jeux √† offrir autant de sensations fortes avec un concept aussi minimaliste, mais dans son genre, Thumper est terriblement efficace. Une petite perle sous LSD qu‚Äôil faudra absolument acqu√©rir quand une belle promo viendra pointer le bout de son nez.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040182778', 'num_games_owned': 382, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 563, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 272, 'last_played': 1626946057}
review:
Thumper is the video game equivalent of strangling your worst enemy to death. 

It's utterly brutal, mortifying, and at times definitely frustrating, but it dares you to hate it. Ingeniously, the game itself is an outlet for your anger. Every rhythmic beat is explosively violent and deeply satisfying. The combination of all of those hits (or "kills", as the game actually calls successful notes), alongside the terrifyingly beautiful art design, results in the most amazing art game I've ever played. People usually say "art game" to deride something for being both not really art and not really a game, but Thumper is definitely both.

Congratulations to the two (two!!!) developers, and thank you for bringing us rhythm violence.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057997322', 'num_games_owned': 285, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 815, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 719, 'last_played': 1576837979}
review:
Fantastic game. Awesome visuals, though you may have a hard time focusing on them considering the frantic nature of the game. The soundtrack is wonderfully dark and distorted, with a massive low brass amplifying the feeling of darkness and dread. 
My only gripe is that the later levels (excluding 9) tend to start looking and sounding the same - the game could've done with a bit more variation in its patterns and visuals.
Aside from that - the game will take you about 9 hours to beat - far more than I expected to spend playing the game , I also see myself going back to this game, to improve my scores and play the brutally tough PLAY+ mode.

9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197994523365', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 183, 'last_played': 1495235331}
review: This is the greatest Hot-Wheels track.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120274791', 'num_games_owned': 241, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 525, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 465, 'last_played': 1519992490}
review: Never have my armpits sweat so much.

author: {'steamid': '76561198113366106', 'num_games_owned': 3175, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1334, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1334, 'last_played': 1493203418}
review:
Thumper is a very fast paced, beautiful looking "Rhythm"/ Reaction game. I'm having a hard time calling it a rhythm game since big parts of the game solely rely on fast reflexes and muscle memory, so dont expect a game where you cruise around to the music.

That said, Thumper is one hell of a experience. The game already starts out pretty challenging, but ramps the difficulty up higher and higher with every level. Beating the game isnt a very easy task already and requires some dedication. If you want to go for "S" rank on every level you better be prepared for a wild ride, cause that will take some serious commitment.

The best thing about this game is probably the feel of the gameplay. Taking sharp turns with full speed or hitting a flawless segment just feels so satisfying. I really enjoyed my time with Thumper and it delivered a very unique experience, that I can recommend to anyone that likes a little challenge.

author: {'steamid': '76561198164593247', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1428, 'last_played': 1518549791}
review: One of the best games i've ever played. Creepy atmosphere, unique gameplay, beautiful graphics, great sounds etc. If you like rhythm games you must buy it, it's definitely worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005022607', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1160, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 354, 'last_played': 1673992407}
review: I'm a huge fan of rhythm games and timing execution. I've been playing them since Legend of Dragoon games on the PS1, Frequency and Amplitude on the PS2. This game takes the cake in regards to VR. Easily find myself getting lost in it. Love the trippiness associated with it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975607409', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 318, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 291, 'last_played': 1533609818}

author: {'steamid': '76561198119621670', 'num_games_owned': 96, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1599, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 286, 'last_played': 1649719987}
review: YES YES YES, TO THE F*CKING YES, this game is perfect if you have the ability to let yourself go and immerse yourself into a world of rhythmic violence! 100% worth the price

author: {'steamid': '76561197960830998', 'num_games_owned': 926, 'num_reviews': 264, 'playtime_forever': 193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 119, 'last_played': 1625446713}
review:
One of the most polished VR titles in my library (HTC VIVE).

It's a rhythm game and not a rhythm game in my opinion, you definately score higher and do better when you are playing to a ryhthm, but its a mix of visual and musical queues.

Feels like stepping into a 1980's special effect futuristic trippy cutscene  - think of the starchild / stargate scene in 2001 - A Space Odyssey!

Pros:
Good visuals 
Good music
Unique VR title (so far)
Simple graphics settings and easy to pop the headset on and just play

Cons:
Occasionally feels slightly out of sync on my computer
Music could have a little more variety.

9/10 - top 5 VR title.

author: {'steamid': '76561198127059779', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 689, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 338, 'last_played': 1665861232}
review:
Skill based and innovative, Thumper takes a few basic controls and blends them seamlessly as you play a psychedelic beetle on a mission to destroy a floating robot head in space. As one might imagine, you play this for the gameplay not so much the lore.
If you like music based games (like Patapon!) this is definitely a game you should pick up.

However, the sound design was amazing. Overall, this game gets a 10/10. Amazing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198102446306', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2169, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 124, 'playtime_at_review': 859, 'last_played': 1712181032}
review:
I'm in my thirties, i've played a lot of games.

This is hands down one of the most unique experiences i've ever had in front of a computer. Please don't think of it as a just a rhythm game even though my music sensitivity basically had a 14-hour long orgasm.

The dark aggressive overwhelming aesthetics resonate with me on all levels but I guess that might not be the case for everyone.

Also: A TOP 3 MUST BUY FOR VR USERS.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966614354', 'num_games_owned': 242, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1332, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 443, 'last_played': 1545500274}
review: This game is awesome even though it took me 6 hours to beat it. A very fast-paced rhythm / reaction game that kept me entertained the entire time (and I think I'll be coming back for those S-Ranks). The atmosphere in this game is top-tier and I love the dark sinister music to accompany it. I suggest you get it and play through at least the first level.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001813417', 'num_games_owned': 457, 'num_reviews': 850, 'playtime_forever': 53, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 43, 'last_played': 1504542100}
review: Wahnsinniges Rhytmusspiel mit nem Skarab√§us! Einzig, da√ü die Steuerung f√ºr die Vive nicht erkl√§rt wird ist negativ, aber mit ausprobieren klappt es dann auch!

author: {'steamid': '76561198025176680', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 1025, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 912, 'last_played': 1594162488}
review:
Just when you think you're getting good, when your confidence is soaring, the game will make you curl up into a ball and watch gems fly past you. But you've got to get out there eventually. You've got to get those gems, even if it means dropping your defenses near a rapidly-approaching series of obstacles.

And whether or not you realize it, you'll learn the telegraphs for the turns. A slight tilt of the track, and your finger is already prepared to push in the direction of the upcoming turn.

And once you get really good, you'll beg yourself to quit being reckless. And then you'll jump into the air, slam into a gem, and jump again; You'll remain airborne while artfully turning corners against your will. You don't know if you'll ever be able to pull that off again. But you will.

It's like Rez. Your first playthrough's about surviving. After that, survival's never the issue.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019908616', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 676, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 444, 'last_played': 1596959797}
review: The most perfect game since Hotline Miami.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019306646', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 477, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 180, 'last_played': 1501888595}
review:
Absolutely stunning visuals, fantastic atmospheric sound.

However, this is not a rhythm game - audio ques are simply dreadful, and the game becomes about pattern recognition and memorization, with little meaningful interaction with the music.

Still fun, and will recommend to those who understand exactly what to expect.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999552598', 'num_games_owned': 2305, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 1944, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 282, 'last_played': 1665337708}
review:
One of the most difficult questions I've had to answer as a parent came when my son came in while I was playing this and asked me, "What's this game about?"

It's... like guitar hero, but with less buttons.  And you're a beetle on a roller coaster. Which features tentacles and weird geometric shapes and centipedes and things. And the music is something like a drum & bass remix of a horror movie soundtrack. It's somehow simultaneously entertaining and deeply unsettling.

But despite that rather unflattering explanation, it's a good game. It's hard to describe exactly what makes it a good game, but it has my heart beating faster than a liter of energy drink, it's making my hands cramp up from gripping the controller so hard, and it's making me sweat despite it being 68 degrees F in this room, and any game that can elicit that kind of a physical response has got to be good, right?

This game is the biggest motivation I have right now to buy a VR headset because I can only imagine how amazing it would be with one. Or horrifying. Definitely one or the other, and I want to experience that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087858194', 'num_games_owned': 685, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 592, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 592, 'last_played': 1492180819}
review:
Gorgeus and really satisfying rhythm game with a different and captivating soundtrack. Everything in this game fits perfectly together. 

I had tons of fun getting S ranks in all levels so recommended for completionists/perfectionists as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999455936', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 3433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 520, 'last_played': 1663621491}
review:
The slickest game I've ever played.

You know a games is good when you enjoy it even though you know that it is trying to make you go blind.

I was initially concerned that it only had 9 levels. But I've owned it for months and I've only made it to the end of level 8.

Of course this could also be because I need to lie down in a dark room after every 20 minutes of play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065621158', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 112, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 112, 'last_played': 1481005228}
review:
This is a really enjoyable game, I got decently far into it, despite only playing for almost 2 hours though I'm sure there is MUCH more than that.

It eases you into the game really well, and is really easy to pick up, however, I haven't played it for a few months and then tried to come back to it and found that I was not prepared at all to pick up where I left off. I feel like I'd have to play from the beginning again just to get back into the rythem and how the game works.

Other than that, I highly recommend it for people who enjoy rythem based games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068580495', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 459, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 137, 'last_played': 1587846243}
review:
Thumper is a brutal rhythm game that never ceases to be challenging. The heavy music and the abstract, dark art style complement eachother forming not just a very fun game, but a legitimate piece of artwork. The game is divided into 9 levels and each level is split into a couple dozen pieces with a smooth transition between each piece. Every level brings new mechanics that are so good that there is a desire to finish a level just to see the next mechanic. The game is actually easier than it looks, but it is still definitely far from easy. Every obstacle is fine-tuned to match the beat of the song not only by the sound it makes while crossing the obstacle, but also the sound it makes when spawning. In VR, despite the very erratic nature of the game, there is absolutely zero motion sickness, because, technically speaking, the VR camera is stationary and everything moves towards the player. The checkpoints always come on time, none of them feel spaced too far between eachother. But, it is actually easy to miss the checkpoint, which, even though the game still saves, does not get the second health layer back if you encounter an obstacle before.

In conclusion, this game is highly polished and definitely worth buying even in full price. It is very fast paced and hurts your fingers eventually, but that should definitely not deter you from this amazing experience. If you enjoyed Bit Trip Runner, this is a must-have.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030421664', 'num_games_owned': 168, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 878, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 291, 'last_played': 1627749964}
review:
The most viceral and intense at PAX EAST 2017 that I found. Maybe not the cutest feel good fun time game - but if you enjoy a challenge and feel beats, Thumper will do you right.

Thumper is a game for the rhythmic masochistic. It's like if Dr. Mario prescribed DMT to PaRappa the Rapper and he then somehow gave birth to an alien beetle to save the universe from a Crackhead.

Two dudes made this game. Watch the video and let that sink in.

review: ËøôÊ¨æÊ∏∏ÊàèÁöÑËÆæËÆ°ÁêÜÂøµÂæàÂ•ΩÔºåÁ°ÆÂÆûÂèØ‰ª•Âú®Áü≠Êó∂Èó¥ÂÜÖËÆ©‰∫∫ÊûÅÂ∫¶‰∫¢Â•ãÔºå‰ΩÜÂêåÊ†∑ËøôÊ¨æÊ∏∏ÊàèÁöÑÁº∫ÁÇπÊòæËÄåÊòìËßÅÔºåÂ∞±ÊòØÂú®Èü≥‰πê‰∏éÊâìÂáªÊÑüÁöÑÁªìÂêà‰∏äËøúËøú‰∏çÂ§üÔºåÊúÄÂ•ΩÁöÑ‰∏ÄÂÖ≥Â∞±ÊòØ1-13ÈÇ£ÂÖ≥Èü≥‰πê‰∏éÊâìÂáªÂÆåÁæéÁªìÂêàÔºåËÆ©‰∫∫ÊäïÂÖ•ÂÖ∂‰∏≠„ÄÇÂà∞ËææÊ∏∏Êàè‰∏≠ÂêéÊúü‰∏çÂ∫îËØ•‰ªÖ‰ªÖÊòØÂú®ÈöæÂ∫¶‰∏äÁöÑÊèêÂçáÔºåÂçïÂçïËÄÉÈ™å‰∫∫ÁöÑÊÑüÂÆòËÉΩÂäõ„ÄÇËøôÊ†∑Áé©‰∏ãÊù•Ôºå‰ºöËÆ©‰∫∫ËßâÂæóÂæàÁ¥Ø„ÄÇËææ‰∏çÂà∞ËÆ©‰∫∫Âú®ÊúâÈôêÁöÑÊó∂Èó¥ÂÜÖÔºåÊîæÊùæË∫´ÂøÉÁöÑÁõÆÁöÑ„ÄÇÊàëÊâøËÆ§ËøôÊòØ‰∏ÄÊ¨æ‰∏çÈîôÁöÑÊ∏∏ÊàèÔºåÊàë‰πüÊé®Ëçê‰ªñÔºå‰ΩÜÊàëÂ∑≤ÈÄâÊã©ÈÄÄÊ¨æ„ÄÇ‰∏çÂñúÂãøÂñ∑

author: {'steamid': '76561198060839827', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 970, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 970, 'last_played': 1490589317}
review:
Before I go on I would like to preface everything I am about to say with, I don't dislike the game and I have a very adept music background, so rhythm is something that I'm very good at and used to feeling.

 It is a very well made game, however, the audio ques for the action commands are flat bad. They do not stand out enough against the very basic beat to make it noticeable when you need to do something at many times.

I would be trying to find the rhythm of a particular section and I end up memorizing the pattern by watching it and doing it over and over rather than actually feeling the beat of the music and reacting based on that beat. When the game is based off rhythm, this is not acceptable.

I still do not think this is a bad game per say, but there are just times when the rhythm part of the game isn't standing out enough to actually feel the rhythm and this is most likely due to the fact that there is so little actual rhythm music in the damn game. I went through a level and all there was in that level was a snare on a pattern that did not deviate at any point with the patterns in the level, to make it worse it was a boss fight. I did not enjoy that boss fight for any amount of time.

The game is good, but the rhythm aspect of the game needs to stand out more and the music needs to support it more otherwise it doesn't feel like a rhythm game, but rather a pattern recognition game.

Also the effect for taking damage is so distorting that it makes it very difficult to recover if you are in a hard section both with the way it affects the rhythm and the view of what is coming toward you.

The game is very much made for VR more than anything else. The view of the game is great and cool and all, but the rhythm aspect of the game (which is the entirety of the game's base purpose) isn't standing out enough to make it good in my opinion.

The instrumentation is the same throughout the entire game. It is always going to be the same metallic drum with an increased increment on the time. (1/4 time 2/4 time etc etc) Due to this the patterns, while increasing in complexity, are beginning to run together and feel the same after 4 levels. 

So after everything is said and done, the rhythm isn't good enough and standing out enough to make it a good rhythm game and the patterns, while they increase in complexity as the game gets higher in level, are very same-y throughout the entire game. The instrumentation is far below average for a rhythm game.

This is a game best suited for those with VR and no one else. I cannot in good conscience recommend this game for anyone without VR.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996054737', 'num_games_owned': 511, 'num_reviews': 147, 'playtime_forever': 320, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 237, 'last_played': 1607230721}

author: {'steamid': '76561197966465521', 'num_games_owned': 589, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 22, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1490437116}

author: {'steamid': '76561198027372201', 'num_games_owned': 1131, 'num_reviews': 215, 'playtime_forever': 245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 114, 'last_played': 1650899421}
review:
Thumper is a greatly challenging, exhausting and absolutely gripping, and truly athmpsoheric experience that had me reel from its truly terrificly creepy bosses.

You race along a track and to the rhytm of the music have to perform maneuvers like evading bariers left, right, pushing a button the minute you reach a light on the track, jump and fly of a specific amount of time and block attacks.
The palette of these maneuvers becomes bigger and bigger as well as the the way the track shows itself. For example the track later gets multiple lanes that it counts to navigate on top of everything else.

It's perhabs biggest hurdle is this, the rather quickly surmounting difficulty. 

If you are not a fan off repeating the same stages again and again then i would advice to stay away since this will simply a big part of the experience and the nature of this game.

The difficulty offers also another problem, at least to me personally. Since you first need to get into the rhytms and immense speed in wich the game challenges you it is difficulty to pick the game up just like that. You will have to play the whole thing over again or it will take even more retries to get back into the rhythm and speed of the different levels.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994545779', 'num_games_owned': 290, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 110, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 110, 'last_played': 1489121509}
review:
Thumper is a fun game, if you have a nice monitor and decent speakers to provide you the immersive feeling. Haven't finished the game yet but it's getting a lot harder as the level goes up, you just have to be extremely focused to get S without endless retries. But I fear that if people are playing this game using VR, it is gonna be super dizzy.
Anyways, recommend, especially for ppl who loves adrenaline music

author: {'steamid': '76561197970532781', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 172, 'last_played': 1654027276}
review:
I have very few rythm games I have ever taken a liking to. The DDR craze along side Guitar Hero type games were never  really my thing. The last rythm game I was really impressed with was Pa-Rappa, its quirky characters and super memorable songs hit just the right spot. It's been a long time since that game, and I always wished something would impress me the way that title did for the rythm gene...enter Thumper.
Unlike Pa-Rappa there is no story, quirky charaters, or zany ass songs...hell its not even like Thumpers soundtrack could be considered a song, more like a drumtrack from hell (but still so good). This is Rythm at its core.
I'm only on the 3rd level as of now, and I can tell you its a white nuckle affair. Super trippy graphics play perfectly to a soundtrack to get your heart pumping, and controls that are spot on. I have read elsewhere that someone said there was  lag after an update. I had no such problems, everything worked great with my 360 controller.
People looking for more than arcade rythm game might look elsewhere. This is not a story driven game, nor should it be. When a game is this slick, gameplay wins over story. Its all about hitting the jumps, turns, and marked location with the correct presses of the d-pad and the A button at the right times. You don't have real freedom of movement, but soon in you'll realize you wouldn't want it anyways. You'll be too busy just trying to stay alive, and 2 misses and it's game over. It's hardcore, and it's fun. A must buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104336419', 'num_games_owned': 530, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 425, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 411, 'last_played': 1621357135}
review:
I previously made a review for this game about 4 years ago, congratulating the game on its soundtrack and brutal difficulty. What I failed to ponder nor even question then however was what the game itself was trying to achieve. 

I purchased this game the year it came out and since then never gotten around to beating it. (Update, I just beat it. The final boss exemplifies the following more than I could imagine.) Not only is the game immensely difficult, requiring an almost inhuman reaction time and ability to ignore the blaring and abstract background at all times, but I genuinely cannot find a game that leaves me so mentally exhausted every time I give it another go. Its a cruel game. Sweat will run, joints will stiffen, and eyes will dry. 

Now I can forgive a game for that. I'm not one to back down from a grueling challenge, more on the opposite side in fact. The game is advertised to bring "blistering speed, and brutal physicality" and somehow delivers more than that. What I cant forgive is the description of "rhythm violence: classic rhythm-action". 

Thumper is not a rhythm game. That, or it lies just on the edge of the boundaries of what classifies a rhythm game. Its like someone that despises rhythm games set out to make one to hurt those that enjoy them. Normally when I play a rhythm game, I love getting lost in the music whilst focusing on the game play. The music in Thumper is droning ambiance combined with heart hurting drums. 

Layout of the obstacles in a level is constantly chaotic and can change pace faster than when you inhale when it happens. After every single level, I felt completely exhausted from the chaos I had went through only to find out that there was always more discord to come. The game is not nearly as reliant on rhythm as much as it is on visual cues. Sure, occasionally, notes spawn at a consistent rate. The time it takes to get to each one is the same. That is rhythm. If I just had more of that put through the game, I would probably word this review a bit differently.

Please don't misconstrue this, but Thumper is a really good game. I just truly don't see why this is classified as a rhythm game. Never once within the game did I have to rely on the sound to do well. Thumper is just a terrible rhythm game, and since the game advertises itself as such to a gross degree, It fails to deliver what it promises.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097632017', 'num_games_owned': 395, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 336, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 139, 'last_played': 1503258885}
review:
I was sceptical when I got this game, despite all the good reviews. The Pictures and the video looked as if there isn't variety in this game and I wondered if this feels like a Mini-Game you play for a few Minutes like some shallow Smartphone games.
It took like 20 Minutes and I was completely sucked in.
I must admit, I am not a big fan of the soundtrack, not because it is bad, but because its not the kind of music I listen to. BUT it fits incredibly well and it is needed to create the package. And maybe that's exactly the success formula of this game: It is a perfect package.
The visuals alone are psychedelic and if you look at them alone without playing or hearing the music, it's nothing special. The gameplay itself is polished, but nothing that hasn't been done before. But if you take it all together, it's so complementary, that you get an truly awesome immersion.
The pure speed which makes the gameplay thrilling, the beats which lets you literally feel the track, the flow you get... I don't remember anything I can compare it to.
I can imagine that you can play this game for hours without getting bored... Cleary recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561198017341939', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 962, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 564, 'last_played': 1709360965}
review:
This game really shines in VR

You can really feel the speed while you zip across the beautiful levels,  The game ease you in by giving a short tutorial. As you get into higher levels the speed will ramp up so will difficulty.

The way the rail moves and flows are very eye pleasing in VR. 

Even with all the action and movements in the game, i did not feel any motion sickness at all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020156278', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 762, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 414, 'last_played': 1571332358}
review:
One of those New VR Titles that surprised me in a very positive way.
It's very addicting , beautifull and fun to play for numerous times.
For a Rythym game the soundtrack is also very innovative, because when playing the first level you kinda don't really know what to expect but think it's al fun and games but when the music builds up and delivers you those in game breakdowns and often weird structures, it also creates a new interest for people interested in musicianship from electronic to just acoustic/instrumental music in all forms.
this one didn't feel like such a Tec Demo like some of the other Oculus titles out there right now.
Even if you dont specially love Rythym or music games in general,  id highly reccomend this to anyone new to Virtual Reality like me and a lot of other people.

author: {'steamid': '76561198218236675', 'num_games_owned': 169, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 790, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 171, 'last_played': 1648340054}
review:
This is a REVOLUTIONARY rhythm game, rising up to perhaps the first true modern rhythm game. It goes beyond the traditional design of using icons to tell you what to press found in games like Parappa the Rappa, Dance Dance Revolution, Guitar Hero, and Beat Mania. Thumper goes beyond it by telling you what to press visually. The ominous repetitive drum rolls give you the tempo needed for you to have sense as to what goes on, and the visual & sound queues come up just a couple seconds before they are needed to activate.

There is an awesome sense of reward if you land certain queues correctly, which may give you a shield if you don't already have one, to simply a neat effect complementing it with point multipliers. The boss battles could get intense and require several tries to beat them since that is when the queues become even more unpredictable but fair enough to queue you if you react in time.

At first my impression of the first level was "Okay, this is kinda cool." By the time I was on the third level the game began to get so difficult but was hooked at the sound effects, the combos that the game teaches you, original dark ambient/techno-ish soundtrack which progressively gets more complicated, and deceptively simplistic mechanical control. All these factors make you want to BEAT the level.

This is an AMAZING and REVOLUTIONARY game, giving you the right amount of difficulty and queue time to get better. Thumper should not be missed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062390596', 'num_games_owned': 117, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 106, 'last_played': 1499365261}
review:
-Not really a rhythm game, it plays more on reactions than anything else.
-Soundtrack is really good and very energic.
-Visuals are really nice but get in the way a little too much, its worse when you lose a life because the screen starts          shaking like mad and theres this loud distorsion going on all while the games keeps going.
-Callsigns blend in a little too much so you rely a lot on vision.
-It's so satisfying when it works but really frustrating when it doesn't
-Overalls it's a good game, there are better RHYTHM games but this game is nice.
 Not really that hard if you've played games like Rhythm Heaven, Audiosurf, Osu etc.

7/10
Will keep playing.

Would be better if:
-Bigger emphasis on actually building a sense of rhythm patterns/sequences and such.
-Less visual clutter especially when you lose a life cause that's when you're at your most vulnerable.
-Better audio mixing, louder callsings, beats for counting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062813911', 'num_games_owned': 1958, 'num_reviews': 2050, 'playtime_forever': 997, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 960, 'last_played': 1663717149}
review:
[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review, if you want a full review, then please read better reviews then mine [/h1]

Thumper is a game developed and published by Drool

Thumper offers an unbelievable soundtrack. It is extremely original and amazing. The visuals are incredible, they are so trippy and immersive. 

Thumper offers a very challenging and intense gameplay, but it's fair and simple. There is no luck involved, just skill. The soundtrack, visuals, and gameplay are so good, it doesn't need a narrative.

The only issue with the game is the keyboard controls, they feel pretty awkward compared to a controller, to be fair they do recommend an XBOX360 controller from the start

If you like rhythm games, this game is a certain MUST. Between the incredible soundtrack to the amazing visuals, Thumper is a nice tight package of a game that requires a lot of skill

But when you beat that boss that's been killing you for past three hours, the feeling is so damn good 

Prepare yourselves for the best space rhythm battle of your life! 

[h1] RECOMMENDED :) [/h1]
[i] THEPCGAMER'S BEST GAME IN STEAM LIBRARY! (What's this? :- Like some games get "Best Game of 2014" or "Best Indie Game", etc... So I have decided to make my own!) [/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198047142862', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 239, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 236, 'last_played': 1489825891}
review: This game was made for an arcade stick. I really enjoy the pace of the levels. As the mechanics build you learn new pieces of information and it's given at a consistent rate. One mechanic you learn on a level is immediately used and a new one is introduced. It's a great system and really builds up the player's skill. Once you have learned enough to progress you feel like a boss, and that at the end of the day is what some of us are looking for.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097168561', 'num_games_owned': 178, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1762, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 566, 'last_played': 1707818275}

author: {'steamid': '76561198044699957', 'num_games_owned': 331, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 2172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 747, 'last_played': 1697843873}
review: This game will amaze you, it's like entering a world in which before you is a void that tests your every bit of skill as you progress. I got this horrible vibe when I played this like I was descending further into a place where the world itself and monsters are trying to stop you from reaching...... well you don't know what you're reaching for on this. You start straight into the action and the games teaches you new mechanics in a flued way where you are told the new way to approach this obstacle as you perform the action. Boss fights are crazy and the music gets your blood pumping. You are sucked into this game moving your body and banging your head as you hit a turn and hear the scrape of your character on the walls, as you hit a note and the map shakes and bends in response while a deep bass floods your ears. It's hard to explain how much anyone will love this. You will get sucked in and you will play to find out why you are on this journey that doesn't give you even a tiny idea on what the aim of your character. All you know is there is a light and the universe around you doesn't want you to reach it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198160272882', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 748, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 373, 'last_played': 1575254650}
