author: {'steamid': '76561197996724591', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 974, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 560, 'last_played': 1619262376}
review:
Never before has a story about a metal bug reaching the singularity been so thrilling. This rhythm game cares less about the music you're trying to match and more about whether you survive its onslaught or not. Each level is an endurance test laced with adrenalin and boss fights with only slight breathers sprinkled in. Between that and it's very surreal visuals, it's a brilliant jump-start to the senses and one hell of a substitute for caffeine. 

Having said all this, wait for a sale. $20 is a bit much for a game that stops varying its obstacles mid-way through and the faster it gets, the harder it becomes to tell what's ahead thanks to the visuals becoming a blurred mess or red and silver. (This is why you don't speed, kids.) Not just that, but there should be a penalty for games that only offer health when you're playing well...meaning that you don't need the health when you're rewarded with it 90% of the time. Just adds salt to the wounds from crashing cus' one level is kicking your ass and you can reeeeeeeally use that health the game spat out last level. That fact is especially true in boss fights. The health refill only appears when you do a section perfectly the first time. The only way that system works is through trail and error and again, by then you generally don't need it when you're given it.

Another thing is by about world 5, the game gets hard. By world 6, you're expected to master everything, even techniques never taught to you. For example, you can bounce. Game never taught me that, but the game expected me to have perfected this hidden technique. You told me how to slam down on the ground from the air, why not tell me how to stay in the air? That goes double for those arches that appear long past your normal flight strength. I still haven't figured out how to get them cus' the game never told me.

Still, despite the grips, it's a fun curiosity that's worth trying. Where else can you go fight a giant devil doughnut?

author: {'steamid': '76561198003023219', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 5959, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5530, 'last_played': 1669690543}
review:
This game is a rush. It is for insane people. I'm pretty sure I've been subliminally brainwashed, and it's only a matter of time until I'm activated by some code phrase that's been slipped into a breakfast cereal ad. "Beating" Thumper was just the start: things really took off for me in the dozens of hours I spent climbing the leaderboards in Play+ mode, where the stakes, the speed, and the highest highs are all even greater:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oLOr9CfGpzc

Become the beetle.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054645245', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 12523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4755, 'last_played': 1691247318}
review: It's great. Extremely challenging and visually gorgeous. 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198067070296', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1350, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 302, 'last_played': 1707360538}
review:
Pros: 
- Unbelievable soundtrack. Its extremely original and amazing. 
- VISUALS. Incredible, so trippy and immersive. 
- Very challenging and intense gameplay, but it's fair and simple. There is no luck involved, just skill.
- I'm generally not a huge fan of games with almost no narrative, but this game is an exception. The soundtrack, visuals, and gameplay are so good, it doesn't need a narrative.

Cons:
- Keyboard controls feel pretty awkward compared to a controller (to be fair they recommend a controller) 

Overall:
If you like rhythm games, this game is a MUST. Between the incredible soundtrack to the amazing visuals, Thumper is a nice tight package of a game that requires a lot of skill. But when you beat that boss that's been killing your for past 3 hours, the feeling is so damn good. I've spent hours playing it on a PS4 and I will continue to keep playing it on Steam until I beat it. And oh man, is that going to take a while. 

Prepare yourselves for the best space rhythm battle of your life! 

Rating: 9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197976575453', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1151, 'last_played': 1533320519}
review:
So I've played this game on and off for a while now and I think it deserves a review. I stumbled upon this game when I watched an unrelated Gaming Video with short scenes of this game spliced into it and knew I had to have it just by the looks of it, so I bought it on sale and haven't been disappointed.
Thumper is a rythm game. It's also kind of a horror game with lovecraftian themes. Controls are simple. You have a Stick with four directions and a button, the game throws you the beats and some obstacles and then it goes like this: *THUMP*---*THUMP-THUMP*--*CLING*-*THUMPdangdang*---*THUMPdadingSrrrrrrrrrrrrr*---*WUMP*. Or something like that. The game just feels great. I think what sets it apart from other rythm games is that it's not only important to hit the beat at the right time (the hit window is actually pretty generous) but also that you have to keep the button pressed to not crash into obstacles and release it at the right time to get the next beat. Then add some basic horizontal and vertical movement and you have a simple yet challenging and fun game.
The Game is hard but fair (in most cases, some obstacles you can't possibly see coming), you can repeat any checkpoint without punishment, if your reaction time is lacking you can always memorize the patterns. But you will still die a lot, because the game is fast and you only get two chances before you die. But the game also eases you into it, the first 4 levels are basically tutorial, Level 5 is where things get rough and you struggling just to survive. It also is the kind of game where it is really fun to play it again after you have beaten it just to see how much you have grown as a player and how easily you can get an S-Rank on a part you struggled so hard before.
Overall two thumbs (thumps?) up, highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198171075429', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 322, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 112, 'last_played': 1503534818}
review:
If ever you've wanted to pilot a musical spacecoaster through alien hell, Thumper is the game for you. 

"Rhythm violence" is an apt tagline. It's throw-your-controller maddening, but you'll retrieve it and try again a hundred more times anyway. Such is the will of the Thumper boss, a flaming hellskull whose siren bass all are powerless to resist.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971348987', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 625, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 428, 'last_played': 1647189838}
review:
Thumper is like a rythm oriented psychedelic "Audio Surf" with a mandatory dubstepish soundtrack. 

The action gets FAST, and my 42 year old reflexes were seriously put to a test, but I did manage to finish the game partly by memorizing and "feeling the bpm". 

It was at times a pretty frustrating experience, but also equally rewarding when finishing the last 3-4 levels. 

I must admit I bought the game mainly due to it's high praise on PSVR as one of the best VR games on that platform. I don't get it - there's NO VR element in it. You have no incentive to look anywhere but straight ahead.  You get the same experience by sitting close to a big stereoscopic 3d display.

If you're a fan of the genre, I reckon it's a must buy, but if you're mainly just looking for a great VR title look somewhere else.

68%

author: {'steamid': '76561198041798556', 'num_games_owned': 133, 'num_reviews': 133, 'playtime_forever': 807, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 807, 'last_played': 1502564652}
review:
This game is insane, in a good way. 

It offers 10 levels with an increasing number of sections that introduce new mechanics each time and get more difficult as they progress. It's not as short as it seems, for the later levels have an increasing amount of sections. Overall, I am impressed and the concept is really interesting and original. Thumper also supports controllers, ultrawide resolutions and the HTC Vive. Runs surprisingly smooth, both inside and outside of VR and it's great performance seems very consistant. This game is intense and offers unique, psychedelic visuals. 

There is a learning curve and a fairly high difficulty factor, but if you like a challenge and have some patience, this game is for you.

Overall Rating: 4.5 of 5

author: {'steamid': '76561198198291685', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 294, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 214, 'last_played': 1522458652}
review: This game is pretty much a living hell, and that's why I love it. The gameplay is kind of a mix of the extreme twitch controls of platformers like Super Meat Boy and the original Mega Man and rythym games like Guitar Hero, but then also kind of it's own thing. It seems chaotic and bizzare at first, but just play for a few minutes and you'll find yourself unable to stop.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072287711', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2103, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1354, 'last_played': 1661658367}

author: {'steamid': '76561197988267862', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 13, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1485922810}
review:
Its an alright game but it gets frustrating. The worst thing I found initially was total lack of 3D vision support so I am stuck playing a trippy game in 2D which is lame. The game gradually gets more and more difficult and more visually twisted as you advance. I can see this as being a neat experience but after a while it looses its charm and begins to get boring quickly like most fast reflex games. Its worth getting on sale if you are interested or have a VR headset. I would suggest you play with a controller. The keyboard controls are fine though once you get used to them and it will take a while when you get to advanced stages.

If they added 3D vision support, I would be more inclined to play further.
Recommended for VR.
Boring in 2D after first playthrough.
Not much replay value after that unless in VR.

author: {'steamid': '76561198147855175', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 287, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 100, 'last_played': 1658679166}
review:
[h1]If you own a VR headset, this is a must-have. [/h1]

I've only ever reviewed one other game and that was just to satisfy the steam community badge. Needless to say, this game exceeds my expectations- no this game has become [u]the standard, the pinnacle for VR seated experiences[/u]. I've had my Vive since launch and have played most everything room scale. I didn't think a seated VR game would even come close to the level of immersion experienced via other room scale games but this takes the cake. 

Gameplay - [b]10/10[/b]
While not entirely rhythm based, Thumper lends itself to a series of visual and audio cues to alert the player. Quick reactions, and keen foresight are needed to obtain the highest score for each level. I find myself replaying levels and checkpoints just to get the coveted S rank. Mistakes are pounded into you in Darks Souls fashion.  

Visuals - [b]10/10[/b]
Astounding, exemplary, beautiful. I run a GTX 1070 so there's no lacking in graphical throughput. That said, the visuals throughtout are as smooth as a car ride in the countryside. Despite being a roller coaster-esque experience, the visuals don't overshadow the sense of scale, and wonder as you zoom through the obstacles. The geometrical shapes and patterns accompanying the ride flow like a river. There are moments of muted austerity, which is then contrasted by an elongated grandeur. 

Sound - [b]10/10[/b]
Imagine laying down for an MRI. You're semi-naked in the patient garbs, and you're being slowly thrusted down this tube of magnets and xrays. The incoming radation that will blast through your body is unnerving at first, and you don't realise how it affects you until the doctor shows you your results. This is what the OST to this game does. It accompanies you on a journey and heightens your senses. Like laying there defenseless, you let it overtake you, embrace you at times. Harsh, almost industrial at times, but soft, and orchestral at others. Perfectly balanced for levels, and bosses. 


[i]Every sound, every light, every movement is orchestrated to provide a thrilling, terrifying, and mesmerising experience. [/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198104510325', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 49, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 49, 'last_played': 1485909558}
review:
Even on the lowest of settings the game still has issues reading key inputs. I have died several times because i hit the wrong direction for a turn and that is on me., But I have died even more with the right direction held down before the obstacle and the game still not recognising it. and yes you can hold stuff down before you reach it. There is next to no rythem  for this game except for that which you create by playing the thing. there is nothing to really get into and hell sometimes it will through things at you that are out of sync witht the rest of what is going on. 

Visually it looks okay, and you can tell when the game is having trouble loading the next stage. Over all I have played rythm games on the phone that make this look like somthing that was spat out at a game jam with a talented artist on the team.

8 pumkins out an apple tree.

Currently wating on refund.

Update: refund attained.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069729839', 'num_games_owned': 181, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 1045, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 700, 'last_played': 1647059901}
review:
As an avid fan of rhythm, amospheric, and horror games, I had to give this a try. I saw it on sale and grabbed it for $14.

It was totally worth it. 

By far, the most unique rhythm game I've ever played. I mean, the closest thing I can compare it to is either Audiosurf or Amplitude (2015). But that's kind of a stretch.

First of all, the difficulty as you complete levels scales damn near perfectly. It introduces new machanics and controls as you go along just enough to keep it interesting and challenging without throwing too much stuff at you to deal with. 

It took me about 10-11 hours to beat all of the songs. Each song/level takes about an hour to complete, assuming you'll miss some sequences sometimes and have to start over at a checkpoint. I was worried that I wouldn't get enough playtime out of this game but even after beating it, I want to revisit the levels again and try to get an S rank on all of them. I can see myself getting another 5 or 10 hours out of this game easily. 

ALSO, it's VR supported. I don't have a headset, but you can bet your ass this is the first game I'd play if I got one.

In short, if your a fan of rhythm games or just experimental dark indie games, this is a must play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042499541', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 244, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 201, 'last_played': 1668969391}
review:
J'ai vraiment √©t√© √©tonn√© par ce jeu. Il est pas compliqu√© √† prendre en main, au d√©but on se suffit du mode "Jouer" puis ensuite viens le mode "Jouer+" ou il n'y √† pas de points de contr√¥le, donc √ßa va jouer sur vos r√©flexes. Niveau Musique, j'ai pas grand chose √† dire, √† part que des fois on arrive pas √† descerner QUEL type de note va sortir pour les pr√©voir (Escentiellement ce qui va se passer la plupart du temps, parce qu'un mur = CLAP, un point = sort de tambour et murrets = ticks)
Visuellement il est beau, tr√®s limit√© mais beau, les effets psychedeliques sont sublimes. Si vous avez genre 30 minutes pour partir dans un TOUT autre type de jeu et vous depayser de ce que l'on peut retrouver habituellement sur Steam, il est fait pour vous.
Si vous aimez la sensation de vitesse, il est fait pour vous.
Si vous aimez les jeux de rythme, il est bif bof, y'a mieux. Mais dans son genre c'est l'unique ce qui en fait une perle.

Je conseille vivement. Franchement un jeu surprenant et vraiment fun.

(Pour ce qui est de la dur√©e de vie, c'est √† vous de voir, soit vous faites que le mode "Jouer" et vous avez moins d'une dizaine de niveaux d'une dur√©e de 10/30 minutes. (Je dis 30 mais on voit pas DU TOUT le temps passer). Si vous faite le mode + avec, vous an avez pour votre argent pour r√©aliser des S et pas un A ou un B (rank)))

author: {'steamid': '76561198320257758', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 319, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 94, 'last_played': 1666201421}
review:
First off, if you're a fan of hard electronic music, like NOISIA, Knife Party, The Glitch Mob, NERO, The Prodigy, Feed Me/Spor, Kill the Noise, Phace, and the like, then buy this game, immidiately. Incredible rythms here.

Extremely well optimized game. It was kinda refreshing to see something this visually pleasing and viscreally satisfying running at 60fps on an Intel HD550. It really is quite gorgeous and trippy!

The gameplay itself, as mentioned above, [u]feels[/u] incredibly weighty and there is a very prominent sense of mass to every thing you do in this game.

Now would also be a good time to mention that this game is hard. Very. Hard. Not punishing, mind you, but hard. It does "difficult" right, where it's always your fault if you die; resets are quick, and checkpoints, frequent.

It also has that tetris effect where you think about this game even when you're not playing it.

I can see myself playing this over and over again for a while now, 20 bucks well spent.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009463887', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 845, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 718, 'last_played': 1554890751}
review:
I downloaded this game and was hooked right away, ive been playing for 3 hours straight now and just beat lvl 4. im only halfway through the game but ill list some pros and cons so far:

Pros:
visually this game is like being on drugs or something. VERY psycadellic & trippy, looks AMAZING
music is good, lots of different sounds, and the bass truly does thump as you play
easy introduction and the difficulty scales well over time 
the freedom to choose how i want to beat certain parts of levels is very cool
replayability 9/10.. i find myself wanting to keep playing without too much frustration or getting tilted
leaderboards are nice, being able to see where you rank against your friends and the world
violent game, lots of crashing against walls and dark-heavy music, its not a feel-good experience (which is awesome)
runs smooth, with no glitches that ive seen, lightweight and small download

Cons:
sometimes the game starts moving so fast that you cannot simply play it, you have to die over and over to memorize sequences in order to get further. this is very frustrating 
the music doesnt change hardly at all, its the same stomping techno/breakbeat. and the sounds that the beetle makes never change
the price is too high at $20
for being a music-driven game the audio options are non-existant 

Overall I rate this game 8/10. This is some beautiful next level stuff visually and sometimes the beat hits really hard i find myself grooving to the music in my chair. I recommend Thumper to anyone that can spare the $20 to get it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037464856', 'num_games_owned': 203, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1589, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 749, 'last_played': 1597632994}
review:
"HOOOOOOOLY FUUUUUUUUUUCK" -Me when starting level 5

Buy this game, it's batshit insane and you will love every minute of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964142424', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1485057375}
review:
I bought Thumper for the VR version and was sorely disappointed. The controls were unintuitive and unresponsive. The 10 minutes I spent playing it were pure frustration. Imagine if ever fourth press of your keyboard or gamepad didn't work and you'll get an idea for how this controls in VR.

The VR controls don't even take into consideration the full range of motion you could get with HTC Vive controllers which is what I was expecting. The game should honestly not let you use the Vive Controllers and force you to play with a gamepad.

Unfortunately these 10 incredibly frustrating minutes have poisoned my impression but since I personally know some people who have played this game using their  gamepad and can't stop saying how good it is I hope to come back and give it another chance.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050356628', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 982, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 474, 'last_played': 1705718924}
review:
Stoked I stumbled upon this game. I used to love Rez on dreamcast. This has a very similar vibe. 

Only complaint is from my hands hurting after playing with my xbox controller from mashing the A button. Switched to keyboard and spacebar + arrow keys seems to be pretty good. Think it would be awesome with an arcade button and joystick

Update: just got a Qanba Carbon arcade joystick and it kicks ass with this game :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198000050134', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 378, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 282, 'last_played': 1565923078}

author: {'steamid': '76561198045905819', 'num_games_owned': 265, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 634, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 448, 'last_played': 1592029293}
review: Thumper is an incredible title that has extremely responsive controls, both beautiful and horrifying visuals, and immense replayability with 9 levels, each with 15+ stages. Getting up there in one of the most difficult rhythm games i've ever played, it also provides plenty of challenge for completionists. The best part about this game is landing those perfect hits, the way the visuals warp and the controller vibrates really feels like you're putting all your power into the pressing of a button. This alone makes thumper an incredibly enjoyable experience, but with more level mechanics being added as you play, it never gives you a dull experience. play thumper and youll find yourself getting dragged back into it again and again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028511007', 'num_games_owned': 159, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 725, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 325, 'last_played': 1559933195}
review: Intense and beautiful.

author: {'steamid': '76561198221952968', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 365, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 178, 'last_played': 1557788848}
review: I wasn't expecting too much going into this game especially for ¬£15, but I was so surprised by how addicting it is! The gameplay is so smooth and the tracks just seem to pull you and make you want more! From trailers I watched I thought it would begin to get repetitive but I found myself wanting to go back and replay levels over and over. Playing it at 144Hz makes for very smooth gameplay, I am yet to try 60 but I'm sure it wouldn't be a problem even though this can be a very fast paced game. I would definitely reccomend this to anyone looking for something simple to play with a bit of a challenge to it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060158502', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 536, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 504, 'last_played': 1485127103}
review:
Thumper is an extremely unique game and really quite enjoyable! You play as a beetle riding through what I can best describe as an interdimensional hellscape. I've thoroughly enjoyed the game so far (though it pisses me off sometimes because of the challenge), and I have one big complaint: It doesn't feel like I'm being rewarded when I make air-to-ground combos. Once I start racking them up, the game stops for half a second to show off how strong my combos are and really throws off my rhythm, and it makes me not want to do those combos. I understand the game going crazy when I take damage, but interrupting the rhythm of a RHYTHM game when I'm doing well? Come on, devs. I give Thumper a 4/5.

TL;DR Game is very fun but combos feel more punishing than rewarding.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005492118', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 699, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 362, 'last_played': 1600296510}
review: A few hours in and my experience of Thumper turned from pure delight to pure horror, as I desperately attempt to avoid mind-bending obstacles at light speed, while being bludgeoned with frantic industrial music. And I loved it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198001552113', 'num_games_owned': 1142, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 375, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 359, 'last_played': 1680894005}
review:
A very good rhythm game with a small change on the usual formula. Instead of having to do actions to a melody, you do actions to the beat of the percussion. As the game is fast paced, it leads to a tense experience as you perform split second reactions to obstacles in the way. 
There's no big story, just a fun rhythm game about a little space beatle.

review: Rhythm games are not usually my thing, but once I saw this game in action I HAD to try it. And sure enough, it's excellent. Definitely recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198154890380', 'num_games_owned': 86, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 527, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 234, 'last_played': 1708109211}

author: {'steamid': '76561197973137082', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 75, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 62, 'last_played': 1532488628}
review: I get motion sick in some VR experiences.  This game looks like it would cause motion sickness but it doesn't for me at all.  This game is a lot of fun and progresses in difficulty very smoothly.  One cool thing about this game is that I can play it seated with an xbox controller while my wife is in the same room on her computer.  i don't have to clear her out for VR time.  Great beats, fun concept, awesome visuals.  I definitely recommend this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023262472', 'num_games_owned': 540, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 546, 'last_played': 1702887587}
review: Thumper is a gaming experience unlike anything else I've ever played. It's brutal, difficult, and unforgiving, but I love it. Unlike a lot of other brutally difficult games, I never felt like my deaths were cheap. Everytime I died I knew exactly what I did wrong. If you're looking for a difficult but fair game that completely turns the rhythm game genre on it's head, I cannot reccomend Thumper enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198193281053', 'num_games_owned': 99, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 731, 'last_played': 1653926802}
review:
This is a fantastic rhythm game that is absolutely worth checking out.

The pacing is perfect for new players (minus a single nitpick), the difficulty is astronomical in the later levels, but still forgiving in the sense that respawns are fast and the game is consistent (minus a single nitpick), and the music is pretty good.
Global leaderboards are a neat addition that give everyone a goal to reach for.
Fun game overall.

The single nitpick: the snakes in the later levels are inconsistent and too fast to react to, so they wind up being a kill point for every first run through a checkpoint with them. The solution to this would to be to make the snakes come in from the opposite direction that one must dodge to clear them, to clear up the constant visual confusion they come with otherwise. If that is all that ever changes in this game in any future update, I will be a happy man.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048242070', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 228, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 178, 'last_played': 1498179657}

author: {'steamid': '76561198035622433', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1005, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 487, 'last_played': 1678834062}
review: Highly recommended. The rhythm of the game is different than a lot of other rhythm games in that you add to the rhythm instead of just following it. Very good game. My father even played it and enjoyed it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980314410', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 805, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 509, 'last_played': 1485897459}
review:
Thumper is a rythm game. Right now at level 6 there are only few inputs you have to get right. Up, down, left, right, with or without pressing button A.

I find this game very hard, because often I just don't recognize any rythm, that I could get in sync with. There are just so many Beats, Breakbeats, Off-Beats that I sometimes just play as well with the sound off. On the other hand it is still exciting to play. 

It can be frustrating at times, when you could swear you pressed the right Buttons at the right time and you die and you look at your hands and see your fingers still pressing the right buttons. But that might as well be due to input-delay (wireless-controller) or output-delay (sound).

I'd like to have some easy-mode, where you have more armor or larger time-windows for input. 
And I wished a hundred times to see a record of my play together with the input to see what went wrong. 

Nonetheless. The game is very challenging and visually impressive. I like it for occassional playing when I don't have much time. I cannot play Thumper for more than one hour without pause, because it requires so intense concentration.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027543212', 'num_games_owned': 274, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1613720810}
review:
Thumper is a particularly interesting game, in that it uses only a stick and a button, but still manages to be one of the hardest games I've ever played.
Think of it as Audiosurf, but you're on PCP and Cocaine and you're fighting monsters by punching lights on the floor. Sounds cool, doesn't it?
The first few levels start off relatively easy, giving you warnings and prompts, and from then on game slowly eases you into a blender called rage and hatred. And by 'ease', I mean it throws you in at the speed of sound.
This is the most rage/depression-inducing, anus-clenching, flashy-neon game I've ever played (besides perhaps Hotline Miami, which I also recommend checking out), and I love it. I think.
Try not to break your controller.
[b]6/10[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198078471874', 'num_games_owned': 187, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 724, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 293, 'last_played': 1659489754}
review:
3 words.
Trippy and intense.

Positives:

I love it, Thumper is so much fun! The visuals are fucking amazing and its very fast paced. Once you get past the first few levels the difficulty spikes and thats when it gets really intense. Going for that S rank is what makes you strive to improve. Each level includes a boss with their own unique challenges. Theres also plenty of combos to do along with the pretty visuals to keep you entertained. As well as the amazing yet ominous soundtrack to keep you immersed.

Negative:
- Game starts off slow, doesnt get intense till lvl 5

- At $20 I would say its a bit overpriced, on the last deal it was a decent price

- Not a rhythm game as it states, just a few nice sounds when you press the corresponding key and it doesnt actually produce a continuous beat/song

-  Probably just on my end, but its prone to occasional crashes

- Prone to repetivity, but the intensity/difficulty redeems it a bit

7.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198024995482', 'num_games_owned': 632, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 320, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 143, 'last_played': 1599208082}
review:
Calming strings play softly as you glide down the track, tripply fractal visuals lull you into a zen sense of wonder and you loose yourself in the moment... until the kettle drumming starts up once again and pulls you back into focus as a new onslaught of turns, barriers and barricades comes hurling at you, with only the rhythm to save you.
Let me get the bias out of the way, I LOVE rhythm games. Nothing blisses me out more than getting to that place where the music is king and all you're doing is reacting to is. 
Thumper is a champion of this, like Rez, the trippy visuals only enhance what is ostensibly a largely audible experience. 
I tried playing this with headphones for a while, but cranked up speakers, ones with really good bass, is where it's at for this. You'll find yourself picking up audio clues all over the place to help you navigate the roller coaster.
A lot of effort was put into making the experience here viseral, this isn't a simple navigation of multi track mixing like in Aplitude or Frequency. This is a roller coaster ride of audio violence that lets you feel your mistakes. If you fail, you fail hard, with only one shield shell to make protect you. The checkpoint system is incredibly forgiving though, and with levels that go on upwards of 10 minutes or more, they're really nessesary. You can back out, and return to the part of the level you left on at any point. 
Right now, I can't find anything to complain about. Like all rhythm games, sync is important, so if you're playing on an HDTV, you might find a bit of lag between the video and the audio. For a game that requires such precision, it kinda does suprise me that there doesn't seem to be an input lag adjuster present in the game.
Anyway, yes, I highly recommend this game if rythm games are your jam.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998465825', 'num_games_owned': 548, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 1957, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1398, 'last_played': 1608860780}

author: {'steamid': '76561197967692485', 'num_games_owned': 765, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 1408, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 473, 'last_played': 1501613711}
review:
No words, no backstory, no bullshit. You're thrown onto a space rail at blistering speed and promptly begin to Thump for your life as the game introduces the basics with short, deeply immersive tutorial segments. Thump. Bank to survive corners. Slide through obstacles, hover above deadly traps, and more as you complete the first few levels.

Words cannot do justice to the intensity of Thumper's gameplay. The visual/audio design is fabulous and will immediately make you feel its trademark "rhythm violence". The adrenaline really builds up as the segments get longer, faster and more twisty. And oh my god, the MUSIC. It just fits perfectly within this brutally psychedelic universe.

Hardcore. With its ever-increasing speed and rhytmic complexity, Thumper gets hardcore real quick, or surely feels that way. But never the wrong kind, the punishng, the restart-your-entire-level hardcore (unless you choose the Play+ mode). As challenging as they become, the segments are never unreasonably long and you get a checkpoint at the end of each one, with as many retries as you need. Thumper is perfectly possible to enjoy on a casual level, although the Leaderboards will make you cry a little inside. Yet the subtle scoring mechanisms may well make you feel like the levels you've already beaten have a bit more potential and depth than you thought... and nudge you into inflicting some of that rhytmic violence upon yourself again.

Thump, get thumped. Play Thumper.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046926989', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 35, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 35, 'last_played': 1483852637}
review: I do not think this game is worth near $20. It feels more like a $5 game. I have no idea how this game is getting so many postitive reviews and high praise. It literally is a desktop game, just thrown in VR, with no VR elemets to it. You NEVER move your head around or look anywhere. There is no VR aspect to this game, it is solely a cheap desktop game thrown into VR for absolutely no reason.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044234486', 'num_games_owned': 534, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 233, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 222, 'last_played': 1499378659}
review:
Thumper. Oh. My. Goodness Thumper.

I remember seeing the trailer for Thumper a little while back and I was interested right off the bat. The concept looked really cool and I wanted to play it at some point. Alas I never jumped on buying it until I managed to get a new computer which could handle the dang game but once I did, Thumper was one of the first games I played on it and holy heck is it good.

Now a word of warning. If you happen to suffer from A. Siezures caused by lots of flashing lights. B. A bad sense of rhythm and/or C. Bad reflexes then Thumper really isn't the game for you. Otherwise there is basically no reason to NOT buy Thumper. 

It's an incredible rhythm/action game and despite the somewhat trial and error gameplay at times it still manages to be INCREDIBLY satisfying when you manage to pass a section that gave you a particularly hard time (Looking at you most of level 4). If you're ready to brace yourself for the MASSIVE difficulty increase that happens at level 4 onwards then you'll be in for a real treat with Thumper. Just, make sure to play with a gamepad and headphones (like, seriously you'll be doing yourself a major diservice playing without either a gamepad or headphones)

author: {'steamid': '76561198000689626', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 499, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 38, 'last_played': 1508076329}
review:
The following is an excript from H.P. Lovecraft's The Music Of Erich Zann. It's also an accurate review of Thumper, especially in VR.

"I heard a sound myself; though it was not a horrible sound, but rather an exquisitely low and infinitely distant musical note, suggesting a player in one of the neighbouring houses, or in some abode beyond the lofty wall over which I had never been able to look. Upon Zann the effect was terrible, for dropping his pencil suddenly he rose, seized his viol, and commenced to rend the night with the wildest playing I had ever heard from his bow save when listening at the barred door.

It would be useless to describe the playing of Erich Zann on that dreadful night. It was more horrible than anything I had ever overheard, because I could now see the expression of his face, and could realise that this time the motive was stark fear. He was trying to make a noise; to ward something off or drown something out‚Äîwhat, I could not imagine, awesome though I felt it must be. The playing grew fantastic, delirious, and hysterical, yet kept to the last the qualities of supreme genius which I knew this strange old man possessed. I recognised the air‚Äîit was a wild Hungarian dance popular in the theatres, and I reflected for a moment that this was the first time I had ever heard Zann play the work of another composer. . . .

Then I remembered my old wish to gaze from this window, the only window in the Rue d‚ÄôAuseil from which one might see the slope beyond the wall, and the city outspread beneath. It was very dark, but the city‚Äôs lights always burned, and I expected to see them there amidst the rain and wind. Yet when I looked from that highest of all gable windows, looked while the candles sputtered and the insane viol howled with the night-wind, I saw no city spread below, and no friendly lights gleaming from remembered streets, but only the blackness of space illimitable; unimagined space alive with motion and music, and having no semblance to anything on earth. And as I stood there looking in terror, the wind blew out both the candles in that ancient peaked garret, leaving me in savage and impenetrable darkness with chaos and pandemonium before me, and the daemon madness of that night-baying viol behind me."

author: {'steamid': '76561198011551980', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 107, 'last_played': 1606527231}

author: {'steamid': '76561198052315982', 'num_games_owned': 230, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 4267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2183, 'last_played': 1688675159}
review:
I've played quite a few different rhythm games before, but this is something exceptional. This is an audiovisual experience. The aesthetics are incredible with the bizarre environment and ambient sound design. The gameplay is simple to get a hold of but provides a nerve wracking challenge when accompanied by the dreadful ambience. Playing this game makes me stressed and I love it.

Easily one of the best rhythm games I've ever played.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002386226', 'num_games_owned': 245, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1084, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 930, 'last_played': 1601493063}
review:
I've played over 10 hours of Thumper in the last few days, S-ranked all the levels and I'm done for now. But I'm certain I'll come back to this game in the future, because it's so goddamn amazing.

I am deeply impressed by Thumper. It was one of the most intense and thrilling gaming experiences I've ever had, for that I'm sure. If you're into challenging but fair games and also a bit in music, that game is for you. And this game rewards you for the challenges in a way that only Dark Souls had before.

Despite being heavily minimalistic in its controls (WASD + Enter/Space), this game has a whole lot to offer. Stunning visuals and a creative art style, an addicting audio atmosphere and so much to learn. Thumper nailed the art of having a well-shaped learning curve by being beginner-friendly at first and making it more and more difficult over time. I was never frustrated by this game.

I have also played the first levels with the HTC Vive. It worked seamlessly and looked fantastic.

If you're looking for a truly unique experience, go and get it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197982785450', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 666, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 443, 'last_played': 1710433607}
review:
I can't recommend this game enough.  It's the nightmarish sci-fi rhythm game I never knew I needed in my life.

Pros:
[list]
    [*]Plays like the lovechild of Guitar Hero, Super Hexagon, and Race the Sun
[*]Asthetic is simple, unique, and compelling -- it's like all of those games got sucked into a black hole while listening to heavy metal and having a bad trip
[*]Gameplay and presentation are incredibly polished
[*]Evokes a sense of rhythm amidst chaos, and requires a laser-sharp focus
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
    [*]I wish it had a no-fail mode like Guitar Hero.  It can be frustrating once you get to the harder levels.  But there's joy to be found in this challenge, too.
[*]The name sounds kind of silly.  Wish they'd called it something else.

I'd never heard of this game before seeing it on a couple of best-of-year lists, so it came as a total surprise.  Now it's one of my personal favorites.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002596603', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 196, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 162, 'last_played': 1565744591}

author: {'steamid': '76561198048876713', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 267, 'last_played': 1483403765}
review:
Thumper is a decent to poor rythm game, but has many frustrating elements which lead to it becoming very borig. Vissually, it looks great, especially in VR.

While the game is a rythm game, I never feel like I can get into the rythm like I can with most rythm games. I need to constantly  use my eyes to figure out what is coming next, with the rythm providing only a tiny hint of timing.  Even still, the game often repeats the same subsequence in the game several times, so you can learn it that way. But I never felt really into the music, and the music generally isn't that pleasent, I can hardly call it music at all.

But certain actions are much more difficult then they should be, specifically pounding. A few bosses require the pound move to complete, but I could only get the pound move to work around a third of the time. When a boss required several pounds to be performed in a row, I ended up repeating that section several times (for at least 10 minutes) before being able to progress. At that point, the boss became boring. He could not hurt me because his attacks were trivially easy to dodge, and I could not hurt him because I could not pound consistently.

Visually, the game is quite breathtaking, but you can't really stop to enjoy it. If your looking for a game that gets you into the zone in VR, this might be what your looking for, but the near random nature of the music keeps you from really honing in on the rythm.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987060149', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 35, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 35, 'last_played': 1483393323}
review: Trippy graphics but play seems repetitive and frustrating. Not my cup of tea.

author: {'steamid': '76561198171441007', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 426, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 336, 'last_played': 1697573487}
review:
Review eines Oculus Rift Users.
Thumper ist zwar kein "echtes" VR Spiel, sondern ein klassisches Rhythmusspiel mit VR Modus, ich w√ºrde es aber nicht mehr in 2D spielen wollen. Der VR Modus tr√§gt ungemein zum Geschwindigkeits[strike]-Gef√ºhl[/strike] -Wahnsinn und zur r√§umlichen Wahrnehmung bei.
Man muss dem Spiel etwas Zeit geben, die ersten beiden Level sind noch Lernphasen mit moderatem Tempo, danach zieht das Spiel aber ordentlich an.
Sch√∂ner Schwierigkeitsgrad, fordernd aber nicht unfair. Wenn man stirbt, wei√ü man immer genau was man gerade verbockt hatte. Wenn man es durch hat, lockt noch ein "Spiel+" Modus, der noch mal eine Schippe drauflegt.
Es gibt auch keine Techno-H√§mmer-Musik, sondern der Soundtrack ist eher atmosph√§risch, und geht mit dem Level mit. Kommende Hindernisse werden per Audio angedeutet.

Unbedingt holen, egal ob f√ºr Desktop oder VR.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990996093', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 111, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 111, 'last_played': 1483669453}

review:
One of the most thrilling game I've played in the last year.  Played in on the Vive in VR as well, it makes the experience even more engrossing and actually makes me play a little better.

The gameplay actually has surprising depth in later levels because you can actually play with extra flair and cool move to maximize your score and regain health.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996712153', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 105, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 93, 'last_played': 1515245397}
review: What happens when you let Rez and the Cthulhu Mythos breed, and then stuff the resultant horrors full of amphetamines.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974341875', 'num_games_owned': 1385, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 589, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 576, 'last_played': 1659329242}
review:
I'm coming back to this review because I realized I should say something meaningful.

This game is extremely challenging, even on the first episodes. I've had this for a long time, yet I haven't been able to pass chapter 4. I hope I do, eventually (it's not the first time I thought I wasn't able to do something).

That being said, it does feel fair. Every challenge ahead makes a sound that alerts you it's coming. You need to follow these cues, and you need to practice to improve your reaction times and learn the layout of each section. It's more of a memory game than anything. Practice makes perfect.

Now, about Thumper being an "existential dread" game? While I can see the aesthetics and the music getting on people's nerves (from what I've seen from some playthroughs it does get creepy), I find myself so focused on the challenge that I don't mind. I do get frustrated, but I guess that's just my natural reaction to these types of games. Scared? Nah.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079138827', 'num_games_owned': 215, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1876, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1713, 'last_played': 1645219339}
review:
I bought this game on a whim, set it to installing, and went to put the kettle on for tea. Came back, game was installed, booted it up to play the first sequence and see what was what. 

I look up and three hours have gone by. My tea never happened. I can't move my thumbs. Something is funky with my eyes. I'm more revved up from adrenaline then when I last fell down the stairs. I have a bizarre rhythm stuck in my body that I can't seem to recall when I actively think about it, but my muscles tap it out on the table when I'm not paying attention. 

I've never been so capitvated in my entire life, and I don't usually enjoy rhythm OR racing games. This game is insanely polished, creative, and has the best scaling of difficulty I've ever seen. Would I have payed full price for this if I hadn't snagged it on sale? Hell yeah. I'm not the sort of person to buy the same game across multiple platforms, but I even grabbed it for my Switch the second it got ported because a) the devs are great & deserve all my money, and b) lengthy airport layovers never go by so fast as when I'm engrossed in this game. It's just that good.

Edit: I've since 100%'d the game. It took me a little over 25 hours. I still dream about this game and the weird rhythms that don't make any sense until you're in the middle of them. Usually once I perfect a game, I very rarely touch it again for at least a year or so. Not so with Thumper -- while I may have gotten all of the Steam achievements, I've far from mastered it. I can do better. I WILL do better. Time to boot it up again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064007536', 'num_games_owned': 1217, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 190, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 146, 'last_played': 1623297989}

author: {'steamid': '76561198068762834', 'num_games_owned': 250, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 72, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 72, 'last_played': 1483212858}

author: {'steamid': '76561198141985794', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1375, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1152, 'last_played': 1497794331}
review:
One of the best games I've ever played. My only complaint is that I can't play it as much as I want to; when I close my eyes after a long session I still see the colors rushing at me and when I fall asleep I dream about it and when I walk around I hear the rhythms pounding in my head timed to my steps and it is maddening. My only complaint is basicallly that this game has annexed my subconscious mind. 

The difficulty gradually increases such that early levels that seemed insane to me are now totally managable. I love that each level has musical motiffs that eventually become visually recognizable. The shifting time signatures, the visuals...the exhiliration of playing this game well is addictive beyond measure. I haven't finished yet and I want more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198277435614', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2551, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1074, 'last_played': 1547797380}
review: I've been looking for a good rhythm game forever and this is the one!! It gets hard, but it feels fair. Fun to play, wonderful graphics, tight controls, amazing soundtrack. Defeinitely good for playing again and again. Hands down my favorite game of this year.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007148018', 'num_games_owned': 1020, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 135, 'last_played': 1563661967}
review:
This game can really wear you down, but not that that's bad. You've already lost your shell which means one more miss and you're dead, you're barely hitting everything that's necessary and missing all the extra stuff, and then you finally make a fatal mistake before the end of the level and you attempt it again. Learning from your mistakes is key in this extremely different rhythym game. 

It takes everything you know and flips on it's head. The game eases you into new concepts with each level then pounds you into submission as it gets exponentially harder and faster until you finally reach the level boss which is, in it's own way, a summation of the level you just went through. The boss plays with you at first then gets serious as it realizes you're a worthy foe. Sometimes you find yourself smashing through the levels at a breakneck pace and the game rewards you with a break. A chance to breathe a sigh of relief until you're breaking obstacles and flying over spikes again.

This game is a lot of fun for me, it's crazy, cacophonous, dissonant, yet ties it all together in a great package called Thumper. A very fitting name for the percussive soundtrack to which your silver beetle races to down the single dimension that is all you know for 10 long, grueling, painful levels.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012902673', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 380, 'playtime_forever': 473, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 472, 'last_played': 1592999975}
review:
Thumper is a very different beast of rhythm game from the norm, and it is a singular experience. The controls feel great, and the music, art direction, and level design all make for a more unnerving experience than most rhythm games. It makes so much sense that Brian Gibson of Lightning Bolt fame is half of the game's core development team.

If I had one gripe, it's that with all the effects the game uses, it can sometimes be hard to make out what's up ahead. I had to turn down my monitor's brightness just to make out the lane in one of the last sections of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990189544', 'num_games_owned': 1623, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 104, 'last_played': 1526080935}
review:
A friend of mine recommended this game to me, because of a shared interest in rhythm games.  I was hesitant at first, because it just appeared to be a prettied up clone of Audiosurf.  Man... was I wrong.

After purchase, I had only intended to play a couple levels to get the feel for the game.  An hour and a half later I'm only stopping because of the frustration I got playing one of the last stages in level 3.  This is why I love it.  Much like Guitar Hero did back in it's earlier release, this game leaves you with a feeling of frustration, determination, and the sweet sweet relief you feel after you finally nailed that part that kept blowing up your space ship.

The music is great, the visuals are great, using a keyboard on this game seems to handle well enough, though I will be trying with a controller soon enough.  This game alone has me considering investing in VR technology.  

Absolutely worth the full asking price, even better if you catch it on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062186934', 'num_games_owned': 1457, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 148, 'last_played': 1485037932}

You won't regret this addition to the VR library.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995273133', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 393, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 333, 'last_played': 1489803304}
review:
Thumper is a really neat game that is not for Rhythm Action purists.

'Presentation' is usually a secondary goal for Rhythm Action games.  It's generally considered to be of critical importance that the track is readable and consistent.  Thumper says that ideaology is bunk and and puts presentation front and center.  The two major consequences of this are that it 'feels' really good to play when you are in the zone and doing well.  There is a lot of visual reinforcement for nearly every action and it really is a pretty unique experience in the RA genre.  The other consequence of this is that any kind of mistake generates a lot of implicit punishment.  That visual reinforcement becomes visual noise that you have to see through to try and recover.  The audio stutters and breaks when you make a mistake, making it that much more difficult to find your flow again.  Whether or not you doing well, Thumper is a noisy game.

This kind of presentation extends to effects where you do things right as well -- 'Thumping' on a gem from the air (An action that is not only good, but generates a bonus for the player) causes the track to stutter for an audio effect and generates a big graphic that ripples along the entire track, distorting it all along the way.  Coming from a more traditional Bemani line up of games, these kinds of effects feel extremely disruptive and I honestly shy away from doing them lest I generate more noise in an already noisy environment.

The contrast of the world doesn't help.  Often times you'll find gems on the track colored bright blue, along with the rails, the background and some of the 'tunnel' objects.  It makes parsing the screen pretty difficult at time.  The contrast of the track 'notes' ranges from acceptable to very questionable throughout the game.

Beyond that, there are a handful of track layouts that are borderline not fair.  You don't get a reasonable amount of time to actually react to some elements, specifically some turns that come out immediately after another turn.  These are pretty rare, but encouraging memorziation as part of learning a track is generally Not Cool‚Ñ¢.

I'm ragging a lot on this game and pointing out stuff that irked me some, but I think it's as important to note that I really do enjoy this game and in the whole scope of things, the game is very nicely polished and delivers a truly unique experience that moves the needle in an interesting direction for the RA landscape.  I can't wait to check it out in VR!

If you are a hardcore RA purist, then be ready to make some track readability concessions in favor of graphical and audio flair, but if you just want a fun, unique Rhythm game with an emphasis on presentation, then you really can't go wrong here.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982933378', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 169, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 132, 'last_played': 1495676620}

author: {'steamid': '76561197968514859', 'num_games_owned': 245, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 590, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1704644451}
review:
VR review.
Thumper's visuals are unique and strange. Paired with the rhythmic music it is very hypnotic and trippy. I love the feeling this game gives me. Driven by the rhythm I can't help myself, but to replay checkpoints until I get it right. If you're a musician, you'll know the feeling when you play a hard part perfectly. :) It is so satisfying and you can't get enough.

VR is perfect as it can be on Gen1 devices. The colors are spot on and you won't see any halos or blurriness.

Thumper is calming and soothing, the right thing when I have to chill the fuck out. ;)

Like it much much more than Redout which I played just for 20 minutes before I got bored.

author: {'steamid': '76561198308769965', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 44, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1542170807}
review: After only a few sessions, Thumper is clearly the type of game that draws you in very quickly and entrances you with rhythmic compulsion and the need to continue playing. It was hard to set it down. Everyone should try this, it reminds me of playing Wipeout XL back in the day on a giant projector. Only more immersive. And hellishly dark.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030560713', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1484603867}
review:
I bought this game expecting awesome visuals, and boy does it deliver. I've played it exclusively in VR, and it's an amazing experience from that angle. 

However, where it really suffers is the soundtrack. For a rhythm game, the soundtrack is *essential* and unfortunately, this game's music really disappoints. It is, for the most part, monotonous droning and repetitive, overcompressed cinematic-style drumming, interspersed with synth drumkit samples as in-game sound effects. "Overcompressed" is really the important takeaway. There's hardly any dynamic contrast anywhere, and the mixing is middling at best, with hardly any lows and a heavy top end that only distracts from the in-game sound effects. I played the game with my sony MDR-v6's and then listened through the OST again on a pair of DT 770's to see if it improved outside of the game, and it was actually worse, as the best low-end actually came from one of the in-game effects.
While I think the style of the music is promising outside of this context (with a bit of mixing to get the drums more into the foreground), it doesn't fit the fast-paced rhythm game and only serves to detract from the experience.  

Spiel out of the way, this is still an excellent game, especially in VR, as the visuals are absolutely amazing, and the rhythm components are quite well executed despite the mediocre backing music.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057351773', 'num_games_owned': 764, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1488082607}

author: {'steamid': '76561197988462221', 'num_games_owned': 727, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1578790462}
review:
Thumper is the best music game I've ever played, and one of the best designed games I've ever played full stop. At first I thought it was a lot like the classic BIT.TRIP Runner series but moving forwards in 3D instead of sideways in 2D. However, after completing the first couple of levels Thumper seriously comes into its own, over and above other music/rhythm games. As the pace and complexity picks up, so too does the tension - and that feeling of tension is increased by the creepy, drug-trip-gone-wrong visuals and 'thumping' (see what I did there) industrial soundtrack. 

As the game got tougher (I'm on Level 4 of 8 and it's already hurting my thumbs) I found myself barely even consciously registering what I was doing and reacting subconsciously to the audio and visual cues - this is usually what's referred to as a state of 'flow' and I've never had a game induce this feeling quite as much (I would say Super Hexagon comes close).

Above all else, the game feels finely-tuned and very well thought out, every level slowly ramping up in difficulty and adding new concepts in an almost seamless way.

If you're a fan of tough rhythm-based games such as Super Hexagon and BIT.TRIP Runner, this is a no-brainer. And if you have a VR headset, play with that too, I found it massively enhanced the experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989261102', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 657, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1, 'last_played': 1605748276}

When they said rhythm violence i wasn¬¥t expecting violence towards my thumb :S

This game is awesome, from the music to the aesthetics, to the gameplay! 

The only "complain" I have for now is the lack of a difficulty settings because in the later levels, you really need good reflexes! For an older person for example it can be a little hard to do the later levels. However, the music, the subtle sound queues and the gamepad vibrations really help a lot.

Definitely a must buy!

author: {'steamid': '76561197972025376', 'num_games_owned': 1072, 'num_reviews': 265, 'playtime_forever': 250, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1615093306}
review:
New Index Review: I bought this game back when it got VR support in 2016, and I got to level 2 and gave up. I didn't really understand the controls. It was on sale recently, and I bought it again and gave it another try and liked it A LOT more because I finally understood the controls. Contrary to what I thought before, you don't have to press a button or direction precisely at the right time. You can usually simply hold them down in anticipation of upcoming objects/turns. I think I didn't realize that before and was getting frustrated. This time, I got to level 5 on my first try and had a good time.

Old Vive Review: I'm not really into rhythm games, so it's no surprise that I don't like this. It's ok but not worth the 15.99 sale price to me. There simply isn't much to it, and the visuals are repetitive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198293551951', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 706, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 76, 'last_played': 1487026036}
review:
I actually have no idea where to start with this review. 
uhh... 

Thumper is a game like no other, honestly I haven't seen anything like it.
The way the Developer described it is the only real way to summarise/categorise this game; Rhythm Violence.
It's Utterly Violent, without there being any real form of violence.  It's anxious, it almost forms this fear within you that you aren't going to be quick enough to react to it's lightening quick obstacles.  However after a few levels you will start to get the hang of the Rhythm, you really listen out for the audio cues that alert you to which action you need to perform next. 

Aside from the overall gameplay and sound, the game also has really nice visuals. They're crazy, unrealistic, neon, glossy and Psychedelic.  This game really sucks you in, its hyper immersive in that fashion, You intentively listen to every audio cue, you wait almost painstakingly for the next obstacle to appear. 

All in all, Thumper is a Violent Rhythm based game with an amazing soundtrack and a wonderously horrific setting that will have you hooked until completion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119408009', 'num_games_owned': 528, 'num_reviews': 143, 'playtime_forever': 488, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1607965500}
review: absolutely brilliant! i bought this a couple of days ago and it shows through my lack of skills, but nevertheless it's very enjoyable and addicting. it's pretty difficult and sometimes you don't even know why you failed the level which is a bit annoying, but overall thumper is a brilliant game and i would most definitely recommend it

author: {'steamid': '76561198064553688', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1020, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 850, 'last_played': 1550203575}
review:
My entrance into the realm of rhythm games. Boy what an entrance it was. Thumper combines stunning visuals with a very simple set of controls that the gameplay layers quite cleanly, all set to an agressive soundtrack that drives it forward at blistering speed. The best trait I have to say this game has is its fairness in the difficulty of each level. There were little to no moments where I felt the game was the reason I messed up. Either your timing is on point or it isn't, especially when all you use is the A key and directional stick. I used a controller and recommend everyone else do the same if they can. Not much I can say about this game that goes against it, as anything I could come up with would be rather nitpicky in my opinion.

All in all an outstanding game and a must have for rhythm based game lovers or those looking for a challenge.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970369196', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 996, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 600, 'last_played': 1674502747}
review:
Addictive rythm game, with brain melting video and audio.

The VR version is easier in some ways, more difficult in others. You can see farther and look up to see how the course looks ahead, so it is easier to get the "S" achievement. On the other hand, at least on my controllers it was almost impossible to get it to register "down" clicks, so the ground slam was impossible, a move that is required for later levels.

author: {'steamid': '76561198124320996', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 187, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 161, 'last_played': 1482933719}
review:
Thumper is fine. There's absolutely no variety to it, it's extremely overpriced, and if you're looking for a rhythm game, you might get sick of Thumper really quickly. Why? Because it's not a rhythm game as far as I'm concerned. There's absolutely no structure to the "music" you're playing, so the early levels revolve around you listening to audio queues that come a bar before the note they correspond with. It's a game of call and response, kind of like Simon, but on rails. After a few levels, the audio cues become completely and utterly impossible to decipher. Then Thumper becomes a game purely about memorizing the most boring and repetitive levels I've ever seen in a rhythm game. The boss fights are all identical. The levels are all identical, with identical music. The visuals are impressive until you realize that there's no variety to those either. Every level looks exactly the same. This game looks, feels, and plays like a procedurally-generated game, but then you get to the end and there's no more.

Maybe if the game had gone with a more readable art style (as opposed to the twisty-turny tracks that are constantly preventing you from seeing what's ahead), maybe it wouldn't be so frustrating. When you fail, it's not because you didn't stick to the rhythm or you made a mistake - 90% of the time, it's because the game decided to make you take a sharp right immediately followed by a note you couldn't see and an audio cue that you can't fucking hear. 

The game's not buggy or broken, it's just an interesting experiment that makes too many missteps for me to enjoy it. I'm a lover of rhythm games, I'm a fan of quick-fire high-difficulty challenges, and Thumper seems to provide both at first glimpse, but it soon becomes a struggle against trial-and-error level memorization and a control scheme that works against the game's fast-paced nature. The music is good, but it's not good enough to be reused on every single level with no variation apart from the nonsensical rhythms you're beating your ship against. Wait for a sale if you're still interested, the game's worth money, it's just not worth the asking price and the game has a disappointing amount of variety. No alarms, no surprised. Just memorizing headache-inducing levels to a looped beat you'll hear dozens of times per level.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970685913', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 1218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 467, 'last_played': 1548567556}
review:
Thumper makes me feel like I need a cigarette break after I finish a single level, and I've never even smoked before.

Edit: I really feell like I should do this game justice and expand on that pithy one-liner review. You might be looking at screenshots of this game and thinking 'it's just Audiosurf and I played Audiosurf so why would I buy another Audiosurf'. But Thumper is not Audiosurf. For sure, it's on a track, it's got crazy psychedelic visuals, and it's rhythm-based, and that's Audiosurf. But Thumper is suffocating. It's panic-inducing. It's a f'ing metaphor for this crazy ride we call life, a constant uphill battle of curveballs flung at you right, left and centre where you're given no freedom to dwell on what the best action might be, just let your lizard brain take over and act on the instincts that the flashing lights and clanging sounds tell it to do. Thumper is a transcendental experience. Play Thumper. Live Thumper.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054087847', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 504, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1675484595}
review:
1 word: **INTENSE**

remember that scene in the first Tron with the light cycles, when they switched to a first-person view and they were just barely missing the walls and the timing had to be perfect otherwise they'd die? that is the level of intensity this game invokes, only way more visually stunning (as in holy crap seizure inducing) and intense (the soundtrack is pretty awesome). 

...after playing this game for an hour, i can play drums like brian chippendale...ok not really. i'm just really glad i'm not drinking coffee right now.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981124799', 'num_games_owned': 799, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 160, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 100, 'last_played': 1536934665}
review:
[strike]This is not a "thumbs down" so much as a "slightly more negative than neutral" review. I'm by no means saying this game is not worth your time, but the price is a bit much for what you get if you do not have a VR headset (which I suppose is the target audience). This game is fun when it works, frustrating when it doesn't. It's hard to explain the difference but I'll try to summarize it because there really isn't much detail to get into.[/strike] I've completely changed my mind, because of the few mechanics added since I last played. I was avoiding adding time due to how Steam refunds work but now there's enough for me to jusitfy the $16 I spent. I would still recommend waiting for a sale however if it's above this price.

Sometimes the game gives you great visual/audio cues as to what you need to do, and sometimes it basically just throws additional steps that are not telegraphed at all and you need to rely purely on reflexes. I have no clue if that's me missing a cue, if it's intentional, or something else, but it's frustrating when it does happen because it doesn't feel like I'm the one who messed up, although I very well could have. Tunnels limit how far you can see ahead, and since walls don't have a significant visual cue you'll end up getting hit a lot in a way that feels more cheap than fair. 

The game looks great but you can't enjoy the visuals without messing up, so that's just annoying, and I can't imagine playing this in VR without dying constantly. Some level segments will instantly segway into the next one, meaning you cannot look at your score/rating without immediately missing something. This just seems like an oversight and I question why it's in the game. The 2x score indicator is also distracting but I might just be nitpicking (I think you can disable this by turning the entire HUD off but haven't tried).

My largest complaint is how hoops work, because they're so frustrating I might end up refunding the game because how agitating they are. They're so bewilderingly fickle I actually think they might be broken. In order to break hoops, you must press A and IMMEDIATELY hold up on the left stick, something that feels like it doesn't work around 20% of the time. There's also a mechanic that enables you to hit buttons by slamming down on the left stick, which ALSO only works around 20% of the time unless it's a scripted part of the track. It's almost like they didn't expect you to do this unless it was clearly indended by the obstacles. It's so much fun and I want to love this game but it ends up being more frustrating than enjoyable for me, maybe I'm just bad but man I cannot play a full level without feeling cheated at least once.


If this was baseline $15 maybe, but $20 is a bit steep for how basic this game is at its core. Far be it from telling people how to price things, I don't think I'll get my money's worth though. This game is far from bad, but I do NOT understand the overwhelming praise it seems to be getting.


EDIT: Again everything here is still true, but it's too fun for me to keep this review "thumbs down". This is more of a tenative recommendation however, so if you're not interested in what you see in the trailer I'd avoid it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025530605', 'num_games_owned': 250, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 152, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1486869245}
review: Have you ever wondered if any of your ancestors had epilepsy? Yes? Then strap on your headset and find out.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998557568', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 884, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1666686766}
review: It's hard to describe how I enjoy this game. Without a doubt, it's one of the most visceral music experiences I've had in a while, including live concerts and all the harmonix games as well. The sheer amount of visual feedback is paralleled only by One Finger Death Punch but where in that game it feels like a cheap thrill, Thumper combines a custom soundtrack with an incredible twitch based beat game to make an experience quite unlike any I've played before. There are only 9 "levels", but each level is based on different time signatures, making each one feel unique and even if played perfectly, they each can be a good 20-30 minutes a piece. Very hard, but very addicting, combining the percise input needed from Super Hexagon with the "runner" style made popular from Audiosurf. There is no custom soundtrack, which is disappointing but understandable. Aside from that, I've really enjoyed my time with Thumper and I'll definitely be playing it through again.
