author: {'steamid': '76561198066914263', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 239, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1579916204}
review:
I don't even know where to begin describing this game. You're a beetle sliding along a Hot Wheels track in some sort of surrealist hellscape and you have to hit lights and jumps and turns in time with the beat until you reach a giant, silently screaming head which you have to explode. It's... certainly unique.

VR integration works nicely. Whilst it's not first person the weird, pulsating backgrounds certainly get some benefit from the immersion and it runs nice and smooth. I did have some problems with my Vive controller always recognising left/right movements on the trackpad so it might be better played with a standard controller when things start to get hectic. All in all, I would reccommend for anyone looking for a healthy dose of existential dread and cool music. Also beetles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056321793', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 81, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1539368639}

I probably won't continue to play it.  I think the game is ok, but pretty overhyped, not as  trippy as most are making it out to be.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018348970', 'num_games_owned': 1889, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 76, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1495331701}
review:
A beautiful, terrifying, punishing, sublime rhythm game.

This game is all about atmosphere. Dark, trippy visuals are paired with a pounding, driving soundtrack as you hurtle through space as a metal beetle. The excellent sound design trains you to be able to subconsciously make split second moves you wouldn't think you could pull off on reflexes alone. I've only played it on a flat screen but I can only imagine that it's absolutely incredible in VR. Not really much to say about this one. If you like punishing rhythm games, you'll love this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076518473', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 552, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1682297625}
review: (Also HTC Vive owner)  I was very skeptical of this game from the videos.  It looked really boring and simple with little to no gameplay.  I was way wrong.  I was addicted immediately.  I literally could not stop playing.  It is very satisfying and challenging.  It keeps a good pace.  Sometimes they cut you a break with the difficulty and then ramp it right back up again.  I will say it is significantly easier playing in VR.  Or maybe I just got used to it.  It runs and looks great in VR.  The best looking VR title to date.  Don't listen to any nitpicking about the flat bosses.  The scale is massive and the style works really well in VR.  If that will deter you then you will be missing out.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970833892', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 78, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1482691163}
review: This is a review for the game played on an HTC Vive only.  I purchased specifically to play in VR as soon as support was added by the developers.  Something is very strange with the stereo rendering in VR.  The near track and bug look 3D, but the track in the distance becomes 2D, and every boss battle looks like you are staring at a 2D cinema screen up close, with the boss showing as a projected movie.  And when your bug explodes, debris close to you again looks 2D.  This sadly detracts from the game in VR, and at one point I was trying to fight a boss with one eye closed to try to fool myself into "believing" that everything was actually in 3D.  The game could have been amazing in VR, but this strange 2D-ness totally ruins it.  From the Discussion page, the devs are aware of this, but seem to suggest that there is no possible fix and that it is a failure of VR as a whole that far away objects look flat and only object at a virtual distance of 1 to 3 metres will ever look 3D.  I am really not sure this is the case, given a large number of other games made for VR (as opposed to having VR bolted on a 2D game like this) work fine, and so as it stands I cannot recommend this game for VR.  Sorry.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008591010', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 415, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 89, 'last_played': 1634015424}
review: This game requires less explanation than many others.  Look at the trailer, and see if it looks appealing to you.  If it does, I guarantee it's every bit as good as it looks and then many times better.  For what this game is- for it's core formula- it's literally perfect.  This game will have you sweating and panting.  I lost track of how many times my jaw *literally* dropped after an extremely rhythmic series of notes has been pressed.  The environment is one of the trippiest I've ever seen in any game, and that's an awesome thing.  This game is like if you mixed "BIT TRIP RUNNER" with guitar hero, and then made the resulting mixture 10 times better.  The way the setpieces blend seamlessly with your actions, and the way your actions blend seamlessly with the game's rhythm, is phenomenal.  This game is incredibly "crunchy-" your movements feel hyper-responsive and extremely "physical" as many reviewers have put it.  Seriously, buy this game pronto- I can promise you'll love it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041019715', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1463, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1081, 'last_played': 1514224412}
review:
I've never played a rhythm game like this before.

Every other rhythm game I've played has tried to create a sort of "flying" sensation. A generally lighthearted tone is created, and these games often try to replicate a really good night at a rave. This isn't a bad thing, but Thumper showed me something very different.

This game is brutal, visceral, hellish.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008119266', 'num_games_owned': 1674, 'num_reviews': 117, 'playtime_forever': 839, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 70, 'last_played': 1622333728}
review:
It's not quite "fun" if you use a certain definition of fun. It's what you get if you take a bit.Trip game and drain all of the color from it. It's... something. But I think I can recommend it.

It's one of the few games that kicks my a[b]s[/b]s over and over, and doesn't ellicit anger from me. Just grim determination. Your brain turns off, in a way. Your conscious thought dies as you give in to the flow. The flow consumes you. The thump consumes you.

So anyway yeah, check it out. I'd suggest watching someone else play first, because it's definitely not for everybody.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021623889', 'num_games_owned': 422, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 2557, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2007, 'last_played': 1675749789}
review:
As someone who's not really keen on rhythm games, I bought this game almost entirely on the aesthetic, which is cool as hell. 
Gameplay is really solid, and it feels as much like a racing game as it does a rhythm game. The gameplay feels visceral,  thumpy (you guessed it), and responsive (for the most part). I only hope I'm good enough to keep playing.
EDIT: I was good enough. I don't usually come back to games after I've finished them, but I've enjoyed playing through New Game Plus and doing S rank runs. 
It's actually quite a forgiving game, as you can just skim by on C ranks, barely keeping yourself alive, or go for perfect S/S+ runs - and these two mentalities they're as different as night and day. I would say don't worry about your skill level coming in to this game. You'll pick it all up along the way, and if you keep at it, you'll be doing things you would have thought were impossible.

Suggested playing order:
Standard Game (just try to survive!)
New Game Plus (don't worry about perfect corners that much)
Standard Game S rank run (here's where you should really focus on mastering perfect corners!)
New Game Plus S/S+ rank run

author: {'steamid': '76561198004485931', 'num_games_owned': 399, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 518, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 231, 'last_played': 1661512753}
review: Absolutely exceptional game that is gushing with style, foreboding atmosphere and unique gameplay. Thumper looks like an animated version of M.C. Escher's mathmetical collection of paintings that were drowned in a futuristic hellscape. The simplicity of the graphics is frequently overlooked as you're dazzled with a myriad a blazing light shows and particle explosions as you race down the runway with no intention of stopping. I was especially impressed with the unique take on button presses for a music and rhythm game. You'll find yourself holding down a face button while quickly pressing, and sometimes holding, a directional button in rapid succession in response to cues on the runway; The button presses feel visceral as they're translated to the onscreen action. Make no mistake, this game is also relentless with it's difficulty ramp. It starts out fairly simple with timed button presses and a single path along the runway, but it takes a bewildering nosedive the further you progress. And it's awesome. Checkpoints are generous and each level is broken up into two or more dozen sections that climax with a boss encounter. Getting an S rank on every section is a fantastic challenge, and with enough practice you embrace the cacophonous percussion, entering a Zen-like state with perfectly timed button presses. The addition of VR makes the atmosphere and sense of scale appreciably more intense, and it's my preferred way to play this game--but certainly not required--as the game is excellent without VR. Buy this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045480868', 'num_games_owned': 206, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 775, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 296, 'last_played': 1677587559}

author: {'steamid': '76561197990626550', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 663, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 325, 'last_played': 1518889161}
review:
Frustration. That's what I feel the most when I play the later levels of Thumper. Missing a turn I previously got on another attempt, reset. Miss a thump, reset. In ways, the game feels like something I would have given up on ages ago.

And yet, it keeps drawing me back.

Maybe it's the crazy soundtrack that assaults your ears, maybe it's the visuals, maybe it's the fact that this game manages to capture the feeling of satisfaction so well. Whatever it is, I'm glad Thumper has managed to work its magic.

author: {'steamid': '76561198287861256', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 21, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21, 'last_played': 1482530880}
review:
This is the type of game that wins rewards and reviews well, but its fairly milquetoast unless you're dying for a rez-like driver, but without all the creativity and weirdness of the original Rez game.  This is definitely a fun and interesting game but ultimately could really have used more models and textures and more general weirdness.  Even in its current form, its worth recommending, but it helps to ignore the hype and keep expectations reasonable. I went in with pretty high expectations from all the hype and was somewhat disappointed, but its still a good and fun game, just not a great game.

From a gameplay perspective, its fairly twitchy and it hits difficulty ramps quickly. 1-13 took me 4 or 5 attempts when 1-1 to 1-12 were very easy for me.  I also had a little trouble understanding what the controls on the screen meant. "R" isn't press right, its trigger on the right Vive controller, for example. The game also started behind me when I launched it which took a minute to figure out, so I may have missed some intro elements. Games starting behind you or displaying critical text off screen in VR is inexcuable  this late in the game. Not sure why this is still an issue with some games.  

I am anxious for someone to get this genre right in VR. I imagine if the dev group that made this had 2x the budget and 2x the time they could have really filled it out more.  As-is its kinda thin. Not bad for a Jeff Minter inspiried  space driver.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061451627', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 67, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 36, 'last_played': 1482872992}
review:
I love it when a game sucks you in.

I'm not talking about graphics, although they do help from time to time. I'm talkin about mechanics that just make you raise your head after a while asking "how could it be that this much time has passed?!" in wonderment.

While this doesnt go crazy on the VR side, it feels like a game i could play day by day on it, like my oculus is a console just like my PS4, improving my skills and just passing some time having  fun.

Really recommend it for anyone who likes to play games and get that "score rush" when everything is done right.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024161337', 'num_games_owned': 5174, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 1208, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 356, 'last_played': 1702770205}

author: {'steamid': '76561198120222580', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 119, 'playtime_forever': 517, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 235, 'last_played': 1554933037}
review: Better than it looks, and it looks pretty good. If you're interested in getting it, you'll probably love it and get hooked in a minute. It's aiming to be something, and it definitely succeeds at it. More than just a simple game, it's a psychedelic trip gone right. The music is pretty catchy, groovy with a tribal/ambient feel to it, which is a nice change from all these melodies you get in similar games, though it could use some variety. The controls aren't too simple, not too complex either, but still pretty intuitive, with a quick and pleasant learning curve through a subtle "tutorial". This game is fast, intense and challenging, yet not frustratingly hard or "trial and error", and forgiving enough (properly synced as you would expect from such game aswell). Everything is balanced in the oh so right ammount, and it's a breath of fresh air among typical video games. Graphics and the art are also pretty cool, plus, they do not require an overkill gaming PC. The gameplay, the patterns and sound effects feel really good, it's just immensely satisfying. Thumper has it all and is perfectly designed, you don't get that feeling of terrible repetitiveness many games like those leave you with pretty quickly. My biggest complaints would be the lack of variety in the music and the ammount of levels, which isn't a flaw per se, but it does leave you wanting more because it is that good. Still, not overly short either, and it's understandable that a level would take time to make. Thumper is a solid 9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198000141719', 'num_games_owned': 142, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 31, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1482469923}
review:
Great graphics but unless you have insanely fast reflexes (or maybe use something other than the Vive controllers) the game turns quickly into a massive repeat fest just to inch along progress.

Reccomend you try it but if after 15-20 minutes of starting you're like me and sick/frustrated of trying to master specific control responses just to advance to the next sequence where you have to memory map the sequence, take advantage of the free refund from Steam.

Game really needs ability for complexity levels.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988906058', 'num_games_owned': 177, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 411, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 60, 'last_played': 1582209117}
review: Pretty amazing experience.  I have played rhythm games since the days of Parappa the Rapper.  Huge Bemani fan too.   I also played the clarinet from 5th grade through high school and I haven't had any issues with things being off tempo at all in Thumper.  You just have to become enveloped in the sights and sounds of the game and let the beat fill your mind and body.  I had no problem clearing most segments with an 'S' ranking.  Really, really fun game and it runs silky smooth in VR on my GTX 770.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963126130', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 347, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 125, 'last_played': 1563333987}

author: {'steamid': '76561198027127826', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 196, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 107, 'last_played': 1667497542}

author: {'steamid': '76561198105565073', 'num_games_owned': 424, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 77, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 77, 'last_played': 1482443161}
review:
I don't think Thumper is a bad game, but there are some core mechanics that I don't necessarily agree with:

1) Thumper uses auditory cues to tell the player what "notes" are coming up and uses visual cues to indicate when to play those notes. In my opinion, this causes the game to feel somewhat "out-of-sync".
2) The sound effects when you hit/miss the notes are way too loud and masks the visual cues of future notes.
3) The slow-down effect when you mess up and lose your outer shell breaks the flow of the rhythm.

It's certainly a very pretty looking game and I can understand its appeal, but I don't think it's the rhythm game for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969388941', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 467, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1545114439}

This game was already amazing BEFORE it had VR support.  It is so intense.  It reminds me of Bit.Trip Runner in many ways.  The controls are extremely precise, and you will get sucked in just trying to beat one more stage.

This is my favorite VR game, currently.  Flat out.  It is pure sensory overload.  The colors, the sense of speed, the split second timing.  Well done!

author: {'steamid': '76561198263285411', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 439, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 331, 'last_played': 1703471435}
review:
Well, let's start with the good stuff. Thumper is one of the most intense and beautiful games I've ever played. It's got fantastic art direction; the graphics make it look like you're traveling between universes, and combined with the music it creates an incredibly tense atmosphere as if some kind of eldritch beast might jump out at you at any moment. My personal favorite part are the bosses: their design is often so incredibly weird and unique (ranging from the giant head forecast in the trailers to what appear to be sentient wormholes) that it makes me want to see more. 


So what's bad about this game? In short: the gameplay. 

I haven't played many other rhythm games, so I can't exactly compare, but I found that this game became damn near impossible around level 4. Specifically, the final boss of said level. In the levels leading up to it, I could [i]eventually[/i] beat them by meticulously memorizing the pattern over the course of fifteen minutes and ignoring most of the obstacles. That isn't an option in the boss levels. Combine that with the nearly split-second timing required to hit some of the panels and the fact that, because of a bafflingly bad gameplay decision by the programmers, you're not allowed to switch rails while holding the space bar, and by the end of level 4 the game has become, as far as I'm concerned, borderline unplayable. If it weren't for the existence of footage of people beating the later levels, I'd accuse this game of being literally unbeatable, especially since it appears to continue scaling in difficulty at the same rate. And that's a shame, because the atmosphere and music are spot on; this is an absolutely fantastic game in every area [i]except[/i] the gameplay. 

tl;dr version: If you have the free time, look up a walkthrough of this game. I guarantee you'll enjoy it. But don't waste twenty dollars on the game itself. It's not worth the rage you'll experience trying to beat it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030519086', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 649, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 466, 'last_played': 1658715986}

If you have any kind of love for rythym games in the slightest - buy this.  If you're looking for something to hone your reflexes - buy this.  If you've just started tripping balls and wanna see if its possible to explode your head like in Scanners - buy this and play it in VR :)

(in case I wasn't clear enough I freakin LOVE this game!)

author: {'steamid': '76561198000058525', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 273, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 273, 'last_played': 1482278969}
review:
If you're into rhythm games and imaginative premises, this is most likely for you. If i had to explain it to someone, it's akin to audiosurf with breakneck and rather technical gameplay, striking sound and music, pretty visuals and is really addictive.
Well worth the price tag: it's just purely harsh fun and nothing more than it needs to be.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042269532', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 73, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1482201584}
review:
This is amazing in VR.  

For anyone wondering if this will get you sick, the answer is "probably not".  The game is so surreal and abstract that it doesn't give you that weird feeling you usually get with artifical locomotion.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969101080', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 157, 'playtime_forever': 712, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 489, 'last_played': 1651437967}
review:
Finally the highest quality meets VR and is just perfect, it's a marvellous and essential concept. Compelling, stylish, damn fast, sickness free. Very smooth with a 970 with highest MSAA enabled. Any respectable owner of a virtual reality headset had to add this one to his library.

EDIT: Just finished the game in the normal mode (I will finish later in the "plus" mode) in +7 hours with a crappy ranking in most of tracks. Huge replayability. One of better videogames ever made, this is pure art.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072475166', 'num_games_owned': 711, 'num_reviews': 173, 'playtime_forever': 19, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1482104856}
review:
An attempt to make music-based games something other than audiosurf, and something more inspired than DDR, Thumper is a game about a metal beast of sorts. Could be an isopod with wings, could be a sci-fi bullet, or it could be a scarab, but whatever it happens to be, it loves its hotwheels track, and prefers to stick to it.

Controls are hyper simple and the game doesn't lie to you when it claims that the controls are 'a button and a stick. Because of that and as it goes, they can crank up difficulty by having some curves tossed in. Yes these curves and and will kill you, and as such, this forces you pay attention only to the track itself, so that you can not die long enough to die to the boss, which is a crying shame since the world around you is a living thing with pulsating shapes and colors, not dissimilar to your friend on news years eve at 9 PM. 

The bosses, as well as foes in general, are cut and dry basic geometric shapes with what appears to be tenticles to at least some degree, but they merely exist for show. You damage yourself, rest assured. The bosses and other foes puke up the hotwheels track you exist on, and present you times to damage them, but not before throwing in a curve or two, or some toothpicks for you to dodge under. If you fail to press the button at each 'damage time', however, the entire course will reset. Again, keeps it predictible which isn't a bad thing, but after a while it stops being a pleasure and starts being some mumbling about that toothpick that keeps killing you.

All damage periods, and curves corralate to the beat of the music more or less, and said beat can only be best appricated with a pair of bass boosting headphones, of which I do not own; because the beat has to resonate, and replace your heart beat, so when you force your metal thing to die, you will too, but in real life, and only once.

The game is unforgiving and yet checkpoints are aptly placed; just enough to force you to try, but not so few that dying is a major set-back. Its quite rewarding to get everything right the first time, and its entertaining to see that triangle writhe in pain as you fling green balls of bile deep into the center of it. 

It just gets irriating fast, I'm afraid. Naturally if you die on a set of track, the track doesn't change, so the game remains predictible in that way, and after hearing the same few sets of the same electronic song, it merely gets old. 5 years a second old. 

I'll be continuing this one.

8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198005136160', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 818, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 473, 'last_played': 1530079820}
review:
I'd been a holdout on getting a controller for a long time, but the reviews of this game convinced me to finally stop being such a keyboard/mouse snob.

My hands are now cramping and my right thumb is going from sore to numb and back again and I am breathing heavily as if I'd just done something atheletic. And that speaks to how utterly absorbing this game is.

This is one of those gaming experiences that makes you feel like you're a kid again, just discovering the wonders of video games for the first time.

And there's more. This game is so demanding of your attention that playing it becomes almost a kind of trance or meditation. You stop paying attention for one fleeting moment and you crash. But if you can keep your mind on it you can navigate it. There are moments that seem impossibly fast and complicated at first but, as you master them, it's almost like they start going by in slow motion.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974957459', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 1389, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 882, 'last_played': 1513562479}
review:
[b]edit: HOLY CRAP it looks jawdropping with my Vive!!![/b]

I really like Thumper, it's an amazing and intense game, but you shouldn't buy it expecting a game like Guitar Hero or Rock Band. It's not a rhythm or music game in that sense, it has a much heavier emphasis on fast reflexes. The player character (the beetle) should usually be thought of as playing an accompanying instrument, not directly matching the background music. [i]This isn't a problem with the game, it's just important to have the right expectations before buying.[/i]

If you're having a hard time, here are some pointers:

- Don't aim for high scores the first time you play a level, you'll probably just get frustrated. After playing later levels your reflexes and instinct will have become so sharp that you'll be able to come back to earlier levels and ace them without any need for memorization or restarting.

- Turn up your speakers/headphones. This will allow you to better hear the audio cues that come in advance of many obstacles, especially corners.  It also helps makes the game even more enthralling and gets you into its rhythm.

- As far as I've played in the game, there have [b]never[/b] been two turns the same direction in quick succession (within a half second or less). It's always Left-Right or Right-Left, never Left-Left or Right-Right. If you see a turn in one direction, be prepared to turn the opposite direction immediately after. I also haven't seen an obstacle aside from turns that require you to hold A+Left or A+Right, so there's probably no harm in just immediately holding the opposite direction after completing a turn to be sure you aren't surprised.

- Once you get good at jumping/flying and landing, this is often a much faster way of hitting beats that come in quick succession compared to just hitting A as fast as you can. Later in the game (level 5) it's virtually impossible to hit every beat without using this technique.

review: Psychedelic ride through hell. In levels 8 and 9 blinking can be deadly and you end up getting totally enveloped - it almost pulls you in. Going back to play the earlier levels makes you realize just how much better you are from when you started. This is a unique game and should be praised as there's nothing else quite like it. The Play+ mode is cool too but would be nice if you got achievements for beating them like in the actual game. Can't wait to play this in VR.

author: {'steamid': '76561198128088505', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 90, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 90, 'last_played': 1478869073}
review:
Get Thumper!
Thumper is a unique rhythm game, because it's not actually a rhythm game. How? Rhythm games, like Audiosurf and Geometry Dash, follow a specific pattern to follow a soundtrack or song. In Thumper this is not the case. Thumpers soundtrack (DLC) is only a base of the beat YOU have to create. Another difference is the the fact that this game is pretty violent. Not by blood and gore, but by the sheer intensity this game has. The beat definitely has an "oomph" to it. It sounds like you're going into battle with a war drum on your chest! 

For anyone who likes these types of games, this is for you. But be warned though. This game can be raging, but since the tutorial is well laid out and gives you time to master the basic skills, you'll fling through the levels in no time! But, of course, the developers know this, and the levels they made will test not only your skills, but also your reflexes. What I'm saying here is that Thumper can be healthy for you, because by the time you finish the game, your reflexes will be a lot faster, since everything happens so fast.

You will never regret getting this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198002651559', 'num_games_owned': 240, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 357, 'last_played': 1485212926}
review:
I would love to say this game is amazing because it really knock your teeth when you play it :p


But it is so much a waste that 50% of the things displayed on the screen are only there for scoring. So if you don't care about the score, you can juste keep pressing X, ignore 75% of the game mecanics and reach the end with a much lesser difficulty.
You can also try hard for weeks to improve your score and reach 139th world position instead of 4352th, but what's the point of that ?

So this game must be played for its unique feeeling, but only for that

author: {'steamid': '76561197994192651', 'num_games_owned': 574, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 813, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 648, 'last_played': 1483861176}
review:
Thumper feels fast. Thumper feels angry. Thumper feels /incredible/.

It's one of the best games this year and handily one of the best rhythm games I can think of. The "zen state" of getting into the flow of a level in Thumper is so exhilarating, and every checkpoint you rocket through is one you earned. It took me until after I beat the game to really understand the scoring system, but now I have a refueled desire to play through it again and attempt for some S-ranks.

Thumper is an experience that is wholly worthy of your time. It is a wonderful time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992399820', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1304, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 178, 'last_played': 1642926143}
review:
This game will make your brain melt and your heart thump. I imagine this game will be more favorable to you if you are musician with fairly decent background, as the game moves VERY quickly and if you don't anticipate the rhythms in odd sections (offbeats, leading beats, complex meters) by eventually catching on to the pattern, it will feel somewhat random.

Gameplay/challenge: This game will best suit you if you're a fan of hard games as this game is VERY challenging and beyond that has an EXTREMELY high skill cap if you are going for a high score. That said, the game is fairly well designed and will teach you new techniques and patterns in isolation before mixing it in with other stuff. Checkpoints are typically frequent, so you will slowly progress if you keep trying, although you will certainly not hit any great grades if you do this without trying to master each segment.

Music: But seriously, get this game. The soundtrack is very intense and has a great weight to it. Stylistically, think of it as playing a whole rhythm game where the soundtrack is pulled from Invader Zim industrial background music with a modern twist. The sound effects when you properly hit notes just *feel* powerful, and you'll find yourself pressing the controller and stick much harder than you probably need to on occasion as a result of its weighty feel.

Visuals: This game is BEAUTIFUL and visually is one of the most impressive I've ever seen. Seriously, just look at any of the screenshots. The game looks like that ALL the TIME but with nonstop motion added and constantly shifting colors. It feels like a drug trip without drugs and tends to intersperce calm sections where you just appreciate the scenery with the brutal sequences of rhythm.

TLDR: High challenge/skill cap for perfectionists/twitch games, mind-boggling visuals, gripping gameplay with an equally gripping industrial Zim-esque rhythm soundtrack, bonuses for trained musicians who like mixed meter. If any of these things seem appealing to you, do yourself a favor and take yourself on a trip with this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069532861', 'num_games_owned': 642, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 558, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 432, 'last_played': 1672088843}
review: If you think this game looks cool buy it. The way it plays is just as impressive and hypnotic as the visuals. Thumper is a very intense rhythm game that teaches you it's many mechanics and expects you to remember and practice them well. However, with just the use of the A button and left control stick the game remains very simple to learn. One of the many great indies to come out of 2016.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963269143', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 204, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 167, 'last_played': 1559945889}
review: I'm not sure I can describe this game.  You're a space beetle flying through Pink Floyd album covers, with gameplay that looks like someone took Audiosurf, added obstacles and weapons, and then gave you synesthasia.  It gets absolutely insane in the later levels.  It's really fun, but I will say trying to play it with an Xbox controller kills your thumb (this is due to the design of the controller buttons rather than anything with the game).  The best options involve x360ce, and involve using either a Gamecube controller or an arcade stick.  Both work pretty well.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987036634', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 919, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 250, 'last_played': 1632598865}
review:
Imagine playing Through the Fire and Flames on Guitar Hero while you're sitting in a rocket going through space at Mach 25 and getting punched in the face.
That is this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970644090', 'num_games_owned': 461, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 1800, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1041, 'last_played': 1693369495}
review:
I only just found out about this game when it released. Saw a few videos and had to get it.

I'm a musician, and instructor. Have been playin music for most my life and this game kicked my butt. 

There's parts of each level that groove and feel "right" while a lot of the rest of the level doesn't seem to fit with the tempo/time signature, (each level number represents it's time signature). It frustrated me a LOT. I felt like the devs put in those groove sections to make it seem like a rhythm game but most the filler was just an out of time mess.

I was wrong.

The more you learn about the mechanics, which are actually fairly complex for one button and stick, the more you'll apreciate how finely tuned this game is. So, a lot of the patterns don't exactly groove like typical rhythm games, but once you start feeling how all the more advanced scoring mechanics work together, you'll start feeling the music in really interesting ways.  It's hard to explain, haha.

Yes.... your thumbs will get sore playing this, like... seriously. But man.... when you nail sections and feel how it all fits together there's no comparison to how awesome it makes you feel.  

There's PLENTY of replay that can be had in this, plus the music will stick with you and make you want to play more just to hear it again.

It's worth the price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065957155', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 20, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1480911710}

author: {'steamid': '76561197991981121', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 229, 'last_played': 1573158812}
review: A remarkably focused piece of game design. The product of seven years spent honing five basic inputs, paring away the unnecesary to reveal the essential. Tense and trance-inducing, abstract and visceral. Thumper appears as an alien artifact from a parallel dimension, its bass-heavy beat the echo of an exploded world where game design evolved after its own internal logic rather than mimicing more established media. No uncanny mimesis, no turgid diegesis. Just flowing challenge. Thumper is a sickening antidote to the ills of an increasingly directionless medium, painful pennance for the sins of an industry gone astray. Buy this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198279621511', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 610, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 509, 'last_played': 1655794356}
review:
[h1] Dear kids, forget drugs, forget weed & play this instead.[/h1]

Oh yes, this must be the literal visual manifestation of high dosage in harmful drugs. 

[h1] Overview [/h1]

This rhythmic violence game is so vibrant & aesthetic that it comes with pleasure, pain, eargasms, serizures, and thumb aches. Its got it all!

The controls are pretty basic. You make use of the analog stick and a single button on the controller. You combine and use a mixed array of combinations to hit notes, slide, jump, etc. Don't underestimate it cause it does get challegning over time, thus despite the intuitive and simple controls, the game does increase in difficulty as you progress.

The game comprises of 9 levels and has lots of sub levels with a boss in one of the early rounds and another at the end. With achievements to collect and S ranks to achieve, the game has great replay value. The developer recently introduced a new mode to the game, known as " + Play " that's a lot faster, unforgiving and frightening with no seconds chances for mistakes made.
 
Thumper has won  8 - 9 awards and still is anticipated to win many more. The VR comptability is on its way and will be freely patched into the game. 

With or without VR, the game is completely worth the price tag for that which it's offered considering the time of release and the adrenaline fuelled joy it packs.


[h1] Tips to savour the game to the max [/h1]

~ Make sure to raise up the volume in the settings menu in the game to the max. 
~ Wear headphones / earphones.
~ Turn off the lights and play in the dark. 
~ Use a controller for optimal experience. [spoiler] Keyboard works just fine too though.[/spoiler]
~ The game gets really intense after reaching Level 3 , so consider 1 and 2 a warm up.

[h1]Warning: [/h1] 

Those with a history of epileptic seizures should stay away from the game and also kids, stay at school, weed kills brain cells and drugs will destroy your lives.

---------------------------------------------------

My summed up reaction to the overall experience of the game:  http://imgur.com/EZvmNfP

author: {'steamid': '76561197973608826', 'num_games_owned': 680, 'num_reviews': 242, 'playtime_forever': 1138, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 622, 'last_played': 1683669147}

author: {'steamid': '76561198010359527', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 579, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 111, 'last_played': 1603340257}
review:
Are you not a big fan of, or never even thought about playing, a rhythm game? 

Doesn't matter, play this game.

This is one of those games that grabs its genre by the balls, drags it outside to the lawn, and beats the living shit out of it, and absolutely establish dominance over its predecessors. 

Don't think of it as a rhythm action game. Think of it as a bloody good game.

I haven't felt this much thrill while playing a game in a very long time. The controls are tactile. The music is phenomenal. The visual is just out of this fucking world. Combine all of them together, and you need a new pair of pants. Thumper is a violent disruption that will shape its genre for years to come. Thumper is an alpha fucking wolf that will steal your pack and make you beg to become its side bitch. Thumper is a motherfucking lovechild of the patron saint of lit beats and goddess of sexy visual designs.

Thumper also happens to be a name of a rabbit from Bambi, but that doesn't really add much to this review.

It would take a gun pointed to my head to not recommend you this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198103216424', 'num_games_owned': 465, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 4472, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2703, 'last_played': 1482309985}
review:
thumper is a (very fast paced) rhythm game in which the player assumes the role of some sort of futuristic space beetle, perenially running through various tracks of exquisite, colorful, psychedelic beauty.

despite the extreme simplicity of its control scheme (you will only use the analog stick and one button), it features a considerable amount of game mechanics (which include, but are not limited to, hitting notes (obviously), jumping over obstacles, flying through rings and bursting through barriers) (note: some of the latter ones are missing a tutorial at the beggining of the level, which makes them unnecessarily hard to grasp and makes the game a little more frustrating than it should be).

not the kindest or most gentle of masters (although it did become more forgiving of players' mistakes, especially those going for the s rank, by allowing one to replay the previous checkpoint, something which was not possible when the game released), thumper won't really take you by your hand and proceed to calmly guide you through its many obstacles and thrills: it will, instead, grab you by your wrist and speed ahead, not very concerned if you are able to keep up, occasionally slapping you in the face. stick with it, however, and you will start doing things you likely didn't think yourself capable of. and it will be amazing.


tl;dr: http://i.imgur.com/fVdRIP7.png

author: {'steamid': '76561198026024492', 'num_games_owned': 782, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 3613, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2393, 'last_played': 1666209494}
review:
I had been hyping myself up for Thumper since spring and can safely say it lived up to the hype, it's an [b]outstanding[/b] game and even after all my hyping, it still managed to exceed my expectations!

The gameplay is the most unique I've played this year, it's unlike any other rhythm game I have played. I expected something similar to Audiosurf, but that assumption was blown out of the water when I played the first level. One button and one stick sends your chrome-clad space beetle on its way careering down its metal track into the unknown whilst encountering harsh conditions along the way. You get a sense that you will never know what will appear next in the game due to the different rhythms that will batter you, and it will always keep you on your toes.

It goes without saying, but with a tagline of "rhythm-violence", this game is hard. It's going to force you into a sense of rhythm and will make you good at the game, whether that means dying countless times. At the end of each level you'll have a massive head looming over you, throwing beats your way hoping to kill you in the process unless you smash the four glows without error. Getting them all and delivering a supercharged shockwave towards the demonic head gives you the sense that you perfected the level, just like getting all the notes right on an instrument. But knowing once you get good at Thumper, and that you can perfect that one level you had trouble with ages ago with ease, just like perfecting a piece of music, you feel that nothing the game can throw at you will stand in your way. 

Visuaully, it's astounding for such a limited-ish game: my little space bettle shining in its full glory down the track (with no video settings at that) adds to the simplicity of the game comprised of a long metal track, a massive circle unforgiving of your mess-ups and the right-angled turns make for a simplistic but nonetheless aesthetically pleasing visual style.

The sound design in this game is quite simply untouched. The soundtrack is extremely unique with higher levels composed of their respective time signatures, so level 5 is 5:4 and level 7 is 7:4. It really does spice up the gameplay making you consider the different rhythms that will come later in the game. With a vast array of elements like audio cues, bassy thumps and the squeaky clank on a perfect turn, it makes for a flawless augmentation onto the science fiction-esque OST.

With the addition of the Play+ mode, it has kept me on edge every single time with the sense of annihalation if you slip up twice. No going back. I managed to complete Level 8+ in one sitting without dying, and it was the most heart pounding moment of this game yet. Knowing that I could die at any given moment after being stripped of my chrome armour, getting especially tense during the appearance of the "Ring of Death" hoping to tear you apart on any miss on multiple lanes. Horror games can boast their jump-scares and scary monsters in the dark, but can't compare to Thumper's bleak, glooming atmosphere and the sense of not knowing what's coming next.

There are only one or two cons I feel I should mention. 

Sometimes, the beats that the game throws at you can be extremely unexpected and often land on the off-beat of the music, which can make it difficult to get into a real flow of the game. This mostly happens in levels 5, 6, 7 and 9 where the game speeds up and gives you less time to think about the music and make it more about quick reaction. However, these levels have irregular time signatures so that may be a factor. 

It's got a slightly high price (¬£15.99) , which is pretty uncommon for an indie single-player game. I would have expected a price closer to ¬£11.99 because there are many other games which offer more content at a lower price, but the game is still definitely worth it at ¬£15.99 and has offered me close to and imminently upward of 40 hours with the score-attack replayability of its levels.

Straight recommendation. The best game I've played of 2016.

GOTD

author: {'steamid': '76561198002008434', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 677, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 501, 'last_played': 1595266381}
review:
You are a beetle careening down a track at breakneck speeds. Ahead of you are a series of glowing lights on the track, followed by several consecutive curves, more glowing lights, floating rings, translucent tendrils, then more glowing lights. Boom. Boom. Boom. Ching. Ching. Ching. BoomBoom. Schick. BRAAAHHHH. Boom Boom. The beat perfectly complements the hellish music which accompanies you on your seemingly endless journey through the depths of interdimensional cosmic hell.
 
A smile emerges on your face as you feel a shiver go down your spine. Awestruck and wanting more, your knuckles go white as the next series of glowing lights approach.
 
The gist of the game is fairly simple: as you travel down the track, you must hit a button in line with the lights on the ground, and occasionally you lean/move in a given direction when appropriate. The stages start out simply enough in the beginning, with new mechanics like flying, multiple lanes, and oncoming enemies being introduced every so often. The difficulty rises gradually over the course of the first 3 levels, but then takes a sharp spike upwards at around level 4, where the increasing speed and introduction of new mechanics begin to take their toll. It can be frustrating. But each failed attempt brings you closer and closer to finishing a stage, which serves as a teacher that prepares you for the iterative mechanics of each subsequent stage.
 
Although punishing, Thumper becomes increasingly rewarding with each level of mastery you attain. The ranking system is simple enough, with ‚ÄúS‚Äù ranks being essentially perfect runs, ‚ÄúA‚Äù ranks being great runs, and so on. However, the skill ceiling seems to be so absurdly high that, at a certain point, even an ‚ÄúS‚Äù rank doesn‚Äôt necessarily feel good enough. There‚Äôs always a turn that could‚Äôve been executed better. There‚Äôs always a series of beats that could be more rhythmically pleasing. Thumper has a surprisingly effective carrot-on-a-stick that extends the replay value almost indefinitely as you strive to get a ‚ÄúPerfect‚Äù on every turn and rack up the multiplier while simultaneously crafting a beat that sends a feeling of frisson down your spine.
 
Part of what makes Thumper so great is the fact that you aren‚Äôt just playing along with the music, in most cases you are actively contributing to it.
 
As a fan of the ‚ÄúNoise rock‚Äù band Lightning Bolt I may be a little biased, but Thumper‚Äôs soundtrack is phenomenal. Created by Lightning Bolt‚Äôs Brian Gibson, it is a cacophony of sound that engulfs you in its unsettling embrace of booming drums, shrill screams, and foreboding drawn-out soundscapes. It‚Äôs something that works in unison with the gameplay so well that the development process and unification of the gameplay and audio seems deserving of a documentary in and of itself. Text on a page doesn‚Äôt do it enough justice.
 
Visually, Thumper is nothing short of impressive.
 
The track you find yourself on loops back and forth, ascending and descending through what can best be described as interdimensional space. Flurries of lights, sparks, and other post-processing effects explode from your cute little beetle as you interact with every beat and curve. If that wasn‚Äôt enough, mastering mechanics makes things even more overstimulating. If executed properly, a flight-beat followed by a down-beat combo will shoot a ball of light that travels ahead of you down the track, illuminating other beats, killing tendrils, and creating the illusion that it created the track‚Äôs curves up ahead. Chaining these sorts of combos together multiple times is easily the most overstimulating and satisfying experiences you can have in any game. Objectively.
 
Despite not being a fan of other rhythm games, Thumper has been the single greatest unification of music and gameplay that I have ever experienced. It‚Äôs frustrating and difficult, but in a way that drives me toward perfection. It‚Äôs overstimulating and chaotic, but in a way that induces a trance-like state. It‚Äôs chaotic and violent, but in a way that shoots a cosmic beetle through the mouth of a fiery hell-skull. Thumper is amazing, and it‚Äôs something that deserves to be experienced as a whole. In all of its unsettling, heart-pounding glory.

(http://www.shatteredjoystick.com/single-post/2016/10/28/Thumper-PC--Review)

author: {'steamid': '76561197993431013', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2429, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1161, 'last_played': 1672363801}
review:
So, now that I finally S ranked all the levels, I think I'm qualified to leave a review. Although I'll [i]try[/i] to be unbiased.
As a side note, I play rhythm games a LOT. I'm nowhere near the best, but definitely not the worst.

In short, if you rhythm games and twitchy gameplay, you should get this game. However, I would only recommend the full price ($20 USD) if you see yourself going through and perfecting the levels, as it is only 9 levels. Otherwise, wait till it goes on sale, even if for $15.

Now for a little more depth.
Visuals:
OH MAN. When they add VR support (as of November 30, it's been promised in a future update), I'm tempted to pick up a headset just for this game. It is BEAUTIFUL. The entire game looks like the screenshots, but even better. And since they made this game for PSVR, it is optimized to hell and back. For comparison, I've got a Radeon R7 370, and its running 1080p, 4x MSAA at a smooth 144 fps.

Audio:
I'm suprised I haven't gone deaf playing this game. I just keep turning it up louder and louder to get enveloped by it. And the soundtrack starts out so simple, but by the end, you are being borderline assaulted by noise, and it's everything I could ever want. But that's just cause I love the tribal feeling. It's very high quality. The composer knows exactly what he's doing.

Gameplay:
Okay, so this is where everyone seems to be torn. The problem is, I wouldn't necessarily call it a rhythm game. More like an [in]finite runner where all the obstacles happen to be on beat. Sure, it is "call and response", but towards the end, everything becomes so chaotic, you can't really hear the "call" anymore, and you have to rely on sight. Which is also hard, seeing how fast-paced it gets, and how it starts hiding things behind corners.
Anyway, I would liken the feeling towards being in the rhythm section of a band. You gotta keep the beat and listen for what's coming next, but be ready for anything. You get in the zone, and feel what's coming next.

All in all, this is an amazing game, that's hard to pin down. I was a little sad about the length, however with the PLAY+ update, I've got much more reason to keep playing and keep perfecting. I would definitely suggest trying before buying, unless you know you like these kind of mechanics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198337142022', 'num_games_owned': 125, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 73002, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24110, 'last_played': 1705724175}
review:
First of all Thumper gets a 9.8 out of 10 hands down. (would be 9.9 if level editor was created)
Love the game so much I'm writing a new review!

I have never played a rhythm game thats been this fun and there are tons of amazing rhythm games!(like wow) 
You are a space beetle that thumps on pads to dark industrial / percussive beats and its so satisfiying. I will just say if you do not get this game you will never experience the epicness of it and missed out on a GEM of this century.(its that fun)

Now what I love about the game is that you get to explore different time signatures each level and the track is literally coming out of the bosses MOUTH thats so hardcore lmao. I've grown a bad addiction to this game and I love it. Pick it up see if you like it if you dont you know the return policy.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969654812', 'num_games_owned': 579, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 91, 'last_played': 1481339917}
review:
This is one of the best games I have played in a while. The music, the physicality - it all meshes so well. If you like rhythm games, buy it. If you don't like rhythm games, buy it. The music and visuals are phenomenal. There is almost no menu, just you and the best game this year.

Get a good set a headphones or speakers with a sub, crank up the volume, turn off the lights and prepare to be... terrified? delighted? It makes me nervous to play, but it keeps drawing me back in. Every time I make a mistake, I know why and want to try again. It gives me a lot of the same feelings I got when playing Super Meat Boy for the first time. It is an instant classic.

Buy now. Don't wait for a sale. Support the indie dev and buy now.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960432298', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 535, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 293, 'last_played': 1673049637}
review: It took me a long while to figure out how to describe this game in a review. Raw? Primal? There is something in Thumper that just triggers a part of my brain that isn't intelligence but just an instinct. Survival. This is a game you have to feel. Blast it in your headphones. Pump it out your speakers and just let it envelop you. It can be seen as a standard rhythm game, match the prompts, play through the level. But when I played it I was entranced and couldn't get away from it. I have not felt this way since I first played Amplitude which was the first rhythm game I ever purchased.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027786166', 'num_games_owned': 515, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 889, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 662, 'last_played': 1526042612}
review:
Lets start by saying the obvious. This game is BEAUTIFUL. Visuals are trippy and the gameplay compliments it. 
The music is also awesome. Minor complaint is that the game stops being a rythm game and more a reaction/memorization game from around mid of level 3, and then becomes a rythm game again at level 8, so basically at the end of the game. Other than that this game is a great play and I've enjoyed it greatly. Worth it IMO

author: {'steamid': '76561197999704089', 'num_games_owned': 536, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 82, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 82, 'last_played': 1480268009}
review:
Amazing and original rhytmic game, Audiosurf that actively wants to murder you - a fragile silver scarab on a cosmic highway. Very good at teaching you mechanics, patterns and at scaring the living fck out of anyone who dares to play it drunk at night.

I have no interest in VR, but I really want to try out Thumper in it after having a blast with a common version.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014088046', 'num_games_owned': 518, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 703, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 618, 'last_played': 1559671021}
review:
This game sends shivers down my spine, it's really great!
Thumper is a rhytm game based on sound AND visuals.

You must follow the rhytm pattern by repeating a sound sequence (for things that aren't visible from distance and appear), and at the same time be ready to react to obstacles visible from afar.

Some people find this game not very rhytm based because of the chaos, but that's what I like about Thumper the most - finding a pattern in adrenaline rush, when you hear and watch closely.

As you progress through game you learn new tricks that can be used in earlier levels to earn more points - those tricks were there all the time, you just didn't know about them (no need to "unlock" them). So I recommend to play a bit instead of trying to complete it all S from the start.

I've been watching this game for over a year and I'm not dissapointed with end product :) Recommended!
If you are curious about early stages of the game there is some footage on their YouTube channel, guys did a great job on this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982572424', 'num_games_owned': 1385, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 1704, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 937, 'last_played': 1692853384}
review:
Thumper is an insanely intense rhythm game sort of in the vein of Frequency (PS2) or Audiosurf. "Rhythm violence" is a very apt description - thumps and turns have a brutal physicality to them that you don't often find in games. It just [i]feels[/i] good to play. This is the kind of game where blinking can have devastating consequences, and successfully completion a section will produce an audible sigh of relief. 

It departs from typical rhythm games in that it's not really based around "songs" so much as a call-and-response system, focusing more on reaction time and twitch reflexes. Although I probably won't be listening to the soundtrack too often, the music/sound effects are brilliantly designed and really add to the physicality of each action, and helps create the psychedelic musical hellscape that is the hallmark of the game.

The game ramps up in difficulty as you progress through it's 9 lengthy courses, but thanks in part to its generous checkpoints it never gets too frustrating. The difficult part is then trying to perfect your play and climb the online leaderboards, especially in the recently added "Play+" mode which is even faster and has no checkpoints.

Thumper is one of the most intense games I've ever played in my life. It will melt your face off and leave your thumbs blistered and I loved every minute of it.

review:
The game. You opened it. We came. Now you must come with us, taste our pleasures.
No tears, please. It's a waste of good suffering.
Ah, the suffering. The sweet, sweet suffering.
We have such sights to show you!


I thought I'd gone to the limits. I hadn't. Thumper gave me an experience beyond limits... pain and pleasure, indivisible.
(As he is torn apart) Hell yes S rank

author: {'steamid': '76561198009658366', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 721, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 321, 'last_played': 1626744924}
review: This game beats me down but with every successful run through a level builds me back up to a point where I can play it even better than before. This is one of my absolute favorite but least played games. I feel excited to play but it requires a warm up. After that, though, I feel the music and hardly need to pay attention to the oncoming flurry of obstacles. This game is definitely for people who love a challenge but one where you can easily notice the progress of getting better through every playthrough. It's partially memory but I'm only 5 levels into the game and it's become instinct to react to each obstacle. This game is a spectacular battle with music that can be won with practice and good headphones.

review:
You need to have a great sense of rhythm to understand the beats of this game. No, it's not easy (I still can't clear level 5), it's not like other rhythm games where you only push the bass on a very clear frequency. The game almost don't let you breath and blink and will make you frustrated and nervous and tense a lot. 
Buuut the music is great, all the enviroment is great and bosses are a pain in the ***. And once you get the beats, you even dance together!

Just try not playing it before sleep, because you won't. O_O

author: {'steamid': '76561197972944473', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1043, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1000, 'last_played': 1696518051}
review:
A triumph for modern rhythm gaming. 

Equal parts endless runner (think BitTrip) and classical rhythm game, it blends the parts with a smooth and slick aesthetic that has no peers in its choice of style. The visuals are just gorgeous, and never has any game looked smoother. The HUD (or to be more precise, for the most part the lack thereof) serves to further immerse in the abstract and hypnotizing environments.

The music (some would probably debate it can even be called that) is brutal, visceral and driving. You don't feel the rhythm, you become the rhythm. You lose yourself in the thumping or you crash and burn. 

And oh will you crash and burn, time and time again. The difficulty is no less brutal than the acoustic backdrop, but that makes progress all the more satisfying. Being able to switch between different buttons for the main input button after a recent patch is much appreciated, because the thumb used to play it tends to mirror the tenseness of the experience.

One often-raised complaint is that the game is not a real rhythm game, and relies more on reflexes and memorization than on rhythm. I simply cannot fathom how people arrive at this opinion. Every obstacle in the game has a precise audio cue beforehand, and every single note is placed with enormous care to fit perfectly into the rhythm of the track. That rhythm may sometimes be weird, and confounding, and at times even infuriating, but it is absolutely there. When missing a lot of notes, it can feel like it is purely random noise, and relies on reactions alone, but that is definitely not the case. This becomes apparent if you push through and start actually nailing difficult sections and suddenly it all fits together like a well-oiled machine. At that times the rhythms turn from chaotic and mindboggling to intricate and mesmerizing. 

The musical landscape (hellscape?) created by noise-rock veteran Brian Gibson may not be easy to stomach for some, but it is apparent that this was exactly what the developers were aiming for. The game projects a tremendous feeling of unease and nervousness. It pushes just the right buttons to make people feel uncomfortable, but at the same time it pulls you in with its spiraling visuals and its enthralling industrial-tribal thumping sounds.

This is one game of very few that managed to take one simple concept and distill it to its purest form, and that form is glorious.

Addendum: VR support makes this game even better. In VR, due to the increased immersion, it becomes an almost medidative (if straining) experience. Very much recommended to try this out if the chance presents itself.

ora vi dir√≤ perche:

author: {'steamid': '76561197971572722', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 877, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 270, 'last_played': 1486322793}
review:
Thumper is a game that should have been perfect for me. I'm a musician focused on drums, I love drones and dark ambient, I love the demoscene, I loved guitar hero, I love bullet hell shooters and masochistic difficulties, the list of reasons I should love this game just goes on and on. But I really don't.

Instead, Thumper is a slog to play that deals less with rhythmicality than rote memorisation. It goes out of its way to screw with any accumulated sense of rhythm over levels that take far too long to complete to ever want to return to (upwards of 15 minutes each). 

A gimmick of the engine is that every successful interaction the player has with the game triggers percussion, which means if your rhythm is off, the triggered sound is off too. The background audio functions as a sort of metronome intended to give you something to correct to, but the audio mix reduces that beat to a noisy growl under the din of your own off-center beats, meaning as levels increase in intensity your own off-ness creeps into your entire performance: Since the beats sound "right" to you but are in fact off by some margin, you slowly but surely creep closer to the offset where the game determines you straight up missed it. Among the reliable beats are the turns (which go off when they must as opposed to when you turn), but the levels of syncopation and sections of silence mean they are about as useful as a person next to you randomly bumping into you as you play. It's just maddening.

Thumper at its highest intensity (if you're not counting the endless rinse-repeat memorisation of drilling down a checkpoint until you perfect it) boils down to reading audio tells, but again the audio mix fails it. The thing about such a noisy soundscape is you run out of room to communicate with subtlety in the high frequencies. I never got comfortable with the tells for the elevated notches for instance (I was surprised to find out they even have one), and the game frequently sends you through turning and twisting tunnels depriving you of any visual tell to go by. No audio mix options to tweak the game to your own system exacerbate this.

The biggest failure of the game, IMO, is in its inability to build and sustain a rhythm, opting instead to give you frequent bouts of silence and random bouts of syncopation. It doesn't matter if you've a looping drum roll going in the background if the actual beats you have to hit on top of that are so haphazardly placed you are almost never allowed to "get into it". Add to this the game's love of animations and audio cues that don't have bearing on the rhythm whatsoever (the beetle hop when you release the boost is a constant annoyance for me) as well as frequent messing with time (recovering from a collision and other slowmo) all go into removing any pleasure I could get from what could otherwise be a pounding and satisfying drum session. Instead levels on first encounter are 15-20 minute grinds followed by further grinding checkpoint by checkpoint to build "mastery" that really just comes down to remembering patterns. It just goes on and on and even at its best I don't think it's rewarding my time. Halfway through *level 5* I was just exhausted. No thanks.

Thumper is too long, too repetitive, too random, poorly mixed, with a confounding scoring system. When Drool called this Rhythm Violence, irritating the player to the point of needing to punch a pillow wasn't what I thought they had in mind.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070152222', 'num_games_owned': 522, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 557, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 546, 'last_played': 1487673622}

author: {'steamid': '76561198113610783', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 457, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1563750957}
review:
This is a great game.
From the asthetic to the difficulty, it nails it. The difficulty is hard, but not unfair; I've never felt angry at the game for any death, I jsut felt the need to improve. That's a hard line to walk. Speaking of walking lines, the asthetic is weirdly enjoyable: you are a chrome beetle riding a rail through the trippiest of environments; I almost wish that I could go back to levels that I've beaten and just enjoy the scenery. One more thing to note is the audio. It's hard to call it music because all ofthe sounds happen when you succeed- or fail- a cue, it all comes together in a nicely thrilling percussion-based interactive soundtrack. All in all, its a great game well worth the 20$ asking price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076046468', 'num_games_owned': 237, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 320, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 203, 'last_played': 1578120999}
review:
I've played many rhythm games. osu!, soundodger+, bit+trip, and thumper. All of these rhythm games, excluding Thumper, use the background music and rhythm to build the game. I'm not saying I hate any of the mentioned games. osu! is a great rhythm clicker and aim-practice-er... ehrm.. soundodger has stood the test of time for me in the dodge-rhythm genre, and bit+trip is a great rhythmic platformer.

One thing that separates Thumper from these other games is the way it handles rhythm. The song provides minimal support of rhythm to go through the levels. [b] You[/b] are making the rhythm as you go along. This is what makes Thumper so incredible to play.

One other thing is that Thumper's controls, while simple at heart, get ever more complex with rising speed and different combos to pull off. It's a fantastic rhythm game that is worth the money to anyone who loves rhythm games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086151669', 'num_games_owned': 439, 'num_reviews': 183, 'playtime_forever': 670, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 212, 'last_played': 1607017968}
review:
https://niveloculto.com/analisis-thumper/

La pista de infinita de Thumper brilla entre explosiones psicod√©licas mientras nosotros, un escarabajo plateado, avanzamos a trompicones a trav√©s de un universo cercano a la concepci√≥n que un Peter Gabriel en los noventa muy puesto de LO MULTIMEDIA tendr√≠a del infierno. Bajo esa apariencia inmaculada, donde la suciedad no existe y la m√∫sica solo insin√∫a, se nos pide alcanzar un estado de sinestesia, que asimilemos, aunque solo sea un instante, el total de lo que all√≠ se nos ofrece. La diferencia, la gran diferencia de Thumper con propuestas similares, es que al alcanzar el nirvana a trav√©s del flow que genera cada uno de sus elementos, no encontramos una apacible sensaci√≥n de tranquilidad, sino que nos asomamos a un abismo mucho mayor del que insin√∫a esa pista de la que no podemos escapar.

He tenido que pasar varias horas con Thumper para entender las razones por la que desde Drool lo anunciaban como un t√≠tulo de violencia r√≠tmica. Tras este periodo no creo poder dar una explicaci√≥n exacta, pero les puedo asegurar que he pasado, al menos, tanto tiempo pensando en Thumper como jugando con √©l. Buena parte de esto creo que tiene que ver con su envoltorio, no ya est√©tico, sino mec√°nico. Hemos pasado ya por las suficientes pistas infinitas llenas de ritmo como para bajar la guardia ante una propuesta similar. Yo ya he estado ah√≠ y s√© lo que esperar. Dame m√∫sica y elementos que vengan en mi direcci√≥n que ya me ocupar√© yo de mejorar lo suficiente como para que al darle al bot√≥n adecuado todo encaje. Thumper es eso, o al menos lo es de una manera que no puedo calificar de otro modo que abyecta. Hay algo inc√≥modo en cada pulsaci√≥n. Puede que se deba a que no hay un ritmo claro, que vaya desde el juego hacia el jugador, sino que en cierta manera lo va creando el propio jugador por s√≠ mismo. Este cambio, de experiencia dieg√©tica a extradieg√©tica, mantiene el permio entre los reflejos y la capacidad de predecir el siguiente movimiento, pero a√±ade un elemento de ansiedad de que va m√°s all√° de no acertar en el momento correcto con la pulsaci√≥n exacta, pues requiere un reaprendizaje constante de las reglas de este extra√±o universo.

La otra pata sobre la que crece esta violencia r√≠tmica es la representaci√≥n de nuestras acciones dentro del t√≠tulo, pues realizar correctamente cada una de las combinaciones no obtendremos una respuesta emocional tranquilizadora, sino cargada de intensidad, la cual se siente a veces casi como una agresi√≥n a la propia representaci√≥n de Thumper. No es por tanto la cl√°sica representaci√≥n de una prueba de habilidad que en base a nuestra pericia nos termine otorgando una puntuaci√≥n m√°s o menos alta, aunque esto tambi√©n se encuentre aqu√≠, sino que el concepto de juego r√≠tmico deriva en un t√≠tulo de supervivencia en el que nunca tendremos muy claro si somos nosotros los que estamos sobreviviendo al universo de Thumper o √©l a nosotros.

La confianza de Drool en su propuesta y sus ganas de realizar un t√≠tulo que escape a los c√°nones del g√©nero tiene su m√°xima representaci√≥n en la selecci√≥n musical elegida. Antes de poner mis manos sobre el juego me preguntaba por qu√© trat√°ndose de un t√≠tulo r√≠tmico se estaba hablando tan poco de la m√∫sica de Thumper. No sab√≠a si ser√≠a posible incluir un listado externo o descargar nuevas pistas. En definitiva, buscaba otro Audiosurf con un escarabajo metalizado. La respuesta te la da el propio juego, pues la banda sonora se construye a trav√©s de una partitura que va modific√°ndose, acort√°ndose y alarg√°ndose seg√∫n avanzamos. Una tormenta industrial que no teme descargar su ira a base de sintetizadores o moverse en una calma tensa que m√≠, al menos por momentos, me ha recordado a un Vangelis de bajona.

Lo dem√°s es arcade del bueno. Del jodido. Del de ‚Äúvamos a parar un rato porque quiz√°s acabe reventando el mando contra la pared y esto vale un dinero‚Äù. Hay decenas de obst√°culos, cada cual m√°s envenenado que el anterior. Hay enemigos, por supuesto. Enemigos que atacan y a los cuales √∫nicamente puedes golpear con una bolita que sale despu√©s de haber realizado una serie de combinaciones perfectas que pueden acabar con la paciencia de m√°s de uno. Hay una curva de dificultad perfectamente medida para que creas que siempre te encuentras el borde del desastre, pero sin embargo avanzas un pasito m√°s, y otro. La recompensa es m√°s m√∫sica, m√°s violencia, m√°s sentirte inc√≥modo mientras lo disfrutas a demasiados niveles como para intentar explicarlo.

Thumper es sencillamente el mejor juego musical al que he jugado nunca. Lo es porque ha conseguido que dentro del g√©nero no me haya sentido como una cobaya que ten√≠a que pulsar el bot√≥n rojo en el momento que se me indica para ganarme mi recompensa. Soy consciente de que eso es exactamente lo que hace, pero con la diferencia de que en esta ocasi√≥n tengo la sensaci√≥n de que el ritmo me pertenece, que puedo hacer algo m√°s que salivar cuando el cient√≠fico de turno toque el silbato, como por ejemplo arrancarle la mano.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132333943', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 462, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 319, 'last_played': 1538165647}
review:
Richtig nice
Das beste Reaktionsspiel in meinem ganzen Leben
Der Einstieg ist intuitive Erkl√§rt und man Versteht sofort was man machen muss.
Die Musik ist richtig Fett und auch die Steuerung funktioniert wie man es erwartet.
Aber das geilste ist einfach das Spielgef√ºhl, man ist so voller Adrenalin gepumpt wenn die Musik spielt und man durchgehend alles Richtig macht und mit einer Geschwindigkeit durch die Levels fliegt, das ist einfach nur GEIL!!!
Man braucht zwar etwas Skill aber das lernt man schnell, die Lernkurve ist einfach perfekt, anfangs verliert man fast nie macht aber auch nicht die volle Punktzahl, und die sp√§teren Levels werden richtig mies schwer und man will einfach das Level schaffen.
Die Entwickler haben einfach das gesamte Spiel so perfekt vom Concept gemacht es stimmt einfach alles und f√ºhlt sich geil an.
Ich glaube ich l√ºge nicht wenn ich sage das hier ist das beste Musik/Rythmus-Spiel das es gibt.
Vieleicht werden einige die Musik oder den Still nicht m√∂gen aber dann wisst ihr es schon wenn ihr euch den Trailer anschaut.
