author: {'steamid': '76561198064760563', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 5797, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1325, 'last_played': 1666833394}
review:
[h1][b]What I think after playing the game[/b][/h1]
When you first jump into this game your like, "Wow, this isn't hard at all." Until you get later and your like, "Holy shit what the fuck is this, did I take drugs before playing this level!" Until you notice that your ultra focus and you just can't stop playing that game until your body is like, "Hey, I need some food and/or water or go to the bathroom or both." Then your ultra game drug high goes down and you cannot wait until you get back into the game.
[h1][b]Added[/b][/h1]
The ending is probably the most euphoric ending to a game when you beat [spoiler]level infinity and the level before that amd it just keeps speeding up and slowing down at, what seems like random invervols[/spoiler].
[h1][b]TL;DR[/b][/h1]
It's like taking a drug and you cannot stop taking it no matter what and if your off it for too long you just crave it even more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198163570627', 'num_games_owned': 305, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 1531, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 736, 'last_played': 1690531086}
review:
Thumper has the simplest controls I've seen in a game of this caliber (just the A button and the joystick; you could theoretically play this on an Atari 2600 controller) but it has so many mechanics working in tandem that it's very easy to forget that fact. I love this game because of it, but my thumbs think otherwise.

Also, this game makes you feel like a god when you land a combo on a particularly difficult level; it's a feeling not many other games can replicate. I'm not even that good at the game and I feel like a god at it. That's how to make a good game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982942926', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 513, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 203, 'last_played': 1672859034}

author: {'steamid': '76561198214404868', 'num_games_owned': 231, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 1369, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 905, 'last_played': 1703107331}
review:
Extremely good game, definitely recommend. 
It might be a couple of dollars steep. (12 hours for me to complete the game, roughly.) However, the game does offer a more challenging "+ Playthrough" if you are content with not beating your high scores.

- Very difficult game. The game trains you well and starts slow but, due to it's fast pace and execution, after a certain point in the game every stage is capable of challenging you. On subsequent playthoughs it won't be as bad because you will develop your muscle memory, but it is especially brutal for a Thumper virgin. Brutal but, very satisfying.

- Beautiful visuals. I decided to play this game after only seeing about 30 seconds worth of footage through a stream. Exquisite colors and effects bombard your eyeballs as you desperately try and keep your beetle alive through his LSD-esque adventure through space.

- Sound Design. Excellent sound. However, you might need a good headset or speaker system to make full effect of this. Thumper is a ryhthym game, and using your eyes is incredibly helpful at certain points in the game. At times you might find yourself blinded by the acid trip, and being able to discern what sounds are what DOES make a difference. 
DON'T RELY ON YOUR EYES TOO MUCH.

- Execution. You don't need to hit every obstacle to earn a good rating but, dropping a combo will hurt you. There are lots of little mechanics that require tight timing, though they aren't necessary for completion. For the most part you have a choice of whether to avoid *some* things, or to put yourself in danger for a big point bonus.

---

CONS: There are not really many actual problems with this game so they can likely all fit in 1 or 2 sentences.

- Sensory Overload. Sometimes you just won't be able to keep up with everything on screen. You need to keep your eyes open, ears primed, and fingers dancing. You may be blinded at one point, or unable to discern one sound from another, Or you can't execute everything, like hitting a hard combo in a fighting game.
- There is one aspect of the game that I'm still trying to figure out if it has a tell or not. Apart from visually discerning it at 100mph, lane switches are hard to see. That's about it.

I'm having some cognitive dissonance on whether or not to bash the game's difficulty in discerning sound, being a rhythym game. It can definitely be an annoying issue when considering how difficult the game can be. I'm going to leave it at this for now.

____
Now all we need are custom tracks!

author: {'steamid': '76561197962200300', 'num_games_owned': 754, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1726, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1103, 'last_played': 1705374192}
review:
The core mechanics in this are really solid, and it's a great example of easy to learn and hard to master.  The controls are really simple (in fact, it could be played on an old Atari joystick if you were so inclined).  The game will tutorialize things pretty well and then mashes things together and complicates them as you go.

Pros:
Gorgeous
Great music
Love the audio cues before each thing (that fit with the music)

Cons (for some):
Can be visually tiring
Can be very demanding - will punish you if you're not there in the moment

Nitpicks:  
Had crashes changing resolution, then the game wouldn't start.  I deleted and redownloaded it and everything worked fine (including saved data).
The mechanic where 2 fast up+jumps make you stay in the air longer is not obvious.  If you are trying to get an S on 6-1 and can't get everything in the air, this is your problem.
Last 2 levels don't have the same feel as the rest of the game.  They aren't that hard though, so I can overlook it.  
The blocks with the green trails don't seem to behave differently than normal.  I'm still not sure what they're there for.

Overall I'm really happy with it.  I've 100%'d it (which is tough, as of right now only 0.4% have) and I'm actually a little sad as I'll not end up playing it much more.  Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003926508', 'num_games_owned': 326, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1274, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1098, 'last_played': 1561159277}
review:
Vraiment, il n'y a rien √† redire sur ce jeu. Il y a un m√©lange de plusieurs choses qui en font un jeu vraiment exemplaire et prenant, pouvant convenir pour beaucoup.

Tout d'abord, c'est un jeu de rythme violent. On ne per√ßoit pas forc√©ment le rythme, et on le cr√©√©. Avec de bonnes grosses basses. Et le feeling est tr√®s bon, le feedback aussi.

Graphique, √ßa explose dans tous les sens, sans jamais g√¢ch√© la lisibilit√© (bon des fois c'est hyper chaud, mais c'est le rythme voulu).

Vous aurez aussi beaucoup de challenge. Disons que les 3 1ers niveaux sont simples, et vous pourrez les refaire √† foison avec beaucoup de plaisir. Du 4 au 5, vous allez en baver, mais c'est largement faisable. Par contre pour scorer, √ßa commence √† devenir chaud. Et les 3 derniers niveaux, vous clignez des yeux vous √™tes mort.

Il y aura en plus des ajouts, il y a eu un new game + ajouter gratuitement... Bref, une tuerie qui vous mettra litt√©ralement en transe.

Par contre si vous n'aimez pas les jeux de rythmes, les grosses basses, et le challenge, passez votre tour.

review:
Caras... Que jogo sensacional.

O objetivo √© simples, "derrotar um man√≠aco cabe√ßudo do futuro", com uma jogabilidade que te faz n√£o querer parar de jogar enquanto n√£o chega no fim de cada sequ√™ncia de fases... 

Thumper faz voc√™ controlar esse besouro mec√¢nico futurista com comandos b√°sicos de qualquer outro jogo (W A S D), al√©m do space pra pular. O jogo come√ßa lento, fazendo com que o jogador aprenda a mec√¢nica (que d√° pra pegar em poucos minutos), e depois s√≥ vai intensificando, aumentando a quantidade de movimentos, diversificando os mesmos e aumentando a velocidade.

√â dif√≠cil descrever esse jogo em palavras, sinceramente... Mas valeu cada centavo, e olha que n√£o joguei nem 1/3 dele ainda.

Graphiquement c'est tr√®s g√©om√©trique et metallis√©, il faut aimer, mais √ßa se pr√™te parfaitement √† l'ambiance.

review:
*Looks at game page and sees "horror" as a popular tag
Me: "How is this game horror?"
*30 minutes later 
Me: "THE HORROR,THE HORROR!!"

This game is not at all what i expected it to be, in best was possible. I am a huge fan of rhythm games such as trip.bit, xonic, or amplitude. It is the dark shadow of those three games in a twisted and high adrenaline game. It has some of the best rhythm moments i have ever seen. Highly recommend if you enjoy the genre and also like difficult games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104193133', 'num_games_owned': 429, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 710, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 329, 'last_played': 1703628600}
review:
Thumper is one of the best games I've played in the past few years. It has amazing visuals, terrific sound design, and it's just... [i]fun[/i]. It's just as insane to play as it is to watch, but you enjoy (almost) every second of it. I say almost because it's pretty difficult, but beating that boss that's been kicking your butt is really rewarding. I very rarely got legitimately frustrated with it, if ever.
My only complaint would be that sure, you have to do things to the beat, but the way the game plays currently, especially in later levels, it barely qualifies as a rhythm game. Near the end it just becomes furious button-mashing as you try to make sense of all the colorful, hurtful objects flying at you constantly.
But the final boss battle is pretty cool.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065332753', 'num_games_owned': 301, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 1538, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 563, 'last_played': 1698721091}
review:
Very cool and Very fun! The levels where challenging and the beats where great. The very last boss was interesting Slow-mo and Fast-mo switching back and forth, I wish there was more of that because that was just amazing. The visual effects were very interesting, not sure how you can think of something like that without some weed but who knows?

I highly recommend this game.. Oh and use a controller!

However, I don't think getting S rank on all the worlds is gonna be easy! xD

Here is a little tip btw:

To fly off turns you have to perfect the turn. The game makes a noise when you perfect it and that is the only way.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048266315', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 173, 'last_played': 1649128398}
review:
You know when you see Cyberpunk films and they have those weird digital games or sequences that the masses are supposedly addicted to constantly? Technology that is treater more like drug than game?

Thumper is what those fictional citizens are playing. You don't say "how long have I been playing" instead you go "How long was I out for."


If you like that sort of experience, buy Thumper.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012873891', 'num_games_owned': 368, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 225, 'last_played': 1478009264}
review:
I got Thumper because I love rhythm games and the game was described as such. The more I played the game, though, the more I realized how it evolved from its rhythm based premise to a pure trial-and-error experience which - to me - is a big disappointment. 

If I had to judge Thumper on the first 2 or 3 stages alone, I would give it a positive review. It features beautiful visual and sounds, everything about the game is captivating, the game mechanics work nicely and you really feeling 100% immersed in the game flow. Unfortunately this changes over time. The stages don't get more challanging, but just more unfair, with incredibly harsh sequences that the player cannot remotely foresee. The vibe of the game becomes monotonous, the rhythms fairly similar throughout the entire stage. 

Once again, if you come with the idea of getting a good rhythm game, I would probably not advise you to get Thumper. On the other hand, if you think that you will only play the first few stages and you are intrigued by its beautiful audio-visuals, go ahead and get it, don't even hesitate.

author: {'steamid': '76561198130718317', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 2600, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 889, 'last_played': 1609108447}
review:
Have you ever had something you just love but can't quite explain why? You try explaining it to your friends, but cant quite get across why its to excellent. This game is that for me.
It is without a doubt one of the best feeling games out there, it is incredibly tight, the controls are responsive, and everything works the way it should. The game only uses 2 inputs. the left analog stick, and a button (Use a controller, its way better), but the amount of complexity it manages with just those two inputs is staggering. Ill admit it starts off too slow, but after the first "Level" it ramps up beautifully. This is not a traditional rhythm game, the best way to describe it is a "call and response" system, credit to the other review I stole that off of. It matches to the beat, but isn't really a huge part of the song if that makes any sense. In fact that would be another gripe of mine, after the first couple levels the background music gets less interesting as it relies more heavily on you properly hitting the notes and beats. 
The game also ramps up difficulty very well, introducing not only new mechanics each levels but also speeding it up and limiting what you can see ahead of you through tunnels and such. You become less reliant on visual cues and more so on the actual sounds the game makes, which while they could be a bit louder clearly tell you whats coming. 
Overall I love this game and highly recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022595480', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 117, 'last_played': 1552966938}
review:
Final Edit: I would like to make it clear that the biggest issue i have with the game is the audio cues. Its musical and Rhythm aspect. Everything else about this game really feels great, but the audio cues being faint and hard to hear makes this game frustrating to play, and any mistake i make, in most cases, feel like its the game not giving me any warning at all to whats coming up, and it feels cheap and unfair. I don't mind difficult, i just want fair difficulty, where it was my mistake that made me lose, not the game just throwing something at me out of nowhere with no warning and no time to react.
If you don't mind a more visual focused rhythm game, in which incredibly fast reactions or memorization is the main focus, with a little bit of rhythm mixing in, then definitely go for this game.
I just expected the game to be more fast paced Rhythm and visuals mixed together, not Visuals with just a bit of Rhythm too it. Read the rest of the review to know why i expected both a Rhythm and a Visual game mixed together, and why the game is clearly marketing itself for being both.

Many rhythm games don't need audio cues since you can easily see whats coming up next, and basing yourself on the rhythm and beat, you can play whats coming up correctly. Examples would be: DDR (you see the arrows and know the rhythm so you know how to play them) Amplitude (You can clearly see all the circles coming up and what rhythm and order you have to play them in), guitar hero/rock band (similar to amplitude, you can see the notes coming up and know the rhythm you need to play them in and what order)

This games visuals make it very difficult to see whats coming up next, and things just pop up infront of you and give you only about 1-2 seconds to react at best. As such the developpers added "Audio Cues" that tell you whats coming up to allow you to listen, hear the rhythm and beat and what you have to do, and then go with it. The problem is that the audio cues are too faint and hard to distinguished and so, many times you get caught because you cant hear/see what you have to do and get killed in a cheap annoying way. This ruins the "rhythm" aspect of the game, and instead you have to memorize certain parts of the tracks since its just easier then trying to listen to what you have to do. I have played a lot of rhythm games in the past, and this game is really close to beating all of them. It just needs this one little adjustement and it would be absolutely amazing. instead it just ends up being frustrating and cheap to play.
If the audio cues were better, this game would instantly be one of my favorite rhythm games of all time. And right now, it still kinda is a rhythm-music game, it just doesn't do the rhythm-music part right.

I don't want the game to be easier, i don't want the game to change its own style, its a fast paced rhythm violence game. The problem i have is that the audio cues just mix in TOO much with the music in the background. While the visuals outright block whats coming up, most notably, in the tunnel sections, leading to some very cheap and annoying deaths that can only be avoided by memorizing the track. I can hear the audio cues sometimes, i know what they are, but if its going to market itself as, and i quote:
"Thumper is rhythm violence: classic rhythm-action, blistering speed, and brutal physicality. "
(taken straight from the steam "About This Game" section,  "classic rhythm-action is clearly stated here, and in the description aswell.)
then i expect the rhythm part to also be a major part of the game, and for it to be consistently clear and important. Its definintely trying to be, its just not succeeding at it. 

The game also has the Rhythm and Music tags to it, so you can't tell me its not trying to also be a rhythm game. I know its trying to be a mix of rhythm and bullet hell style, where things come at you in large numbers and quickly, giving you little time to react, but rhythm games thrive on having easy visuals, but difficult rhythms that are still clear. bullet hells are good at having really clear visuals that are hard to avoid. This game fails at both.
But it comes very close to doing it right, if steam allowed neutral reviews i would give it one, but it doesn't.
In the end you CAN go with the rhythm, but only after you've memorized the tracks already. You can't use both your eyes and ears to know whats coming up and then do it perfectly everytime simply because you're that good at music and reacting. In this game, when you get stuck in a tunnel, the audio cues are faint and hard to hear, so you rely on your eyes, only for the game to throw two sudden walls when you couldn't possibly see the second wall until it was already too late. And if the audio cue was just a little bit more obvious then it would be purely up to the player to hear it, realise what he has to do, and then do it in the rhythm of the song.

I cannot hear the audio cues and so i cannot do the right actions to the rhythm of the game because the visuals block most of what you can see at times. And so, its clear the developpers wanted to add something to fix this issue, which is the audio cues ive mentioned many times. But these are too hard to hear, to difficult to distinguish in the song, and so everything falls apart, the visuals end up being distracting more then impressive, the difficulty becomes more cheap then challenging, and the music aspect becomes more reaction based then rhythm based. One small change could make everything i've just mentioned worked. And until that change to the audio cues is done, this review is gonna stay negative.

review: Frightening, heart-stopping, wicked. Within the fouled skies of the void a jet-black highway pierces the colorful clouds that surrounds it while rythm and harmony rot. Every rest is an oasis of false safety. You can't go slower. Master every beat, every corner and every hop and instead of a descent into the scorching hellish void this psychedelic journey will be a race trhough the brightest stars.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988437235', 'num_games_owned': 836, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 11888, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 694, 'last_played': 1691096494}
review:
I've never been a fan of rhythm games like Rock Band or Guitar Hero. Although I like music focused games, I don't think just putting a rhythm spreadsheed over existing written music can make an extraordinarily well designed game. And now here's Thumper, a game that looks, on the surface, a lot like Audiosurf, but at its core, it's something much, much different.

You're a beetle, riding down a lane with an ever increasing speed, having to dodge obstacles and trying to get combos by performing rhythmically accurate actions. It's so simple and yet so difficult. The difference to Audiosurf lies in the design of and the interplay between music and the levels. Everything is produced with the gameplay experience in mind. Levels build up on each other. Simply the fact that the time signature increases one beat per level shows how the developers intended to get a pacing into the game that could never be there with generative levels.

While I do think, Thumper hasn't realized its full potential and some improvements could have been included, I must say that I had tons of fun and even more tons of frustration just barely making it through the 9 levels alive. To me, this game is probably the best music game I have played since 140.

Highly recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561197968173607', 'num_games_owned': 206, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 1273, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 395, 'last_played': 1537636498}
review:
My brain hurts...

Learning curve is pretty normal at the start and goes totally bonkers after the middle of the game, but it's never unfair.
Excellent game for thouse who are into extrem skill based games and/or rythm based games.

For people without borderline masochism... hummm dunno if I would recommend it to you.
The rush you get from the neck breaking speed and sound is for everyone the same, but maybe you would lose interest/give up after 3-4 levels B-cuz you can get the feeling of slow progress. Or there is a part you just can't get through, something that will definitly happen a lot.

The game itself is a rare gem, but not for everyone I suppose.  ; ]

author: {'steamid': '76561198005579075', 'num_games_owned': 589, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 376, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 104, 'last_played': 1588377984}
review:
TL;DR: If you're here for the rhythm aspect, I would stay away until an update fixes some things. If you're here for the high octane, "game-feel" defining gameplay,  and don't mind purely reaction-based stuff, this is your game.




I bought this game under the assumption that the focus of this game was rhythm. That's not the case, however. Where the game fails as a rhythm game, it succeeds as a reaction/memorization game. Though this game is SO frustratingly close to being an excellent rhythm game, there are a few details that keep it far from that title.


The visuals, while absolutely stunning, detract from the clarity of the game mechanics. Whenever you go through tunnels, the wall obstacles make the player turn a sharp corner, which prevents you from seeing obstacles that are around it. It also doesn't help when the color of the tunnel interior matches the orange glow of the wall; making it practically invisible. It cheapens the game's difficulty.


Absolutely none of that would be an issue if the audio cues that indicate which obstacles you'll have to avoid next were clear and distinct. They sadly aren't. They are unreasonably quiet, a fact that is painfully clear when the sound of dodging the current obstacle, plus the roaring tribal drums completely eclipse it. The cues also sound too similar to each other. When dozens of sound cues are constantly bombarding your ears, you need to be able to distinguish between them subconsciously. Vary the pitches, make the sounds have fundamentally different textures, anything you can to make them clear as crystal. The current system is simply too muddy to be useful at all.




All in all, if you like reaction-based "endless runner" style games and aren't afraid to do some track memorization for some of the S ranks, you'll really enjoy this game. This honestly may be one of the best "feeling" games I've ever played. Every time you clang into a turn or crash through a bar, it leaves a palpable and utterly satisfying impact. 


If you came here expecting a new rhythm game to grind at and master, you're gonna be disappointed. I really hope the devs touch up the game and really nail the little things, so you can play the game musically.  I can't help but feel a bit mislead by the "Rhythm Violence" tagline, as I don't feel it quite meets the standards of a  rhythm game. For me personally, it's not worth $20 in it's current state, that's the reason I refunded the game. I would be more than happy to re-purchase it when these issues are addressed or when the game goes on sale.


Thanks for reading. (I've said the word "rhythm" way too many times.)

author: {'steamid': '76561197986478744', 'num_games_owned': 472, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 250, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 250, 'last_played': 1477328987}
review: A fantastic and relentless rythm game. Excellent aesthetic and soundtrack. Tons of fun and super challenging. So satisfying when it all clicks.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063064475', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 105, 'playtime_forever': 370, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 186, 'last_played': 1615498780}
review:
An enjoyable fast-paced game.  You get quite a lot of content if your reactions are quite slow, starts to get tough at the end of Level 3 with very fast left-right turns that seem to trip me up all the time.

The disappointing issue is that you can't replay stages - you have to replay the whole Level with 20+ stages.  This reduces replayability for me, as I want to improve my score on small sections, not have to play long levels.  I hope the developers can add an option to replay parts (not letting me submit highscores is fine).

With being forced to play whole levels and potentially hitting a wall quite soon, I'm not sure my playtime will go much past 5 hours.  But let's see if the developers give any updates that help give longer total game playtime to us older players.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033558515', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 541, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 164, 'last_played': 1686804123}
review:
Like hurling yourself down Yog-Sothoth's spinal chord in the black depths of the supermassive black hole at the center of our galaxy. At a quarter the speed of light. While on LSD.

That's the closest comparison I can make to what playing this game is like.

Thumper is the most intense and terrifying euphoria I have ever experienced. Thumper is not for the faint of heart, and it does not fuck around. By the time I'd finished the first level, my hands were shaking, my ears were ringing, and my thumbs hurt from how hard I was jamming the A button into my controller. And I fucking loved it.

10/10 would gaze upon the face of god again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198327925889', 'num_games_owned': 188, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 7254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1891, 'last_played': 1701547924}
review:
Thumper: A game you can FEEL!!!!!.... and you can Quote me on that...

Edit: Dec/20/2016

So after I was done screaming of excitement over the VR support being added yesterday, I set my Oculus up again and (after makeing sure the seting for allowing unknown sorces use the headset to ON) I went from level 8-5 (which i had been stuck on for 2 weeks) to beating the entirety of level 9 in under an hour today (completion time aprox 25 hours)! If anything I think playing it in VR is.. Easyer in a way... But thats not bad! IT IS SOOOOO SURREAL! I've played 3 games in VR, War Thunder, Lucky's Tale and this... This is the best I've played! I love the new camera angle, it's almost like your sitting on the beetle!... RECOMENDATION TO ALL: If you have 300 bucks and a good computer, get a freaking vive or oculus and play this in VR you WILL NO regret it (but your stomach might! ( Õ°¬∞ Õú ñ Õ°¬∞) ) anywho Thankyou for makeing this game. It is truly somethin else.



This game is just... where do I start. The Graphics are amazing and simple, the color style is brilliant, and the gameplay... ohhh the gameplay. Ive got about 9 hours under my belt at the time of this review with about 8 levels done on Level 5 and at this point I can say is my favorite part of this game is the boss battles not just the final ones but the mini/mid bosses as well especialy with (i think it was level 3 introduces it) the Stomp 'attack' that is just sooo satisfying to do on the final 'cube' to fire a shot at the boss (the last little bit of the trailer shows this attack). I consider this game one with a rhythm that you can feel, one that sends chills up your spine every time you play it. Although one problem that i have.. its probably nitpicking but ill say it anyway, is also what makes this game good.. the speed.. yes this game is supposed to be fast but i sometimes find myself not able to keep up with whats going on.. and this is comeing from someone who loves speed games... but again its probably nitpicking anywho I give this game my final rateing of 10/10 (since my only complant is a nitpick) Buy this game and let your fingers impress you.. thats all i have to say, and if youre recording this for Youtube like I am... I recomend haveing a camera pointed at your hand.. a 'handcam' of sorts. I know I will

author: {'steamid': '76561198190684322', 'num_games_owned': 814, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1211, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 556, 'last_played': 1543302678}

author: {'steamid': '76561198176718471', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 534, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 426, 'last_played': 1515547886}
review:
Pretty heafty on the price for the content, albeit still fun.

Plays well with keyboard and controller.

So, lets begin with the pros - a very interesting aproach to a rythm game which fully utilizes its one dimentional environment. The visuals are pretty nice, the space theme seems to suit this very well and reminds me of the original TapTap :). Adds lots of new obstacles as the game progresses, kepts it fresh.

Now, unfortunately the cons - the music is a bit too quite compared to the sound effects that you produce, in the first levels it isn't as noticable as in later levels where there are more obstacles. The music seems very very similar through out levels, and what slight variation there is gets masked by th esound effects. A lot of obstacle "combos" repeat, like "long left", "long right", "long left", "long right", these repeat on a lot of levels and get very predictable. Also the general route seems to be "left", "obstacles", "right", "obstacles", you rarely encounter more than 3 turns in the same direction in a row, so it is very predictable. Finally the thing I absolutely hate, why try to make a level harder by simply making it last ages? Also if you do intend in making harder levels longer, make them consisten, that is start with the shortest level and end with the longest (not counting "bosses", which are a very nice touch in my opinion). Seriousely, I currently just finished "world 6", and the fith last level (if I remember correctly) lasted a good minute, the next level over in 10-15 seconds. 

Overall it is a nice challenging game, the challenge curve was a little to small for my taste as I havent died once untill towards world 3 but enjoy the challenge that the game is presenting to me right now. I rate this as "recommended" as I enjoy the gameplay, the music is a HUGE let down, considering this is a music game but still. I would like the price to be somewhere around ¬£8-9 at most ¬£10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061419106', 'num_games_owned': 285, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 249, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 208, 'last_played': 1518877256}
review:
Thumper is a fast-paced and exciting rhythm game, into which I can see myself pouring countless hours into. The music is unique, and the art style of the game is something unlike anything I've ever seen before. It's something that's new and fresh in a genre that isn't quite so new, and it goes about it in such a way, that it almost deserves it's own sub-genre.

In totality, Thumper is an experience altogether hard to describe, unless you experience it for yourself.

review:
My hands were sweating and I had to keep drying them.

The visuals and atmosphere were incredible. If you look at playthroughs, it seems like it would be impossible to see the actual game elements coming at you with so much trying to distract you, yet it flows very nicely.

Another thing is the music. I personally like the music, but if you don't like what you hear in the trailer, this game probably isn't for you. On the other hand, if you started tapping to the beat, you'll love it!

[strike]One warning: The game mechanics aren't entirely described in the game, so you may never discover things like smashing a beat while flying to restore your health. There's a slightly more complete manual at http://thumpergame.com/manual[/strike] Actually that is demonstrated in-game; some of the bosses downright require it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077849193', 'num_games_owned': 117, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2385, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 613, 'last_played': 1697446515}
review:
The music, visuals & fast-paced gameplay blend seamlessly. Sometimes visuals and speed are so overwhelmig that you have to rely only on your instincts and feeling of rhythm to overcome obstacles. In these moments the game sucks you in completely, you lose the sense of presence, time and space all the while being bombarded with violent psychedelic visuals provoking truly ecstatic experience.

All in all Thumper is a very masterfully crafted game but it could use more variety. All the game mechanics are introduced largely when you are halfway through the game. The game throws some new stuff here and there but it feels as though these bits and pieces could have been developed further to really unravel the game's potential. That's why as much as I hate the very idea and concept of DLCs I would love developers to come up with a few of them introducing unexpected twists to a solid foundation that exists already.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055612372', 'num_games_owned': 242, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 644, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 644, 'last_played': 1477746393}
review: The game really gives you this wardrums feeling. this awesome serious war feeling, it is kind of like geometry dash but the beats does always fit with your move, ALWAYS.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962318796', 'num_games_owned': 1335, 'num_reviews': 429, 'playtime_forever': 93, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1577746392}
review:
There's an underlying sinister tone to everything here, from the visuals to the soundtrack. The art design is like some bizarre fusion between Journey's music album cover art circa 1980 and Lovecraftian cosmic horror. The sound and music is like someone made a rhythm game out of early 80's industrial music, or at least the parts where people banged on random things in their songs.

The entire presentation feels violent, and it just completely sucks you in.

Play it in a pitch-black and silent room on a big screen and with headphones... or in VR. Because holy shit if this isn't the most exciting thing to happen to rhythm games since plastic guitars.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993262862', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 205, 'last_played': 1485649573}
review: Exhiliarating. Mind-blowing. A purely psychedelic trip. Thumper is undoubtedly the most intense and violent rhythm game you'll ever play. Think MAD MAX: Fury Road on acid. 'Existential dread' is the perfect phrase to describe this experience. *WARNING* - you may begin to fall into a hypnotic trance where you question Life and whether you are merely an insignificant bug, endlessly dodging and hurling into unexpected obstacles until Death takes you, swift and merciless. Yes, eventually I began driving over the dotted lines on the freeway and trying to drift + A when I saw lane dividers. 99/10 would die again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023483029', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 799, 'last_played': 1653651856}
review:
This game is incredible. I got so tense playing this that I had to conciously tell myself to relax a bit. Especially since I wanted to keep playing, but my thumb was starting to hurt.

I got 12-13h for my 20 Euros and I think it was well worth it. If you just do the minimal of combos you might have a shorter experience, though not sure how you'll survive the later bosses if you don't use all the mechanics.

I kind of would like to also see it in VR, but you don't need a VR headset to play this. The devs have also been quick to implement requested features like a quick restart so maybe we'll get more Thumper down the line. But for now after finishing it I feel like I should take a nap.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120331550', 'num_games_owned': 143, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 2218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2218, 'last_played': 1483707657}
review:
THUMPER - A pSycho-dellic rhythmic adrenaline fueled rollercoaster ride to hell.  

Now that I've 100% the game's achievements I feel that I have enough knowledge of the game to review it.  First and foremost, playtime & difficulty.  It took me 9 hours to beat the base game and took 9 more hours to complete all levels with an S rank.  For the majority of players it should take you beyond that much time and may even take some less than that time.  I don't recommend the game for casuals as you'll die in two hits, there are ways that the player may choose to make the game easier but can still be hard to beat.  

Next, the base game.  You'll boot up the game, choose the first level, get a quick tutorial of some of the basic and most important mechanics and will then start to get into some regular levels.  Even though most view a tutorial in games as bad I feel as if it's really important here since without it you may not be able to finish it and will get frustrated.  It's satisfying to hear the loud drum percussion of each wall, red bar, and blue ring and also provides the player a visual heads-up so they can plan their next move (as is with most rhythm games).  Each Level has a boss and an "Omega" final boss with sub-levels inbetween.  If you are struggling with a section it's always safe to hold spacebar and preemptively hold the arrow key of the wall that you're approaching, thump pads and red bars, and blue rings that appear on the track are optional and can be avoided in sub-levels.  However, the level boss and final boss have green thump pads which require you to hit each one in order to deal damage to the boss, if one is missed the level will loop until the player has either died or successfully hit every thump.  The final level is not only incredibly challenging and rewarding when you beat each section but also has one of the best endings of any games i've experienced this year, well worth the trip there.

Secondly, S Ranks, and advanced moves.  S Ranks on sub-levels, boss, and final boss levels are reached by getting a large score percentage in each level, it's possible to miss some thump pads and get damaged on some walls and still beat a section with an S rank.  S Ranks are not easy, you'll have to replay a sub-level multiple times in order to achieve it but is an excellent challenge for those willing to attempt it.  Advanced  moves range from perfect turns, stomping, and kills.  Perfect turns are preformed by pressing the arrow key at the last possible moment before reaching the wall and is rewarded by a higher score and a satisfying sound effect.  As you start to feel the rhythm of the levels these will start to become easier to perform.  Stomping is achieved by pressing up and holding spacebar when reaching a thump pad and pressing down instead of spacebar when reaching another thump pad.  If your score multiplier is 2x or 3x (shown in the top right and plays a sound when reached)  The player will spawn a glowing thump pad which can restore your shield if you lost it and has a marginal difference in score gain then regular thump pads.  If you thump on a glowing thump pad in a sub-level the game will temporarily pause and spawn another thump pad, giving you a small amount of extra time to view the track so you can act accordingly to the enviornment. Tentacles growing on the track can actually be destroyed!  By stomping on any thump pad tentacles that are in front of you will be killed which both clears the screen giving you more vision of the track and adds to your score at the end (displayed by Kills x #).  

Lastly, issues and closing thoughts.  Two of my major gripes with the game is the lack of an option to display your score on the hud, and that [b][strike]you need to restart the level from the beginning if you get an A or worse while attempting the (All S Rank) challenge.  The game provides you with a quick restart button "R" which allows you to restart a sub-level but should provide the player with a way to re-do "failed" levels to not deliberately waste yout time and erase your progress.  This happened to me several times and would've completed every level with an S rank more quickly if the option to re-do levels was implemented.[/strike][/b] (SEE EDIT)  Overall I enjoyed beginning to end in the game, the game seems fairly linear and limited at first but will introduce new concepts and unique boss types/changing final boss that both challenge and interest the player.  I recommend the game particularly for those who are accustomed to and seek challenge and for those who would like to try a difficult game out.  Below is the S Rank for Level 9 for those interested (Spoiler warning)!

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=784915834

EDIT 11/4/2016: You can now restart from the previous sub-level if you get a score that's less than an S so I only have one gripe with the game now, it's a shame this change couldn't have come on launch day but it's a much appreciated and welcome change.  Good job devs!

Have a great day!

author: {'steamid': '76561197993029514', 'num_games_owned': 298, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 258, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 258, 'last_played': 1477127024}
review:
I don't normally write reviews, but I felt I had to for this game.

I thought I was really bad at first, but I was using a bluetooth controller - switching to a USB controller made things immediately better. I also had my PC connected to my TV at the time, when I switched to my monitor, I was nailing the levels. If you're having lag issues, switch to a wired controller and your normal monitor.

It's a game with microsecond timing, and if you lose your rhythm the whole thing can go to shit instantly. But when you nail the timing you feel like a god.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993440292', 'num_games_owned': 713, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 105, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 96, 'last_played': 1489845212}
review:
When I noticed this game a year ago, it left a big hole in my soul, which I wanted to fill immediately, but couldn't.
This game has such a unique style, while combining all the familiar aspects of a good rythm-game, that you just can't really replace it.
So I tell you what, being a fan of games that require perfect timing for your actions - this one got me on a first try.
It's just so satisfying to play it... Like the same level of satisfaction as getting successfull riposts in the Dark Souls series. It just feels right and you want more of it.
Will I recommend it to everyone? Certainly not, this game is pretty demanding (though, not unreasanoble), but for the rythm-game fan - it's a blessing. Go buy one, and get the soundtrack too, it's damn awesome!

author: {'steamid': '76561198118669906', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1150, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 374, 'last_played': 1694379608}

author: {'steamid': '76561198145764128', 'num_games_owned': 247, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 427, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 427, 'last_played': 1476902102}
review:
Thumper is a Rhythm game that has incredibly simple controls yet keeps you highly enguaged with its hypnotic visuals, violent progressive sound track and overall style, I'm highly enjoying it.

---Thumper is best played in short bursts as it can cause headaches and eye pain after a while due to being very visually demanding so if you've got sensitive eyes just be aware of that---

author: {'steamid': '76561198012173134', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 356, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 356, 'last_played': 1477102440}
review:
Challenging and visually appealing, was positively surprised. Would recommend to anyone who's into rhythm games.   
Having said that, there's some minor problems that you should keep in mind before buying.  

- Thumper is designed around chasing highscores.   
The first reason is the way of "clearing" levels. You clear a level by reaching the next checkpoint, but this can be simply done by ignoring most of the objects and only avoiding real obstacles. All you need to do to progress, is to survive. This also applies to levels you'll face later on. Now of course this takes away the fun from a rhythm game and you wouldn't intentionally abuse this, but it will happen. 
The second reason is the amount of playtime needed to finish the game. After 6 hours I completed the game and all that is left, is to chase highscores on each level.   
   
- Some levels don't scale logically.  
The beginning is easy, the end is hard. But inbetween you might struggle on one final boss and clear the next with ease. The same applies to consecutive parts of a level. I couldn't help but feel like some parts were just added as fillers or simply placed in the wrong level.  

Considering that some aspects of Thumper could use some more fine-tuning, I would still recommend the game as a whole. But if you're not the kind of person who tries to get the highest scores, I'd suggest you wait until the game is on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963835468', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 405, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 240, 'last_played': 1689627531}
review:
Thumper is as though someone took the foundations of Amplitude or Audiosurf but took the genre in a different direction. Crafting levels and songs that complement each other perfectly and increasing difficulty by adding new mechanics and obstacles to overcome rather than increasing BPM and notes.
Interestingly, Thumper is not unlike a shoot 'em up game in some ways. A niche game in a niche genre, to be sure, and while those who pick up the game casually might prioritize "merely" surviving checkpoint to checkpoint (a fun and very challenging task requiring a good ear and better processing speed/reflexes), the game is a scoring challenge at heart. The game becomes more about strategy and balancing risk/reward so one can safely complete an entire level while maximizing score without losing health, dropping a beat or having to rely on a checkpoint and losing score multipliers. 

Hopefully, the devs will continue fine-tuning the small annoyances (a task they have done very well at so far) and add additional content (perhaps in the form of DLC tracks) and propel the game to the masterpiece status it deserves.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008042890', 'num_games_owned': 454, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 1489854660}
review:
There are two problems with this game :
- The "song" or "track" you're supposed to follow, is playing its sound 1-2 seconds in advance, so that you can predict by listening what you will have to do. BUT this "track" is just too low in volume to be heared when playing, as you also produce sound by correctly following the track.  
I think the reasoning behind it, was the track should be playable the first time you play. 
But in doing that, there is a lot of frustration comming from it, as you are constantly trying to appreciate the feeling of correctly playing the track, but at the same time concentrating on listening the 1 seconds offseted track you're suppose to play.
- The visuals effects are very annoying to estimate distance between you and the next "thing" you should tap onto.
This is produce situation where in 7 levels you're estimating the distance without thinking, and just at the boss level, each time you successfully hit him you fail miserably at the first "thing" you should tap.
The track shaking is the best example of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990336513', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1028, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 982, 'last_played': 1496102108}
review: Just beat all the levels, and I gota say, this is an amazing game, the visuals are out of this world and the game play is fun. Super glad that I bought it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965922642', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 170, 'last_played': 1551506212}
review: Unique graphics and AMAZING soundtrack.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998943420', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 1028, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 485, 'last_played': 1564106048}
review:
An insanely polished score-chasing rhythm/action game with a high-ish difficulty curve.

Even if you don't typically play games to get high scores, each level can be difficult enough to take some time on its own, depending on your reflexes. Controlling your chrome beetle feels great, there are generally enough cues to let you know what's ahead and everything about the sound and visuals is vaguely unsettling.

There aren't too many mechanics to learn, but they are enough to keep things interesting throughout every level and for only using one button, they manage quite a lot. Occasionally the difficulty curve can be uneven, you can start a level having a hard time, then the middle is relatively manageable but then it goes back to being very difficult at the end. Most of the time it's pretty consistent though.

Thumper has a ton of replay value too, given that you're ranked in every section of every level it does well to make you want that "S" rank, not only with the score but also when you hit every obstacle, it adds to the soundtrack, like a strange extra drum beat.

I've been waiting for this for a good long while and I'm so, so glad that it's satisfying. 100% recommended and I would be totally on board for a sequel. Also, thanks for not copping out and giving a "USE A CONTROLLER" splash screen. It plays perfectly fine on a keyboard.

author: {'steamid': '76561198145694358', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 1493, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 428, 'last_played': 1617398285}
review:
A visually stunning rythm game. Every 'thump' feels incredibly powerful and in later levels when executing a string of thumps and turns perfectly just makes your adrenaline go wild.

The difficulty scales well in my opinion, but I do have a lot of experience with rythm games. People who don't might struggle a bit more on the earlier levels. Luckily there are many checkpoints and restarting happens in a smooth continuous fashion. Dying is not as frustrating as in other rythm games.

Because it's a fairly new game there are some bugs and issues. But the development team is bringing regular updates which solve the most requested issues. I myself posted a technical issue and received an answer in less than two days.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043149228', 'num_games_owned': 313, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 2133, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1416, 'last_played': 1545952900}
review:
- La carrera fractal -

Thumper es sin duda, una de las grandes sorpresas del a√±o para mi. Hac√≠a ya un tiempo que no jugaba a algo que solo utilizara un bot√≥n de acci√≥n; todas las acciones r√≠tmicas se llevan a cabo con las direcciones y un bot√≥n. Es tan simplista en mec√°nicas que ni te lo tienen que explicar, enseguida entiendes el prop√≥sito.

Como juego musical r√°pidamente se conjuga con la acci√≥n: hay jefes, e incuso puedes matar fractales, tent√°culos y trozos de escenario haciendo combos. No sabes en ning√∫n momento si te est√°s guiando por el sonido, por la vista, o por la memoria (o todo a la vez), pues el ensayo y el error es necesario, sobre todo, si queremos la S, puntuaci√≥n perfecta. Para este prop√≥sito existen checkpoints al final de cada peque√±a fase o tramo. Hay 9 mundos subdivididos en fases, si mueres, reapareces al principio de esa fase. El objetivo es cruzar los aros intentando tomar bien las curvas, saltando los obst√°culos, rompiendo aquellos que se puedan, pulsando tambi√©n las luces del suelo, que son las que permiten que saltemos o matar a los jefes.

El juego adquiere un frenetismo y una exigencia muy alta ya a partir del mundo 6, a√±adiendo hasta aqu√©l reglas nuevas: cada mundo es como el anterior pero aprendiendo una nueva mec√°nica, que se conjugar√°n de foma endiablada ya por el final. Ojal√° bastase s√≥lo el o√≠do, esa es la mala noticia: Thumper no es un juego r√≠tmico sin m√°s. Es una aventura, una carrera donde la vista y los reflejos de tus pulgares es casi m√°s importante que lo que se oye. 

Los jefes son una aut√©ntica pasada: han creado un g√©nero nuevo con esto. Para poder matarlos hay que hacer las secuencias correctamente hasta que aparezca el disparador. A los 4 golpes, el jefe muere. Tu escarabajo cibern√©tico puede morir de dos simples golpes, pero podemos recuperarnos en ciertos puntos. M√°s adelante luchar√°s m√°s por memorizar d√≥nde recuperarte que en hacer los tramos a la perfecci√≥n. En ese √°mbito el juego suma m√°s del triple y cu√°druple de horas, a m√°s exigente quieras ser, a m√°s elegante quieras realizar tu partida, m√°s horas te demandar√° Thumper.

Una banda sonora contundente y que va dando pistas de los elementos que van a aparecer, ya que se basa en la m√∫sica. Pero que no os enga√±en; hay que tener mucho m√°s √©nfasis en lo que se ve que en lo que se oye. Con todo ello, un trabajo supremo.

Thumper es el juego de acci√≥n perfecto camuflado tras una propuesta mel√≥dica. Es un viaje psicod√©lico y adrenal√≠nico por el surrealismo, mundos fractales, geom√©tricos y pesadillescos. No tengo muy claro si este juego surgi√≥ de un mal sue√±o, pero parece tejido con elementos que dan bastante mal rollo.

No siempre se necesita algo cinematogr√°fico para sorprender. Thumper es simple, muy simple, y funciona a la perfecci√≥n.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965361589', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 259, 'playtime_forever': 1964, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 613, 'last_played': 1686518081}
review:
Phenomenal.
A simple wordless tutorial gets you started.
Immediately, you're struck with the blunt thump that will guide you through the rest of the game.
Gradually, more controls are taught, the complexity and speed ramp up, the visual spectacle blossoms, and the beat grows heavier.
By the end, your hands are a flurry, and your eyes refuse to blink.
Don't come here expecting to ride your own music.
It's the track that makes the "music".
The developer, Drool, is impressively present in the forums, and have already acted on constructive feedback from the community.
I had reached the end after 9 hours of play, but I'm far from finished playing simply due to enjoying the ride so much.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040692932', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 333, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 174, 'last_played': 1495492052}
review: It's... a rush. If your fingers get sore easily, you have low stamina for sustained high stress, or you get frustrated easily, probably not the game for you. But damn if it isn't a hell of a time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012627238', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1228, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 703, 'last_played': 1683856828}
review: Thumper, while having absolutely no story, has simple, but extremely challenging gameplay. It's punishing when you don't follw its beat, but it is merciful if you can't get every point, and even then, you would have this really odd sensation to come back and perfect what you've missed. The psychedelic visuals of polygonal tunnels amidst a sky that resembles the Aurora Borealis, powerful time signatures with high-speed tempo, and bosses with complex rhythmic segments will make you question your sanity and sense of rhythm, but the satisfaction from defeating those bosses, getting every rhythm down, and overcoming obstacles you thought was otherwise impossible will assuredly keep you coming back for more. To those hungry for a challenge of reflex, rhythm and memory, you've come to the right place.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038278354', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 716, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 399, 'last_played': 1691512728}
review:

I could wax lyrically about the many incredible and defining features of this game, but then you'd be wasting your time reading this review instead of buying it and playing it. 

Get. This. Game

author: {'steamid': '76561197994004562', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 467, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 467, 'last_played': 1476725172}
review:
Best game of the year so far! Best rhythm game I've played in a good while! Reminds me of the excellent Super Hexagon, and of Runner2: Future Legend of Rhythm Alien. The gameplay is absolutely intense and the music is amazing, plus the game loods terrific! 

My quibbles about this game are extremely minor (sometimes "slamming" seems to occlude the visuals a bit too much). The game is a bloody masterpiece.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975431568', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4344, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 837, 'last_played': 1683813953}
review:
Drool has made a fan out of me.

Playing Thumper is like playing through a terrifying musical score, with abstract cover art being transformed into the main visual setting in which you are navigating through with aggressive rhythm. There is nothing more satisfying in a rhythm game than feeling like you are the performer in the music. This game succeeds in this, rewarding skillful execution with amazingly impactful sounds and visuals, elevating the audio-visual experience to jaw-dropping levels.

Not since Rez have I played a music game that executed its vision so perfectly. This will be a timeless classic. I am sure of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987642512', 'num_games_owned': 1118, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 384, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 188, 'last_played': 1566404123}
review: Like Rez, Amplitude and Audiosurf had a demonic lovechild. Fast intense beats, synaesthesia like immersion and an incredible, simple artstyle and gameplay loop I can highly recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997274496', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 57, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 57, 'last_played': 1476381456}
review: Insanely intense so far!

author: {'steamid': '76561198010520957', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 836, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 546, 'last_played': 1639911402}
review:
No game has demanded such intense concentration from me before. To THUMP perfectly you must THUMP yourself into a trance. This may take minutes, hours or days but once you reach that perfect zen of THUMP, you feel unstoppable. And it feels good!  

  The game requires undivided attention and punishes unmercifully, but the learning curve is very gradual and forgiving. If you're a fan of rhythm games it's a must-have hands down. There's more than enough replay value for the $20 price tag and it's a beautifully crafted game. The way the gameplay flows it's easy to have long play sessions and get stuck in the trance, however progress is saved fairly so if you need to dip out or are just plain overwhemled (some stages feel like an uncontrollable, never ending rollercoaster), then you aren't punished for taking a break. 

  Overall it's a game that demands love, attention and perfection but in the end it gives back as much as you put in. Highly recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561198022914679', 'num_games_owned': 380, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 144, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 101, 'last_played': 1595715760}

author: {'steamid': '76561197963764030', 'num_games_owned': 231, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 530, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 461, 'last_played': 1520058714}
review:
I can't express enough how blown away I am by this game.  This game is incredibly beautiful, intense, and nightmarish all bottled into one package.  It emits a breath of fresh air to gaming.  The visuals in this game are superb.  I would recommend this to anyone who is an audiophile with a great sound system, and/or a 1080p projector to flood your eyes and ears with this candy.

Pros:  
Intense
High replay value (Due to highscore board and grading system)
Beautiful
Amazing soundtrack

Cons:
I didn't realize my fingers were pushing the buttons so hard that they hurt afterwards.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978347625', 'num_games_owned': 461, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 3548, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1515, 'last_played': 1694398208}
review: Fantastic game in just about every way. Great music, beautiful graphics, and ridiculously well optimized gameplay. It's very difficult; don't think otherwise. But it's the [i]good[/i] kind of difficulty. I screwed up a lot, but never once did I feel it was the game's fault. No cheap deaths or near-impossible sections. Every bit of each level truly feels passable, and every failed attempt left me feeling one step closer to overcoming it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018983229', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 114, 'last_played': 1507107471}

author: {'steamid': '76561198040884867', 'num_games_owned': 2434, 'num_reviews': 901, 'playtime_forever': 175, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 151, 'last_played': 1502406233}
review:
[b]Absolute brutality.[/b]

That's how to describe this game. You don't just play a casual round of [i]Thumper[/i]. In fact you really don't 'play' this game as much as you hang on and let the experience throw you around. [b][i]Thumper[/i] is awesome.[/b] I don't think I've had an experience like this, maybe ever. 

Even after I watched the trailer and a few LetsPlay videos, I couldn't really 'get' what you do or what is going on. I'll try to explain. This isn't a rhythm game like [i]DDR[/i]. To a certain extent things go along to the beat, but from my experience, you really can't rely on that. This is more like an endless runner like [i]Boson X[/i] or something, where you hit a button at a certain event. You see a turn? Hit a direction plus 'A'. You see a solid marker on the ground, hit 'A' to jump. Things like this.

But what really sets this title apart is the experience. The music and sound is so badass. The levels are beautiful, and the controls are tight. [b]Playing with it loud is mandatory.[/b]

[b]Pros:[/b]
+Totally original experience as far as I'm concerned
+Music couldn't be more awesome, and this isn't typically my genre
+Tight controls, and this really matters here
+Awesome twitch-style gameplay where it's always your fault when you lose
+While 9(?) levels seems short, it's really not; after 2 hours I was at the end of level 2

[b]Cons:[/b]
-It [i]seems[/i] pricey, but IMO it is worth it
-Best played in long play sessions (not so much a 'con', but I thought I'd throw that out there)

[b]Wild experience.[/b] Even if you don't want to pay full price, you [i]need[/i] to try this at some point.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011479897', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 219, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 183, 'last_played': 1504211621}
review: I bought this game as per a Reddit review, and I have to say, not a single thing he said was incorrect. This game was very well executed, pleasantly challenging, great music, and my god I love the style of the graphics. Most certainly worth the purchase.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031725194', 'num_games_owned': 1271, 'num_reviews': 309, 'playtime_forever': 1298, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 966, 'last_played': 1659283818}
review:
(More details on scoring and leaderboard at the end)

This is bloody brilliant.

It's one of the few games that I can see most people enjoying based on the gameplay alone, yet still manages to introduce something very alien and unique through its art (both in its audio and visuals).

The shortest description I can give is that it's something out of 2001: Space Odyssey? The weird part. The really, really crazy part.

And it's beautiful.


The game can get tough, but it never seemed unfair, to me. I really enjoyed the challenge and now I'm planning to go through it all over again several time to master it... why? Because the flow of the game is amazing. It's a rollercoaster, in many ways... But it's hard to judge it when you have to restart some levels repeatedly. I'm curious about how it would feel to go through it in one single run. ... It might take a while, though.


The music is very interesting, and probably not something for your mp3. Brian Gibson has a "noise rock" band, which is... noisy? The game itself is what I would call "noise classical", perhaps? Know the discordant violins in horror movies? That's a big of part of this.
The other part is the industrial/metallic tribal percussion.
It's strange, but it's perfect for the game.

The visuals are also very abstract and metallic, but very beautiful, in parts. Something harmonious, sometimes discordant as well. And always very alien.

The "feel" of the game is some of the best I've seen in any game... ever?
It's that good. If you string combos together, your hits become very powerful, complementing the strange rhythm of the music with the rhythm of the level, which are not always "cooperative".


I can't say much more about it, for now. But it's amazing!
If you're looking for a rhythm game in the vein of Guitar Hero or Stepmania, this is not at all for you. It's not about playing your own music... This game is its own beast. If you're not into its aesthetic (which I can imagine many people are not?), you will probably not enjoy the game very much... some people consider it all to blend together. I disagree, but I can see that happening, depending on what you're expecting. 

So yeah. If the videos seem cool, definitely get it. There's a lot more to the game than shown in the videos due to the visceral feeling and impact of the game.

So good!



P.S.: I've now beaten the game twice, to see how much it would change. On general terms, there's definitely replayability without wanting to climb the leaderboards. This is because you can still play the previous levels in a very different way by using the new mechanics that you didn't know when you first did the levels.
This can make some levels far, far, harder. But also much more satisfying! It's really cool to see how levels were designed in different ways depending on how much of the game you've played before.

The scoring system is also more complex than it first seemed.

There's a basic C-B-A-S "rank" for each sub-level, and then calculated for the full level. These mostly depend on your misses. S being for missing no "Thump".
You can't replay specific levels, at the moment, but you can restart the sub-level that you're playing. This means that you have to play the whole level from start to finish to get these rankings, but you can restart each one as much as you'd like before moving on.

The scoring, which will get you on the leaderboards, is where the real game is.
For these, restarting carries a penalty. So, to reach the top, you need to play every sub-level in a row, as well as you can, without restarting to get the optimal score for each one. It's a marathon, more so than a sprint.

I can see this being a somewhat controversial system, but I like it. It's the hardcore way to play the game, and I'm glad that there is one, rather than seeing how restarts the most.

For the score, you have to study the levels, somewhat, because of the "stomp" mechanic. On 2 consecutives Thumps, you can use the first to fly, and stomp the second for extra points. This is even more important in boss fights, where you're awarded multipliers for stomping the final thump (sorry for this vocabulary haha).

Aside from that, there are the riskier plays of trying to make a perfect curve, etc. (to get a perfect, you have a much narrower window to turn -- otherwise, you're dead).

It makes it much more interesting, choosing when to play aggressively or not, trying to get a good score. 


There's quite a bit of depth for those looking to climb leaderboards, so that's definitely another plus!


P.S.2: Consistency is way more important than I realized before. Each consecutive level you beat without a Miss gives up a 1+ multiplier. The same for No Damage levels. So your score really gets out of control if you can avoid missing/damage for many consecutive levels. It's good to keep the competition high!

One kinda big problem I have, though, has to do with the "game feel". I really like the whole impact the game conveys, but I think it takes a step too far by slowing down the game too much for give a very high impact in a long combo. This slow down actually throws me off completely, sometimes, because the rhythm breaks in these situations. So... you're expecting a certain obstacle at a certain time, but the tempo slows down a lot and then speeds up again. 
It leads to a rather inconsistent rhythm when you're actually doing great!
Which is a negative. Sure, it makes it harder to do perfect runs, but it essentially punishes good play? I would much rather have a lower impact in these long combos, but be able to keep the "flow", so to speak.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007027992', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 210, 'last_played': 1503578082}
review:
Absolutaly Nuts!

I'm not usually a rhythm game person but the asthetics made me take a punt, and it was so worth it, The game feels like the sound and visuals were made for eachtother, and this is something you will notice as playing, but without distracting you. This game just works. I cannot put it down

Cant wait for the PC VR availability in the coming months. That should be an even bigger rush!

author: {'steamid': '76561198072611898', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 112, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 112, 'last_played': 1478466774}
review: Very atmospheric game. For a rhythm game enthusiast it definitely has that zen appeal. It doesn't have the most complex set of key input combinations compared to some other popular titles in that genre, but thats what makes this game really unique. It balances being a rhythm game, and a driving game, set in some weird acid-induced hell that you are trying to break out of, really quite nicely. The soundtrack wavers between elating and totally demented. This is not audiosurf, and it is definitely not step-mania, so you shouldn't go in expecting gameplay just like that. It does it's own thing really quite well and is surprisingly challenging.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062614140', 'num_games_owned': 113, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 2049, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 437, 'last_played': 1710804896}
review:
Very addicting! The difficulty scale is pretty evenly spread out so you're learning as you go. They focus on a specific routine for each chapter so you pick up on it rather quickly. It becomes muscle memory from there. Love it.

It's like a giant LSD trip so a lot of the time I do get a bit of vertigo playing but i love it so much. Worth my $20 easily. I didn't beat the game or get bored of it in five minutes flat. In fact, I dumped like 2 hrs into this game and never even realized what time it was until I mentally begun to complain to myself how my eyes were sore and i couldn't stop yawning!

10/10 will lose my sense of time again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044747694', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 623, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 282, 'last_played': 1584046959}
review:
The best rhythm game I've ever played because it's exactly that; a rhythm game, not a music game. Once you understand how the game treats rhythm and you get in the zone, it's an adrenaline ride that had me smiling as I rode that road into the depths of hell. Amazing aesthetic, killer sound design, runs like butter. 

*** minor minor spoiler ***

The mechanics of the final stage were counter-intuitive to what made the game fun but hey, thematically it was neat I guess.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040622293', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 328, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 182, 'last_played': 1555823869}

author: {'steamid': '76561198038596892', 'num_games_owned': 388, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1127, 'last_played': 1477444150}
review:
Thumper is the feeling you get when your clothes don't fit right.
Thumper is the feeling you get when the music is off-key.
Thumper is the feeling you get when you miss a beat you thought you had down.
Thumper is the strain of staring into the abyss.
Thumper is the clearing of your eyes after salt water splashes into them.
Thumper is the satisfying feeling of your knuckles cracking against the pavement.

Thumper is a good game. Don't be fooled.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990144203', 'num_games_owned': 1439, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 577, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 508, 'last_played': 1669431107}
review:
Furieux,impitoyable et addictif,voila les mots qui decrivent le mieux Thumper !!! 

Avec sa violence auditive et sa vitesse demesur√©,ce mix improbable entre un jeux de rythme,Rez et WipeOut,hypnotise totalement le joueur,le met sous pression avant de le broyer au moindre defaut de concentration !

ATTENTION,ce jeux rend completement fou........et avec la VR on est completement transport√© dans cet univers psychedelique ou l'on atteint un etat de transe total !!! Vraiment le top !

author: {'steamid': '76561198052844506', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1122, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1029, 'last_played': 1532355062}
review:
There's nothing quite like this one. Immediately jumped high up the list of my all time favorite games. It starts out easy, and ramps up in difficulty at about the halfway point. Don't go into this thinking you'll be tapping A on the beat - this game has you filling in the blanks (syncopation) to sort of compose the song as you play.

Very intense. Very fun. Highly recommended. GO FOR THE S RANKS!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198065005013', 'num_games_owned': 225, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 151, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 123, 'last_played': 1504139093}
review:
J'en suis au level 4 sur 9, et clairement ce jeu fais tr√©s mal, pour son ambiance comme pour sa difficult√© qui s'accrois en faite √† chaque checkpoint quasiment, un tres tres bon jeu qui vaut largement son prix, avec un leaerboard qui nous oblige √† retenter le niveaux avec un meilleure score, mais s√©rieusement, d√©ja je vous conseil de r√©ussir tout les chapitres avant de vous mettre √† la course au best score, surtout bon courage √† tous h√©h√© ! 
entrainant, difficile √† d√©crocher ( √† si √† un moment mes yeux on d√©ccroch√© √† un moment ) 
PS: jeu avec E N O R M E M E N T d'effet, de lumi√®re et de couleur, √ßa pete de partout, et √ßa va vite, tr√©s vite, donc,
pour conclure, ACCROCHEZ VOUS !

author: {'steamid': '76561197971416468', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 1290, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 220, 'last_played': 1637977709}
review:
Race with unhuman speed in cyber hell! Now it's up to you and your trusty chrome scarabeus.

Amazing artstyle and music. Fantastic alien atmosphere. 
The game is challenging but fair. Don't play if you have problems with your heart, because it will pound on maximum speed.

Nice sideeffect: Teaches you odd meters and polyrhythms in a playful way.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055831568', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 226, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 47, 'last_played': 1638462596}
review: Just like any kind of instruments, you need lots of practicing, then devote all yourself to perform a flawless track.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039524706', 'num_games_owned': 836, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 115, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 114, 'last_played': 1477196029}
review:
Why I like it: a brutally difficult rhythm game that uses a much less forgiving version of osu!'s HP system and is better for it. Cathartic. Industrial music heaven. Beautiful aesthetic that somehow still manages to communicate that the game will kick your ass (and you will probably like it).

Why I don't like it: the fact that I can't ragequit by Alt-F4ing in fullscreen. Stressful, both mentally and physically. Call-and-response reliant, rather than actual musical timing.

Overall: recommended, since this is the kind of rhythm game I've been waiting for since O2Jam was deleted from the public consciousness.

-Crypt of the Necrodancer is great though, plug plug-
