author: {'steamid': '76561198024868579', 'num_games_owned': 1239, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 520, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 440, 'last_played': 1569524313}
review:
Thumper ist schwer. Zu diesem Zeitpunkt, 3-4 Tage nach dem Release haben bis jetzt nur 1,7% der Spieler alle Levels geschafft (laut Errungenschaften).

Es f√ºhlt sich so gottverdammt gut an wenn die Eingaben aus den Fingern gleiten und man mit dem Rhytmus und den Effekten verschmilzt; Dieses Gef√ºhl hatte ich lange nicht mehr bei einem Spiel. Diesen Flow kenne ich bisher wirklich nur von Rhythm Games oder wenn ich Instrumente spiele. Von daher denke ich, dass der Begriff "Rhythmus-Actionspiel" ziemlich gut passt. 

Man misst sich √ºber Ranglisten mit der Welt. Die anf√§nglichen Level lassen nicht viel kompetetiven Platz, jedoch bieten die sp√§teren Level viel Raum f√ºr Geschick und Reaktionszeit.

Es gibt zwei handvoll Levels, die nach und nach neue Elemente reinbringen. Das Momentum f√ºhlt sich gut an und mit der Zeit kommen immer schwierigere Herausforderungen. Diese neu kennengelernten Elemente lassen sich auch in den fr√ºheren Levels integrieren - somit hat man einen Wiederspielwert indem man seine Punktzahl nachtr√§glich erh√∂hen kann. Zudem kann man die alten Levels dann in einem neuen Licht sehen. :c)

Thumper ist eine intuitive und coole Erfahrung, die ihr euch nicht entgehen lassen solltet.

100%ig einer meiner Favoriten von 2016.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072840185', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 288, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 132, 'last_played': 1634925570}

author: {'steamid': '76561198064843033', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 36, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 36, 'last_played': 1476550475}
review:
Thumper is a great game. It's also an incredibly hard game. If you get frustrated easily, you will not like this game. I had to actually sit back and take a break to prepare myself after I failed the world 1 final boss a dozen times in a row. This game has nine worlds. If that sounds intimidating, that's because it is. I honestly don't think I will be able to finish this game completely.

The game's aesthetic is quite pleasant, IMO. The beetle/color scheme looks like something off of a Journey album, and I love it. The music and animations are very harsh (hence the term rhythm violence), and it really serves to set the atmosphere for this game. It's incredible how this game can be so colorful, yet so dark and intimidating at the same time.

Bottom line: If you like rhythm games (and are pretty good at them), this is a no-brainer. It's very polished, and the controls are extremely simple; it's just the timing that will kill you. Over and over again...

author: {'steamid': '76561197980696096', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 88, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 88, 'last_played': 1476333426}
review:
Rhythm violence.  Audiosurf on PCP.  This game is really, really good.

 Play it with headphones or speakers with a good amount of bass, and crank the volume until you can feel the rhythm in your bones.  Pay attention to the audio cues - it's a call-and-response game, where what you do should be more in response to the audio cues rather than the visual ones.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023620234', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 207, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 178, 'last_played': 1691018418}
review: Thumper has some of the most gorgeous visuals I've ever seen in a rhythm game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977146636', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 306, 'playtime_forever': 203, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 119, 'last_played': 1476467394}
review:
Its kind of a good game, although not much content there i fear and also suffers from some bad design decisions. Thge gameplay itself is good, really good. The problem lays in the structure surrounding the good gameplay, the way they handled the gamedesign here.
Also i dont get why people call it rythm based, because i cant see that.
It is "rythmic", as in when you press the buttons at the right time it give sounds that make the game music sound rythmic, but its not really rythm based in a way that a track is played and you press the buttons in a way to reflect the music. 
Means, i couldnt find a good connection between the games music and the gameplay. Its not that there are beats or so when you have to press a button, its also not that you can try to listen to the music/sound and then find the best pace or pressing. So you have to rely alot on visual feedback, more so than on rythmic feedback. But because the game often is not only overloaded visually but also doesnt even show you what will come for the next 2 seconds and you have to do a hectic button press and hope for the best, this can cause problems.
In the end its not rythm based, but rather rythmic.
The visual overload can cause other problems aswell.
For example it suffers from a known problem of when you mess up one time you can throw the run often into the bin. You have two lifes in this game, so you can mess up once and also get the chance of regaining (health). But messing up once often just causes that you lose entirely.

This is supported by a large degree of graphical effects thrown at the player, together with narrowed viewpoints and two weird black fields that limit the screen on the bottom (i have no idea why they are there) and you can forget your second life instantly when you messed up once.

Positive:
- Fresh idea
- nice gameplay overall
- deep enough, although sometimes a bit too overloaded with stuff
- nice visuals, although at points too many effects and a weird narrow view that i dont really like and seems to not serve any purpose
- nice music 

Negative, i explained some bad points already, but this might be interesting aswell:
- not content rich, i miss different modes, especially an endless mode or a mode where you do all the levels mixed together in a different order, or a boss run.
- sometimes too effect heavy
- a bit bad camera view, especially narrowed by some black fields that have no point and can be very annoying
- its not rythm based, only a bit rythmic. You will mostly only realize that with stepping a bit behind the system.
- sometimes levels become frustrating, when obstacles are only spammed at you it gets a bit tedious and annoying instead of "hard".
- music becomes a bit onesided after a while. 
I fear it suffers a bit from not having a "play your own track" mode with trackgeneration.

But now the worst point, which pressed me to give it a negative rating although i had it on positive before and explains a bit the surrounding structure that covers the good gameplay in a horrible mess of design of progression and options:
You cant do a highscore run and get an S rating on every section without playing the level completely as a whole from the start. You just cant select a single section and play that (although they are there and also visible, you cant select them though). 
Thats extremely bad design and a bad decision. And the worst, you cant even set back to a previous section WHILE doing the level. 
Means, you do a section, lets say the second last section of the first level, you felt you did good and it was enough points-wise? 
You reach the goal of that section (a gate on the track) and hit the A button to gather the last point and lock the section behind you, then the points summarize and you see you got an A or even just a B for example. 
Well, yeah then your whole run was worthless, even though you had an S rating on the 20 sections before the last one. 
Oh you think you can press the start button and press "load from last checkpoint" so you get back to the start of the section and try it again? No, screw you player, you cant. 
When you gathered the last point and the summarize appears showing you your rating, the game treats it as finished and the "restart from last checkpoint" will only set you to the start of the next section (the last one in our example). Doesnt make much sense. Its not really a point of being easy if you could select a single section anyway.

The developers decided it was a good idea to not show you your rating until you cant turn back and restart it. And the real thing is, level 1 for example is basically easy, but even with practice you will screw up there sometimes. And the first level only has about 15 sections. 
Later levels will be 5 times as hard and have 25 or so sections. 
Again, you screw up once, you have to do it again. 
We talk about possibly an hour of investment here sometimes. So you can be perfect in the first 24 sections, when you screw up only one button press in the last one and you didnt realize your points werent enough to get you an S ranking, you can do it all over again. 
Thats tedious bullshit. 
Why not let me do single sections or a part of a level?

This ties in with another problem the game has. It might give you many different gameplay elements, but only in pieces. Means you start the game with the first level, teaching you how to press A and do turns in curves. 
Then level 2 teaches you a new element like flying, the next level teaches you the element of lanes and laneswapping. 
And so on. 
When you reached level 5 you have quite an arsenal of different things you can do on a track. Problem is, all the levels/section up to that point are not designed for the gameplay elements that come after them.
Means, Level 1 doesnt have any lane sections, doesnt have flying or whatever else. So it is limited to only doing the first basic things.

When you reach a point in the game where it becomes interesting, its already 50% beaten. 
And the real problem i have with that, that there are modes missing that have all the elements in them. 
When i want the full experience of the game, its worthless to play the first 4 tutorial levels, as they dont have all the elements combined in them. 
Thats limiting. 
And there are quite some nice sections in the levels. 
But they are so short or basically so easy, that it becomes boring fast.
I will finish the 8 levels in the game (yeah, 50% of those are basically tutorials focussing on one element) and then wait until they get new modes into it. 
I thought i could also complete the achievements and reach an S ranking for each level, but seriously, i value my time more and instead play something else, as not being able to select single sections becomes already tedious for the first 2 (the easiest) levels. 
And the fact that screwing up only once meaning all my time investment was worth nothing, gives me the impression that the game doesnt value my time.

Resum√©e: Sadly a good game not valueing my time enough with throwing BS design decisions at me and even taking on the challenge doesnt feel satisfying but rather annoying or frustrating. Theres nothing to unlock, i fear, content is baren and not really there now. 
It lacks modes and levels, especially some infinite or customized content. 
And at the time as the gameplay becomes interesting, its already over for 50% as the earlier levels arent designed for later gameplay elements (which makes no sense for me, they still could have included later elements there for players that want to use them for some score ranking).

Would have been better to have one tutorial level introducing all the gameplayelements and then have the rest contain all of it, instead of delivering it piece by piece.
Some sections are really nice to play and fun and cool to look at. But i dont want to spend 20 minutes to reach that point because they happen to be in the last third of a level.

review:
5/10  
A Rhythm game that demands you hit your button and toggle  arhythmically.  And by that I don't mean simply not on the down  beat.  I was struggling with a level so I turned the sound off and breezed through on my second attemp just going off the visual cues.  That's a bad thing.  The weird thing is, when you play correctly and out of sync with the beat the timing on your beatle works out so that it hits all the correct targets on the track at the right timing to make a cool beat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067800292', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 392, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 199, 'last_played': 1582958309}
review:
The rhythym game you've been looking for. 

Over the years, I've bought and played several rhythm games. Thumper is undoubtedly one of the best. The game looks and feels amazing. Each successful turn and thump feels incredibly satisfying, and each mistake feels devastatingly earned. The intersting soundtrack and abstract visual style contribute a lot to the game's unique tone. "Rhythmic violence" sounded like a gimmick to me, at first, but it captures Thumper frenetic gameplay to a T. Its visceral, fast-paced, and a lot of fun.

Perhaps the only drawback is the price. $20 ain't exactly cheap for a rhythm game, no matter how good. In its defence, Thumper has a substantial amount of content and replay value (perfecting each level, reaching the top of the leaderboard). It's also incredibly polished, and the hardwork that went into development is apparent. 

All in all, definitely give Thumper a try. Might wanna wait for a sale though if you don't have twenty bucks to burn.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017903821', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1944, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 534, 'last_played': 1623779289}
review:
Thumper is great!
-----
*Perfect difficulty - not too easy, not too hard, very well balanced
*Works for rhythm/music/reaction game beginners
*Flawless, forgiving controls
*You don't get frustrated because Thumper is never unfair and checkpoints are plentiful
*It's simply great fun to play
*Longer than you might expect, you easily get 10+ hours from a playthrough
*Replaying levels is fun, you just don't want to finish a level and forget it, you'll want to keep coming back and master it (also replaying is great practice for later, harder levels)
*Fantastic violent atmosphere between the stress of barely surviving and losing control, and the triumph of easily clearing stages that seemed insane at first
*Visuals and soundtrack are excellent
*Simply a very polished, well made, quality game
-----
Even if you, like me, never considered music/rhythm games before, and you just like the soundtrack and visuals, try this game! Well worth its price.

Disclosure: I'm at two thirds of levels cleared with 8+ hours of play time (including 2h of replaying levels for fun). Looking forward to what the rest of the game has to offer!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970245566', 'num_games_owned': 512, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 167, 'last_played': 1498538228}
review: The Dark Souls of space beetle abstract music games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989683828', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 1394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1058, 'last_played': 1653715327}
review:
Very challenging and distinctive rhythm game with slick visuals which achieves a synesthetic effect few games have come close to, where the thumps and slams as you careen madly along this hellpath form a twisted music you can feel in your body.

There is a purity to this game, and a demented visual style that does merit some comparison to Devil Daggers, although they are completely different games. I find I like them for similar reasons.

The rhythms in this game can become very challenging as more varied polyrhythmic syncopations are introduced in often acyclic sections, and the fact that, as another reviewer correctly observed, the level number is the time signature for the track. Level 5 is where it starts to get really tricky.
On top of this, there is a layer of arcade skill involved in mastering the gameplay to maximise score and take advantage of opportunities to recover health which adds an element of strategic play and risk-reward.

Despite not being a biggest fan of the rhythm genre, I did pay full price for the game and I regret nothing, but I could see how you might want it to go on sale if you're on the fence. It delivers what it promises and if you are a progsnob, industrial or mathrock nerd you will probably enjoy the technical challenge and angular beats that Thumper throws at you.

One final note about the soundtrack, it suits the game well and you might think a rhythm game would have a killer OST but the music is very minimalist, with the real "music" of the game being revealed by playing the levels well. But for listening purposes I don't see it being very essential, unless you like very minimal drum tracks in different rhythms with some airy synth, possibly more useful to a musician to provide a mix of droney beats to practice to. I think most people will not get much out of the soundtrack.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009305306', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3347, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 426, 'last_played': 1695587455}
review:
Thumper is a fun game. It's the sort of game that I only stop playing when it feels like my eyes are about to bleed. The music haunts my daily life, and I find myself tapping to the beat of the soundtrack hours after I've stopped playing. When I close my eyes to sleep, I lie awake for hours, my mind still racing down that chrome track, heart pouding in time. 

Thumper is a fun game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038905471', 'num_games_owned': 595, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 834, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 461, 'last_played': 1674696254}
review:
I'd say Thumper is  a "reaction time" and "call and response" rhythm game. As you gain more familiarity with the way to respond to patterns the game becomes more rhythmic, but it strays from what some may be used to playing since sounds and cues don't always fall on a note or traditional rhythm timings of the music. 

More often than not a rhytmic pattern is felt advancing somewhere outside the music. I was tripped up at first learning to play because I was trying to match the music timings to the rhythm pattern very directly and that's not how this works. 

So why am I rambling about all this? Because everything becomes a lot more fun once you grasp the concept of reaction time rhythms and syncopation. Thumper is challenging, but in the good kind of way. I love this game, it seeps into every dark corner of your mind and makes it really hard to put down. At first I was weary of the 20 dollar price, but that was easily forgotten the more I played and realized Thumper  is an experience as much of a challenge. It's a very high quality and addicting  game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006221028', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2040, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 570, 'last_played': 1619402898}

author: {'steamid': '76561198038942769', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2861, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 897, 'last_played': 1574204784}
review:
This game is maddeningly addictive! 

The core of the game is the familar music sheet and note markers which players of the Rhythm Action genre will recognise, but the way this game riffs on the established conventions makes it something very special. The track you follow is the music sheet, and the player character is the visual marker signifying when notes should be played. Controls are very simple; a directional input and one button. You have 4 actions at your disposal, meaning there are 4 types of "note" to play in time with the music, these actions are: 

Thump - press the [Action] button when a glowing marker aligns with your character.

Smash - hold the [Action] button when faced with a set of barriers on the track.

Turn - press the [Action] button + a directional input at the moment your character encounters a turn.

Fly - pressing an upward directional input + the [Action] button on any note marker will launch your character into the air, where it can fly for a brief period. If you press a downward directional input while flying, you will activate an Aerial Stomp.

Basic scoring is determined by how accurately you enter the appropriate input when you meet a "note" on the song sheet, with a multiplier accumulating for long periods of perfect inputs and no mistakes. The beauty of this game lies in the arrangement of the "notes" and the behaviours they encourage from the player; you only have a small number of actions at your disposal but you must make expert use of combinations of these actions in order to survive the courses.

Where things get really clever is when you incorporate the Aerial Stomp into your game. Any "note" marker can be used to trigger flight, once in the air you can then Stomp downwards onto the next "note" of the course, the resulting shockwave is capable of breaking barriers, awarding health pick-ups and awards more points than a ground Thump alone. Once you get the hang of this mechanic, you start to think about and tackle the game's courses in a completely different way, constantly working out how best to maximise points.

With online leaderboards and an absolutely gorgeous audio visual aesthetic, this is a game I can see myself playing for a great deal of time to come.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066954820', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3380, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 575, 'last_played': 1667862057}
review:
Thumper is a very demanding game. It's a test of timing and patience. Despite the steep difficulty curve in the latter half of the game, nothing about the challenges was truly "unfair," not even the laser rings which penalize (and damage) you for missing beats. Suddenly requiring perfection during a sequence may seem a bit extreme at first, but if anything, it's encouraging you to do your best. During tough sequences and boss fights, I saw and knew what it was that I had to do--I simply had to do it right, even if it meant dying multiple times. Trial-and-error became commonplace for me after a while, but it was never as though the game was throwing something impossible at me. Taking damage and dying can ruin the flow of the game, but again, that's just another reason to try harder.

One criticism--the closest thing to a negative--would be that, even though the game's visuals are slick, stylish, and great to look at, sometimes there CAN be too many visual effects happening on-screen to be able to focus on what's coming ahead. One or two bosses are practically exploding with color and bloom lighting, sometimes obscuring a fair amount of the oncoming track. It's tough to anticipate the red bars indicating turns when the boss is flashing red, as well.

The layout of obstacles in these levels will always be the same (meaning replay value will REALLY vary from person to person), so you won't see any sudden variation when revisiting them, but at least you'll have some familiarity when coming back to them to go for higher ranks and scores.

Most importantly, quality headphones or a home theater system are a must, not just for the sake of enjoying the music, but also for being able to clearly hear the backing instrumentation and sound cues indicating upcoming obstacles, so you'll be ready to take them on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016630634', 'num_games_owned': 996, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 147, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 108, 'last_played': 1530627635}
review:
Thumper absolutely nails the idea that games are "experiences".

It's fast, it's dark, it's extremely challenging, and it fills you with the feeling of existential dread with its presentation.  I've described it to friends as a "Horror Rhythm game".  The entire atmosphere, mixed with the fantastic ambient soundtrack create an incredibly unique play experience, which as you progress becomes more and more tense, as each level throws a new mechanic at you, and new ways to die, along with increasingly difficult combinations of acrobatics your fingers will be forced to learn to pull through the level.  In doing so, ever elevating that feeling of what I would liken to anxiety, as the music picks up and you become so focused that you begin to feel as if your life is at stake if you don't nail this next passage.

It's really rare I jump on steam to review a game this quickly after purchase, or at all.  But this game is an absolute must buy for anyone seeking a unique experience, and a new twist on the rhythm genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970371316', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 758, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 757, 'last_played': 1477855832}
review:
Holy hell, this is a rhythm game with an attitude. Grabbed me instantly. You're a metal beetle speeding down a path, and you can hit Guitar Hero style squares on the beats, hit the sides of the tracks in time to the music and jump over obstacles. But that's the simple version - the game quickly ramps up the difficulty with clever variations on the theme, and the whole thing looks like an abstract nightmare from the 80s with a rhytmic soundtrack that will pound your brain into submission.

It's hard to convey just how hypnotizing the experience is. Your beat-le (zingggggg!) just responds in that spot-on perfect way that is the hallmark of an extremely polished game, and every beat, jump and slide just feels exactly right. Combined with the ominous visuals and the fact that you're actually on your way to beat the **** our of a giant glowing skull at the end of the track, this becomes a truly remarkable experience. VIDEO GAMES, HOORAY!

I can't even begin to imagine how crazy this must be in VR.

After having finished the entire thing, there is no doubt in my mind that this is a masterpiece. Some people have complained that this is not a true rhythm game since it will sometimes throw unconventional patterns at you that seemingly don't conform to any meaningful musical beats, but for me, that is just a way of keeping players on their toes rather than simply memorizing everything. My only real gripe is that the visual and sonic chaos will sometimes drown everything else out, making it super hard to decode what's actually happening, but even so, my overall opinion stands. This game is so intense and so unique, it is without a doubt one of the best experiences I've ever had.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009627287', 'num_games_owned': 576, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 1008, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 191, 'last_played': 1583193784}
review:
This game is phenomenal, and I'm saying that as someone who never, ever plays rhythm games and is utter garbage at them. It's brutal going, but totally worth it.

I've only finished up to Level 3, and I'm trying to focus on S ranks first (though I'm gonna change that moving forwards). However, with that mentality, there are two major flaws that get in the way of going for those achievements.

Firstly, a checkpoint pad counts as a hit, and if you miss it, you get an A rank for that segment and cannot go back unless you restart the whole level.

Secondly, why oh why is the restart checkpoint option in the menu so many button presses to reach? Devs, players ARE going to play the game just trying to S rank using resets, so just make it easier for us please?

Clearly the game is meant to be digested in one continuous run focused more on overall score, so I'm going to do that moving forwards and come back for S ranks, as resetting a dozen times for one segment certainly becomes a bit mind-numbing.

I can't even imagine how much more difficult things will get after Level 3...

Gameplay Design: 8/10
User Experience: 8/10
Aesthetic Visuals: 8/10
Technical Visuals: 6/10
Audio Design: 10/10
Music: 10/10

review: What can I say? I like it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001180221', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 285, 'playtime_forever': 676, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 340, 'last_played': 1547255116}
review:
GLANCE RECOMMENDATION: [u][b]82% YES[/b][/u] / 18% NO

[h1]GOOD[/h1]
[list]
[*]Just the craziest, beautiful art and animations flying in your face.
[*]Absolutely fast, thrilling gameplay that actually made me scream like I was going down a roller coaster at times.
[*]I adore the beetle ship you control so much. I'd love to get this as merchandise.
[*]The music is super bass-e and adds to the sheer terror of the gameplay. I hadn't focused on how my games were sounding for quite some time. I even had to plan out my day so I could play this before disturbing any neighbors and get the full enjoyment out my speakers.
[*]This game seasons you. I had an incredibly difficult time on most levels 4+ each time I first dipped my toe in, but coming back to them after beating the game made them a LOT easier.
[/list]

[h1]NEUTRAL[/h1]
[list]
[*]I'm a bit torn about the difficulty spike starting with level 4 and continuing till the end of the game. Levels 1 - 3 were expertly balanced, feeling midlly challenging and intensely fun. These were the moments I most enjoyed. Levels 4+ REALLY run your face along the asphalt as you're bursting at 100 MPH. Additionally some of the sections, like the level 6 boss, feel just a tad on the brutal side that leave you more frustrated than anything else.
[*]This game can wear you out. More than any other game I've played in a long time, I can confidently suggest you take a LOT of breaks between levels or, hell, during a level.
[/list]

[h1]BAD[/h1]
[list]
[*]I would argue that some of the perspectives on your track and the visuals flying into your face INCREDIBLY hamper your ability to see things clearly. Especially during bosses the color of the surrounding area can really hide the thumps you're supposed to be 100% hitting, which is frustrating. Additionally getting hit once was almost always a death knell. The animation for getting hurt once, which is screen shaking and ship parts flying everywhere, means almost certain death if you're in an area where objects are coming at you at an incredible pace.
[/list]

[h1]SUMMARY[/h1]
Thumper is an incredible game that is thrilling, terrifying, tiring, and sometimes a little frustrating. If you're a beat junkie, this is a great opportunity to not only stop at S ranking courses, but also timing hitting objects just right to get the maximum amount of points. I can easily recommend this at the full $20 USD price tag.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988162898', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1115, 'last_played': 1537587962}

review: Its like you were on drugs and started playing Audiosurf... And then gave it drugs too.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975277858', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2500, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1048, 'last_played': 1702108934}
review:
I'd been waiting for this game for years and I'm happy to say I wasn't dissapointed. The feeling you get playing this game is so satisfying when you nail the course just right. The music keeping your heart pounding and the visuals make your eyes glisen over. You get better and better as you move on into the harder courses just from the fact you can't put the game down is so fun even as the later tracks kick your ass over and over.

I've beat the game in about 11-12 hours of time but still I can't get enough I find myself finding courses I really enjoy and I play them over and over trying to master them and go for higher scores. I understand that even thou I've done the whole campaign I did piss poorly score wise so now I'm obssessed with finding the best methods to earn high score and master advanced techniques to clear the coures in the most badass way possible.

Highly reccomend this game to anyone who loves hadcore music and fast paced rhythm action, buy it now and drop some sick space beetle bass!

author: {'steamid': '76561198039221368', 'num_games_owned': 1432, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 160, 'last_played': 1514581811}
review:
Thumper is a rhythm game at heart with action elements, raw, psychedelic visuals and a heavy, electronically inspired soundtrack. This is one of the best surprises of the year for me as the visuals are original and stunning to look at, the controls are immensely tight and the gameplay is thrilling and extremely satisfying. I would highly reccomend this game, though it isn't for everyone as some parts can get quite difficult but the satisfaction you get from beating a hard level more than makes up for it.

9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198056178227', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 353, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 205, 'last_played': 1571257833}
review: Amazing game! Killer soundtrack that sounds even better when you get an S rank

author: {'steamid': '76561197980088665', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 1089, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 957, 'last_played': 1579021660}
review:
Beautiful, dark, haaaarrrrrrrrdddddddd, engrossing.

Doesn't give a crap about accepted rules of vanilla music games, in a good way: sometimes weird rhythms, extremely repetitive music (and no, it won't play your Beyonc√© tunes), but overall an experience a zillion times more precise and crafted than your average beat game.

Thumper had me spend hours re-doing levels for score, which I usually never do.

Also, the final levels are epic.

Buy buy buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027307542', 'num_games_owned': 691, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 603, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 348, 'last_played': 1603903620}
review:
Hands down the best rhythm game I've ever played
It's a shame being a rhythm gamer these days since not many rhythm games get released, especially not on steam. And as a fan of many rhythm games/series such as guitar hero, rockband, DDR, Deemo and Rhythm Paradise, this is honestly the most rewarding. The price tag may be a little high but the challenge, replayability, horror elements, industrial soundtrack and level length make this a truly memorable game. Be warned though, this game is brutally difficult and if you haven't played many rhythm games before, this probably isn't the best place to start.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044443027', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 399, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 263, 'last_played': 1577376859}
review:
This game is just pure perfection. The Graphics, the Animations, the Bosses, this strange bug you're controlling, the fast paced style of the game. It just works so well!

Even when doing a mistake while doing a boss, the game is not going off-beat, the segment gets flawlessly repeated so you have another chance. 

I don't buy games often. I really don't. I despise the lack of originality many many other games have - but not this one. 
THIS! is fun!

review: This isn't really a rhythm game. You can't "feel"the beat and play along like in other games such as Kickbeat and Bit Trip Runner 1. I find myself relying on the visual cues rather than audio cues. To make matters worse, the early part of the first level the hit boxes are completely off. When I press the jump button as I hear the beat, the game fails to register it cause visually the hitbox has passed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032349752', 'num_games_owned': 749, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 577, 'last_played': 1700973734}
review:
[h1]This is an excerpt from my full review for the online publication Hey Poor Player[/h1]

Thumper is a rhythm game. That‚Äôs all you really need to know, but it‚Äôs not all I‚Äôm going to tell you. The game would never allow me to get away with such a modest descriptor. It‚Äôs more appropriate to speak in intangibles. Thumper is anxiety. It is restlessness, wretchedness, abjection, pain, failure‚Äîand ultimately, hope and triumph. It‚Äôs a reflection of everything about yourself that you hope to never face, laid bare in the dark light of Hell. It‚Äôs what Franz Kafka might dream up if he met Trent Reznor and they invented their own programming language.  

It‚Äôs a damn fine video game, and I urge you to use this critique as a jumping-off point to do your own investigation (i.e. buy the hell out of it).

Thumper represents the next logical evolution in what rhythm games can (and should) be. Where Dance Dance Revolution celebrates the ecstasy of motion and flow, Thumper commands you to listen to the shrieking, clanging anxiousness inside each of our minds‚Äînoises that we‚Äôre unable to quell when the evening is upon us and we long for some peace and quiet. It takes a single mechanic and spins it into a tapestry of visceral destruction. It is punishingly hard, and it will make you wish you had never fallen under its spell. In my case, it made me wish I could create something even half as important.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993603640', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 93, 'last_played': 1477263584}
review: I fucking love this game. Seriously, 40 minutes in, and I fucking love it. Like many have stated before, it's just... Raw. That's the best way I can describe it. It has to be played to be understood. Simple, Raw, and enjoyable. The atmosphere this game has is something many games could learn.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035456794', 'num_games_owned': 1304, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 340, 'last_played': 1649877440}

author: {'steamid': '76561198024756050', 'num_games_owned': 361, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 957, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 668, 'last_played': 1668273024}
review:
oh. my. god.

This game made me physically exhausted.

Addictive, difficult, and super fun. Not sure if its worth the $20 yet, but so far its fantastic.

EDIT: Yup, I beat the game and I still want to constantly go back to try and improve my score. I'd say this game is well worth the money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022465039', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 311, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 171, 'last_played': 1546911166}
review:
I love this game. Works super well with an xbone controller.

The music fits the gameplay perfectly and often it felt like my heartbeat was in sync with the rhythm.

The only complaint I can even think of is that sometimes the visibility isn't perfect for some obstacles and occasionally you'll get hit when it doesn't feel like it's your fault, but only occasionally.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983700258', 'num_games_owned': 662, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 507, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 452, 'last_played': 1476932161}
review:
Thumper is an experience unlike any other. I may be partial to this game because I've played a lot of rhythm games, but the visuals and music in this game are incredible. Gameplay is simple, but gets to a crazy intense level. This game is NOT easy. 

If you are looking for a challenge, look no further.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001295915', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1487223582}
review: Holy shit.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009981363', 'num_games_owned': 1443, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 288, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 87, 'last_played': 1541641704}
review: feels like this game is a monolith.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976922449', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 358, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 196, 'last_played': 1482535303}
review: The game is far longer than you'd expect; levels quickly get up to 25, 30 individual sections, and can take quite some time to complete.  It also introduces the game mechanics at one per level, so you never get too frustrated; luckily if you screw up a section you just go back to the start of the section rather than the whole level. Before you know it you wont just be hitting lights and grinding corners, you'll be moving between lanes, gliding across obstacles and slamming down to open gates, and having to complete small "perfect run" sections to avoid the Laser of Dissapointment. There's a great building menace, tension, and unease as you play (a great pair of headphones helps the experience). Don't judge it on the first level, that's really just the most basic tutorial.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066491911', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1147, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 283, 'last_played': 1699194440}
review:
Having played Thumper for an hour and twenty minutes... straight, I'm honestly surprised to find that my heart still remains in my chest.
Thumper is an experience I don't think you can find anywhere else, combination of the intense drumming fit for wardrums you persistantly hear throughout the game, and the fact that you otherwise just don't feel safe, meaning that you get a sense of having your heart in your mouth that is unparalleled and unrivaled by anything else you can fathom.
I heartily reccomend this to everyone, as this is an experience I think everyone should feel. Just make sure you are not weak of heart.

seriously, holy sh!t

author: {'steamid': '76561198103610762', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1322, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 541, 'last_played': 1681326267}
review: Simple mechanics; ludicrous speed. Thumper isn't the sort of game that takes you out for dinner beforehand. It's an intense, breakneck experience and can feel somewhat overwhelming at moments. You're not so much following a structured melody as creating the beat yourself, which means mistiming your inputs can really throw you off. Thumper isn't shy about its difficulty. When you get it right however - particularly at speed, you can't help but crack a grin. Performance wise everything runs smoothly, no issues for me on a 950m laptop. Get yourself a decent pair of headphones/speakers and you're good to go. Simply put, if you've gotta go fast, then this is the game to be playing right now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198316448953', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 173, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 90, 'last_played': 1692072208}
review: it gets progessively more intense as you get further through the levels and the music and visuals match the intensity to make for a unique and wonderfully frenzied experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007726297', 'num_games_owned': 387, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 87, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 87, 'last_played': 1476216074}
review: I knew that Slimelight acid tab was more than a hallucination: it was prophesy.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971417681', 'num_games_owned': 579, 'num_reviews': 238, 'playtime_forever': 846, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 678, 'last_played': 1672273830}
review:
I owned this before VR and it was great then, now in VR it's awesome!

Intense, challenging, nice graphics, good soundtrack.

Things start of easy enough but slowly ramp up the further you go, that's when things get pretty intense, then come the bosses, more intense!

There are many levels and the levels are long which is great, I've not completed it yet and loved every minute of it so far, at time of review I've got 11 hours so far.


There's a plus+1 mode but haven't tried that yet, just trying to get to the end of it right now.  Up to level 7, each level has sub levels, eg 7-1, 7-2 7-3 etc and they can have many sub levels plus bosses.

Best with a joypad.

Definite purchase if you like fast intense action, great soundtrack, challenging gameplay, nice eye candy and have VR, although it's still fantastic without VR.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055402421', 'num_games_owned': 1636, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 141, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1701654823}
review:
Despite it looking somewhat similar to Audiosurf it plays completely different. The game is more focused on total stimulus overload. The game has very simple mechanics that are easily utilized but the way they get twisted by the end of a level makes it so you're constantly on the edge of your seat. 

Despite me buying this game on Humble for no difference in price my review won't count toward the overall ratings which is a shame. This game is definitely worth the play and for $20 you will be getting what (so far, after about 3 levels) seems to be around 10 hours of content, especially if you try to get S rank on every level.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027930050', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 606, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 140, 'last_played': 1560466025}
review: A beautiful game that will give you a heart-pounding experience. Before you know it, there will be tears running down your cheeks.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961132372', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 328, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 207, 'last_played': 1665347702}

author: {'steamid': '76561198162410567', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 203, 'playtime_forever': 157, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 157, 'last_played': 1476302109}
review:
Verdict: 6,5/10

To begin with: I purchased the Thumper game+soundtrack. Don't buy the soundtrack. It's quite simply not worth it unless you're into "ambient landscape" where the whole appeal of the music relies on the samples(and even for ambient landscape it's not that good). Other than "Beetle", the last and only good track on the album alongside "Triangle", nothing has any redeeming musical quality besides really crisp sounds - which for me personally isn't quite enough to listen to it.

Now about the game:

The game is very "raw". Everything has a very "raw" metallic feeling to it. It's not at all "floaty" relative to the ever changing background; instead it actually feels quite fast and threatening in it's own unusual way. The game is very short. I've just completed level 2, and there're like 11 or so? I'd say around 6/7 hours gameplay given the last few stages aren't frustratingly difficult. Is the game "hard"? Yes and no. It's really managable to get past everything, but quite a challenge to do so whilst maintaining proper "grades"(each level consists of several checkpoints, inbetween each you get a "grade").

The gameplay is rather simple, you use a combination of the keys and spacebar. No pointers there, it's kindof what I expected.

Overall the game is quite unique, it has a very strange atmosphere to it. It's smooth as silk, the soundtrack is good(ingame is a whole different thing than buying the actual tracks outside of it; where all of it seems just...pretty bland), the game looks "okay" if you're into it's style. It's pretty fun to play. Biggest downside is is that the price is somewhat steep for what it actually offers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038711801', 'num_games_owned': 877, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 40, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 40, 'last_played': 1476153043}
review: It's a fun rhythm game... but It's not my kind of rhythm game. I don't normally write reviews, but I think I have to since I was looking forward to this game for a while. First, you have to understand that when they say it's a rhyhtm game it really is just that. I played for 45 minutes and only heard rhyhtms and no actual music *FROM WHAT I'VE PLAYED*. Maybe it gets actual music later, but the lack of an actual melody or anything of the sort just turned me off. Second, It feels very repetative. It's fun and difficult but it feels like you're doing the samething over and over with more or less the same background. Yes the background does change, but not all that much. I think the concept of this game was good and will probably appeal to a lot of people, but I just couldn't get into it at all which is sad since I'm a big fan of rhythm games. But in the words of Simon Cowell "It's gonna be a no from me".

author: {'steamid': '76561197996721754', 'num_games_owned': 1223, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 315, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 141, 'last_played': 1580412093}
review:
A hellish Audiosurf filled with the sinister tension of Devil Daggers.

You will go fast, but you will also be spooked.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037974491', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 81, 'last_played': 1705082885}
review:
I'm not one for rhythm games but I watched a short video on YouTube and the soundtrack alone pushed me to purchase it (inc the soundtrack DLC). This game has been in development for years and I'm so happy I stumbled upon it. I probably won't continue to buy rhythm games in the future but I'm truly happy I purchased this. 
The soundtrack is truly incredible and this game has my heart racing constantly as you push forward to try for the S rank. The hand, eye and listen quardination is very intense in this game but I think that's what makes it so satisfying. 
The only thing I would knock is the variety when it comes to the end of level bosses. Apart from that, visually stunning with a soundtrack that has to be turned up to 11 whist playing. 

9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198021155753', 'num_games_owned': 979, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 177, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 142, 'last_played': 1633381302}
review:
Update 2: Taken me five years but I've finally experienced the game in VR and oh my god, the game really shines in VR. If you have a VR headset, pop some headphones on and be prepared for an amazing experience of an already amazing game.

Update: I have (as of 2018) bought the game three times (PC, Switch and iOS). That should be enough of a recommendation. 

"Rhythm violence" isn't just some marketing fluff made up by the devs, it's a pretty accurate description of this game. 

Everything you do in Thumper has this oomph about it that compliments the intense soundtrack perfectly to create something that's extremely exhilarating. The gameplay is really simple (you'll mainly be using one button and directions) but, once the game picks up and gets faster, it will get tougher. It's a nice difficulty curve, easing you with new mechanics every level before really testing your skills as you go on. 
The soundtrack is this orchestral/electronic mix that feels both epic and terrifying. Even just listening to the soundtrack on its own is intense.

Honestly, it's one of those games where if any one element was missing, the game wouldn't work. As a combined package though, Thumper is easily one of my favourite games of the year.
It's a game I've been waiting years for that didn't just deliver, but exceeded my expectations.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972137229', 'num_games_owned': 362, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 137, 'last_played': 1528830252}

author: {'steamid': '76561198101774774', 'num_games_owned': 913, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 1185, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 751, 'last_played': 1701190851}
review:
Ach du ...! Das Warten hat sich definitiv gelohnt. Und f√ºr 19,99‚Ç¨ bekommt man ein richtig gutes Spiel mit genialem Soundtrack. Aber den Soundtrack w√ºrde ich pers√∂nlich nur im Spiel h√∂ren. 

Viele vergleichen Thumper wahrscheinlich mit Audiosurf, aber das ist aus meiner Sicht falsch. Man sieht √Ñhnlichkeiten, ja, aber bei Thumper spielt man nicht seine eigene Musik, sondern die schon vorgegebene. Das ist schon einmal der st√§rkste Unterschied. Noch dazu sind Fehler fatal. Pro Stage kannst du dir max. 2 Fehler erlauben, au√üer du schaffst es, ein besonderes Gameplay-Element zu benutzen, um deine "R√ºstung" wiederzubekommen. Noch dazu f√ºhlt es sich nicht wie ein Spiel an, indem man wie bei Audiosurf einfach eine Strecke generiert zur ausgew√§hlten Musik abf√§hrt. In Thumper macht die Strecke teilweise auch die Musik. Taucht eine Kurve auf, h√∂rt man das, taucht ein Ring auf, h√∂rt man das und das mit allen anderen Objekten auch. Das zusammen mit der stimmigen Grundmelodie ergibt den finalen Soundtrack. F√ºr mich ist Thumper eher ein Abenteuer als eine einfache Fahrt auf dem Soundtrack.


+(23.11.2016) Da ein neuer Spielmodus hinzugef√ºgt wurde, f√ºge ich meine Meinung dazu noch hier rein. Der neue Modus ist f√ºr die, die sich selbst noch einmal testen wollen. Nachdem man das Hauptspiel geschafft hat, ist die Luft weg gewesen, doch nachdem der neue Modus hinzugef√ºgt wurde, ist nun wieder ein Teil da. Jedoch h√§lt dies nicht sehr lange.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998844556', 'num_games_owned': 1583, 'num_reviews': 189, 'playtime_forever': 315, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 283, 'last_played': 1503939694}
review:
If you're not used to rhythm game, you can still play it but say goodbye to scoring. Actually, the game runs and plays great, there are so much tricks to surpass if you want the best possible score on a level.

There are checkpoints every 15/30 seconds, meaning you don't have to restart at the beginning of a level. And man... This is HARD. You'll have to keep the pace with rhythm, but there are so many stroboscopic effects (and BEAUTIFUL ones) which are trying to distract you. This is a game that asks you to play in a room, lonely, with a maximum focus. It will surely break your nerves as you progress through the game, but damn, it's satisfying as hell.


Edit : Also, the game's atmosphere is stressful, I mean, a lot. Exit happy music when you're tapping on rhythm, this is the kind of music that plays when you're playing for your life. Litterally. Everything is hostile in this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012926479', 'num_games_owned': 261, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 200, 'last_played': 1495380133}

author: {'steamid': '76561197969514813', 'num_games_owned': 792, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 265, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 245, 'last_played': 1476830233}
review:
Thumper is an incredible audio/visual experience‚ÄìIt's basically a rhythm game where you have to match specific inputs to objects coming at you‚Äìeach different obstacle requiring a different input. it starts out simple, showing you the ropes and easing you in and then it starts to add on mechanics and ramp up the difficulty. 

I'm currently only part way through the campaign but it has already become extremely intense, demanding quick reflexes even to stay alive, let alone keep your score multiplier going. The music (part background track and part created by the obstacles you pass) combined with the beautiful, stylized visuals create an almost oppressive feeling but are completely effective in pulling you in and immersing you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004721369', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 258, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 1655437793}
review:
The only way I could enjoy this game more is if I didn't suffer from tinnitus. 

9/10 with tinnitus
10/10 without

Protect your ears kids.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049641617', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2417, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 877, 'last_played': 1563299939}
review: An incredibly heart-racing game, with a pounding soundtrack and simple controls. My only issues are the ludicrous difficulty spike at about 4-11 and the visual clutter in the background which can occasionally make it overly hard to see what beats are coming round the next corner. It ends up making Thumper a very frustrating game the further you progress, but I'd still have no problem recommending it to fans of rhythm action games. It looks amazing, sounds phenomenal and is really satisfying to play when you nail a sequence perfectly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053990523', 'num_games_owned': 474, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 195, 'last_played': 1521126722}
review:
Von Thumper habe ich erstmal geh√∂rt als Jim Sterling (Youtuber) es in einem Video Reviewed hat. (Link [spoiler] 	https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oq3FzSJIPLE [/spoiler]
Ich dachte zuerst 20‚Ç¨ w√§re etwas teuer f√ºr solch einen Titel und wollte ihn mir nicht Kaufen sondern nur auf die Wunschliste setzen f√ºr den n√§chsten Steam Sale.

Dann kam mir der gedanke das ich f√ºr Trippel A Titel gerne mal 60‚Ç¨ ausgebe und 20‚Ç¨ f√ºr Thumper ja nicht so eine schlecht investition sein K√∂nnte.

Und Gott verdammt hatte ich recht!

Thumper ist ein sehr sehr gutes Spiel! Warum ? 
[list]
    [*]Thumper hat einen einzigartigen Grafikstil den man sonst so noch nicht gesehen hat und sich perfekt ins gamplay einf√ºgt.
    [*]Die Game mechanics sind sind "Easy to learn but hard to master" so gelingt der einstieg sehr gut und man wird immer besser.
    [*]Der Sound bei einem Rhythmusspiel, wie Thumper, ist enorm wichtig. Das haben die Entwickler scheinbar verstanden den Thumper bedient sich einer riesigen Palette an Rhytmen welche daf√ºr sorgen das Thumper einen enormen "Flow" bekommt welcher einen fesselt.
[/list]

Alles in allem kann ich nur sagen Thumper ist ein sehr gutes und erfrischendes Spiel was ich nur weiter empfehlen kann!
Lasst euch nicht von dem Preis abschrecken er ist es auf jeden Fall wert

author: {'steamid': '76561198000046933', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 655, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 303, 'last_played': 1606497259}
review:
If you ever played and liked Audiosurf and like fast-paced, adrenaline packed games, buy this game right away.

The grimm atmosphere and music are fantastic and the controls are easy to learn, the difficulty relies on the speed of the game.

If you like games to test your reaction speed and make you feel rewarded when you pull a perfect combo, instant recommendation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053070647', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 155, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 155, 'last_played': 1476463562}
review:
Was I dreaming? Now I am awake.


Thumper  has this amazing effects on your conciseness, it's gives you something that only few games can, like a mind altering drug. 

After playing almost hour, I need a break to absorb this wonder. Playing with a controller is amazing experience (first time i'm enjoying my xbox360 controller).

10/10. 
Worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962505126', 'num_games_owned': 1049, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 694, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 232, 'last_played': 1508010297}
review:
Had never heard of Thumper until today, looked it up for 5 minutes on Twitch and decided to buy it thinking it would be a perfect candidate for a Steam Refund if i happened to not like it and yeah...the refund isn't happening.

This game is simply awesome, the visuals and the heavyness of the music puts you in this trance where your hands move by themselves and react to whatever obstacles they throw at you rather than you actively thinking about how to react to what comes next.

The obstacles follow the rhythm of the music perfectly which is what was the most important thing for me coming in, the #1 reason i never liked AudioSurf is that the procedurally generated tracks never actually followed the beat of whatever song you chose but since this game's music and tracks were (i'm guessing) built together, it makes for a very enjoyable feeling.

This game gets a ''must buy'' rating from me.

review: This game is a masterpiece in visuals, sound, and gameplay. Difficulty rises as it teaches you basics and then continues on an upward ramp as not only do you need to remember what to do at a given point, but to also remember patterns. The trippy visuals and the music complament each other to a T. If you have $20 and want a rythm game that will keep you going, this is the one. And I never usualy promote a game over the awsomness of DDR, but this game is just...so good.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033565423', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 132, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 70, 'last_played': 1534920236}

author: {'steamid': '76561198004490967', 'num_games_owned': 782, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 723, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 245, 'last_played': 1662325622}
review:
Thumper embodies viscerality. "Rhythm Violence" is a term so appropriate, you'd think they conceived it first and then designed the game. Each beat leaves you wondering if you're being punched in the gut or dealing said blow. The soundtrack instills a sense of imminent doom, as if you're fleeing from a serial killer... until you realize [i] you're [/i] the threat. 

Gameplay operates much in the same manner as Rhythm Heaven, with each note type having a cue that precedes your input by a measure. The result is that by a few levels in, you're forced to be looking at and listening for the notes you'll be playing moments in the future as you input the controls for those you signaled in the recent past. This means you can't play the game simply by watching the highway like you might Rock Band, you must achieve a flow state much in the vein of Hotline Miami or Super Hexagon.

With visuals that look like Tool album art rendered in the world of Tron, and music that combines thunderous tribal drums and hints of industrial and dubstep, the presentation is top-notch, though don't mistake it for style over substance: every element of the appearance and sound of the game feeds back in to the exhilarating, rewarding gameplay. Literally the only complaints I can muster are that the menus are a tad sluggish, and the effect when you take damage is slightly too obtrusive. Anyone that considers themself a rhythm game fan owes it to themself to play this.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968498835', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 534, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 534, 'last_played': 1476425968}
review:
I have obsessed over this game for years while it was in development. I played it at every demo opportunity. I feared I was building up my expectations to an unreachable level.

I was not disappointed in the slightest.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044047349', 'num_games_owned': 289, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1507, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 632, 'last_played': 1703715135}
review:
[b]Overview:[/b] [i]An addictive, glorious, intense and intensive child of the chaos aesthetic and oppression of action games and the rhythmic precision and flow of music games. If you like either, or if you're curious, dig in. Gameplay, environment, and cue are intense and relentless, but they also make it feel satisfying. Don't play if you have motion sickness or get frustrated.[/i]

Bought it full price tonight (an hour after it was released), played for five hours straight and got through four and a half "levels." Thoughts so far. 

This is a rhythm game for people who hate the cheery cliches of rhythm games, and an action game for rhythm game players who hate the clutter of action games. If you don't like rhythm games nor action games, pass on this one, because you'll just have a bad time. And if you don't like AudioSurf, maybe you should pass, but it's not just "copying AudioSurf." It's an action game that looks like AudioSurf from the surface. It's more oppressive, more hectic, and overall more satisfying. 

If you're willing to make the dive, consider Thumper less of an "innovation" on the [i]rhythm and music[/i] genre as much as it is on the [i]action[/i] genre. Yet, that makes it even more interesting. Like, imagine the most intense boss battle music you can think of. Now, imagine [i]becoming that music.[/i] In other words, it's less that you're [i]playing[/i] the song and more that you're [i]acting as[/i] the song, or maybe the song's acting as [i]you?[/i] That's what Thumper is. Because Thumper on its own could be another action game, but they incorporated rhythm game features, and in doing it so well, that mentality becomes most of the experience of this game. I might expand more on my own in a more extensive talk/review about what this means and why I love it, and I'll update here if I do, but that's the gist of it.

From here, I'll just do a bare-bones review of the game's major mechanics/gameplay points. 

[b]PROS:[/b] 

[list]
[*] Easy to learn. Not disgustingly hard to master. Extremely intuitive once you get the hang of it. But I'm only in level five and I've given up for the night so we'll see how that holds out.  

[*] The soundtrack is intense. Like I said, it feels like a giant boss battle, except you [i]are[/i] the music. 

[*] Extremely responsive environment and interface. The game has excellent non-verbal audio-visual cues that make every hit feel so satisfying while making you regret just "scraping by." With every hit, you add to what you hear, and that's an extremely fulfilling part of this game, as much as completing stages and levels and beating your own scores. 

[*] Rewards rhythm game mechanics and instincts, without forcing you to feel like it's a rhythm game. If you're a rhythm game player, you'll get what I mean when you get into it. If not, you'll hear what I mean as you tap your keyboard/controller.  

[*] Extremely addicting. Once you start, you just keep going. 
[/list] 

[b]CONS:[/b] 
(I know there are as many "cons" as "pros" but they're extremely minor -- consider it constructive criticism rather than "reasons why this game isn't worth your time.") 

[list]
[*] [b]If you have motion sickness issues or can't handle "psychedelic" aesthetic, take a pass. Warning you now.[/b] 

[*] The music and rhythmic style gets over its own head sometimes, which is sorta expected from such a heavy industrial percussion-ambiance style of music. Some stages are extremely difficult to follow rhythmically, which is an issue, given it's a rhythm game, coming from a rhythm game nerd. You can survive just on visual cues alone, but as a rhythm game, this becomes a frustration. 

[*] The game's tighter "tunnel" points are unnecessarily and annoyingly difficult -- that is, it's difficult to see the next part coming often, especially when the environment causes parts to blend in. You will NOT finish the game without dying at least a few times. 

[*] They really don't instruct you on things. Again. Do not expect to go through this game without dying a few times. There will be [i]a lot[/i] of trial-and-error. 

[*] Needs an audio-visual calibration system. Badly. 
[/list] 

One note that's extremely neutral is that the game doesn't punish you until about halfway through for "just getting by." That is, it doesn't detract if you aren't doing perfect combos of the square taps, except in boss battles. I'm split between whether this is a good or bad thing for the game, but as a player, you can absolutely tell the game gets irritated for being lazy. 

Also, it feels intense as hell. If that's not your thing, skip it; if so, go wild. 

Basically, the gameplay is perfect, the execution isn't, you know? Like, they have a system perfected, but it gets a little bit over itself sometimes. But if the "pros" sound even remotely good, it's worth picking up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036213213', 'num_games_owned': 1015, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 225, 'last_played': 1498848478}
review:
This game is insanely cool.  The closest parallel is probably Amplitude, but it's not a great comparison: Thumper has a fresh set of mechanics all its own.  It controls with just a single analog stick and button, but requires incredible reflexes and timing.  Your ship travels in one of four planes, controlled by holding the analog up, down, left or right.  Holding or releasing the button alters your trajectory in each of these planes, effecting creating eight "lanes" for you to navigate at a given time.  Obstacles spring up to the beat and require you to be in a certain lane to avoid them, forcing you to navigate a treacherous, high-speed path through a psychedelic wonderland.  It feels a bit like playing a (beautiful) endless runner, trying desperately not to crash, but the levels are all preconstructed and crafted meticulously to the music; you won't find any RNG getting in your way here.

Thumper is sensory overload.  It's stunning to look at, an assault on the ears, and an absolute joy in the hands: crunchy, fluid, responsive and rewarding.  It's the most kinetic and unique rhythm game that I've played in ages.  Check it out immediately if you're looking for something arcadey and different from the norm.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007390216', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 82, 'last_played': 1476589403}

Runs like a dream, not a single hiccup in sound or graphics so far. As others have said, easy to learn, difficult to master. A very welcome addition to the genre.

Reminds me of the old PS2 game Amplitude, if Amplitude had done way too much acid and gone to a very dark place and never came back...

author: {'steamid': '76561198089775460', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1554, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1554, 'last_played': 1478968262}
review:
>11/12/2016 UPDATE:
>Even after so much time after launch people are still reading this, so I will just add this little bit here while keeping the original text at the bottom.
>First of all, I want to say that I curently hold all this achievements in this game. This means I've gone through everything that this game has with an S rank.
>I still also maintain the opinion that this game is not musical enough, and that you can not predict the thumps by sound alone. The BPMs are too low for any consistent rhythm for the most part. You react a lot more to what you see than what you hear. And for the sake of it I played the game on mute for a while and not much was lost in terms of performance.
>I double down on the visual aspects getting in the way of the gameplay argument. The midboss in stage 7 is definetly the hardest part in the game to get an S rank at solely because the visual clutter and the spins are just too much for you to make out what you're supposed to do. To pass it with an S rank I just memorized the pattern and did it by memory. That's not a rhythm game.
>I still also think the walls are a bad mechanic. At some point I just learned that the best strat is to buffer all the turns unless the ones in which perfect turns are absolutetly necessary.
>Yes. I am aware that walls do have a callsign, but the fact that I wasn't able to notice it at first shows how much this callsign blend in when compared to others.
>The restart button was added a while back. I'm aware.
>The new mode seems tacked-on and pointless to me. It does not add the replayability a rhythm game needs.


The visuals are amazing, but this game lacks the tightness of an actual rhythm game.

-The charts are weird:
The notes are constantly spread too far apart. It almost feels disconected from the song at some points.
It also makes inconsistent decisions in terms of being in syncopation or not.
And because of that you start to rely in visual reaction for timings instead of using the beat of the song.

-The visuals get in the way of the game:
In some levels, you go through tunnels that hides the obstacles ahead, which just doesn't feel like a fair challenge. Specially for S curves in succession.

-Walls make you play off-beat:
The walls are probably my biggest gripe with this game at the moment.
Unlike the other obstacles, walls have no audio cue to them when they spawn. I don't see why, it's inconsistent.
Turning at the perfect beat rewards you with a perfect turn, which is what you want, but the game is too harsh on lateness for these, while presenting no punishment other than no bonus score for being early.
This makes going for perfect turns too risky, so you go early. But at this point your not on beat, and isn't this a rhythm game?

-No quick restart button:
This is a minor point, but as a rhythm game player, I want o S everything. So restarting is something that I want to be doing a lot. I don't see why this game doesn't have this feature.

This game had a cool idea, but the 4 button game underneath it doesn't feel very good to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028425712', 'num_games_owned': 860, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 483, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 328, 'last_played': 1476588023}
review:
Thumper is loud, intense, stressful, uncomfortable, and above all, fun.

The music and visuals tell you something is wrong, there are writhing mechanical tenticals, dark industrial music, and a huge fucking head that grows bigger spikes every time you kill it. And you see all this out of the corner of your eye as you fly down the beetle superhighway. However, sometimes there's a break, where nothing happens to you for about 30 seconds, and you get to sit back and just take it all in. 

And then the music starts again.

The gameplay is chaotic and complex. For using only one button and the joystick, there are a suprising amount of mechanics that you have to worry about. It's very intense and almost stressful, and more than once I found myself hunched over my controller gritting my teeth in concentration. Take the time for a deep breath every now and then.

The difficulty is very interesting. The game doesn't have a difficulty setting, like easy, medium, or hard. Instead, the game is only as hard as how good you want to be at the game. There is a score system involving hitting consecutive beats and performing combos that is very hard to pull off perfectly. However, if you just want to survive, you don't have to hit a single beat all the way to the boss. Although, just because you can skip the beats doesn't mean it will be a walk in the park.

When I quit the game for the first time, still on the main menu, there was only one thing going through my mind. "I can't wait to play this game again."

This game's value goes much further than the $20 price tag. I reccommend it very much.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027022258', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 115, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 99, 'last_played': 1657827384}
review:
My Review for Thumper, AKA: Assclench - The Game.

It all started with an interesting trailer a couple years back, but since then, silence....

And now here it is seemingly out of nowhere and a few days before it was even scheduled to come out and WOW, this game is truly something special.

The GOOD:

-Graphics, By far the most striking part about the game is the look of it. Sharp, colorful, and absolutely stunning to look at in motion. Screenshots don't do this game justice.

-Soundtrack, Grab some headphones, crank up the bass, put that volume up to 100%, and feel the POWER.

-Gameplay, Simple controls, simple mechanics taught at the beginning of each level, but don't confuse simple with easy in practice. Once the game ramps up and the music gets more intense, you'll be forgetting your lefts from your rights and smashing into everything in no time. Very difficult, but so damn rewarding when you hit max rank on each level.

-VR Support, While i haven't tried it(Don't own a Rift or a Vive) just the thought of playing this in VR makes me as giddy as a schoolgirl.

The MEH:

-Price. Now after playing it, i'm absolutely happy with my purchase and will probably buy the soundtrack, BUT 20 bucks is a bit to ask of some people when comparing it to other games that are a bit more deep than this at a similar price. Its a minor gripe but i believe this wont have any problems selling a ton of copies.

Overall, I expected this to be different, a little indie game that looked neat but would be dusted away in the mess of games released every day. But woah...im so glad i pulled the trigger and got it. FAR exceeded my expectations, hopefully the media picks this up and runs with it, the devs deserve all the love for what they created.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057112146', 'num_games_owned': 330, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 166, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 166, 'last_played': 1476151582}
review:
Based on my 3 hours of gameplay at the writing of this review, its hard for me to say that this is a "rhythm" game. I do enjoy the game, but here are a few things to keep in mind before you buy it:

- The game is very visually noisy. I found my attention directed more to the screen than to the beat of the music. Hard for me to call it a Rhythm game based off this.

- When you take damage, and you will take damage, the game freaks out, throwing colors and effects at you and making it very difficult to see where you are or what you are doing at the moment. You gain a little bit of invulnerability when you take a hit, but when you are trying to hit something and you suddenly can no longer see it at all, the game takes a much more un-fun turn.

- The beats are there, but sometimes with so much noise happenign around you it is hard to keep track of it. I find myself constantly losing the beat of the music, and unable to hear the music very well due to concentration on what is in front of me, and the growing sound effects from everything.

- I've never once felt like anything I do, any light I hit or move I do was in sync with the music. There are times I notice that I do something and it coincides with a beat, but most of the time I'm ignoring the beat because it serves little purpose when things I can't see until they pop in are coming at me  from around a corner.

- It's nearly impossible to look ahead because most of the time you cant see anything until it is about half a second in front of you. This makes it very difficult to predict what is next, so some parts of levels you have to beat purely by dying over and over until you have muscle memory.

- The music is very abstract, and the tunes are often hard for me to follow, and I almost always very quickly give up on keeping the beat. 

Despite these gripes of mine, I enjoy the game a lot. It's difficult, and i wish the music had more of a presence and afferct on the actual gameplay. But it's a good game. If you're looking for a twitch reflex action game, I'd recommend it. If you are looking for a purely rhythmic game, this might not be the right one for you.
