author: {'steamid': '76561198023591719', 'num_games_owned': 878, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 68, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 68, 'last_played': 1476193654}
review:
If you're interested in the Rhythm-battle style of Video Game and want to see how far the genre can be pushed, this is the game for you. It's not overly difficult, the soundtrack doesn't have much variety, the control scheme is basic - however the game pushes the genre in other ways. The soundtrack, visuals and actual gameplay all feel unique and interesting, a game that fleshes out the genre in a welcome way.

Instead of hitting the right keys on expected notes and beats, like Guitar Hero style games, or learning patterns and practising specific songs for hours, like Osu or Beatmania style games, this game has a consistent soundtrack with specific audio cues notifying you when a certain type of obstacle is going to come up. If you hear a clap, you turn. If you hear hefty bass, you're jumping. These audio cues are outside of the soundtrack, however, and it feels ever-so-slightly jarring and takes you out of the game a little. Think of it like a one-man audience alongside the soundtrack and that's the person you've got to listen to.

This might seem simplistic at the face of it, but when you're hitting those maneuvers your character is also making sound and, in some cases, it's specifically planned out so that the sound of your character masks the sound of what's coming. You learn to use both your eyes and ears independantly to figure out what's waiting for you, and the game punishes you for failure. 2 tries and you're out.

Given all of the priase, and also the thumb up, you might think that I'm telling you that you should buy it. However, at ¬£16 this game feels lackluster. It's a unique take on the genre, changing pretty much everything you expect, but realistically it doesn't push much further. I don't believe that there's a challenge mode, there's no variety game-modes, it's just the levels you get given and there aren't many at that.

Like I said at the start, if you're into the genre and want to see a different view of it, I do think this is the game for you but at this pricetag it's hard to recommend outside of that. If it interests you I'd recommend picking it up and playing through the first few levels - if it isn't for you, you can simply refund it. I've rated it up because I believe that it's a good game, price tag excluded.

Note: The reviews in the video on the Steam page hype it up to be more than it is. There's nothing "existentially dreadful" about the game, nothing "terrifying". It's good, but come on.

Also note: I've not completed the game, yet. I'll amend my review should my viewpoint change as I play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024348300', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 634, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 380, 'last_played': 1498165937}
review:
This is one of the most intense [non-osu] rhythm games I've played since Rhythm Heaven (EDIT: I haven't played any BEMANI games, so take that part with a grain of salt if you have played them. Regardless, this game does have its intensity). It's got simple controls, but it ramps up the difficulty very quickly. And holy crap, it is really fun. 

The music is nice, but if it wasn't for the level design, it would sound a bit samey to some. I still like it.

Some may find the price point a little high (especially with 9 levels; though you'll be dying a lot), but if you're a nerd for polish and rhythm games (like me) or if you love competing for the best score, then it's worth the full price. 

If you're not sure if you want to commit $20 to an intense rhythm action game, then I'd definitely say that you should wait for a sale. 

Also hey, it has native DS4 support, but most of you shouldn't care.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974284089', 'num_games_owned': 1055, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 1050, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 114, 'last_played': 1546789185}
review:
Thumper is simply an expertly crafted rhythm game. 

The attention to detail in each sound effect, the oppressive and heavy soundtrack, and gorgeous visuals all come together to put you into that perfect zen-like state where you feel like you can just predict what is coming next. 

It is a very focused experience  that I would recommend to anyone who enjoys the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198259490066', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 119, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 118, 'last_played': 1481414929}
review:
What I imagine a relaxing Sunday drive would be like... in hell.
A constant sense of dread while still tugging at you to drive further

The game runs rock solid and the controls are tight and responsive. The game is sectioned in checkpoints that always demand something of you. If you stay alive but fail what it asks, it seemlessly poses the same challenge to you again. This game not only looks amazing, but sounds amazing as well. Kudos to the everyone involved with this title.

The audiowork by Brian Gibson is truly amazing but what's a feat that is hard to see simply watching a video is how well the game choreographs to you what is expected of you input wise. Despite the trippy and luscious visuals I've never been confused on what the game is requiring me to do.

The closest game you could compare it to mechanics wise would be the bit trip runner series in that there is a limited amount of inputs to put it but masterfully placed and paced. Like that game the timing of your inputs aren't always to the main beat of the music but sometimes additional as you get it right. The setting istelf though is definitely worlds apart.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089597843', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 675, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 127, 'last_played': 1580619006}
review: INTENSE. In a way this game brings me back to the days of Geometry Retro Evolved. Slick, refined, FRESH, amazing music, simple control scheme that only gets better and better as you become more effecient at it, a nice simple leader board, and FUN AS HELL. This is such an amazing game. I just want to keep playing to see what the next level brings. I've only got about an hours worth into the game but I already know the price was well worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968097882', 'num_games_owned': 781, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 250, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 58, 'last_played': 1595896020}
review: The best music-based game I have played since Rez.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004277390', 'num_games_owned': 1478, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 84, 'last_played': 1515040425}
review:
Thumper is to rythm games what Ghosts n' Goblins was to plataformers and Dark Souls to action adventure games:

It's hard, unforgiving, scary, intense and will leave your hands sweaty, your thumbs numb, your heart racing and your inner masochist asking for one more level.

Visually, it's like when you have a nightmare during a night of intense fever. Weird and unsettling.

I love it so much.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033504037', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 72, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 56, 'last_played': 1482628106}
review:
Fantastic, heart-pounding game. Looks gorgeous and doesn't let up until you're utterly exhausted. Thoroughly recommend it.

Note: Slightly disappointed there is no cameo of Thumper from Bambi. Then again, I read that rabbits could have epilepsy too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020779012', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 66, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 57, 'last_played': 1483671922}
review:
I have been excited about the potential of this game since I heard about it a long time ago, and for the most part, it doesn't dissapoint.

The game design is well done. Simple controls that are complex to master. Visuals that are...interesting in a good way. A different style of music. Overall, it's a solid game - and don't let the 9 levels distract you, there's a lot of game in each level.

My only gripe is so far (I am through level 4) all the song sound the same. They are slight variations, but mostly they sound the same. Which could start to wear thin towards the end of the game. I applaud the use of a darker, industrial soundtrack, but there is variety in that theme. Maybe it iscoming later and I will update if it does. The other gripe is the last boss in each world (again only halfway through 3) is the same face, maybe slightly different. Be nice if it changed for each level.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975006112', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2738, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 796, 'last_played': 1618407194}
review:
This is what happens when someone takes a genre that's been stagnant and tries something just a bit different. A different sort of control scheme, a different type of music, and a darker visual tone.

Maybe I'm partial to the industrial style, but this an excellent game and I can't wait for the VR support.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031789432', 'num_games_owned': 1154, 'num_reviews': 208, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 249, 'last_played': 1476412746}
review:
Disclosure: Review copy received from the developer.

The developer calls it a "rhythm violence" game, and I think that's an appropriate moniker. Anyone familiar with Guitar Hero or Rock Band will pick this up very quickly, but the addition of obstacles that can destroy you make the game feel as much like an action game as a rhythm one. It's fast-paced, but there are audio and visual cues that make it very easy to keep up with. I love how intense this game is.

It's also very accessible, whether someone is colorblind, hearing impaired, or (I think) visually impaired. It also supports DS4 controllers natively.

You can read my full review on [url=http://indiegames.com/2016/10/thumper.html] Indiegames.com. [/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561198012857251', 'num_games_owned': 1931, 'num_reviews': 199, 'playtime_forever': 282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 76, 'last_played': 1662133575}
review: I've waited a long time for this game. It's exactly what I wanted. It's noisy, hard and feels just right.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960399787', 'num_games_owned': 1733, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 1024, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 414, 'last_played': 1654674305}
review:
I was so excited for the game I downloaded it and played the first level at work.

Despite being in a bright office surrounded by people who could think I'm slacking off and on a measly 1680x1050 monitor, I still had an intense experience playing this game.

If you want a rush, buy this game immediately.

Edit: After playing for more hours, let me clarify that if you can't handle rhythm games that get hard, you may not enjoy how difficult this game gets. However, you should view it as an opportunity to finally play a game that makes your knuckles white, your thumbs sore, and your brain require learning skills to get better. Beating later levels of this game is extremely satisfying in a way that's similar to doing expert tracks in a Rock Band game. Only you'll be sweating more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002308884', 'num_games_owned': 632, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 925, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 480, 'last_played': 1653080040}
review:
Amazing. Just pure focus and adrenaline.

Condenses the call and response of tribal drumming into an oppressive trance-like rhythm-runner.
